PETITION.TITLE: Health Care
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
We the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that,
Australia's population is ageing and most people require more health services as they grow older.
if open not-for-profit health funds are to be able to meet the costs of providing benefits to their older members at affordable rates, they need to share these costs equitably.
some health insurance organisations are being allowed to avoid meeting the health costs of sick and elderly people.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to,
take the necessary action to reverse rising cost trends and provide positive incentives to encourage all health funds to share the cost of health care for sick and elderly Australians.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pornography
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.

The petition of citizens of Australia points out that the community deplores the persistent refusal to ban pornography in X and NVE videos, films and publications, and deplores the resulting escalation of crime and sexual crime in the Australian community.
Because Parliament has a direct and heavy obligation to ensure the safety of women and child-victims, your petitioners therefore request the House:
to ban the importation, and availability of pornography in videos, films and publications,
to prevent black-market trading by banning the possession of X and NVE material,
vote against any recommendation to extend Video and Theatre Film Classifications and Guidelines into television standards,
ensure that Pay Television does not exceed the programme limits of television standards,
control all censorship criteria and guidelines by substantive legislation,

give earnest consideration to these matters, in order that no Attorney-General shall ever again have the power to change our social and home environment for generations to come, without thorough and full debate in both Houses of Parliament.

PETITION.TITLE: `Authority Required' Prescriptions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled; the humble petition of the undersigned citizens showeth:

that your petitioners deplore the Federal Government's decision to remove 53 pharmaceutical drugs from the pharmaceutical benefits scheme including the best available for the treatment of high blood pressure, cancer, epilepsy, high cholesterol and uneven heartbeat-and place them for cost saving reasons only on a special list requiring authority from a Canberra bureaucrat, and;

that we believe a patient's doctor is clearly the best judge for medication needed for their particular illness and that it is therefore wrong and unfair to force that doctor to seek permission from a bureaucrat in Canberra who has no personal knowledge of that case.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled will call on the Government to immediately abandon the proposal and keep its election promise of high quality and universal health care for all Australians.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Andrew (from 112 citizens), Mr Braithwaite (from 188 citizens), Mr Dobie (from 144 citizens), Mr Halverson (from 24 citizens), Mr Lamb (from 54 citizens), Mr Lloyd (from 27 citizens), Mr Pratt (from 27 citizens), Mr Les Scott (from 104 citizens), Mr Sharp (from 72 citizens), Mr Sinclair (from 25 citizens) and Mrs Sullivan (from 27 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: International Earth Repair Action Decade
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
This petition of concerned Australian citizens respectfully points out that:
our total global environment is rapidly deteriorating;
important natural resources vital to human life and livelihood such as ozone, trees, soil and water are being depleted at an increasing and alarming rate;
there is an urgent need to educate all people in conservation skills and the responsible use and maintenance of natural resources;
the United Nations Association of Australia (the peoples' arm of the UN), has proclaimed an Australian ERA (Earth Repair Action) Decade from 1988;
Earth Repair Action will unite people, communities, religions and nations in the productive purpose of greening and repairing our Earth for a safer and more peaceful future.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Parliament will:

Propose that an International Earth Repair Action (ERA) Decade begin on World Environment Day, June 5, 1990 with FIERY, the First International Earth Repair Year, and that this be proclaimed by the United Nations General Assembly. This ten-year plan will ignite the spirit of local and global co-operation to hygienically compost all presently wasted bio-degradable materials into humus to revitalise soils; grow billions of trees to replace forests lost and replenish the atmosphere; establish sustainable, economic and agricultural growth internationally, and end world hunger.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Baldwin (from 12 citizens), Mr Dobie (from 12 citizens), Mr Ronald Edwards (from six citizens), Mr Holding (from 24 citizens), Mr Johns (from 24 citizens), Mr Jull (from 20 citizens), Mr Lloyd (from 12 citizens), Mr Milton (from 12 citizens) and Mr Pratt (from 12 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth:
That your petitioners request that major reforms be made to Australia's Retirement Income System. These reforms are earnestly sought by retired Australians and those facing retirement.
The reforms are:
That the pension be increased to 30% of average weekly earnings (i.e. increasing the basic pension to $146 p.w.).
That the pension become tax exempt.
That the pension be adjusted so that it keeps pace with price rises rather than falling up to 12 months behind.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray that your House/Parliament will see that our requested reforms are implemented.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Courtice (from 89 citizens), Mr Gayler (from 75 citizens), Mrs Sullivan (from 262 citizens), Mr White (from 683 citizens), and Mr Wright (from 653 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: PAYE Taxes and Sales Taxes
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:
the petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House that
The Federal Government has reaped an unprecedented amount of revenue in taxation recently, over and above expectations:
PAYE tax payers are losing one quarter and more of earnings through direct tax deductions:
Sales taxes which are charged on a vast range of everyday goods and necessities add to the taxes already imposed on wage earners:
The range of compulsory licences, fees, and charges imposed by governments and statutory authorities further erode family disposable incomes.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House immediately reduce PAYE taxes and all Sales Taxes by one third and hold all Government and Statutory Authority charges at the current level for a minimum four-year period.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Braithwaite (from nine citizens) and Mr Tim Fischer (from nine citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Constitutional Reform
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:

The petition of certain citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia draws to the attention of the House their conviction that citizens in a democratic society should be able to have a direct say in the laws they are to live under. The citizen initiated referendum, as introduced in Switzerland over 100 years ago and some other countries since, enables a small percentage of voters, by signing a petition, to compel the government to hold a referendum on a law just made by parliament or already in force. If the vote goes against the law, it is automatically repealed. This system has proved outstanding in all the states and countries where it has been adopted.
Your petitioners therefore ask:

1. That as our elected representatives you introduce and pass the legislation necessary for putting to the people a proposed alteration to the Constitution to secure the adoption of the system of the citizen initiated referendum in the Commonwealth of Australia, and
2. That the House note that your petitioners will be petitioning the legislature of the several States in like manner.
And your humble petitioners will most earnestly pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Carlton (from 17 citizens) and Mr Shack (from 19 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Advertising of Alcohol
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:
The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House that:
Alcohol is recognised as Australia's number one drug problem which is responsible for at least 50% of all road fatalities; a high percentage of serious crime and vandalism.
Hospital beds are filled with sufferers of the many alcohol related diseases including: cirrhosis of the liver; heart disease; stomach ulcers; various forms of cancer and mental illness.
Alcohol causes much family unhappiness and marriage breakdown, as well as being involved in some cases of child abuse and molestation.
Television and radio have a persuasive effect on children and young people.
Your petitioners therefore request the House to ban all advertising of alcohol on television and radio.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Lamb (from 15 citizens) and Mr McArthur (from 15 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Star of the Sea Home for Aged at Wallaroo, South Australia
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives Assembled in Parliament:
The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House:
That the Star of the Sea Home for Aged at Wallaroo South Australia, has operated very successfully with 21 hostel beds since 1978 and its associated Nursing Home of 10 beds since 1985.

The Department of Community Services and Health has advised, that as from the 31st of December 1989 the present level of financial subsidy for the nursing home will be substantially reduced making it impossible for the nursing home to continue operating at its present numbers.

As the district, in which the nursing home is situated, has the highest ratio of aged persons, per head of population in South Australia, there is an ever increasing and definite need for the nursing home to continue providing this essential service.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House:

Will ensure that a financially viable nursing home, as an adjunct to the Star of the Sea Home for Aged at Wallaroo South Australia will be maintained, by either a continuation of the present level of funding or approval for additional beds to be allocated.

PETITION.TITLE: X-Rated Videos
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.
The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House that both Federal and State Attorneys General support the banning of rated videos.
Your petitioners therefore request the House to pass legislation banning x-rated videos.

PETITION.TITLE: Censorship
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker, and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.
The petition of citizens of Australia points out to the House that the ACT Classification of Publications Ordinance 1983 has legalised the screening of blasphemy, indecency and obscenity.
Because Parliament has traditionally respected the beliefs of its people, your petitioners therefore request that the House:
1. retain section 13 of the Customs (Cinematograph Films) Regulations as is;
2. control all censorship criteria and guidelines by substantive legislation;

3. give earnest consideration to these matters, in order that no Attorney-General shall ever again have the power to change our social and home environment for generations to come, without full and thorough debate in both Houses of Parliament.

PETITION.TITLE: Food Irradiation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

The petition of certain citizens in Australia, draws to the attention of the House that the irradiation of food by any means degrades the nutritional value of food and is potentially harmful to the health of all consumers and to the environment.
Your petitioners therefore request that your honourable House:
1. Withdraw from the Asian Regional Co-operative Project on Food Irradiation and from the International Consultative Group on Food Irradiation.
2. Take all possible steps to prevent and disallow the irradiation of food in Australia.
3. Ban the export and importation of irradiated foods and animal feeds.
4. Take steps to obtain a testing device to make possible the identification of irradiated foods, as soon as one becomes available.

PETITION.TITLE: Crime and Violence on Television
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Lyne electorate respectfully showeth that:
There is too much crime and violence on TV and this is breaking down the standards and codes of behaviour in our society.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:
Urge TV stations to clean up their act and improve the standards of shows, news and current affairs programs by reducing the incidence of crime and violence broadcast every day into people's homes.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will every pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Land Ownership
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:
The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House:
(a) We have nothing against the Japanese people, or any other people, but we object to them attempting to make Australia an economic and financial colony of Japan, or that of any other nation.

(b) We realise that the economics of nations' is a global issue. However, we cannot allow ``predatory'' countries, such as Japan, control over our economic future in Australia. Japan already owns meatworks and large grazing areas of our rural land.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House:
(i) will immediately introduce legislation so that freehold titles to Australian land and property can be held and transacted only by Australians by birth or naturalisation/citizenship.
and your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Road Funding
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.
The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House that:
Federal fuel excise taxation has reached record levels resulting in high costs for fuel and causing severe hardship particularly for people in country areas.
At the same time there has been a considerable reduction in the amount of Federal fuel excise taxation spent on roads, reduced from 66 per cent in 1983 to 20 per cent in 1989.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the House call on the Federal Government to take heed of the crisis situation facing small business, large fuel users and the crisis situation in relation to road infrastructure and-
1. Reduce by half the CPI Federal fuel tax increases
2. Increase by half the proportion of Federal fuel taxation being spent on roads

PETITION.TITLE: AGPS Style Manual
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.
The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House that:
The sex discrimination chapter of the Style Manual interferes with the Australian language;
The sex discrimination chapter would bring an enormous cost to bear on ordinary Australians if its suggestions were applied;
The sex discrimination chapter would make the Australian language unwieldly and artificially destroy commonly used and understood expressions;
The sex discrimination chapter seeks to invalidate accepted characteristics of the Australian language and destroy part of our national heritage and identity;
The sex discrimination chapter trivialises our literary past and the great literature of the world by its promulgation of mediocre substitutionary language.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House move for a complete review of the sex discrimination chapter of the Style Manual.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Tim Fischer (from eight citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Capable Vessels in Australian Waters
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.

We, the undersigned citizens of Australia, point out to the House the right of any community to safeguard its members, particularly in matters involving radioactive accidents in which historically the truth has been denied to the local communities involved.
Your petitioners therefore ask the House to prohibit the entry of nuclear capable vessels into the Port of Cairns and into Australian waters in general.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth that whereas:
1. They are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian National Flag.
2. They are aware it properly reflects the immutable characteristics of Australia, namely:
(a) the Union Jack, itself the creation of three Christian crosses, represents the Nation's historical origin and the source of its language and law;
(b) the Southern Cross on an azure blue background signifying its geographical location on this planet Earth;
(c) the large star depicting the advent of Federation in 1901.
3. They know the Flag has been a source of inspiration to generations of Australians in peace and war.
4. They recall that millions of native-born Australians and newcomers to these shores from other parts of the world have become united under its proud symbolism.
5. They are certain that any change to the Flag will produce division in the Australian community.
Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House will:
Propose and pass a motion that ``the existing Australian National Flag be changed only with the approval of the Nation as expressed in a Referendum''.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation: Pony Clubs
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House:

That pony clubs throughout Australia are essentially youth organisations formed to promote a healthy sporting activity between the horse and young rider for pleasure, instruction, and competition, and are non profit organisations.
We believe that we are being discriminated against in the area of taxation by being forced to pay taxes as a non profit organisation.
Your petitioners therefore request the House to amend the Income Tax Assessment Act to ensure pony clubs throughout Australia are given a tax exempt status.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Aged Care: Broken Hill
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

The petition of certain citizens of Broken Hill in the State of New South Wales, points out to the House and calls on the Federal Government to accept its responsibility by providing sufficient suitable nursing home and hostel accommodation for those Broken Hill citizens who are frail or aged.
Your petitioners therefore request the House:

(a) Negotiates with the NSW State Government to maintain sufficient long-stay beds at the Broken Hill Base Hospital until it, the Federal Government with whom the responsibility of care for the aged lies, provides the accommodation required.
(b) Also requests that increased funding be provided for support services that provide care for the frail and aged in their own homes in Broken Hill.

PETITION.TITLE: Funding for Cancer and AIDS Research
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:
The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House the desperate need for immediate funding for cancer and AIDS research.

Your petitioners therefore request the House to deduct from every working person in Australia by way of an increase in our current Medicare levy to equal approximately $3.00 per year . . . which from our latest employment figures of 7.5 million working people would constitute 22.5 million dollars per year towards saving the lives of thousands of people worldwide.
Our participation in this scheme could be followed by other nations of the world and pave the way towards establishing a united world research organisation.

PETITION.TITLE: Land Ownership
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:
The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House the large amounts of land, both urban and rural, being acquired by the Japanese.
It appears, that they are doing by money and stealth, what they failed to do in a war, in which thousands of Australians lost their lives in a most brutal and barbaric manner.
These men died to ensure that Australia remained a free and democratic country, to pass on to future generations.
It is the duty of all of us, no matter what the cost, to ensure that these men did not die in vain, and to see that no alien power dominates Australia.
We ask the House to take urgent steps to prevent more of our land being bought by non-resident foreigners.

PETITION.TITLE: Fuel Prices
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House:
That people throughout rural and regional Australia are being discriminated against by unjustly high fuel prices.

They believe the Government should legislate to require a uniform price discount to all wholesalers when this is offered by the oil companies, and thus remove the major component in the retail price differential of approximately ten cents per litre.
Your petitioners therefore request the House to amend the legislation to allow cheaper fuel price justice for country people.

PETITION.TITLE: Plight of Starving People of the World
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

The petition of certain citizens of Australia, draws to the attention of the House, the need for a more equitable distribution of wealth and resources, specifically food, to the millions of people throughout the world who so desperately need this assistance.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the House instruct the Minister for Foreign Affairs to have the matter raised in the United Nations General Assembly, with a view to publicising the anxiety of the average Australian at the lack of progress in attending to these matters, and with particular concern at the lack of food for the starving people of the world.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australia Post
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and all members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:

The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully draws to the attention of the House proposals by Australia Post to close down hundreds of post offices in rural and regional areas.
Your petitioners therefore ask that the House request the Government to ensure that any restructuring of Australia Post's operations does not result in any reduction of postal services to customers.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: X-Rated Videos
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:

The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully draws to the attention of the House that whilst all State Governments have agreed to legislation to prevent the distribution of X-rated videos, a loophole in Commonwealth laws allows the distribution of this material by mail order from Canberra.
Your petitioners therefore ask that the House urge the Government to pass legislation to ban the distribution of X-rated videos.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: `Authority Required' Prescriptions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That whilst acknowledging the Government's desire to contain the growth in health costs, the introduction of 61 new drugs to the `Authority Required' listing will result in potentially serious delays in patients receiving medication prescribed by their doctors.
Your petitioners request the House to immediately reverse the Government's decision and withdraw these drugs from the `Authorities Required' list.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Retirement Income
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned shows:
We are gravely concerned at the plight of pensioners, retirees and superannuants, those in society least able to protect themselves from the ravages of inflation.

Your petitioners request the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, to amend existing legislation to provide protection against inflation for pensioners' investments and to broaden the availability of fringe benefits to pensioners.

PETITION.TITLE: Road Funding
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned shows:

We are gravely concerned at the Government's failure to allocate revenue collected from motorists and transporters at the petrol pump to the adequate maintenance and development of our highway infrastructure.

Your petitioners request that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, amend existing legislation to increase immediately the level of spending on maintenance and development of our national road system.

PETITION.TITLE: Constitutional Reform
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
that your petitioners express strong support for the concept of citizens initiative and veto referendum.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled will:

introduce a Bill into this place which will make provision for the Constitution to be amended by way of referendum in order that the concept of citizens initiative and veto referendum may be included in the Constitution; and

that such referendums (either initiating or vetoing legislation) will automatically take place when a petition(s) has been signed by, and includes the relevant electoral number of, at least 300,000 registered voters in Australia.
Your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Forests of South-Eastern Australia
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament. The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of this House that we are concerned at the threats caused by logging to the integrity and continued existence of what remains of the forests of south eastern Australia.
Your petitioners therefore request the House to direct the Prime Minister and his government
(1) to phase out woodchipping for export;
(2) not to renew a long-term export licence to Harris Daishowa;

(3) to ensure that sensitive environmental areas, and specifically the proposed national park and wilderness areas of Coolangubra, Cathcart, Egan Peaks and the Tantawangalo catchment, are protected and excluded from the proposed woodchip export licence; and
(4) to promote ecologically sound and sustainable forestry practices including:
re-afforestation and plantation of native hardwoods and already cleared land to reduce pressure on native forests; and
minimisation of wasteful uses of forest products.

PETITION.TITLE: Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Madam Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

The petition of certain citizens' of Australia draws the attention of the House to the continued Government interference in the pharmaceutical benefits scheme which is causing hardship and confusion amongst the sick and elderly.

Your petitioners therefore request the House to guarantee the provision of an adequately funded pharmaceutical benefits scheme which is free from Government tampering and provides for the public of Australia a comprehensive range of modern therapeutic products.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare Facility, Runaway Bay and Helensvale Districts, Queensland
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:
The petition of certain electors of the Division of Moncrieff draws to the attention of the House the absence of a Medicare facility in the Runaway Bay and Helensvale districts.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House urgently look into establishing a Medicare facility as soon as possible.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON TRANSPORT, COMMUNICATIONS AND INFRASTRUCTURE

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Saunderson Mr J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure, I present the Committee's report entitled Release of Tyre Safety Inquiry Documents, together with the minutes of proceedings and a letter from the Secretary to the Attorney-General's Department to the Secretary of the Committee dated 14 March 1989.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a small report which deals with a large issue, that is, the reliance one can place on the word of the Parliament. Briefly, on 30 November last year a petition was presented to the House seeking, amongst other things, the publication of the confidential exhibits identified as such in the tyre safety report. This report was presented to the House on 11 September 1980 by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Road Safety. The House referred this matter to the Committee on the same day the petition was presented-on 30 November, the day before the House was due to rise for the summer adjournment. I think there was an expectation in some quarters that the Committee would report within 24 hours. If so, this was an extravagant expectation.

SPEECH.PARA: The petitioner was a firm of Canberra solicitors acting on behalf of a firm of New South Wales solicitors whose client was claiming damages from the Goodyear Tyre and Rubber Co. (Aust) Ltd for negligence arising out of a motor vehicle accident caused apparently by a blow-out of one of the tyres. The tyre safety report had concluded that one manufacturer had acted irresponsibly in not recalling defective steel belted radial tyres. It is clear that the production of the confidential exhibits was expected to prove the accuracy of this statement and to identify Goodyear as the manufacturer which acted irresponsibly. Obviously, such an inquiry cannot be completed in a day. We wrote to the manufacturers seeking their views on the release of the confidential exhibits. Goodyear informed us that there was no need for the release because the solicitors for the plaintiff and the solicitors for Goodyear had agreed to an out of court settlement.

The petitioner had corresponded with me on the inquiry. I was not informed of the out of court settlement by the petitioner. This is disappointing. It is also discourteous. Those who want the Parliament to take certain decisions have a responsibility to inform the Parliament of changed circumstances which may render unnecessary the initial need for the review. Be that as it may, the Committee decided to report on this reference because the House has not withdrawn the reference and also because there are several important matters of principle that relate to the release of confidential evidence. Our basic task required weighing up the disadvantages of releasing the documents with consequential adverse effects on parliamentary committees, with the advantages as they affect the interests of justice.

From its deliberations, the Committee advances two general propositions which are applicable to all committees. The first proposition is that there is a strong presumption that evidence taken in camera or documents treated as confidential by parliamentary committees should not be released, and this presumption is related to the effectiveness in the working of parliamentary committees. The purpose of the proposition is to clarify the protection offered to witnesses in standing order 362. The basic reason why protection is afforded to witnesses is for greater effectiveness in the working of parliamentary committees. People with a full knowledge that whatever they say or present will not be used against them will be more forthcoming. This protection is given by taking evidence in camera and treating documents as confidential.

The second general proposition the Committee advances is that, unless there are good reasons to the contrary, the release of confidential documents when sought or consented to by witnesses does not prejudice the protection of witnesses and, therefore, does not affect adversely the effective working of parliamentary committees. When we apply these two general propositions to the reference from the House, the first holds but the second does not because the tyre manufacturers have objected to the release of their confidential exhibits.

The first proposition has a strong presumption that confidentiality when given should not be taken away at a later date. There are two other disadvantages associated with the release of some of the confidential exhibits. The first is referred to by Pacific Dunlop Ltd, namely that the 27 March 1980 letter from the Chairman of the Road Safety Committee promised confidentiality as a pre-condition for receiving the statistical information. The second and related matter is that the documents were brought into existence solely for the purpose of the tyre safety inquiry. The information in the exhibits complies closely to the information sought in the March 1980 letter.

This set of circumstances constitutes a very strong case for the preservation of the confidentiality of certain specified exhibits. When confidentiality is requested and then given, and even more so when it is promised in advance and thus becomes a pre-condition for receiving information, a contract has been entered into between a committee and the provider of the information. Such a contract is not enforceable legally. The Committee holds firmly to the view that the House has a strong moral obligation to protect such a contract. Not to do so, by authorising release of these documents for use in a court, could seriously impair the future effectiveness of the working of parliamentary committees because witnesses could refuse to be forthcoming in what they say or provide, knowing full well that they could be disadvantaged in court proceedings by release of evidence.

Against this the other side of the scale is the interests of justice. The argument is that the plaintiff's case would be assisted and the hearing of the claim adequately conducted if the confidential exhibits were released for use in a court. The conclusion the Committee arrived at was that the need to protect witnesses for the purpose of preserving effectiveness in the working of parliamentary committees outweighed considerably the interests of justice, whether or not court procedures could discover the information required for the plaintiff's case. An appropriate recommendation is made. I commend the report to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Milton Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House:

(1) commends the Antarctic Division, and in particular the Antarctic expeditioners whose initiative and enthusiasm contribute to expanding our understanding and scientific knowledge of a unique and vitally important environment; and
(2) calls on the Government to provide the necessary resources to enable the Division to continue its valuable research in Antarctica.

I do so because I believe that there is insufficient appreciation by the Australian public of the wonderful work that is undertaken by our expeditioners in the Antarctic. I am fully qualified, I believe, to move the motion because in all the history of our work in the Antarctic over the past 30 or 40 years no other member of parliament has had the opportunity while being a member of parliament to spend the time that I have there. I consider myself to be very lucky. Two years ago I was able to visit Antarctica on the Nella Dan. Because of what is known as the Antarctic factor-that is, the environment is one where anything can happen at any time, particularly weather changes-on that occasion we had a much longer voyage than expected. The whole voyage took seven weeks. I had the opportunity to visit Commonwealth Bay and to inspect Mawson's Hut. We then visited Dumont d'Urville, which is the French base. So I had a chance to see the airstrip which the French were constructing with, I must say, unfortunate disregard for the penguin rookeries which were being disturbed in the process. Nevertheless, the French are continuing with the construction of that airstrip and there has been some confrontation with Greenpeace expeditioners as a result.

We left Dumont d'Urville and went on to our Casey Base to assist injured expeditioners and I had an opportunity to inspect the Casey Base. We then headed for Bunger Hills to unload some expeditioners for scientific work but, unfortunately, we became beset in the ice. After about eight days we were rescued by the Soviet ship Mikhail Somov. That of itself was quite an experience. I was fortunate enough to be able to undertake an Australian Broadcasting Corporation radio broadcast from the beset ship and I described the ice conditions around us and the icebergs that were gradually moving towards us, fortunately at a slow enough rate that we were able to be rescued before we were crushed.

We then went on to the Davis Base and were able to inspect that base also. We also attempted to discover the exact position of the South Magnetic Pole. I had the opportunity to take part as research assistant for that work. As I have mentioned, the trip took seven weeks and it was very fascinating. I did not think for one moment that I would have an opportunity to go again two years later.

It is sad that the Nella Dan grounded on the rocks at Christmas time just over a year ago. Unfortunately, having grounded on the rocks off Macquarie Island, eventually it had to be scuttled. The Nella Dan was a great ship, a wonderful ship, and it is very sad that after 26 years of service with the Division she should end her days in that way.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!
—The Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business is well aware of the tremendous work which that ship and its crew performed on behalf of the Division and Australia.
—About 100 missions, a number that will never be repeated.

—That is right. An exhibition commemorating the Nella Dan is being mounted and a plaque was recently unveiled at the Maritime Museum in Victoria. There is a great deal of recognition for the Nella Dan and a great love is held for the memory of the ship.

SPEECH.PARA: Because the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) decided that he would ask the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts to undertake an inquiry into tourism in the Antarctic, I had the opportunity to travel again to the Antarctic, with three other members of the Committee. The honourable member for Dunkley (Mr Chynoweth), who is in the chamber, will probably make some mention of that trip because he was one of those members who accompanied me. We had another seven-week trip, but the Antarctic factor intervened again. We had problems trying to supply one of our bases and that delayed our voyage. We had seven weeks during January and February and we had the opportunity to visit the Mawson and Davis bases.

We also had the opportunity to go to Larsemann Hills, which is not very far from our Davis base. There we found that the Chinese expeditioners were constructing a winter base. The Soviet Union had also enlarged its previous base. On my visit two years ago I had also visited our base at Larsemann Hills, the Law base, and at that time the Soviet Union had not expanded its operations to the extent it has now. We made courtesy visits and talked to the Chinese and Soviet expeditioners as well as our own.

I also wish to mention the research work which is undertaken by our expeditioners and by the scientists who are supported by the Antarctic Division in undertaking their work. In this sense, we are involved in a range of research activity, particularly marine biology, glaciology and terrestrial biology and upper atmosphere physics. Unfortunately, I do not have the time to mention all the work that is being undertaken, but I would like to mention that when we were there we had an opportunity to visit one of our special sites of scientific interest with the Assistant Director Science of the Antarctic Division, Dr Patrick Quilty. We had the opportunity to observe the work that was being done with the discovery of marine fossils that are some 3 1/2 million to 4 1/2 million years old. While we were there we participated in the discovery of several fossils, one of which was of a juvenile baleen whale. The fossil was of the whole skull and it was a very exciting discovery for all of us. We certainly wish Dr Quilty well with his further work at Marine Plain.

We also had further talks with many of the scientists and expeditioners while we were on the sites. In particular, we talked to Dr Stephen Nicol, who is doing work on krill. He pointed out to us how important the krill are because basically the Antarctic is a krill-based ecosystem and animals like the baleen whales, crabeater seals, penguins and many other sea birds depend directly on Antarctic krill for their food. In that respect it is very important for us to understand how the krill live and generally what sort of effects the environment might have on them. It is my main intention, in speaking in this debate, to congratulate the expeditioners on their enthusiasm and on their wonderful work in an area which carries great dangers. I ask those involved-particularly the Minister at the table, who I know agrees with me-to ensure, even when the building program is run down, that the money we are spending in the Antarctic, which is some $50m annually, continues to be used for the very valuable research work that is being done there.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr I.M.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the motion moved by the honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Milton). I have much pleasure in supporting my colleague's comments and his motion. Five members of parliament had the honour of visiting the Antarctic, and it is an honour to manage a trip into the territory to which Australia lays claim. One has to have a reason for going. The area is supported and controlled by the Antarctic Treaty, which is a world treaty involving many nations. Australia lays claim to about 43 per cent of the territory, so it is very important for members of both Houses of Parliament to visit it. I recommend to all members of this House that they find the time, provided they can get permission from their wives and lovers, to make the six-week break away from home. It is more than worth while and is a wonderful experience for any individual. I enjoyed the company of the honourable member for Dunkley (Mr Chynoweth), the honourable member for La Trobe, the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis) and the honourable member for Newcastle (Mr Allan Morris), who represented the Government side. Of course, as the member for Maranoa, I had to hold the fort for the Opposition.
—You would be more than a match for that mob.

—Of course. I would like to take this opportunity of thanking the leader of the voyage. There is still a deal of interest and expedition-type involvement in Antarctica. It is one of the few frontiers left to us, apart from space travel. I compare the isolation of the Antarctic with the western end of my electorate, which runs out into the Channel Country and central Australia. That is the type of isolation one experiences when one is in Antarctica. One cannot just ring an ambulance to rush one to hospital, or have other people look after one's problems. One is very much on one's own.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to congratulate Des Lake, the leader of our voyage 6 expedition. We formed a subcommittee of the Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts and we looked at tourism in the Antarctic. Personally, I believe that there is unlimited potential for tourism in Antarctica. I do not see why the Australian taxpayer should not be able to make a visit if he or she wishes. As the honourable member for La Trobe mentioned, we spend $50m of taxpayers' good money in Antarctica each year. No doubt that amount will continue to grow. We are three parts of the way through a complete rebuilding program, and I congratulate the people involved, such as the architects, on the magnificent job they have done. They have constructed very substantial buildings which, from what we saw of them, are not going to fall down overnight or get blown away. There are always complaints about design, of course, but overall the people involved have done an excellent job.

Most of the scientists overwinter in the Antarctic. Although the Chairman of my Committee did not like my mentioning it, we were only tourists down there for six weeks and back again. Most of the scientists spend at least 12 months there; they overwinter. Of course, there is no sun throughout the whole of the winter period and the temperature drops to minus 80 degrees. I think the lowest temperature in the world has been recorded in our territory, at minus 89 degrees. I can assure you, Madam Speaker, that it is pretty cold when it gets down to that temperature-even colder than this House sometimes gets.

I would also like to thank the crew of the Ice Bird, the ship we charter from a German company. I thank the captain, Eveal, and Roger, the Australian who was on board getting experience because we are to launch a new ship, the Aurora Australis, next year. It will be doing a lot of work that ships such as the Ice Bird are doing now. We still will not own our own ship, which is a great disappointment to me. It was not until I went on the trip that I realised that the Aurora Australis is being leased. It is a pity we do not own our own ship. I also thank the crew and the captain, Eric, of the Lady Franklin, the Canadian ship we lease which brought us home safely. There was a wonderful company of people on board, including the Army personnel who took us ashore, the people who operated and piloted the helicopters-Pip and his people-and of course the press who were there. Tim Bowden used the visit to promote the Antarctic, and I can also recommend that people watch the Beyond 2000 shows. There will be six scientific episodes; the crew was looking specifically at the scientific endeavours we are discussing today.

We viewed the work being done at both Mawson and Davis. It is important that we continue that work. Obviously the Minister at the table, the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones), does not need to be told about that need. We do not have to argue with any strength that we need more money for scientific endeavour; no-one is more strongly of that view than he is. It is his colleagues around the Cabinet table who need convincing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chynoweth Mr R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —In discussing this motion on the Antarctic Division I would like to read from my diary that I kept on our trip to the Antarctic. I feel I am one of the most fortunate people on this earth, having had the experience of visiting one of the most beautiful places I have ever been to in my life. My diary entry for 8 January, on the way down, reads, in part:

SPEECH.PARA: Rough. 20-30 knot winds. Waves 10 metres high. Boat crashing through. Speed 5 . . . to 8 knots. 60 degrees S 121 degrees west. 11 a.m. . . . Barometer starting to rise . . . Definitely roughest seas I have ever seen. Boat rolling to 30 degrees both ways.
My entry for Monday, 16 January, notes that:
we have arrived in Antarctica; we can see the mountains, sticking up at the back of Mawson through 2,000 feet of ice.

My diary describes the ice sheets, the rivers of blue ice through the cream and the melting white snow pools. There were sky blue pools around the bottom of the mountains where the wind had scoured the mountains. I noted that it was truly magnificent; the weather was fine and dry. I noted also that we held on that day the historic first meeting of a parliamentary committee on the Antarctic continent. We created history when we went down there, on behalf of this Parliament, by holding a committee meeting.

I will not go into it too much, but we had some tremendous experiences, and I hope to have time later to relate in this Parliament some of the things I enjoyed and the way they will affect me for the rest of my life. One night there, while some of our members were arguing politics in a hut on the base of the ice plateau, called Platcha Hut, I went for a walk. It was about 12 o'clock at night. The sun was setting. It takes about an hour or so for the sun to set because of the angle of the earth at the South Pole. I spent an hour or two by myself on top of a mountain on the edge of the ice plateau. There was tremendous silence, and a great experience of the cold. The only living things I saw were a few snow petrels flying to their nests. It has left an indelible impression on my mind; I will never forget it.

I refer to my diary entry for Wednesday, 15 February, when we were on the way back. Our location was 49 degrees 40 minutes south and 127 degrees 27 minutes west. It was 2.30 a.m. I saw an aurora. We had been out for about two hours looking for an aurora. This was to me something that left a truly lasting impression. The diary note states:
2.40 a.m. I am lying on my bunk still amazed at the aurora. It is hard to describe as it melts into nothing or into ghostly shapes and figures.
They were all over the top of me. The diary continues:
It would be one of the greatest sights I have ever seen. In fact the greatest. I think of a passage in the Bible, `God so loved the world'. I can see why he loves it here.

It was an overwhelmingly impressive and beautiful sight. There were lights coming in from outer space. That aurora is something one cannot photograph; one cannot picture. It is truly amazing. While we were in Antarctica we visited a Chinese base which is being established there. I, on behalf of the people of Dunkley, presented an Australian flag to the Chinese. All the work stopped as we put up the flag and exchanged gifts. It was a quite memorable occasion.

In the five minutes available to me I wish to talk about something that could change the whole face of Antarctica. The Australian Government is now discussing whether we should sign the minerals convention. I say at the outset that we should not sign it. I will use all the powers that I have as a member of this Parliament, lobbying every member of the Government and the Opposition, to ensure that we do not sign this treaty. I say that we should not sign the treaty because of some of the evidence which has come forward in just the last few weeks. On 5 March, before the oil spill in Alaska, Reuters in New York put out the following report:

A Government report said improper and careless management of chemical and oil wastes by the oil industry was seriously damaging parts of the Alaskan tundra, the New York Times reported in its Sunday edition.

The newspaper said the report documents hectares of tundra blackened by chemical spills, oil wastes seeping from drilling pads, stacks of leaking chemical drums and failure to comply with Federal regulations for handling hazardous materials.
The magazine Time of 3 April 1989 said this:

It was the kind of ecological disaster that environmentalists had been warning about since oil first began flowing from Alaska's North Slope twelve years ago . . . After taking on 1.2 million bbl. of crude at the Valdez terminal, the southern end of the 800-mile Trans-Alaska Pipeline, the 987-ft tanker Exxon Valdez headed out through Prince William Sound. Manoeuvring to avoid icebergs, the tanker ran into an underwater shoal called Bligh Reef. The vessel's side split open and thick North Slope crude spewed into one of the most pristine bodies of water in the US.

In the press yesterday, 5 April 1989, an article was headed `Exxon determined to search for Arctic oil'. The oil companies have just ruined thousands of square miles of territory in Alaska. There is a huge oil slick. Thousands of birds and animals are dying, and the oil companies are determined to search for more oil. I ask honourable members to listen to what has been said by one of the oil companies, the main lobbyists pushing the Antarctic Treaty nations to sign the minerals convention. The article stated:

Exxon Corporation's president said yesterday that he hoped the ``emotional type of atmosphere'' generated by his company's Alaskan oil spill would not prompt Congress to reject the oil industry's request to drill in protected wildlife areas.
``I want to tell you how sorry I am that this accident took place,'' Exxon's chairman . . . said . . .
. . . since 24 March the accident has been receiving our full attention and will continue to do so.''

I think that is a load of rubbish. All that Esso and the majority of oil companies are doing is pushing to get more areas of the world to explore, exploit and ruin. We in Australia have a great opportunity. I know there is talk within the Cabinet, and I imagine there will be a lot more talk after this speech, to the effect that we should do something about this minerals convention. I firmly believe that we should not sign it. Australia has a great opportunity. If we do not sign it, it does not come into force. We can show to the rest of the world our concern about the environment. We can prove that we can stand up to other signatory nations. The other signatory nations include: Argentina, Belgium, Chile, France, the Federal Republic of Germany, Japan, New Zealand, Norway, Poland, South Africa, the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics (USSR), the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland, and the United States of America.

There will be tremendous pressure on Argentina, Chile, Norway and Poland to sign. South Africa will sign. Germany will sign. Japan will sign. The Soviet Union will sign. The United Kingdom will sign. America will sign. But will we? We will have to withstand huge pressure from the United States and the United Kingdom. However, I think we can do it. I would like to think that Australia will stand up to the pressure that will come on us very soon if there is any talk about not signing.

This minerals convention has been discussed for about eight years. However, I do not think it has all been thought out. Some areas of concern have been raised by many organisations. The convention that we will sign, if we do sign it, will allow mining to take place. If we do not sign it, we can stop it. It is quite simple. We just will not sign.

There is only a limited liability for damage. If one of the companies, such as Esso or Exxon, finds oil-traces of it have been found already-starts to ship it out in tankers from Prydz Bay, which is in the Davis area that Australia has claimed, and it damages the environment, how much does Esso or Exxon have to pay to rehabilitate this area? They will give us nothing. I am quite certain of it. There is only a limited liability for damage. There is no anti-subsidy clause in the minerals convention; that is, countries with large economies, such as the USSR, America and Japan, could actually subsidise mining there.

Australia can take a stance. We must stop the signing of this convention and prove to the world that we alone in this particular area are not greedy and avaricious. We can set aside this beautiful continent for other people and for the rest of the world to enjoy for future generations.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tickner Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House:
(1) notes the development of agribusiness in Australia; and
(2) calls on the relevant Government departments in devise strategies to:
(a) control appropriately the activities of agribusiness companies;
(b) limit further concentration of ownership of their companies;
(c) develop alternatives to agribusiness;
(d) encourage research to enable farmers to move towards more sustainable agricultural practices; and
(e) provide guidelines for the operation of agribusiness in Australia.
I begin by complimenting the honourable member for Dunkley (Mr Chynoweth), a man of passionate and deep convictions, on his very important contribution to the debate on the future of Antarctica.
This debate concerns agribusiness. The first question to ask is: What is agribusiness? One financial journalist has answered the question in this way:
Agribusiness can be a seed company, a fertiliser manufacturer, a food processor, a commodity trader, a bank, or it can be all of these things and more at once.

Agribusiness is a post-World War II phenomenon in the world's food distribution system. It means that big city-based businesses are progressively taking over all aspects of agriculture. Agribusiness companies increasingly are supplying the fuel, the seed, the fertiliser, the farm chemicals, the plant, equipment and machinery and the finance to enable their purchase. Put simply, agribusiness is a few large companies controlling the food market and the farming community. It is important to understand the effects of these developments on rural society and consumers both in the country and in the city.

According to a 1987 report to the United Nations Bruntland Commission called Food 2000, the criteria prevailing in today's agricultural systems are ecologically blind. The Bruntland Commission believes that it is possible to build a more prosperous, just and secure global future, provided it rests on policies that are both economically and ecologically responsible. The report recommends that farmers should be given incentives to adopt ecologically acceptable forms of maintaining soil fertility and increasing productivity, with the ultimate aim of the development of sustainable agriculture. The report calls for the development of an international code for the sustainable and equitable use of life support systems and for all countries to set up structures to give effect to these goals.

We are all aware of evidence that in Australia over the past 10 years and longer farmers have been walking off their land and going to cities in very substantial numbers. Between 1964 and 1979 farm costs rose 235 per cent but returns rose only 113 per cent. This year one small orchardist in Tallong estimated that half the orchard income was spent on pesticides. That is of great interest to me because my late father was born and lived the early part of his life on an orchard near Tallong.

I believe there is a strong argument that agribusiness has a large responsibility for the huge rise in farm costs and while farmers are getting less for their products agribusiness profits are increasing. For example, during the drought stricken second half of 1982 Elders IXL Ltd lifted its profits by 78 per cent. We should ask ourselves why these huge profits are being made by agribusiness companies at a time of rural downturn. The answer, of course, lies in the market power of a few big companies which are able to dictate to many farmers what they will produce and the prices they will pay for essential items such as seed, fertilisers, pesticides, farm machinery and plant. Forty-three per cent of agrochemicals and pesticides are sold to Australian farmers by four big companies. Similar figures exist for the sale of agricultural machinery and the production of poultry meat.

The two biggest pastoral companies in Australia, Elders IXL and Dalgety Farmers Ltd, are the brokers for about 80 per cent of wool sold and 60 per cent of livestock. They are also the two largest rural estate agents. The pastoral companies are also effectively banks for many farmers as they advance credit to enable those farmers to purchase from them or their subsidiaries stock, plant, feed, seed and fertilisers as well as land. They get their repayments when the farmer sells his produce either to them or through them at a price. The farmer has little choice, either as a purchaser or a seller. He or she is caught in the cost-price squeeze.

Regrettably, time does not permit me to give more than one example of agribusiness controls of sections of rural industry, but there are many more. In 1982 chicken processors told their growers that they needed fewer chickens. The growers, who had spent money on equipment and facilities, were geared to supply at least four batches of chickens during the year but they were told that the processors needed and could pay for only three. The growers were not compensated for this loss of output by receiving a higher price per chicken. As one industry spokesman said at the time, the growers lose out badly. Each individual grower often has a huge bank loan, yet during the glut Inghams Enterprises Pty Ltd kept its own growing farms at peak production, leaving the small growers to bear the brunt of the oversupply system. One farmer noted that some growers were on the dole line or lower because they had invested money to build or improve sheds on Inghams' advice or insistence.

When agribusiness sought to gain control of two well-known farmer cooperatives-Dairy Farmers and Letona-this provoked a fierce resistance from farmers and the following critical editorial from The Land newspaper:
The battles now being waged for control of two of the State's biggest agricultural cooperatives, Letona and Dairy Farmers, raise important questions for the future of all farm cooperatives.
Something is radically wrong with a system that enables corporations to gain control of cooperative organisations that were set up specifically to allow farmers to be masters of their own destinies.

Corporations involved in cooperative takeovers defend their actions on the grounds of bringing more efficiency and expertise to bear on the enterprise in question, but this is not the point. The point is that takeovers remove control of the operation from farmer producers and vest it instead in the boards of directors dedicated to making profits for shareholders by whatever means necessary.
The editorial concluded:
Often that means will not coincide with the best long term interest of farm producers.

And, I might add, of consumers. Unlike the farmer, agribusinesses are not affected by the natural cycle of good or bad years. They can still make money from fluctuating money prices, capricious markets and even the tempestuous Australian weather. Agribusinesses protect themselves against loss of money by not becoming involved in farm production.

There are other consequences of the agribusiness phenomenon. The indiscriminate use of chemicals on the farm can directly affect only the health of the farmer in the first instance, but in the longer term the consumer is affected. In handling pesticides and insecticides, farm workers are known to develop aches, cramps, nausea and skin ailments. Further, agribusiness companies put pressure on farmers to buy from them an excessive amount of chemicals, bigger and better machinery, a restricted variety of seeds and money to expand their land holdings. This leads to exhaustive farming practices that in the short term may produce bumper crops but in the longer term reduce the value of the land. The Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation recently has established that approximately 500,000 hectares of prime wheat land has less than 50 years of productive life remaining.

The most important part of agribusiness is its control of people's lives. As one journalist has described it, `Large industrial conglomerates exercise tremendous control over what food is produced and for what price it is sold'. As a member of a responsible Government, I say that we have to face the reality that Australia's rural community is fading fast and has been for a long time, with increasing numbers of people leaving their traditional way of life. Regrettably, city dwellers are often unaware of the incredible pressures many farmers and their families face. We also have to face the reality that control of agricultural activity and food processing now being exerted by agribusiness companies is placing farmers and consumers in a situation where increasingly they have fewer choices.

I do not have a doctrinaire and narrow approach to this question. What I say is that this issue should be placed fairly and squarely on the agenda for public debate in Australia. I believe that the Government, through its requisite activities in various government departments, must play a role in critically evaluating agribusiness in Australia and then respond in turn with appropriate regulation. I conclude by paying tribute to the many community organisations such as Action for World Development which have been doing their best to raise these very important concerns and to place them on the agenda of public debate in Australia. I thank the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith Mr W.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will second the motion to facilitate its debate. The concluding remarks of the honourable member for Hughes (Mr Tickner) are important. On the first reading of this motion I suspected that we were going to hear from him a doctrinaire attitude. I am pleased that that was not the response he gave to the motion. The motion has some elements in it that I think need much broader discussion in the community. I am sure that some of the points that I will make in the few minutes that I have will interest the honourable member for Hughes and also other honourable members. Paragraph (e) of the motion, `provide guidelines for the operation of agribusiness in Australia', is being addressed by the Trade Practices Commission in conjunction with the National Farmers Federation. The issue has some tangential relationship to this area.

SPEECH.PARA: The issue should be looked at in the broadest way. I do not think the motion means that agribusiness is bad; of course it is not. A country such as Australia, which relies so heavily on the development of its agricultural industries, needs to increase its efficiency all the time and its ability not only to address domestic markets but also to be competitive on international markets. Recently there has been much public debate-the debate has yet to take place in this House-on one of our biggest agricultural industries, the wheat industry. We are charting a new direction almost in a bipartisan way as to how we will sell wheat to the rest of the world. The changes that are taking place indicate that Australia, along with the rest of the world, has to develop new ways of supplying food to the world. That is the point we ought to start with.

The honourable member for Hughes mentioned a report called Food 2000, commissioned by the Bruntland Commission, the World Commission on Environment and Development. It also prepared a report called Our Common Future. In the final report that has now been issued there is much discussion about how to develop sustainable agricultural policies. That means that we do not take too much out of the ground, thereby exhausting its use for future generations. The report identified many problem areas. Until now all countries have focused on output growth. Subsidies that have stimulated production in the absence of demand have been one of the major causes of the present severe problems in the agricultural world marketing regimes.

For example, in the United States in 1980, $US2.7 billion was spent on agricultural subsidies. By 1986 it was $US25.8 billion. In Europe, $6.2 billion was spent in 1976. By 1986 it was $21.5 billion. Those figures have blown out even further in recent years, although now there is a world recognition that the continuation of such levels of subsidies corrupts the international food markets. The disruption of world markets hurts the small producer countries that are particularly reliant on specific crops, such as sugar and rice.

It is important to keep the degradation of the resource base in mind. In recent times in this House we have discussed issues such as global warming and its effects, energy use trends-where do we go-and population pressures. We know that the world population is growing. We have also discussed the issue of production over environment. The issue of the soil resource loss is known to all of us who represent rural electorates in this nation. We need to focus far more attention on it. There is the issue of chemical impact. The honourable member referred to the over-reliance on chemicals. This also leads to the degradation of the resource base. We need to develop alternative methods of using scientific knowledge to enhance agricultural production. The development of pheromone technology by the Chemicals and Polymers Division of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation in Melbourne is a good example.

There are forestry pressures. Brazil has featured in this regard in the electronic media recently. Those who read National Geographic would have seen an interesting article indicating that there are major problems in this area. We need to develop sustainable yield forestry policies like we have in Tasmania, where there is a sensible balance between meeting production needs and future needs. Tasmania is leading the nation in those far-sighted policies.

There is the global problem of advancing deserts. Honourable members are probably aware that 29 per cent of the land area of this world suffers some form of desertification. That is a major challenge. Some 850 million people try to eke out a living in desert areas. There are major problems. There are challenges for us. The demand for food will increase as population increases. There is no doubt about that. The global food chain needs to increase food production by between 3 and 4 per cent a year. There is the global food security issue and the issue of the reduction of distortions in the structure of the world food market. The shifting focus of food production to food deficient countries, regions and households is the aim.

The challenge of increasing food production to keep pace with demand, while retaining the essential ecological integrity of production systems, is colossal in both its magnitude and its complexity. The challenge for us is how we do it. The basis of the motion before us seems to be that agribusiness works against this. My view is that it need not.

What Australia has to do in a domestic sense is make sure that our broad agricultural policies are not narrowly focused. Agricultural planning and policies must be broadly based, they must be more interrelated with what is happening in the world. Large agribusiness plays a very positive role. What we must ensure-indeed, many of my colleagues will have seen the global study of the Centre for International Economics-is a movement away from the distortions to the agricultural and food processing sectors that are now so big and prevalent not only in this country but also in the United States and Europe. It is not only the agricultural industry that needs reform; this impinges on bankers, industrialists, the unemployed and broader macro-economic policy. The best prospects for agricultural policy reform lie in groups outside agriculture realising their common interest. The real test is substantially changing the political will of governments to reform bad policies. This Government, as indeed, the Opposition, must exhibit the political will to chart a new course in the development of agricultural policies, but that does not mean that we turn around and put a rope around the feet of agricultural businesses because they are going to be the driving force for the development of our agricultural industries. To distort markets the way we have traditionally I think is a backward step. The question is: How do we bring about this reform?

I think that the honourable member for Hughes, who just spoke, is a member of the committee examining mergers and takeovers. He would be aware, as I am, having been a member of that committee, of the importance of the Trade Practices Act, the questions of substantial dominance test under section 50, the section 46 test of the misuse of market power and the problems needed to balance out between the competing interests of the development of the concentration of ownership and the need to ensure that there is a continuation of competition because it is through competition that there is a full development of markets. Powerful buyers have emerged and there is vertical integration within the agricultural sectors. That need not necessarily be a bad thing. What we have to do is balance off international economic realities about being able to be of a scale to compete and the need to ensure that concentration of ownership does not genuinely work against proper competition. The processing levels and the oligopolies that have been developing are not all bad, but there are mechanisms-this was the point that I was going to make-for dealing with those problems and trying to reach that proper balance.

Under the Trade Practices Act there is a rural guidelines committee which is chaired by the President of the National Farmers Federation. It has on it George Rance, the Executive Director of the Tasmanian Farmers and Graziers Association, John Primrose of the Trade Practices Commission, and several others. Their task is to develop a discussion paper with a view to developing rural guidelines that can apply and give some guidance to the Trade Practices Commission and explain how they work between those two competing interests. Interestingly, that discussion document is being released today in Canberra. It is particularly significant that it is being released because it recognises a problem that those on the land realise; that is, that they have an inequality of bargaining power and by the use of mechanisms under the Trade Practices Act, such as the authorisation procedures, there may well be an ability for the countervailing power of producers to be enhanced against the larger companies.

I think that those issues need a much broader canvassing. The issue of research needs better canvassing. The special Rural Research Council has been in operation and it has been a great success. It recognises that research is important for the development of agricultural industry. It recognises that the education within the farm sector is important for the development of agricultural industry but, most importantly-and the point that I come back to-no-one who reads this motion ought to think that agribusiness is bad. If we want to be competitive in international markets, we must enhance the opportunities for our businesses to be involved in those international markets and any direction of policy which works against that end works against the very best interests of the farm community and every member of the community in this country. There are ways that we can address the competitive aspects and the imbalance of power that may or may not be in the system. The Trade Practices Commission and the farming community have combined to look at those issues. I think that is something that the honourable member for Hughes, who raised the motion, may not have been aware of. Perhaps he ought to be aware of it. He is now aware of it and I am sure that the Government will make every effort to ensure that everyone gets a fair opportunity to compete on those markets that hopefully in time will be uncorrupted by the unnecessary subsidy policies that are being pursued by some of those with whom we trade which have brought us to the situation where international markets and commodities have unfortunately been corrupted.

Finally, it shows the importance of ensuring that Australia is represented vigorously in every trade negotiation area throughout the world. We must put our case strongly, concisely and succinctly at every opportunity. We hear little from the Minister for Trade Negotiations (Mr Duffy), but he can be assured that many of us in this place and elsewhere watch with interest to see what progress he is making to ensure that Australia is treated fairly, because we are trying to treat the rest of the world fairly. We support our agricultural businesses in what they do domestically and internationally.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Milton Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree with some of the points raised by the previous speaker, the honourable member for Bass (Mr Smith), but I think it is a fact that the mover of the motion did understand a number of the matters he raised. I want to draw attention to one aspect of agribusiness which I believe has caused great dangers to the future of agriculture throughout the world; that is, the agrochemical industry. It had its origins in the early twentieth century and had become a highly profitable industry by the 1920s. In the United States, production of the chemical industry increased some sevenfold from 1900 to 1939, but the greatest increase of all has occurred since the end of World War II with the annual manufacture of chemicals having increased by more than 900 per cent for the 30-year period between 1947 and 1978.
