It was during that period that the agricultural use of insecticides, herbicides and commercial fertilisers increased rapidly. The green revolution, as it was termed, representing the large increase of crop yields by the use of capital intensive methods and chemical dependence on synthetic pesticides and herbicides, was enthusiastically adopted by the countries with large agricultural exports, particularly those of the Third World.

SPEECH.PARA: The chief exporters of pesticides are the agrochemical companies based in Germany, which has 25 per cent of the market; the United States, which has 20 per cent; the United Kingdom, 15 per cent; Switzerland, 15 per cent; and France some 13 per cent. I am indebted for this information which I received from the book entitled Pills, Pesticides and Profits-the International Trade in Toxic Substances published by North River Press Inc. It provides valuable background information on the growth and activities of the agrochemical industry. Dozens of synthetic pesticides are banned or severely restricted in the producer and other industrialised nations, but these are exported for use in Third World countries.

The World Health Organisation has estimated that 5,000 people die and half a million people are poisoned by direct contact with pesticides. In the less developed countries there are virtually no laws or any regulatory structures for the control of pesticide imports and virtually no facilities for monitoring pesticide residues in food or in the environment. Insecticides such as parathion and malathion have caused deaths and illness amongst both animals and humans in Colombia, Egypt and Indonesia. In Ghana, lindane, which is a highly toxic pesticide, was responsible for the deaths of fishermen who did not realise that killing fish with the pesticide would mean death for the people who eventually consumed the fish. Misuse of pesticides and insecticides either for the wrong purposes or because of an incorrect application is frequently a cause of illness and death amongst both animals and humans.

In the late 1940s dichlorodiphenyltrichloroethane (DDT) was introduced as the major tool in the worldwide program to eliminate malaria and the initial consequence was a dramatic reduction in the incidence of malaria throughout the world because of the death of the disease carrying mosquitoes. DDT seemed fairly harmless at first, but over time it became dangerous because of its poisonous long life in the air we breathe, the water we drink and the food we eat. In the United States all crop uses of DDT were banned in 1972 and all uses, except in certain emergency conditions, were banned in 1973 on the ground that continued use would pose an unacceptable risk to humans and the environment. However, it is appalling to learn that the pesticide continued to be sold overseas. I quote from the book which I mentioned previously:

Even assuming that exported pesticides are shipped to Third World countries in properly labelled containers, to purchasers who have been informed of the products' risks, with the knowledge and consent of the purchasers' governments, we cannot conclude that workers in those countries, and residents of the areas where the pesticides will be used, have any protection. Informed consent on the part of the purchaser means little if the purchaser is simply a foreign subsidiary of the producing company. Government knowledge of purchases of banned pesticides is of little value if there is no regulatory capability in the importing country to stop the continued importation or prevent the improper use of those chemicals. All of these problems pertain, to some extent, to Third World countries.

Labelling requirements, for example, apply only to the container in which a pesticide is shipped. But corporations and farmers in many Third World countries now formulate pesticides-mix the active ingredient, or ``technical ingredient,'' with inert ingredients, emulsifiers, baits, and so on-after the products have reached their destination. Local formulation is a rapidly increasing practice in the developing nations.

In case we become complacent about the Third World's problems, let me make it quite clear that the problems exist in a very real way here in Australia. That is why I wanted to participate in the present debate. On 27 June 1988 the Australian Broadcasting Corporation's Four Corners program televised a discussion on pesticide contamination of Australian homes and rural areas. The compere of the program, Andrew Olle, said:

The chemical villains are the same big four that nearly destroyed Australia's beef industry last year, Dieldrin, Aldrin, Heptachlor and Chlordane. Each member of this deadly quartet has been taken off the market in the United States where authorities suspect a cancer link. Their sensibilities have forced our exporters to change their ways, but the big four are also used to treat hundreds of thousands of Australian homes each year for termites.

The program went on to describe a number of case studies of Australians on farms, and in some cases urban properties, who had found that they had been physically exposed to organochloride chemical pesticides such as dieldrin, aldrin, heptachlor and chlordane, which had resulted in serious physical defects. These included a sore throat, runny nose, sore eyes, nausea, unsteadiness and disorientation. A reporter made it clear that, despite a new State law which banned organochlorides, it was still possible in Perth to buy with ease a bottle of the pesticide. Paul Barry, one of the reporters, said:

David and Monica Rado grow potatoes on six hundred acres near Manjimup in Western Australia and they also raise cattle, or they did. Till 1981, they sprayed their potatoes with Dieldrin and from then to 1987, with Heptachlor, in each case to kill the black beetle that attacks the crop. What they didn't know was that when they grazed the cattle on these fields, even years after, the cattle picked up the chemical. Then, when the beef crisis broke last year, they found out. Now, some of the best land in Australia lies idle, a wasteland, and the Rados are not alone. In this area, 100 farms are in quarantine and Australia-wide, the number is nearer 900, and most often the farmers will tell you they used the chemical on official government advice.
The program ended with Andrew Olle saying:

Paul Barry, and I must say I found his report pretty depressing to watch. I remember doing a similar story for Four Corners some ten years ago, dealing with some of the very issues Paul just raised, like inadequate screening of chemicals, like their careless application, like the fact that chemical build-up had already forced a number of farms to be quarantined.
I support the motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time allotted for the debate has expired. The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday. The honourable member for La Trobe will have leave to continue his speech when the debate is resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrew Mr J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House acknowledges the essential role that agricultural and veterinary chemicals have played in the development of agriculture in Australia and condemns the proposed Senate inquiry into agricultural chemicals as prejudicial and alarmist.

I welcome the opportunity to speak to the motion, particularly after the remarks of the honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Milton). I think I could be forgiven for presuming that the honourable member for La Trobe was directing his remarks to my, at that stage, unmoved motion. I ought to address in this debate many of the honourable member's emotional comments.

Let us set in perspective what has happened in agriculture in Australia. One hundred years ago every farmer across the world fed six people. Every farmer produced enough to feed little more than his own family. Today farmers across the world feed 70 people. The change from one farmer feeding six people to one farmer being able to feed 70 people is one of the incredible steps that have been made progressively, particularly in Australian agriculture. We are all, including the honourable member for La Trobe, conscious of the enormous impact on productivity that chemicals have had in farms and home gardens. We are all aware of the essential role that chemicals have played in making each of us, either as home gardeners or primary producers, able to be more productive.

I speak with some passion on this subject because of my background in the horticultural industry-an industry which has involved, and still does, a high use of agricultural chemicals. Why is that? It is not because horticulturists are fond of using agricultural chemicals; it is because the market has demanded a product that is unblemished and free from pests and diseases. Let us take as an example changes that have occurred in the last two decades in the horticultural industry, particularly the citrus industry. I well recall, as a teenager, having to help pull tents over every individual citrus tree in order to retain cyanide gas inside that citrus tree and kill the disfiguring pest, red scale. My job was to run along and count out the number of cyanide tablets-they were about the size of a bath plug-which were dropped into a cyanide gun and blown into the tent. That was not awfully good for the local wildlife. Birds caught under the tent would flap and die. If the neighbour's dog happened to wander in, he too faced a similar fate. However, that was standard practice until the development of chemicals such as malathion and parathion, which the honourable member for La Trobe referred to, made it possible for people to do away with fumigation tents and, instead, control red scale with a broad-brush chemical attempt.

Neither the producers nor the chemical companies were happy with that option because of the impact it had on the environment. So today, as a result of cooperation between the chemical companies and the producers, these broad-based chemicals are no longer used. Instead there is a form of regulated biological control. There is a control mechanism: a little wog known as an aphytis melinus is introduced into the orchard. The aphytis melinus is assisted in its control program by the application of a chemical known as white oil. I have no doubt that the honourable member for Wannon (Mr Hawker), who will second my motion and speak to it, will be able to give ample illustrations of his own industry-the sheep industry-and the movement away from broad-based chemicals and total dipping of sheep to the pouring on of chemicals for lice control.

Historically, chemicals in agriculture were arsenic-based compounds. Chemicals such as nicotine sulphate and copper-based fungicides were commonly used. These broad-based killing techniques have now been replaced by chemicals that target specific pests. We can take, for example, codling moth. Once controlled by parathion or malathion, it is now controlled by diseases that specifically target the codling moth. These changes did not just happen. They have occurred because pesticide and chemical companies have been prepared to look for techniques for controlling pests that were more biologically sympathetic than the techniques previously made available.

In order to develop a new product, the chemical companies are required to put that product through an extensive testing mechanism. Research and development costs chemical companies in Australia at least $23m per annum. It takes at least five years to find a new chemical, get it on to the marketplace and put it through the necessary research and development requirements. A test program, which is laid down legislatively, requires every chemical company to develop what is known as a no observed adverse effect-NOAE-level. When a level is achieved which has no observed adverse affect on a human, it must be taken down 100 times before it becomes the acceptable daily intake. The chemical is not available for use on a crop until the level at which there is no observed adverse effect is taken down 100 times.
In April of 1987 Professor Ames made a comment about agricultural and veterinary chemicals. He said:
We are ingesting in our diet at least 10,000 times more by weight of natural pesticides than of man-made pesticides residues.
If this is the case, we should ask what is the risk to Australian society of the present application of agricultural and veterinary chemicals.

TALK.START.PARA: —Dead people.

—I thank the honourable member for the interjection, one that I will respond to in just a moment. If we regard DDT in food as having a relative cancer risk of one, tap water has a relative cancer risk of three, a peanut butter sandwich a relative cancer risk of 100, a diet cola a relative cancer risk of 200, mushrooms a relative cancer risk of 330 and beer a relative cancer risk of 9,300. I restate the simple fact that this has become a very emotive argument, taken right out of proportion.

SPEECH.PARA: Consider, for example, the issue raised by the honourable member for La Trobe in his contribution when he said chemicals nearly destroyed the Australian beef industry in 1987. Do honourable members know what really happened in the Australian beef industry? The Australian beef industry, unforgivably maybe, exceeded the minimum intake allowed in the American market by 0.03 parts per million of chemical residue in the beef. I do not excuse that. It is too much. But I wonder whether honourable members know what 0.03 parts per million is in real terms. It is half the length of my forefinger in a journey from my home in Adelaide to Canberra. I could not even roll my car out of the garage, in comparative terms, if we were to put 0.03 parts per million in perspective-less than half my forefinger in a journey from Canberra to Adelaide.

If we are to set the agricultural and veterinary chemical scene in perspective, let us remember that primary producers around Australia currently spend about $500m per annum on agricultural and veterinary chemicals in order to generate a cost benefit. That cost benefit is hard to ascertain, but it is conservatively estimated at being between $3 billion and $6 billion per annum.

The honourable member for Hughes (Mr Tickner) in an earlier and unrelated debate referred to an orchardist he knew who spent half his income on agricultural chemicals. As an orchardist I found that a little hard to relate to, but I am prepared to take his word for it. It matters not; there is a real cost benefit in what happens for every primary producer currently spending money on agricultural and veterinary chemicals.

The honourable member for McEwen (Mr Cleeland), who earlier interjected about the number of people dropping dead from the excessive use of agricultural chemicals, might like to ponder for a moment the equally real and uncomfortable truth that only three primary producers in Australia have been killed by unintentional chemical use. They were killed as a result of chemical accidents, the spillage of concentrate or ignorance of what those chemicals would do. Only three people in the group most at risk died as a result of their using chemicals.These are not the consumers of Australian food; these are the people using chemical concentrates. Anyone who is involved, as are the honourable member for Wannon and I, in the application of chemicals, knows that the people using them take a concentrate which may well be a little of concentrated chemical and add it to a spray vat or a dip at a rate of possibly one litre in a thousand. That one litre is a very lethal weapon for people to have in their hands. If they reduced the concentration to one part in 1,000 in the spray vat or the sheep dip, and then sprayed it out, it would still represent a far greater hazard to primary producers than to any consumers of Australian food.

Honourable members should consider the reality. A primary producer sits on his tractor seat spraying out a chemical reduced from the concentrate of one litre to one in 1,000. He sits all day in a chemical mist and fog. Relatively, if the Australian consumer were then to take the apple or orange off the tree and consume it straightaway, his risk would not be anything like the risk the primary producer is exposed to. The consumer does not consume the food for a minimum time of at least two weeks, which is the specified withholding period. Given all this, and given the fact that even at that level of application so few, if any, primary producers actually suffer and all deaths have been as a result of some form of accidental spillage, we should ask ourselves why the fuss? Why this inquiry into agricultural and veterinary chemicals?

Coincidentally, my desk diary today, Mr Deputy Speaker, had on it a little notation that said, `It is twice as hard to crush a half-truth as a whole lie'. We have heard a half-truth about the chemical industry which is far harder to destroy than the whole lies that may have been enunciated about other industries. The Australian Democrats in the Senate, determined to curry favour with the limited, unrepresentative electoral group they have, have managed to persuade the Government, as a trade-off for their support of the resource rent tax, to agree to this inquiry. The inquiry runs the risk of being an attack on one of the key elements needed to make our agricultural production more efficient and productive. For the sake of 0.03 parts per million, we have a springboard which will be nothing more than a witch-hunt into the Australian agricultural and veterinary chemical industry. We on this side of the House resist that half-truth. We do not want any primary producer or consumer put at risk, but we see a real risk in that of losing an essential tool that we need to help redress our balance of payments deficit.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?
—I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chynoweth Mr R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —After hearing that little effort, I will show honourable members what it is all about with the humble apple I have in my hands. This is what I will speak about. We have heard about the grapes and other products sprayed with chemicals, but I am not a farmer. We live in the cities and eat the produce that is manufactured and shipped down to us at a high cost.
—Apples are not manufactured; they are grown.

—It is grown on the farm, but it is shipped down to us in the cities. We have to eat the apples. I wish to talk about a report which came into my hands yesterday. It is called `Health Politics Trade: Controlling Chemical Residues in Agricultural Products'. There is a picture of a nice red apple on the front of it. That is what keyed me off and got me going about this fine apple I have with me. I probably eat a couple of apples a day. I really like them. However, I am getting a bit worried because of what I have read in the papers recently.
—Don't believe everything you read in the papers.

—I do not believe it all, but I think we should have a close look at the chemical industry and the way it is pushing its products on farmers who grow the produce and transport it down to the city for us to eat. There is a lot of pressure these days on farmers to make a quid. If they can make a quid by spraying extra chemicals on their crops to keep off the pests--
—It costs money, you dill.

—Maybe it does cost money, but farmers get a greater reward. Instead of getting 100 apples off the tree, if they do not spray the tree with chemicals they might get only 20 apples. They might get 200 apples if they spray more chemicals on it. I think there is a lot of pressure on farmers these days to use chemicals.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me talk about apples. I have before me an article of 5 April 1988 from the Advertiser entitled `Apple sales slump after report on chemical use'. The report states:
Apple sales have slumped alarmingly in South Australia following a national television program that suggested an apple spray, Alar, may cause cancer . . .
Apple industry spokesmen are furious about the report. They have accused the program's producers of scaremongering, and say consumers have been misled with `hysterical nonsense'.
`The bulk of our growers do not, and never have, used Alar, which is a very expensive chemical,' Mr Lockier said.

He is the spokesman. That claim may be true. However, the report does not say that apple growers have never used Alar. It simply says the bulk of them have not; some of them are using it. I do not know whether the apples which my wife and I buy at Ritchies, a good store just up the road in Frankston, are sprayed with Alar. The employees at Ritchies do not know; they buy the apples from the market. The apples could come from anywhere. So how do I know what I am eating? I do not. How do I know what my kids are eating? I do not. I have a report from Science magazine. It is called `Pesticides and Kids'. It states:
A new study charges that pesticide residues pose an `intolerable' risk to children-
this report is of a study from the United States-

Children are exposed to dangerous levels of pesticide residues in fruits and vegetables-residues that may lead to cancer or subtle neurological effects-the Natural Resources Defense Council alleges in a new report. Some 5500 to 6200 children may develop cancer later in life from exposure to just eight pesticides during their preschool years, says the environmental group, which calls the risk `intolerable'.
I agree with the report. It continues:
The worst offenders are some of the foods that kids like best, including apple juice, applesauce and grapes . . .

Kids may face a greater risk from pesticide residues for several reasons. First, their exposure is greater because they eat more food relative to their body weight than do adults. And second, they consume far more fruit, on average, which is more likely than other foods to be contaminated with pesticide residues.

Fruits comprise 34% of a preschooler's diet and just 20% of the mother's diet . . . The average preschooler eats six times more fruit, overall, than an adult woman aged 22 to 30, seven times more apples and applesauce, seven times more grape products, and a whopping 18 times more apple juice . . .
I do not know about that last figure. This is an American article. The report continues:

A handful of pesticides pose the greatest risk . . . Eighty-six to ninety-six per cent of the total cancer risk NRDC calculated can be traced to one pesticide, Alar, and its breakdown product, UDMH . . .
NRDC also found `unacceptable' exposures to four carcinogenic fungicides: captan, chlorothalonil, folpet, and ethylene thiourea (ETU), a metabolite of the pesticide mancozeb.
All of these chemicals are used in fairly large volumes on Australian farms. The report continues:

At least 3 million kids, or 17% of the sample, are exposed to neurotoxic organophosphate insecticides in amounts that exceed EPA's established safe level, or acceptable daily intake . . . These `intolerable' risks arise, says NRDC, because EPA drastically underestimates preschooler consumption of certain foods and has thus set standards that fail to protect them . . .

This is an American article. I would say that the facts are exactly the same here in Australia. I believe we should have an inquiry. I believe it would be good for the farming community, because it would get farmers to look again at what they are doing and cut down the risk to themselves and their own families. They are the ones who have to work in these conditions. In the city we like the products which come to us, but we do not like them full of insecticides. I can assure you, Mr Deputy Speaker, that when I get outside this chamber, this humble apple will be eaten by me and I will enjoy it, but I will be thinking about Alar, with which it could possibly have been sprayed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawker Mr D.P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —In seconding this motion I would like to commend the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew) for his excellent and balanced presentation and the way he put the whole issue into perspective. For too long we have had an emotional scare campaign about agricultural chemicals. Because there have been one or two isolated cases, everyone has been branded as irresponsible. I would be the first to condemn someone who was irresponsible with chemicals. Why, with all the scaremongering going on, do we continue to brand all producers as irresponsible? Why do we continue to put this fear amongst people-fear based partly on ignorance; fear often built by people who have a vested interest in pushing a quite different agenda; and fear which, in most cases, is totally unfounded and out of proportion?

SPEECH.PARA: I take exception to some of the comments of the honourable member for Dunkley (Mr Chynoweth). He went to some trouble to put forward a case, but I think he admitted at the end that he would prefer to have his apple free of moths and other insects; free of bacteria--

TALK.START.PARA: —I said `free of pesticides'.

—Free of pesticides, yes, but he would also like it free of insects and free of the bacteria which those insects might be carrying. In other words, he would like it to be fresh, crisp and attractive. It is a case of wanting his cake and eating it.

SPEECH.PARA: As the honourable member for Wakefield pointed out, the hardest thing to argue against is a half truth. When the honourable member for Dunkley started his speech-he went into great lengths about the associated risks-the key word he used was `may'. He said there may be a risk, which may lead to an intolerable risk which may cause all these wonderful statistical analyses about the number of people who could be affected. He said it may; it could. In other words, he was describing a half truth. There may be a problem and I would be the first to support him if there were. In the meantime, however, why go around scaring the living daylights out of children and mothers about things which, if kept in proportion, involve far fewer risks than is believed. What about the risks associated with not eating apples? If children did not have a decent fruit intake, I suggest that they would be much more unhealthy and much more at risk than they are from the causes put forward in the American article which was quoted.

The honourable member for Dunkley was quick to read an article quoting a spokesman for Australian apple growers who pointed out that the vast majority of apple growers do not use this particular chemical. I would say that now that the chemical has had some publicity, no growers will use it. Farmers are responsible. Farmers have used chemicals over a number of years for the benefit not only of themselves, but also of consumers and the whole nation. As the member for Wakefield pointed out, in 100 years we have seen an increase in the ability of a farmer to feed people, from six people to 70. By any measure, that is a staggering increase in productivity, which has brought with it a staggering increase in efficiency. So it is not only the farmers but the whole community that benefit. The community benefits from cheaper, fresher and a better range of foods-many of which would not be available were it not for the responsible use of chemicals. We ought to keep this matter in perspective and keep this emotional argument out of it.

It has been suggested that the use of chemicals in various livestock industries may present some risk. The fact is that the arsenical dips and so on used in, say, the sheep industry have now been outlawed. In fairness to the people who have used them in the past, it must also be remembered that no-one knew of the problems. It is easy with hindsight to make all sorts of wonderful pronouncements and condemn people, but without the benefit of that hindsight how could anyone condemn people for undertaking what they believed were safe practices. It is time we remembered that. There are many things we do today because we believe they are safe and correct, but in 10, 20 or 30 years' time someone may be able to produce evidence to the contrary. In the meantime, why do we condemn the people who have been doing things in a responsible manner? Let me assure the House that all the farmers I know-I include myself in this-are not keen to use any more chemicals than they have to. We use them in a responsible manner. We follow the instructions on the label and we make sure, if there is a withholding period for livestock or produce, that that withholding period is observed.

I make one other point for the benefit of the honourable members opposite: people in Australia, including I am sure every member of this chamber, are extremely concerned about land degradation, about the erosion of soil throughout the countryside. One of the big advances in farming techniques has come about through what is known as chemical ploughing. With the use of short life herbicides and associated ways and means of eliminating weeds farmers can put in a crop without having to plough fields and rip up the soil, which leads to potential erosion. So the use of chemicals has done something very positive for the Australian countryside and for our land care. We should start to look at the positive side of the chemical industry. We certainly have to use chemicals responsibly, we certainly have to make sure they are properly tested and used in a safe and responsible manner. But having said that, we should not be going around using these half truths to condemn chemicals in an effort to gain political capital when quite clearly the whole nation has benefited to an enormous extent from the sensible, responsible use of chemicals in agriculture.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brumby Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is my pleasure to speak in this debate on agricultural and veterinary chemicals, but the Government does not support the motion put before the House by the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew) and supported by the honourable member for Wannon (Mr Hawker). I make it clear right at the outset that no-one in this Government has ever argued that agricultural and veterinary chemicals are not important-indeed, in some cases essential-to the viability of our agricultural industries. But for the Opposition to say that an inquiry into the use of those chemicals-their efficacy, their economic and environmental impacts and so on-is a scare campaign, that such an inquiry is a witch-hunt, is basically preposterous. It is typical of the Opposition's attitude to so many aspects of Government policy. It is a blinkered approach; it is the view that because something exists at the moment and is used in a certain way it must be right and we must not ever think again, reconsider or evaluate the way in which we use a particular chemical.

SPEECH.PARA: We are suggesting that this Senate inquiry simply examine the use of agricultural chemicals in Australia, to review their use and ensure they are being used in a proper way and are making a significant impact to the benefit of Australian agriculture. To kill this view that there is some witch-hunt or some scare campaign involved in this Senate inquiry, let me read from the terms of reference of the inquiry. The Senate Select Committee on Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals in Australia is to inquire into:
(a) the adequacy of arrangements under the legislation relating to agricultural and veterinary chemicals for administration and co-ordination systems for agricultural and veterinary chemicals;
(b) the efficacy of chemical, non-chemical and integrated management systems; and
(c) the economic, social and environmental impact on Australia of agricultural and veterinary chemicals and their alternatives.

If anyone seriously suggests that those terms of reference represent an attack on farmers, an attack on agriculture and an attack on agricultural chemicals, that is nonsense. This is a sensible inquiry established by the Senate to look sensibly, responsibly and rationally at the use of chemicals in agriculture. The Opposition says there is basically no need for this sort of inquiry, but let us have a think about what has occurred in Australia just in recent times. Because of chemical residues we have put at risk our beef industry with export income worth more than $1 billion.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is fixed now.

—The honourable member for Wannon says it is fixed, but the fact is there was a problem with chemical residues; there was misuse of chemicals; and Australia's food reputation was damaged on international markets. Those things are undeniable. The Senate inquiry will be investigating whether there are other cases of misuse which could have a similar impact on Australia. The honourable member for Wannon shakes his head again. It demonstrates this paranoid approach of the Opposition, that the status quo must be maintained at all costs-because something exists now it must be right. All the Senate inquiry will be doing is looking at the use of chemicals to see whether it is good or bad, economic or non-economic and so on.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Dunkley (Mr Chynoweth) mentioned the recent problems with some apple sprays presently in use in the United States, New Zealand, Canada and in fact Australia. In particular he referred to the chemical Alar, as it is known by its trade name. Its chemical name is daminozide. This chemical is under review in New Zealand, and there have been press reports that its use in that country has been banned. I am told that those press reports are not accurate and that some newspaper reports have been quite misleading. The chemical is approved for use in a number of countries-including the United States, New Zealand, Canada and Australia-and there are relevant maximum residue limits in place. Australia has had access to all of the available toxicological data and it will receive reports of studies currently being undertaken. The National Health and Medical Research Council will evaluate that information. At the moment, on the basis of all of the evidence available to the Government, there is no identifiable substantive danger in the use of that chemical. I should say that its full name is metabolite unsymmetrical dimethylhydrazine, or UDMH. I simplified this for the benefit of honourable members in the House.

In relation to the reference of the honourable member for Dunkley to apples, I eat a number of apples and my children, as many children do, drink a fair bit of commercially produced apple juice. While I fully understand and recognise the need for a viable agricultural industry-I am really an economic rationalist-I also have a right as an ordinary consumer, as all consumers do, to believe and understand that the food we eat is as pure as possible. That is the only issue. The Government is not suggesting in any way that through this Senate inquiry there should be some scare campaign or witch-hunt. We are trying to reconcile, on the one hand, the use of chemicals-which I agree in some industries has led to astronomical gains in productivity and which are absolutely essential to agricultural industries-with, on the other hand, the fact that there is a growing concern and awareness in the world that through the use of chemicals and other things in our environment we are poisoning the world's environment. People have a right to expect that their food will be as pure as possible.

TALK.START.PARA: —And safe.

—Pure and safe. That is what is at issue. Government members of the country task force set up by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) have met with members of the Senate Committee. We have represented to that Committee the views of farming organisations and we have made it clear that we do not want the ratbag element, as the Opposition calls it, to dominate the work of that inquiry. We have every confidence that it will not dominate the work of that inquiry and that it is sensible and rational to examine these matters.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for McEwen (Mr Cleeland), who is in the House, has taken a keen interest in this debate. I was talking to him previously about this issue because he has a deep concern for both the farmers in his electorate and the consumers who eat the food produced by those growers. He reminded me of the damage that has been done in the past through the inappropriate use of agricultural chemicals. He mentioned in particular the use of dieldrin. On hundreds, if not thousands, of acres of land in the Kinglake area of his electorate the soil has been poisoned through the overuse of dieldrin in decades past. That land is so poisoned that it will not be able to be returned to any form of agricultural production for years, if not decades. Some of the chemicals that have been misused in the past-sure, on the best available evidence-are extremely toxic. Dieldrin is one of those. I do not need to remind honourable members that the misuse in the United States of America of the chemicals dieldrin and DDT was responsible for the wholesale eradication of many bird species as a result of their eating the wheat and so on.

We have to be careful in our use of chemicals. That is not an unreasonable thing to say. It is hardly a scaremongering or a witch-hunt type of statement. We on this side of the House recognise that most farmers-and my parents farm-use chemicals carefully and do not overuse them. But they rely on advice which is provided, and sometimes that is not the best advice available. All we are saying is that there is a commonsense approach behind this Senate inquiry. Let us recognise that agricultural chemicals have been good for agriculture, but let us also recognise that times change and that it is prudent to review the use of those chemicals. If we can make less use of toxic chemicals, I think that is a good thing. That is all that is suggested in this inquiry.

I conclude by saying that we on this side of the House have a strong view about the importance of agriculture to our economy. We fully recognise that agriculture is vital to Australia's future but, as we have already seen from some of the problems that have arisen in the beef industry, there is a need for our export produce to be as pure and as safe as possible. Australia can improve its export markets by developing an international reputation for good, high quality, safe food. There are economic benefits in this for Australia. We are quite sensible about that. We recognise the value of agriculture. We recognise that chemicals have transformed productivity and output in many industries. However, at the same time we want to ensure that chemicals are not overused and that we can monitor their economic, social and environmental impact. That is all the Senate inquiry is doing. We think it makes good sense and we on the Government side of the House strongly support it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time allotted for the debate has expired. The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cobb Mr M.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the present Government's program to educate the Australian population with regard to AIDS should be redirected more towards preventing the disease through changing lifestyle patterns of risk groups in the community.

Since the acquired immune deficiency syndrome (AIDS) was first diagnosed a few years ago there has been a general awareness amongst the general public and the scientific community that this is potentially one of the worst diseases ever to afflict mankind. To date over 80,000 people in the United States of America and over 1,200 in Australia have been diagnosed as having AIDS. So far no cure has been found. Everybody who gets the disease dies and the numbers getting it are increasing daily. Some have even likened it to the major plagues of old. However, unlike those plagues, when everyone lived in fear of infection, this is the first plague in history when it appears that most of us can live amongst infected people yet have no fear of catching the disease providing they do not indulge in certain lifestyles, such as male homosexuality, sharing dirty hypodermic needles, and certain types of promiscuity.

However, I believe that the Australian population is not being told the full story. The information we are being fed is at least partially, if not totally, distorted. I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard some tables to which I will speak. I have cleared these with the Minister for Telecommunications and Aviation Support (Mrs Kelly), who is at the table.
