TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. Tables 5, 6 and 7 are from The Lancet of 14 February 1987. I regret to say that the Government and especially the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) are responsible for the situation we are in today. The information being provided through the Government's so-called AIDS education program ignores traditional medical practice and procedures based on sound and conclusive research. This is leading to unnecessary deaths in the community. The Government is substituting a heap of demedicalised nonsense designed to protect the homosexual community from embarrassment or blame rather than facing the medical facts of this disease and getting on top of it in a rigorous, scientifically correct manner.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian figures for AIDS are up to date as at 25 March of this year. They show that 1,270-odd people have been diagnosed as having AIDS. Of that total, 91.2 per cent, or 1,158 people, are male homosexuals; 6.3 per cent, or 80 people, are intravenous drug users, have been infected through blood transfusions or are haemophiliacs; 1.2 per cent are in an indeterminate category and number 15; and only 1.3 per cent-that is, 17 people out of 1,270-are heterosexuals, and there is even a suggestion that some of these people may have indulged at some stage in anal intercourse.

I believe that these official government figures tell us a number of things. They tell us, first, that we are all at risk but that we are not equally at risk. It is true that, the disease having an incubation period of seven to 10 years, we are seeing only what the infection pattern was many years ago. However, this pattern still holds true today. The incubation period for HIV infection is much shorter. The recent figures for HIV infection patterns, which are provided in the tables I have incorporated, show that there has not been much change.

The advertisement in which the Grim Reaper-someone who looked like the Treasurer (Mr Keating) dressed up in a shroud-was shown rolling bowling balls down the alley and knocking over a family-type group was quite deceptive. I believe it was false advertising. The more recent advertisement, which shows many couples in bed-I presume they are heterosexual couples-is, as the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew) said, absurd. Again, it presents a totally false picture.

The tables I have incorporated clearly show that the overwhelming number of people infected with this disease are homosexuals. Further, they show that AIDS is not just a homosexual disease: the infection of homosexuals is confined totally to male homosexuals. Not one lesbian in this country has yet been affected with AIDS. All the infected homosexuals are males. This leads one to suspect very strongly, and I will back this up later with evidence provided in the tables, that the disease is transmitted largely through anal intercourse. The heterosexual spread is very low. As I said, only 17 people in Australia have been diagnosed so far. That is about one in one million of the population. The risk is there, of course, that heterosexuals can pick up the disease. We may even see an increase over the years up to possibly even as high a figure as 4 to 5 per cent of the AIDS infected population. But it will still be low in relation to other groups.

Many innocent people have died so far from this disease. As I said earlier, 80 people have died through blood transfer, such as blood transfusions, et cetera. Fortunately, that has been almost totally corrected. There have been 10 cases where the victims have been less than nine years old. Some of those children, I guess, would have picked it up in utero. Haemophiliacs have died. If one person had died in this country, say, through a uranium accident, we would have 100,000 marching out in the streets.

I would like to go into the reason why I believe that the disease is anally transmitted. The virus, of course, has to cross from the donor to the recipient. It has to enter the bloodstream. Anyone with any knowledge of biology will know that the bowel wall is not designed to do what homosexuals do with it. Government members may laugh at this, but it is a very serious matter. The bowel wall consists of very fragile columnar epithelial cells. It is rich in blood vessels. It is not designed to suffer the traumas homosexuals put it through. Thrusting creates little tears in the bowel wall. The bowel wall is unlike the vaginal wall, which is designed to take those sorts of traumas. Thrusting in the bowel wall creates many bleeds, called petechial haemorrhages. This allows the virus more readily to come in contact with the bloodstream.

There are other technical reasons which enhance infection in the lower bowel, which I will not go into. The bowel is an ideal environment for transmission of the disease. I know that Government members find this particularly funny, and are rolling around in the aisles with laughter; but it is a very serious matter. I would like to talk about some figures which were published in the Lancet in February 1987 and which dissect these sorts of figures further. The Lancet is a very reputable journal. It is possibly close to being the top medical journal in the world. Twelve authors contributed an article from four universities-the University of California, the Johns Hopkins University of Baltimore, the University of Pittsburgh and the Howard Brown Memorial Clinic and Northwestern University in Chicago. The authors took a very large sample of male homosexuals-two and a half thousand. They took the participants' homosexual history for six months before and then they tested them.

Those who tested sero negative for HIV, which is the virus in the bloodstream, were followed for a further six months and then tested for HIV again. They came up with some amazing figures. Of the 646 who had not practised receptive anal intercourse in the six months leading up to the first test or in the six months previous to the second test but had indulged in other practices, such as insertive anal intercourse and the other things that homosexuals get up to, only three were HIV sero positive. That is one-half of one per cent.

Of those who in that previous 12 months period had not indulged in anal intercourse of any sort whatsoever-there were 220 of those people-not one developed an HIV positive test; that is, zero per cent. But, of those 548 who had indulged in receptive anal intercourse with two or more partners in the six months period before and after the first test, 58 came up positive for HIV. That is 10.6 per cent of that sample. That is an horrific figure. It goes to show to anyone who looks at those figures that, outside of blood transfers such as blood transfusions, the disease is transmitted mainly through anal intercourse and, in particular, receptive anal intercourse. I believe that the Australian population should be told that.

The article concluded that receptive anal intercourse was the only significant risk factor for sero-conversion to HIV. The risk factor of this happening increased from threefold, for those who had one partner indulging in receptive anal intercourse, up to 18-fold, for those who had five or more partners. In fact, a further breakdown of the figure for those who had been indulging in this practice and reduced their number of partners shows that the number fell to 3.2 per cent testing positive. Of those who had stopped it in the past six months before the second test was done the number who were testing positive had fallen to 1.8 per cent. Those figures, I believe, are just overwhelmingly conclusive. Any fair dinkum, responsible program must stress the hazards of this practice of receptive anal intercourse.

The article went on to tests of other practices that homosexuals get up to, such as fisting, rimming, dildo use, the use of douches and enemas, and so on. They found that they had little or no effect, with the possible exception of douches and enemas. I guess that that is probably because these later practices remove the protective mucous lining from the bowel wall. It is instructive to look at the lifestyle patterns of homosexual groups, as it shows the urgent need for them to modify their lifestyle habits. Some homosexuals in Australia already have done so, due to the publicity that has been given. But there is still a need for more of these facts to get through so that more homosexuals will be encouraged to change their lifestyle patterns. It was interesting to note that in the last study I quoted, of 2,500 homosexuals, the average age of those who were tested was about 30 years; the average length of time these people had been indulging in these practices of anal sex was about a decade, although some had been doing it for 58 years; and the average number of different partners over the previous six months was 10. It varied from one different partner up to 500 or so. In fact, some had had more than 1,000 different partners over the previous two years.

There was also a higher percentage-64 per cent-amongst those who sero converted to HIV of those having gonorrhoea. There was a higher percentage of those having rectal gonorrhoea. The figure came out at 28 per cent on average. There was even a higher percentage of those showing perianal bleeding during the previous six months. That figure came out at 31 per cent.

In another table in that particular article the authors showed that those who had not indulged in receptive anal intercourse for six months before testing numbered 984 and only nine of those sero converted. That is 0.9 per cent; less than one per cent. In other words, it is rare for anyone to sero convert to HIV if they have not been indulging in this practice for the previous six months. In fact, of those nine, six had been indulging in receptive anal intercourse in the six months before that. There was a steady increase in the percentages of those converting to HIV which rose with the number of partners they had been with. In fact, of those who had more than five partners in the previous six months-that particular group numbered 220 people-30 tested positive. That is 13.6 per cent. So, there is a very strong correlation, which cannot be denied, between receptive anal intercourse and those sero testing positive for HIV and also between the number of partners they have had and those sero testing positive.

On this last point, the Government has been diligent and has put that out in the literature. I commend it for that. I would hope that it would extend that to those other figures. As we know, of those who test positive for HIV, about 35 per cent-the figures vary-will probably go on, in a seven to 10-year incubation period, to test positive for acquired immune deficiency syndrome. Of those, so far, 100 per cent will die, which is very sad.

I believe that this information has to be spread not only about the number of partners-which the Government has done-but also about the types of practices homosexuals indulge in, so that these people can have stressed to them the risks that they are taking. We should tell them about the need to abstain from anal intercourse, particularly receptive anal intercourse.

The Government's solution to date has been centred around giving the impression that we are all equally at risk. We are all at risk, but not equally. The Government is exhorting people, instead, to use condoms. It has done nothing about changing or attempting to change the lifestyle patterns of the group most at risk in the community. The pamphlet put out by the National Advisory Committee on AIDS asks: `How can I catch AIDS?'. The answer is, `By having unsafe sex. Unsafe sex is having more than one sexual partner and not using condoms'. There is no mention of anal intercourse. The pamphlet asks: `What is safe sex?'. It replies, `Safe sex is having sex with someone who does not use intravenous drugs and share needles and does not have another sex partner'. Again, there is no mention of the crucial factor by which the disease is transmitted.

In many ways Australia has gone condom culture mad. We are advertising condoms on the sides of buses and in pamphlets, some of which are quite inane and offensive. Some pamphlets, such as those put out by the New South Wales AIDS Council, could only be described as pornographic. I have those pamphlets here if honourable members want to look at them. There is no need for this. I believe that we are attacking the AIDS problem at the wrong end. I say that in all sincerity. To recommend condoms only is wrong. That should be a recommendation of last resort. If we look at the figures in Choice magazine of January 1989, we see that, of the 7,000 condoms tested to bursting point, less than 200 failed, just under 3 per cent. But perhaps under anal intercourse conditions a more traumatic stress would be put on condoms. In some tests-not all-up to 10 per cent of females have become pregnant while using condoms, even though females can become pregnant on only four or five days out of an average 28-day cycle. The percentage of homosexuals who use condoms for anal sex who get AIDS could be much higher.

It is irresponsible of the Government to put so much emphasis on the use of condoms and not mention the dangers of anal sex, particularly receptive anal sex. People are losing their lives because of the Government's program. We have known the facts for a long time. Many tests have been done. The Government is not telling the people the truth. Why are people not being told the facts? Almost no effort is being made to change these people's lifestyles. The Australian National Council on AIDS and the National AIDS Forum seem to be stacked-if one looks through the list-with homosexuals who have a predilection not to convey the correct information. I do not blame all homosexuals, but homosexuals who have this fixed idea seem to be members of these bodies. Even many of the members who are not homosexuals seem to want to be mouthpieces for the line that is being run. I hasten to add that there are some excellent people, too, on this Council and Forum.

There seems to be a rush in this country to demedicalise this disease, to save the homosexual lobby from embarrassment and blame, to ensure that homosexuals do not have to change their lifestyles. The experts, the medical people, who want to treat this disease properly and inform the Australian people correctly, in a scientific way, are constantly being overruled. Why is the Government doing this? Why is the Minister doing this? Why would he want to do it? Why is he so sympathetic to the homosexual lobby? Why is he stacking these committees and his advisers, rather than giving out the proper information that I believe the Australian people should be hearing? People are asking what the Government's motive is for doing this when the evidence is overwhelmingly to the contrary of the line the Government is taking. There have even been suggestions that the Government, through the Minister, has moved to suppress stories in the newspapers. I hope that that is not true.

I invite the Minister to explain why the proper AIDS information is not coming through and why there is a cover-up and to refute the claim that he is trying to do this. Until this is done, nobody in this country can have full confidence in the Government's AIDS education program which is so vital to the containment of this disease in Australia today.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?
—I second the motion and in the spirit of this debate reserve my right to speak later.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charlesworth Dr R.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where does one begin after the speech we have just heard? The honourable member for Parkes (Mr Cobb) has moved:

SPEECH.PARA: That the present Government's program to educate the Australian population with regard to AIDS should be redirected more towards preventing the disease through changing lifestyle patterns of risk groups in the community.

I would have thought that was exactly what the Government was trying to do. So many suggestions made by the honourable member opposite were fallacious that I must ask, as I have done: Where does one begin? Let us consider where the disease started, Africa. In Africa it is principally a heterosexual disease, not a homosexual disease. It has come to the Western world as a homosexual disease, but we need to consider that the great risk to the vast majority of Australians, who are heterosexual, as the honourable member so rightly pointed out, is that it can become a heterosexual disease in Australia. The Government needs to consider earnestly its campaign against this disease-this disease for which we only have prevention; we have no cure at this stage-and the way in which that campaign is initiated and developed.

It is also important for us to recognise when we are considering diagnosed cases of AIDS, not people who are HIV-positive, that the figures cited by the honourable member opposite reflect the state of play some years ago. The recent trend has been a significant improvement in the figures for homosexuals compared with other groups in the community. I will quote scientific research and evidence to substantiate that.

One needs to look at what the Government has done. Three objectives are outlined in the Government's Green Paper AIDS: A Time to Care, a Time to Act. The objectives are, firstly, to minimise the transmission of the virus and, secondly, to support, care and treat people infected by the virus. I do not think the honourable member would disagree with that objective; he nods his head. The third objective is to educate and prevent the infection of people who care for HIV-infected individuals. Again, I think the honourable member opposite would agree with that. The objectives are clear. The Government's direction is clear. If we look at the guiding principles we find, under `Education': `Education measures and prevention programs can bring about behavioural change and minimise transmission'. That is what we are trying to do. To suggest that that should be the full direction of the Government's course of action is a nonsense.

We have tried, and we continue to try, to change people's habits in respect of smoking and alcohol use, but it is a difficult thing to do and it takes time. During that time we have to make sure that the rest of the population are adequately informed so that they do not get involved in high risk behaviour which could lead to the transmission of the disease throughout the rest of the community. I do not like to say `the rest of the community' because we are all part of one community in Australia. In a sense it is everybody's problem and it should be everybody's problem. The alcoholic who is treated in hospital receives the benefit of my taxes, although I may not be an alcoholic or wish to be. We should apply the same standards to someone who suffers from HIV infection, or from any medical condition.

Under the Government's program in 1988-89, $11.6m was directed towards community organisations and State and Territory governments on a dollar for dollar basis, including a substantial media campaign. The basis of that campaign is to educate the public so that people understand the problem and the mode of transmission and are able to make an informed choice about their behaviour. There are limited resources for such a campaign. We understand that. So the campaign and the money behind it are specifically directed to high risk groups-the gay community, the bisexual community and intravenous drug users. I accept the information the honourable member opposite has given us. We need to understand that the best way to get to those groups is through community development programs and there is a need for money to be directed there. That has been done and the results are quite pleasing. There has been a significant improvement in the behavioural change amongst those high risk groups.

My concern, and the concern of many of us on this side of the House, is that there can be a spreading of this disease into other groups in the community whose behaviour is considered less high risk. It is particularly of concern that we have an all-round program-indeed a mosaic-in our response to the AIDS problem and to HIV infection. That is what this Government is trying to do. The suggestion by the honourable member for Parkes that the direction of our campaign is unscientific and that there is some sort of a cover-up is absolute nonsense. I sit on a liaison group for AIDS within this Parliament. Members of both sides of the House are members of that liaison group. We discuss the information openly. Generally in most areas there is a bipartisan view, but what do we find today? We find the honourable member for Parkes, the civil libertarian, saying, `It is okay, we won't have the Australia Card because that will allow the tax avoider, the social security defrauder or the illegal immigrant to get around and do his best. But God forbid what people might want to do in their personal behaviour in the intimacy of their own home, or whatever. The Government should, in some way, control that'.

The honourable member opposite had a particular interest in unprotected anal intercourse. In Sydney and Melbourne there has been a significant reduction in that activity amongst gay and bisexual men. Data from the social aspects of prevention of AIDS, study A, show that more than half the men interviewed had reduced their number of sexual partners and sexual contacts and a significant shift was reported towards sexual practices which were promoted as safe. The Sydney AIDS project study of 1,000 homosexual and bisexual men has revealed that the rate of new infections in men in this group has decreased since 1985 from 4 per cent to one per cent. There has been a significant change in the behaviour of the high risk group as a result of our policies and the emphasis that has been given to those groups. The honourable member is saying that we should direct it even more towards them. I am saying that the great concern amongst us is that there is a spillage occurring now and there needs to be amongst the general population, as there always needed to be, a better and greater understanding. I suppose the honourable member would say that the community does not want that.

Let us look closely at the NACAIDS study which was commissioned by the Department of Health at the beginning of this proposal. When presented with a problem the first thing that has to be done is that it has to be defined. This study was undertaken with a view to defining what the community's views were. The question was asked as to whether or not people thought it was a good idea that the Government should be involved in a massive educational program. Ninety-nine per cent of the people-we never get 99 per cent in any survey-said that it was a good idea; 97 per cent said it should be aimed at everyone. Ninety-seven per cent of the people said, `We want a program that is aimed at everyone. We want more information; we want to know'. The honourable member for Parkes is suggesting that we should all hide and deny that the problem exists. It is not our problem, it is the problem of those dirty people. When we talk about drug abuse in this country we talk about people whom we do not like using drugs we do not use.

The same thing applies to this problem. It is not right. Ninety-seven per cent of Australians thought that it should be aimed at everybody. Eighty-six per cent had no objection to explicit advertising and the programs, the promotion of the use of condoms and the sorts of things that the honourable member is objecting to. Eighty-four per cent thought that increased sex education for children would help contain the spread of AIDS. These are children in every classroom in Australia, not just those we could perhaps identify who may become deviant or what the honourable member would call deviant. God knows how we are going to identify them. Eighty-four per cent of Australians thought that there should be sex education in our schools and 93 per cent had no objection to including AIDS prevention education in the school curriculum. Maybe it is different in the electorate of Parkes, maybe there is some sort of fascination with sheep, but certainly that is not the case for the vast majority of Australians who take a different view. If we look at further research, it is very interesting to note that there has been a marked increase in condom use and a sharp decline in sexually transmitted diseases and gonorrhoea amongst female prostitutes. This is another high risk group in the community.

The direction of our campaign towards the broader community, with particular emphasis on some of the high risk groups, has been successful and it is increasingly being shown to be successful. I think that we are seeing behavioural change. As I mentioned earlier, it is not an easy thing to introduce. We have tried it in respect of many other health campaigns. It takes time. The most important aspect is that those groups are not alienated and the suggestion that we should be alienating homosexuals is absurd, it is counterproductive and it will not work. But honourable members do not have to take my word for it. Let us look at a leading article in the Medical Journal of Australia of 3 April 1989, which is pretty contemporary. It is not written by someone who is a captive of the gay lobby. Anthony Pinching, Senior Lecturer in Clinical Immunology at St Mary's Hospital Medical School in London, states:

Measures must be taken to outlaw and to prevent discrimination which, quite apart form its personal impact, serves as one of the greatest threats to public health by alienating the very persons whose help is needed to contain the spread of HIV.

He also suggests that one of the problems in low incidence areas-areas where there is a low incidence of AIDS-is that in actual fact the denial that occurs in those places puts back the cause of spreading information amongst the general population as to the nature of this problem, the nature of the transmission, and the best way we should deal with it.

An article appeared yesterday in the West Australian newspaper. A report on AIDS cases in Western Australia showed that there has been a 22 per cent fall between 1984 and 1987. It is interesting to note that the suggestion was that the fall in the number of cases of AIDS being diagnosed-that is the AIDS syndrome being diagnosed, that is not HIV positive infected people-is probably as a result of the fact that these people are caring for themselves better as a result of the education program that has been undertaken. But the very concerning evidence, the matter that concerns me most, is that the study found that women made up 7.5 per cent of reported cases in 1987 and heterosexuals made up 5.4 per cent. In 1984 no cases in either group were reported. We find that there has been an increase amongst women and amongst heterosexuals.

One does not have to be top of the class to realise that what is happening overseas is perhaps five years ahead of what we are seeing in this country, and certainly the things we are seeing in New York. We are finding that 30 per cent of those people presenting with HIV positive infections are intravenous drug users and not homosexuals, and the majority are heterosexual. So the concern clearly is that the disease can infiltrate-if I can use that word-but it is something for the whole community to be concerned about. Clearly we need to care about those people who suffer from the disease and there needs to be constant and vigilant attention paid to that aspect of dealing with this disease. We need to care for those people. We need to be careful about those who care for those who suffer and the prevention methods; we need to look at the law which discriminates in some areas against our preventing transmission; we need to look at the law as it relates to prisons; and we need to look at the law as it relates to intravenous drug use. But, more important than that, people need to know and to be armed with the information so that they can best decide on the sorts of behaviour and patterns of action that they will take. The suggestion that we should all forget about it because we are not affected, we are above it, and we are in some way superior because of our behavioural patterns is a nonsense. It is hypocritical, inaccurate and creates more of a problem than it supposedly solves. Finally, I will quote once again the leading article in the Medical Journal of Australia. Dr Pinching states:

The initial social responses to AIDS were characterized by an enhancement of the divisions within communities and an increased alienation of the groups that already were regarded as being separate from the mainstream of society. Concepts of national or regional boundaries were reinforced. Individuals looked inwards and talked of `them' and `us'. Attitudes and approaches were painfully parochial.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired. The time allotted for this debate has also expired. The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Taxation: Pony Clubs-Occupational Health and Safety: Sheltered Workshops-Middle Income Australians-Mrs Pauline Toner-Mrs Margaret Brown-Nyngan Floods: Parkes Electorate-Homeless Youth-Social Security Payments-South Australia: Clean-up Campaign

PROCTEXT.PARA: Question proposed:
That grievances be noted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McArthur Mr F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I rise today to debate the genuine grievance felt by all pony clubs throughout Australia due to an anomaly in the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936, as amended. Over the past six months my office has been inundated with petitions from pony clubs right around Australia from as far afield as Roebourne and Bunbury in Western Australia, Devonport in Tasmania, Mount Gambier in South Australia, to the far north of Queensland and the Northern Territory, not to mention those pony clubs of Camperdown, Drysdale and Darlington, to name a few, which are within my own electorate. The depth of feeling on this issue is surprisingly widespread and intense; the reason being that currently some 33,000 children and their parents are being discriminated against by virtue of an outdated distinction in the Income Tax Assessment Act. The distinction, which relates to the difference between human and animal sports, originated in 1917 when the then State Premiers, seeking funds to finance their war effort, requested the Treasurer to assist them to end the regime of undesirable galloping, greyhound and trotting proprietary clubs. As a result, all clubs, whether non-profit or proprietary, were subject to tax.

SPEECH.PARA: The application of the principle of mutuality, which applies in the case of pony clubs, recognises that a person's income consists only of moneys derived from sources outside himself. Accordingly, subscriptions, contributions and other receipts from members of the clubs are excluded from the assessable income of each club. However, income from outside investments such as bank account interest, donations from non-members, dividends and shares, et cetera, is assessable. This, in effect, constitutes the present grievance of the Pony Club Association of Australia and its constituent clubs. It will be shown later that the income from such investments is so minimal that it is worth 10 times as much to the individual pony clubs which operate on minimal budgets as it is to the Federal Government.

The present section 23 (g) dealing with the exemptions under the Act was introduced in 1952 following a recommendation from the Spooner Committee. This effectively established the distinction between human and animal sports on the one hand, and sports where human beings are participants on the other-a distinction which has continued since that date despite the rationale for the difference having disappeared long since. A report of the Taxation Review Committee-the Asprey Committee of January 1975-pointed to the difficulty of categorising sports to determine whether or not they come within section 23 (g) of the Act and made the following comment:

In any case, all sports provide recreation to participants and spectators, and it has become difficult to draw any distinction, on the basis of degree of commercial activity involved, between the sports in which human beings are the sole participants and other sports . . . The Committee sees some force in the arguments which would support an extension of the exemption of sporting clubs and associations. But it would take the view that questions as to what societies and/or associations should be exempt are matters of government policy.
Accordingly, I ask the House to record this grievance and the following arguments I raise on behalf of the pony clubs throughout Australia.

If the assumption is made that for every child affected that child's parents are similarly affected, we are talking about some 100,000 people throughout Australia, excluding all those involved in the administration of the pony club movement. The simple fact is that these 100,000 people-the children by active participation, the parents by association-are involved in a community service voluntary youth organisation which is healthy, educational, sporting and non-profit making. Membership is restricted to young people under the age of 21 years, but such is the strength and enthusiasm of the movement that many continue their association by assisting the club in administration and/or by instructing young riders.

The inherent worth of the pony club movement to local communities and society in general is illustrated by the aims and objectives of the movement worldwide. Those aims are: to encourage young people to ride and to learn to enjoy all kinds of sports connected with horses; to provide instruction in riding and horsemanship and instil in members the knowledge for the proper care of their animals; to promote the highest ideals of sportsmanship, citizenship and loyalty, thereby cultivating strength of character and self-discipline in members. If one considers the aims and objectives of similar voluntary youth organisations, such as the scouting movement and the Girl Guides Association, it is apparent that the pony club movement is just as character-building and, like the scouting and guiding movements, it teaches those involved to care for and be attuned to the needs of others-be they other persons or the animals they ride.

The social benefit and cost advantages of encouraging young people into sporting activities such as this must also be considered. Compare the cost benefit of providing tax exemptions to this group with the millions of dollars spent each year by the Office of Corrective Services, the judiciary, and all the ancillary services which are used to encourage, deter and discipline Australian youth who have not channelled their energies into productive activities such as sporting youth organisations. I suggest it is difficult to be involved with animals, especially horses, without one's finer sensibilities being affected. This is especially the case with growing children. Encouraged and instructed in the right way, this can only lead to a more caring and compassionate human being which in turn can only benefit society as a whole.

In an increasingly violent world in which child delinquency is daily increasing, associations such as the pony club movement should be receiving as much encouragement as possible from the Government. It is through the promotion and growth of organisations such as the pony club movement that average Australian children will benefit. I stress the term `average' because the majority of those presently involved in the pony club movement come from middle-income families who have sacrificed their own comfort for the ultimate benefit of their children's development. Indeed, there are many children who fund their own membership of local pony clubs. Taxing such associations serves only to alienate the movement from those who struggle to remain active members despite increasing membership fees. I point out that the clubs are self-funding bodies.

The competitive aspect of the pony club movement is perhaps one of its most important qualities. Gymkhanas, showjumping, horse trials and combined training days provide opportunities for members, often from widely separated areas, to interact, compete and achieve distinction for their skills in horse management. It is a measure of the pony clubs associations success that qualifications obtained in this manner are classed more highly in an educational and employment sense than any similar skills obtained from technical and further education throughout Australia. It should be remembered that some of the world's best Olympic riders, such as the Australian Gold medal winning Roycroft family, began their careers in the pony club movement.

The Australian Taxation Office has been unable to estimate the annual revenue from the 209 pony clubs throughout Australia. However, unofficial estimates from the Office put the annual revenue of the combined categories of pony clubs, aero clubs, other clubs in the fields of aerobatic, autocycling, driving, equestrian, carting, motor sports, polocrosse, power boats and rodeos at approximately no more than $100,000. Of this the combined revenue from pony clubs is estimated to be less than a quarter of the total. The current revenue according to the Federal Government is therefore minimal and of little consequence. Informal discussion with the Taxation Office leads me to the conclusion that the taxation of pony clubs, apart from being of little financial value, is furthermore a waste of the Office's time and energy.
In 1985 the exemption section of the Income Tax Assessment Act was amended to include the following clause on behalf of the Victorian Racing Club. Section 23g, subsection 4 reads:
. . . a society, association or club established for the encouragement or promotion of animal races . . .

It seems somewhat inequitable and incongruous that the pony club movement should be unable to receive the benefits of the same exemption when the multimillion dollar racing industry in Australia has enjoyed such benefits since 1 July 1985. I repeat that the pony club movement is a non-profit making association, entirely self-funded, with limited access to capital, and consequently is restricted in its ability to raise funds compared to commercial enterprises. Exemption from Federal income tax, including the related costs of compliance, would provide valuable assistance to enable further development of the movement and would be a significant incentive for membership fees to be kept to a minimum. It would enable the continued involvement of as wide a cross-section of the community as possible in the Australian pony club movement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Darling Mrs E.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, Australians today work in a more aesthetically pleasing environment than was the norm in decades past. As new office blocks, professional offices and factories are designed and erected, consideration is given to such aspects as airconditioning and colour, while even in older buildings staff rooms and facilities are provided to allow workers to break away from the work routine. Although there are very bad patches in the field of occupational health and safety-and this is the case in some areas in Queensland-many employers are now considering these measures. In most States there is legislative backing. Regrettably this is not so in the case of some sheltered workshops for disabled people.

SPEECH.PARA: Over 11,000 Australians with a disability attend sheltered workshops, the majority of whom have mild or moderate intellectual disabilities. There are 313 sheltered workshops funded through the Federal Government's disability services program. Funding is paid to organisations to provide and oversee the workshops. In 1987-88 Queensland was allocated a total of $19,415m for activities under the Federal disabilities services program (DSP). Of this, some $7.470m was provided to the Endeavour Foundation, which is the largest provider of services funded under the DSP in Queensland, accounting for 45 per cent of such services. These services include 24 sheltered workshops and 24 activity therapy centres. The majority of the workshops may enjoy excellent conditions. I know of some which have a reputation for being well run. Some, however, are causing me, and others closely connected with their operation, grave disquiet.

Sheltered workshops were introduced in 1969 and were expected to provide training for employees to enter competitive employment and long term supported employment, with reasonable rates for employees not likely to succeed in competitive employment. Many disabled people have found the opportunity to work on jobs such as the assembly of small parts far preferable to unemployment and undoubtedly they enjoy the contact with work mates. Carers have also been freer to pursue personal activities. But there is widespread feeling that much more could and should be done to meet the original objectives of the workshops. There has been extensive criticism of the unchallenging and inappropriate nature of the work, the low level of wages paid, poor conditions and lack of access to work opportunities, particularly competitive employment. People with disabilities in sheltered workshops receive from the Department of Social Security a sheltered employment allowance which is paid at the same rate as the invalid pension. They then receive earnings for their 35 hours work.

Data from the Department of Community Services and Health disability census in 1986, which surveyed service providers, indicates that in 1986 the average wage of sheltered workshop employees was $27.35 per week. Social security data indicates that it was $22.41 per week at 1 April 1988. But I am informed that in the Northgate workshop within my electorate disabled people working 35 hours a week were receiving $4, which has now been raised to $8 per week. While disabled people are receiving such a pittance for 35 hours work, a blot exists on Australian society. This takes away a person's dignity. Some disabled people would wish for calm repetitive work, using only their hands, and they should be able to choose this. Others need more stimulation to bring their potential up to optimum and thus lead a satisfying life. No-one should be required to change. But my information suggests that there are many who would welcome the change and who feel locked away from society in appalling conditions.

At the Northgate sheltered workshop run by the Endeavour Foundation, it was discovered some months ago that the disease hepatitis B was present among workers and staff. Staff members advised the management of the presence of the disease and informed them that at least three of the disabled workers were carriers of the virus. Staff at the workshop made repeated requests for vaccination serum to stop further contraction, but after five months no action was taken and it was only after staff met with the Miscellaneous Workers Union that serum was provided. There is a cost factor involved, but so are people's lives.

Following a meeting with representatives of the foundation, workshop staff, union officials and officials of the Department of Community Services and Health which funds the Foundation, I was reassured that steps would be taken to rectify this situation. I was left with the impression that decisive action would be taken. I was therefore very disturbed when I realised a week later that the management did not intend to offer a screening process to the clientele to see if any others were unfortunate enough to have the disease. A brief note was sent to parents or guardians of the workers, providing brief information on what they or their parents could do to safeguard their own health. This is not the action I expected of people who hold the privilege and special positions of trust as providers of services aimed to assist disabled people. I felt seriously let down. Surely personal interviews should be held to outline clearly the risk of hepatitis B and the people should be covered.

I want to outline other serious allegations made to me, clearly and concisely, because people who are already coping with a dis- ability and those providers who are doing the right thing need all of the support that they can get. I will not quote names as I wish to protect the privacy of identities, but each allegation has been put to me directly by the disabled people affected, by parents and by workers; and they are very anxious that these matters be looked into.

Following the hepatitis B situation which I have outlined, I arranged to meet with parents and staff workers from Northgate Sheltered Workshop on 20 April. I have been informed that parents would like to speak to me alone. Staff have informed me that some parents are frightened to speak out in the presence of Endeavour Foundation administration because of a past incident of victimisation of handicapped workers who in any way criticised the administration. This no longer happens but evidently older people cannot get over the fear that it will happen. Others are afraid that they may be considered disloyal or they may feel grateful for what has been done for them but they have concerns which they want to convey to me privately. It is surely the right of these people to express opinions outside the hearing of Endeavour administration. However, I have been informed by the State manager that parents cannot speak to me at that meeting without his being present. I have further been informed by staff that an emergency meeting has been called by members of the State administration to speak with some parents before they meet with me. Another authoritative source has confirmed that people with concerns are afraid to make them public and in the past any attempt at criticism has been met with charges of disloyalty to the organisation.

There are other serious concerns regarding human rights of people working at sheltered workshops and I regret that I will not be able to outline them all. One man, Mr A, was admitted to Endeavour Workshops suffering from severe epilepsy. His intelligence is at normal level. He was grateful he was allowed to go into the workshop as it was the only place he could go at the time. However, after working at two sheltered workshops his skills reached too high a level to continue and he was employed as an assistant supervisor for $40 per week at a sheltered workshop in Brisbane. He ran three packaging benches and did all the jobs done by the supervisor who was on full pay. During this time he continuously applied for a supervisor's job but on each occasion someone else got the job regardless of the fact that Mr A successfully was undertaking full duties at cut rates. Mr Deputy Speaker, I ask permission to incorporate in Hansard a breakdown of figures showing the amount paid to disabled people in workshops State by State.
