TALK.START.PARA: —Mr A is distressed that he was continually passed over and asks why he was not considered for the job. Three people were employed in positions for which he applied while he was working there full time for $40 a week. Eventually he left the workshop and is now employed full time in private enterprise. The discrimination shown here is entirely unacceptable from a Commonwealth funded provider of handicapped services or in fact any provider of handicapped services. There is a moral responsibility involved which has been breached.

SPEECH.PARA: Another serious matter is that of alleged breaching of confidentiality of Mr A's health file with Endeavour. He told me today that he and his wife had applied to Endeavour Foundation some weeks ago to be given access to their own file. This application was refused on the basis that it would breach confidentiality. Yet a couple of weeks after the person concerned was refused his own file, statements were made in a Brisbane newspaper quoting a State member of the Legislative Assembly who gave information about Mr A which he believes could have come only from his Endeavour file. He claims she did not know him and as far as he is concerned there is nowhere else she could have got the information she used except from his file. I will be taking this matter up with Mrs Berys Nelson.

Mr Deputy Speaker, I do not have time to outline all the matters of concern. I do have time to say I am deeply concerned at the implications of the stories told to me. People have sought me out only after hearing of my interest in the hepatitis B issue in order to give me details of what can only be described as abuse of trust. I did not come to this public forum as a first means of attacking these problems. I contacted the Endeavour administration, Department of Community Services and Health staff and, most importantly, the disabled people themselves. It would appear, however, that my attempts to speak in good faith and away from the public gaze with the disabled people and parents who wished to speak to me have not been appreciated; but rather they have been abused.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macphee The Hon I.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, my grievance relates to the Hawke Government's neglect of middle Australia. I refer particularly to the tax burden which wage and salary earners are shouldering. Many commentators have demonstrated beyond question that this tax burden is an unprecedented one and yet one of which the Treasury itself warned the Government in preparing documents for the famous tax summit of 1985 which, as we know, was not just a political disaster but a great disaster for all pay as you earn taxpayers. I refer particularly to excellent articles by Mr Daryl Dixon, in particular those that appeared in the Sydney Morning Herald on 13 and 14 February, in which he has shown that the Government has failed to heed all the warnings of its own Treasury for four years. We have a situation now, Mr Deputy Speaker, where we are moving towards an extremely unequal Australia-an Australia in which restraint with equity to which the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has referred has produced restraint but great inequity.

SPEECH.PARA: Official figures show that income distribution is now less equitable than when the Hawke Government first won office in 1983. The top 10 per cent of income earners now receive 28.4 per cent of all income in Australia while middle income earners have gone backwards. An extra 700,000 Australians have slipped below the poverty line since 1983 and today 2.6 million people, one in every eight households, live in poverty. Also, 440,000 children are being raised in these conditions and are being denied a fair start in life. More than 60,000 people live on the verge of homelessness and 40,000 sleep in refuges, in emergency accommodation or in the open. The Australian expectation of a roof over one's head has slipped beyond reach for 100,000 people. The number of people on public housing waiting lists has gone up by 50 per cent since the Australian Labor Party took office in 1983 to 160,000 people. Australia now has a permanent underclass of nearly 600,000 unemployed people of whom 100,000 are teenagers seeking full time employment. We know also that the suicide rate amongst teenagers has risen dramatically over that period and, of course, the two are related.

Next Wednesday night the Treasurer (Mr Keating) will be presenting his economic statement on the taxation situation. Tax cuts are promised and tax cuts are certainly needed to favour middle and low income earners. It is the middle income group, particularly those on fixed incomes, such as pensioners and those on low incomes, salaries and wages, who have had to bear the restraint which has been imposed as living costs have soared. The majority of Australians have had declining living standards but, of course, some have been doing very well indeed. I do not begrudge executives being paid what they are worth or what the marketplace gets for them, but there is no doubt that executive salaries have risen at a time when other wages and incomes have been reduced in real value and considerable inequities arise because of that. Moreover, it is those people with those high incomes who are importing the luxury goods which are helping to aggravate our balance of payments situation.

It is also good to see that company profits have risen. Net profits are, in fact, up 37 per cent in the first half of this year, but it is disturbing in the extreme to see that some of those companies have made that profit at the expense of their obligations to pay their tax as corporate citizens of this country. If the tax system is such that it is forcing them in the interests of their shareholders to go to tax havens, then the tax system has to be changed, but the companies themselves are letting Australia down by using tax havens and the Government is letting Australia down by not shutting off the access to the tax havens as, indeed, it has promised to do.

A great deal of brain power, as the Commissioner of Taxation himself has warned, has been spent trying to detect people who are going to tax havens. The Government has loved making reforms to the taxation system by press release; by announcing that as of the date of a press release a certain practice would be eliminated and would be the subject of legislation later. That is not retrospective legislation when warning is given of an operative date of legislation. It does not matter how late the legislation is, that legislation is operative from the date of the press release. The Treasurer has not done that in respect of tax havens and that is a great indictment of this Government as many of its corporate friends, such as the Bond Corporation, continue to avoid their obligations as taxpayers and we-the rest of the Australian taxpaying community-pay for that. The Government has made no effort whatever to cut off that abuse of our laws. It appears that the Government has known for at least four years the extent of tax sheltering activities; yet no legislation has been introduced and apparently no legislation is contemplated, at least to be operative, before the 1990s.

Our Treasurer is always talking to us about the `big picture'. In painting that big picture, he has forgotten the little people and has associated and identified himself too much with some of those high-flying business people who have used their income from tax shelters to buy up productive and effective Australian companies, taking them into tax shelters again to make more money to buy up more companies and thus to avoid their corporate tax responsibilities. In doing so they impose more tax burden upon us. Indeed, it is interesting to read the Prime Minister's maiden speech on 26 November 1980 when he had this to say:

The highly privileged have been allowed further to enhance their privilege by escaping their obligation under the law to pay tax while the relative tax burden has been remorselessly increased upon members of the middle and low income groups who have little opportunity to evade their obligations . . . It will be precisely those who avoid the law to their own great financial advantage who will be loudest in their condemnation of these wage and salary earners . . .

Those words have never been more true than they are now under the Hawke Government. Some of its corporate friends have done exceedingly well under the Hawke Government at the cost of the electors of Wills and other people whom the Labor Party claims to represent.

The Prime Minister's election pledge to eliminate child poverty is coming under increasing scrutiny and it is clear from the figures I quoted that child poverty has increased. If one looks at the statistical evidence, one finds that more than 70 per cent of total tax collections come from taxpayers with incomes of less than $45,000 a year. Again, Daryl Dixon points out that the only lasting beneficiaries of the tax cuts have been the highest and some of the lowest income groups, the latter benefiting from the family package. Some of the lowest income groups at least have been relieved of some of their burden, but it is the middle income earners overwhelmingly who have suffered. In fact there has been an effective increase of 10 per cent in the total personal income burden for middle income brackets.

Now we have the crisis in the housing industry. We have the crisis for first home owners in particular. The famous housing summit did nothing to relieve that situation. I commend to the Government an article by Ken Davidson in the Age of 23 February in which he thoughtfully outlines alternatives to several aspects of the Government's policies. In particular, he outlines ways in which we could encourage people to direct their investments into the more productive areas that we need to increase the infrastructure of this country, to increase its productivity and profitability so that we can employ more people and export more goods and services and, at the same time, ensure that those who save do so in ways which are beneficial to the economy.

I strongly commend the Government to do a rethink. It is increasingly tired; it is increasingly ineffective. We will be watching next Wednesday's statement with great interest to try to make sure that we get restraint with equity instead of a situation in which those who have suffered for so long lose their real disposable income and find that, wherever they turn, life becomes harder for them by becoming better for others.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleeland Mr P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —On Friday, 3 March of this year, my friend and colleague Pauline Toner died after a long battle with cancer. She had been the State member for Greensborough since 1977. Pauline was only the second woman member of the Australian Labor Party (ALP) to win a seat in the Victorian Parliament. Before entering Parliament she was the first woman councillor in the Shire of Diamond Valley and the first woman Shire President of Diamond Valley.

SPEECH.PARA: I first met Pauline on the occasion of her success in the 1977 by-election following the death of Monty Vale, who was the then Liberal Party member for the State seat. I took her place on the Diamond Valley Shire Council and followed her as Shire President and ultimately into politics. In 1979 Pauline became the first woman ever to sit on the Victorian parliamentary front bench and in 1982 the first woman Cabinet member in Victoria's history. She held the portfolio of Minister for Community Welfare Services from April 1982 until April 1985. A member of the Australian Labor Party since 1968, Pauline was the current Senior Vice-President of the Victorian Branch of the Australian Labor Party, as well as being a Federal and State conference delegate.

Pauline had five children in seven years and had studied for Bachelor of Arts and Bachelor of Education degrees while she brought up a young family with her husband Brian. Born in Horsham in 1935, Pauline will be sadly missed by her family and friends and within the ALP and her local community. She was a most unique woman. She was always a feminist, but a feminist who never once mentioned the word `feminism' in regard to herself or her own activities in politics. She was first and foremost a friend and a colleague. There are many members of the Australian Labor Party today who owe a great deal to Pauline. She was only a young woman-only 53-when she died, but her value and the reason why people such as I will always remember Pauline and she will always be a part of my life was that she brought people into politics, she educated people about politics and she left a succession in politics that will remain long after she has gone.

The by-election campaign in the State seat is currently on. It is a by-election which the Australian Labor Party is going to win. The seat is held only at 56-odd per cent in two party preferred terms and one would have thought, quite frankly, that, with the Victorian Economic Development Commission and other current critical issues running in Victorian politics, the Victorian Liberal Party would have a fair show of winning such an electorate in a by-election. It is a fairly unique area of Australia. It contains probably the highest number of tertiary qualified people of any electorate in Australia. It is an electorate of high family incomes and high car ownership and a very thoughtful electorate.

But the Australian Labor Party is going to win the by-election because of the legacy of Pauline. The work she did in the area, both as a councillor and as a State member of parliament and, more importantly, as a member of the general community, is reflected in the fact that people will continue to support her successor, who is Sherryl Garbutt. Sherryl in fact worked for Pauline for seven years as her electoral secretary and knows the electorate probably as well as, or better than, Pauline did, being in the office perhaps more often than Pauline was, with her parliamentary commitments. So Pauline's work will not go unremembered and the local electorate well understand that a vote for Sherryl Garbutt is a vote for the continuance of the work that Pauline did. Sherryl is an extremely well-known person.

One must contrast the Australian Labor Party approach in the area and the Australian Labor Party campaign for the by-election with the ineptitude of the Liberal Party in Victoria. It really seems to learn nothing. Of course, the candidate that the Liberal Party in Victoria has selected is Mrs Neil Brown. Perhaps the fact that it has chosen that lady is one of the reasons why it is going to be defeated in the by-election. The reality, of course, is that Margaret Brown was not chosen by the local Liberal Party branches; in fact, Margaret Brown was chosen by Jeff Kennett and the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock). She was deliberately picked and chosen despite the wishes of the local Liberal branches.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish! She went before a selection committee just like anyone else.

—Members of the Opposition say, `Rubbish, rubbish!'. Let me give them a few facts on what is occurring in an area they know nothing about. The Liberal Party candidate in the State elections in September of last year is a councillor in the Shire of Eltham, Councillor Bob Manuel. Councillor Manuel owns several real estate properties in the area, and honourable members might be surprised to learn that on one of those properties owned by the Manuel family there sits today a very large street sign calling on people to vote for Sherryl Garbutt, the ALP candidate. That is what the local Liberal Party branches think of Jeff Kennett and the honourable member for Kooyong's imposition of the candidate upon them.

SPEECH.PARA: But, even more importantly than that, Mr Tony Kennett, who is no relation to Mr Jeff Kennett, I might add, but is the president of the local Liberal Party branch, has resigned in disgust at the imposition of candidates. The reality is that typically, as Liberal Party people tend to do in campaigns, the first thing they are doing is running `honesty in government'. Let those who are interested in the Liberal Party campaign and the claims of Mrs Brown as to where she stands in local communities read the local newspapers and the hundreds of letters in the local newspapers which have totally refuted the nonsense she ran with-letters written not by the Labor Party, I might add, but by local community groups.

Frankly, I was disgusted, when in a newspaper report I read that Mrs Brown wanted to follow in the footsteps of Mrs Toner. What an insult to the memory of Mrs Toner. Pauline Toner fought against everything that Mrs Brown stands for. Is there any end to the cynicism and the dishonesty of Liberal Party members in a campaign? Is there any end to it when they would even try to use the name of a deceased Labor Party member for the area? Pauline fought vigorously, for her entire life, against everything that Mrs Brown and her fellow silvertails in the Liberal Party represent. She fought against elitism; she fought against vested interests; and she fought against privilege for the few. She was a person of enormous personal integrity and compassion. She had a strong sense of social justice and she fought for her community. Yet the Liberals would use her name.

Mr Kennett bought in. Mr Kennett had the gall to say that in the election last year the people of Greensborough voted for Pauline Toner out of sympathy. Could one believe that any person would say such a thing, when the reality was that very few people realised that three years ago Pauline Toner suffered from breast cancer, had an operation, and was given a total clearance on that illness. In fact, it was only late last year, after the election, that secondary signs of cancer first appeared. Yet Jeff Kennett would stand up and say that the local electorate voted for her in sympathy. It is galling for me as a friend of Pauline Toner's to stand here and listen to the Browns and the Kennetts of the world say such things.

After the 15th, when the Labor Party has won this by-election, it is a test of Jeff Kennett's leadership. He and the honourable member for Kooyong chose the candidate, and when she is beaten Jeff Kennett's leadership is on the line. The local Liberal branches did not want the lady who was imposed upon them as a candidate, and I would like to see what the Liberal Party does after the 15th, after the election, when Labor is returned, and what happens to Jeff Kennett. Even John Howard was told, `Do not come into the by-election campaign'. Howard was told, `Get out'. The Prime Minister is coming next Saturday. We do not hide our leader. We are going to bring him right into the by-election. The Prime Minister will be there next Saturday morning. We will win the election. We will win it proudly in memory of Pauline Toner.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cobb Mr M.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was distressing to sit here and listen to the previous speaker, the honourable member for McEwen (Mr Cleeland), make such a personal attack on Mrs Margaret Brown, who is not able to defend herself in this place. I would just like to convey to him and to the listeners that Mrs Margaret Brown is a woman who is held in very high esteem by at least all those on this side of the House. She is, I think, an ornament to the Liberal Party and I am sure that she will do very well on Saturday.

SPEECH.PARA: Today I wish to speak about the floods in the Nyngan region, which is in my electorate of Parkes. I spoke about this matter and the difficulties people are experiencing the night before last, but I make no apology for raising the topic again because I believe that the plight of these people and their livestock in this region of my electorate needs as much publicity as it can get. The national publicity has been concentrated on the damage done to the eastern coastal areas of Australia and the people of Nyngan are, to some extent, being overlooked. Many properties up there have been affected-about 80 or 100 in all-and about 10 or 20 are in very serious trouble. That may not sound like a great number but I remind honourable members that some of these properties are very large and carry many thousands of sheep. In fact some of the properties up there are bigger than some Federal electorates.

The rain that fell there a few days ago was very unexpected and there was no meteorological reason for it. There was absolutely no warning or precedent for this type of fall. I spoke to one fellow who said he had never seen anything like it, or even half as much, in his whole lifetime. The rain fell in particularly heavy quantities over an area of about 40 to 50 kilometres by 100 kilometres-about 5,000 square kilometres. Up to 16 or 17 inches were just dumped on this very flat country in the Nyngan area-mainly around the north of Nyngan, but stretching up to Coolabah, down into the Warren area and also in the area south of Gongolgon. Gongolgon is a little town south of Brewarrina.

Many stock, particularly sheep, are stranded and have been left standing in water for days. No one seems to know the exact procedures that should be followed. I believe that once this experience is over we need to draw up a natural disaster manual so that all this experience can be tabulated. It should include the experiences that people have had and detail what is needed so that a better program of assistance can be run next time. It should set out what needs to be done, what advice needs to be given and that sort of thing.

Let me outline some of the problems. As I said, we have sheep still standing in water. About 40,000 sheep have been standing in water for five days or more now and one wonders just how long they can survive. We have the problem of how best to shift them. It was thought earlier that army ducks might be the best method, but they need either about five feet of water to stand in or firm ground, so they have not proved to be successful. There has been much discussion as to whether helicopters could lift the sheep out. I know that Chinook helicopters can lift about six tonnes or more and I think that they could be useful, though at this stage the authorities seem to think they will not be suitable. I will return to that point later. At present the sheep are being moved out-up to eight or 10 at a time-in small, flat bottom boats and that is very time consuming. Efforts are also being made to swim some of these sheep out, and honourable members can imagine the difficulties with that. We also have the problem of how best to feed these sheep. At the moment we have an Army Chinook helicopter up there, and I am very grateful to the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) for sending it. It put out 770 bales yesterday afternoon in its first four circuits and another 420 bales are on the way.

There are many problems when sheep stand in water for a long time. One of those is with their feet. After a number of days they become very soft and the hooves will disengage themselves from the coronet and fall off. This is particularly so when they stand in the black soil that is prevalent in that area. If the sheep move, the soil will suck the hooves off them. There are also problems with a few heavily pregnant ewes which have pregnancy toxaemia. This problem has arisen as a result of the particular physiological metabolism of sheep. They have very high demands for fructose late in pregnancy and some of the sheep can become low in glucose which is needed for brain activity and they just go quite silly and die. The main problem, of course, is the weight of the fleece. If the fleece is long and absorbs water some of the sheep will be carrying an extra 20 or 30 pounds of weight and they can only stand up in water so long with that extra weight. They become very tired after a while, they go down in the water and they finally lose the will to live and drown. That is a major consideration.

I have talked to some of those farmers on the telephone and they have described the experience of driving these sheep through the water. They try to use bikes where the water is not too deep and they try to use horses. Much of it has to be done on foot and, of course, one does not have the benefit of sheep dogs, which are so vital in that part of the world. Driving sheep on foot can be quite a procedure. Farmers scatter the sheep, send them off and then get the others to follow them in single file. It may take all day just to move a few sheep a short distance. So those are some of the problems. Of course, from about now on we have the problem of fly strike. In temperatures of 27, 28 or 29 degrees centigrade the fleece is so moist that the flies lay maggots and those maggots will eat the sheep alive within the next day or two in some instances. That is very regrettable. There will be an enormous demand for chemicals such as vetrazin as soon as everything starts drying out. In these cases we need spotting helicopters in order to inform farmers where their sheep are.

I shall read out some of the notes I made of these conversations with farmers. Stuart McAlpine, from Tubba Villa, Coolabah, has 5,500 sheep. All are at high risk and he needs them to be lifted out if possible. Tom Yabsley, of Murrawombie, Coolabah, has had 12 inches of rain and his stock, including his stud bulls, is at risk. However, his situation is not too bad because he has some high land. John Fisher, of Colane, Nyngan, had 14 inches of rain on his property, the most he has seen in his 63 years of life. He is particularly keen to see fodder drops arranged. Lionel Kennedy at Benar, Nyngan, has 5,000 sheep at the point of lambing. He has lost a few hundred and the water is too deep for the sheep to walk in. The only way he can reach them is on horseback but that is very dangerous and slow. The other day he spend five hours rescuing 80 sheep, but what are 80 out of the several thousand? Michael Kennedy at Killarney, Nyngan, has had 16 inches. A drover who was shearing at his place, and who has sheep on the road, has lost hundreds of them. Michael Kennedy has no way to move around his property properly because of the rain. But Richie George at The Corners, Nyngan, has has 15.5 inches. John Modra has lost $5,000 or $6,000 worth of fencing alone and his dams are filled up with silt. He has little or no insurance because it is too prohibitive to take out. He has also highlighted other losses. The list goes on and on.

I praise the community at Nyngan for the work that has been done. Geoff Wise, the district veterinary officer, has worked night and day. David Lister, the chairman of the Pastures Protection Board, John Hoare, the president of the shire council, and all those associated with the shire should be praised for the work that they have done in the general community. The stock and station agents have been on the phone day and night organising matters and helping their clients as much as they can. Last night I spoke to a man called Mac George who told the story of how in the mid-1970s sheep had been in water for two weeks. Their hooves came off and in the end when the farmers tried to move them out of the mud onto higher ground, the sheep ran back again to the soft ground because of the pain of their feet without hooves. They just lost the will to live. They would not even feed and in the end the farmers had to shoot 3,000 sheep. This is the sort of tragedy that will affect these people in the next few days as things dry out a bit. They will be faced with fly strike, sheep losing hooves, sheep bogged in mud and the terrible depression that comes from losing thousands of animals worth $60 or $70 a head. So several tens of thousands of dollars will be lost by most property owners in Nyngan. It is a very tragic situation and I hope the people of Australia will recognise it. I hope that the help that should be given will be given to and alleviate the plight of these people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Johns Mr G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —We move from the question of sheep to another flock in a sense-that is, homeless youth. In my 10 minutes I want to raise some issues relating to income support for homeless youth. This is a very sensitive matter but we need to talk about it. When the Burdekin report of the national inquiry into homeless children by the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission, entitled Our Homeless Children, burst onto the scene there were predictable responses. It was front page news around the country. There were those, of course, who shed crocodile tears and blamed the Government for not carrying out its promise that no child would need to be in poverty by 1990. Then, of course, the issue-at least in the public mind-died, but the work goes on. It is a very serious issue and it is one that we are now addressing and will continue to address.

SPEECH.PARA: The proposition that I put today is that a child who has left home should apply for maintenance from the parents. That is, the family should continue to support the child where possible. There should not be the obvious and total mechanism that once the kid has left home, then he, perforce, or she, perforce, must be looked after solely by the state. That may seem a harsh measure but let us put it into context. We have at present a Family Law Act and a system for the recovery of maintenance through the Child Support Agency. This means that when a family breaks down and there is a divorce in process, or completed, the Family Court can come into play and say that the non-custodial parent, usually the father, will pay $X a week-$30, $40, $50 or $60 a week-to the child who is with the custodial parent, normally the mother.

We ought to apply that same philosophy and probably use the same mechanisms when a child leaves home. When a child runs away from home, we must maintain that signal to the family that, no matter where the child is, it is still the family's responsibility to look after the child. The mechanism we need to use is, again, the Child Support Act and the Family Law Act. I would not raise this sensitive issue if I did not believe that the Commonwealth had a proud record of expenditure and support in the area of youth homelessness. We understand that through the family assistance supplement (FAS) scheme we now make payments to 350,000 young Australians.

I turn to the matter of youth refuges and the housing of these poor kids who find themselves outside a family. When we came to power there were 50 refuges in this country; there are now 500, so no-one could dare suggest that we have not done a great deal to try to solve the problems of youth homelessness. We are now suggesting that we are getting to a far more sophisticated area. I would suggest that next we have to attempt some recovery, some maintenance payment from the parents themselves. The current position with the Family Law Act is that a child does have the right to apply for maintenance from his or her parents, but at the moment on an application through the court, there is a broad discretion. For instance, the making of an application for maintenance by a child will often, in practice, put at issue the custody and guardianship arrangements for a child.

For example, a 17-year-old who refuses to live at home because of the persistent violence of his or her parents might apply for maintenance. In such a case the court could well conclude that the custody of the child should be removed from the parents. The level and type of maintenance to be ordered would depend on the type of custody arrangement ordered. Another example would be where a 12-year-old left home because of a dispute with his or her parents over the parents' refusal to permit the child to smoke. Although the child could apply for maintenance, the court would be likely to do what it could to encourage the child to return home rather than order maintenance.

I am suggesting therefore that the court must eventually turn its mind to allow applications by children against the parents for income support. I know that many of the families from which children have run away do not have a great deal of income. A lot have only a single parent who may be on benefits herself. We are not asking that we draw blood out of a stone, we are simply saying that where there is an ability on the part of a family to pay for that child, then I think we all have the right to ask for income support from that family. We have a system at the moment, with our 500 refuges, whereby a child can run away from home and hopefully find a refuge nearby. I am thinking of the refuge of Tandara in Redcliffe, in my electorate, which does a sterling job. I have spoken to the youth workers there about this concept and they are quite favourable towards it because they are saying so many children, usually aged 15, 14 and even younger, reach them who do not have access to the young homeless allowance, I believe, because they are too young, but they do often get the Jobsearch allowance. If we could, through our youth refuge system, give some support to those people, put them in touch with a social worker at the Legal Aid Commission and then use the Legal Aid Commission to allow them to apply for maintenance through the Family Court or the Magistrates Court, then I believe we could get some money flowing from the families to support these children who for whatever reason, and often I might say for the very worst reasons, have been abused. Money should flow from the family to support those children.

Of course, it is all about signals. The signal is that no matter how dispersed that family is there is ultimately a responsibility on the part of the family to at least keep in touch, even if it does not know the exact address of the child, and to attempt to make some supporting payment. That is the philosophy we have used in family law. We are saying to so many non-custodial parents these days that they must continue to pay maintenance for the children which they have reared. They cannot avoid that, and we will use the tax system and the Child Support Agency in order to ensure that they continue to support their children. I see the situation where a family, a husband and wife, may still be together but where one child has left, as being analogous. I think the family still has to make some effort to support that child. I believe we have mechanisms through the child support agencies and through our refuge system to do that. That would not be easy, administratively it would be difficult. Here, if you like, there may be some trade-off. I believe the Commonwealth can look seriously at ensuring that where children enter a refuge or make application to the Department of Social Security they should be supported quickly. When they make that application for a youth homeless allowance or Jobsearch payment, that payment must be made as quickly as possible. But at the same time perhaps an application can be made for support from the family. We should get into a situation where we try as much as possible to gain some continuing support from the family at the same time using the Commonwealth to support that child. It is a very complex area. It is a very sensitive area. It is one that we all need to think about and to debate at great length.

For instance, my two youth workers at Tandara, Redcliffe tell me that they barely have enough time simply to administer the place where they work. They need two on deck all the time to make sure that the place is not wrecked. We certainly need to support those people a little further so that they can bring further support services to the children-to get them up; to get some social workers in-house and to try to get some family reconciliation which, I understand, does not happen all that often. We simply do not have the numbers of workers to try to reconcile families. That shocks me somewhat. Perhaps we can have a trade-off whereby we increase the means by which we get support from the family but also Commonwealth support to try to reunite families.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Halverson Mr R.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —With Mother's Day just around the corner this grievance debate provides an appropriate opportunity to share with the House the story of a mother living in my electorate of Casey. It is a story about a women's lone and lonely struggle to provide a decent, secure and loving home for her six children, three of whom have had special problems including one with spina bifida and one with Bell's palsy. It is the story of a woman who made a conscious decision to put motherhood first; who decided her primary concern and responsibility were to care for her children and ensure that they had the necessary education, guidance and support to enable them to become responsible and contributing Australian citizens.

SPEECH.PARA: As a result of this decision and despite the fact that she has achieved her objectives in so far as the children are concerned, she is sadly disillusioned as to her perceived worth, both as an individual and as a member of the community. Why? Because an uncaring government, an inflexible bureaucracy, has stripped her of self-esteem and condemned her to live in poverty. Dylan Thomas once observed, `I have achieved poverty with distinction but never poverty with dignity. The best I can manage is dignity with poverty'. My constituent knows what Thomas was talking about. Fourteen years ago she was faced with the daunting prospect of coping alone with all the responsibilities of parenting and providing for her family. At that time her children were aged from 12 to two years. Life has been a continual battle ever since. She has managed to survive, but only just.

Last year, my constituent's total income from all sources was $6,661.20. Her four older children had left the family home and were making their own way in the world. Her two teenage secondary school student daughters, who still resided with her, received a separate income of $3,640, made up of Austudy payments of $2,600 and maintenance payments from their father of $1,040. My constituent has kept meticulous records of their combined household expenditure. Of her $6,661, $4,073 went to pay council and water rates, gas and electricity charges and mortgage repayments. That left her with a balance of almost $50 a week. With this grand sum she had to cover necessary weekly expenses, including the cost of medication not covered by the national health scheme; food and household items; insurance; travel expenses; clothing; repairs to her house and to her household appliances; and other sundries, such as stamps and birthday and Christmas gifts for her children. All of this on less than $50 a week.

Her problems are compounded by the fact that due to a chronic debilitating illness and a serious nervous disorder she is unable to find employment. The option of generating any extra income is simply, and quite genuinely, unavailable to her. She cannot do many of the things that most people take for granted. She cannot afford to visit her mother and family in New South Wales. She cannot afford to visit a hairdresser or buy cosmetics. Outings to the theatre or cinema, or any form of entertainment that is not free, are all in the `not possible' category. She cannot even afford to invite friends to dinner. There is no money available to pay for much needed major repairs to her home: the toilet leaks, the faucets are worn, the shower recess is unusable, the bathroom floor has rotted through, the hot water service has a faulty switch and there are faulty power points which cannot be used. Her oven broke five years ago. The floor coverings and window blinds have worn out. The roof needs major repairs. The quotes for repairs to the bathroom alone exceeded $2,800, more than her entire uncommitted income for the year. She examined the possibility of renegotiating the mortgage on her home to cover the cost of repairs but, with increasing interest rates, the payments were beyond her financial capacity.

Her daughters agreed that from their incomes they would be responsible for paying all their own expenses, including the cost of their own food, school books, uniforms and other educational costs, such as excursions and camps, clothing, footwear, dental expenses, hair care, travel, recreational activities and all the other bits and pieces that are part and parcel of being a normal teenager.

In June last year, my constituent received notice from the Department of Social Security that she was to be deprived of some small pension increases to which she had previously been entitled. The sum involved was something in the order of $4 a week-not a lot for most people but a significant amount to anyone endeavouring to exist on a restricted budget. Why did the Department take this action? Because her former husband pays maintenance for his daughters. After a prolonged and fruitless battle with Social Security she wrote me an impassioned plea for some sympathy and understanding. I would like to read some excerpts from her letter. She wrote:

It was my daughters who received maintenance from their father, not I. But it was taken into account in their income and also in mine by the Department of Social Security, and my pension was effectively reduced as a result.

I did not spend the maintenance money or benefit from it. I just received it on my daughters' behalf. It could only be spent once-and was spent by them. The Department's claim that I received maintenance was totally incorrect. I do not. I have never received maintenance for myself. Never.
Her letter continued:
I helped elect this Government. It was the first time in my life I have ever voted labour-and to my regret.
I did so because Mr Hawke gave me the impression of being a fair and wise counsellor during his years with the unions. I really believed him when he said `a fair go for all Australians'.
I believe that the job I have been doing for the past 27 years is a very important one.
Yes, I'm talking about motherhood, and raising responsible, respectable young adults who are to be the future of our nation.
I didn't choose motherhood, it chose me. Nevertheless, when the responsibility came, I stuck with it.

But Mr Hawke and Mr Keating have underestimated my value far too speedily and easily. Perhaps they think that motherhood has such a lowly connotation in this day and age that it need not be taken seriously.

By depriving me of my pension increases the Government has dealt me a personal body blow from which I may never recover. In effect, the Government is saying to me that I am a person of no account. They have rendered me valueless. They have caused me to become a beggar hidden behind walls in a desperate bid to survive without cheating.

I have tried to get support without resorting to begging. It is so humiliating and dehumanising to be continually pleading one's poverty, to have to depend on others for handouts and charity. I have even tried selling what few valuables we have, but no-one would give me a decent price.
I'm not asking for anything but a `fair go'-not only for myself, but for others in the same situation.
My constituent's predicament, and that of thousands in the same or similar circumstances, is accurately summed up by a line from an editorial in the Sunday Telegraph of 11 December last year:
Both Mr Hawke and Mr Keating have spent too much time on macro and micro economics and paid too little attention to the human effects of their policies.

Had my constituent thrown in the towel and walked away from her family responsibilities, it would have cost the Government literally hundreds of thousands of dollars to provide the necessary care for her children. But she did not do that. And what does the Government do to acknowledge her efforts? Again I quote her own words:
They tell me I am just another casualty, another burden, another number, the least of the least . . . so give her the least . . .
It was John Kennedy who so wisely reflected:
If a free society cannot help the many who are poor, it cannot save the few who are rich.

I am not arguing here against profit or wealth. I am simply asking, as my constituent has asked, for `a fair go', for some recognition of her real worth to the community through her continued dedication and comm- itment to her role as a mother.

She has done an amazing job against enormous odds. Despite the impression she has gained as a result of the insensitive actions of a heartless and unsympathetic Government, I want her to know that her efforts and sacrifices are appreciated by those who believe that the family is still the most important unit in our society and that being a good and responsible parent is an achievement of which she can be unashamedly proud. Although a little early, I would like to wish my consistent a very happy Mothers' Day. She certainly deserves it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bilney Mr G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in this debate to lend what support I can, and what commendation I can, to an operation which will be taking place in Adelaide this coming weekend. It is a joint operation between the Adelaide newspaper The News and KESAB-Keep South Australia Beautiful-in what they call `The clean the scene weekend'. It involves, this Saturday and Sunday, thousands of Adelaide volunteers taking to the streets, the beaches, the parks and the waterways of Adelaide-one of Australia's most beautiful cities and personally, I think, the most beautiful-to keep that State and that city as beautiful as possible.

SPEECH.PARA: What they intend to do is to clean up litter and to improve the quality of our urban environment in Adelaide. My contribution to it will be to volunteer myself, with a number of members of my political party-the Australian Labor Party-to clean up the beaches in my own electorate. I have, as you have, Mr Deputy Speaker, some of the most beautiful beaches in Australia in my electorate of Kingston. We plan to clean up the beach at Port Noarlunga, from the jetty north, to keep it as spectacular and clean as it deserves to be.

I want to give my commendation to the volunteers who are going to be giving up their time for that enterprise in a way which follows on from the campaign which took place in Sydney not so long ago when a number of volunteers collected something like 3,000 tonnes of rubbish from around Sydney Harbour over a weekend. As you will recall, Mr Deputy Speaker, that rubbish varied from the absolutely revolting-drug syringes, condoms and so forth-and the very bulky-car bodies, car engines and so forth-to just a whole lot of the detritus of modern civilisation-plastic wrappings, gladwrap and a great amount of non-biodegradable rubbish, which volunteers were able to collect and to send away. It seems to me that this is the kind of thing that a local newspaper can do very well. I am not always in agreement with the political views of some of the Adelaide newspapers, but certainly the way that the Adelaide News has helped to mobilise community opinion and to organise that `clean the scene' weekend is something that deserves everybody's support. I do encourage anyone who may be listening to this broadcast to get out there on Saturday and Sunday and give an hour or a couple of hours of his time to help to clean up our own environment.

The problem of urban refuse is becoming a genuinely major problem in Australia. In some recent studies in Victoria, for example, it was found that every man, woman and child generates something like 800 kilograms, that is, nearly one ton in the old measure, of garbage every year. That amount is growing. The amount of household garbage being collected in Sydney, for example, is increasing at a rate of about 8 per cent a year. While it is one thing to clean up some of that garbage which is thrown away, and that is certainly a start, what we really need to do is to look to a more permanent future solution by placing a greater emphasis on the recycling of garbage.

In South Australia, the State Government has taken steps which are somewhat in advance of those in the rest of Australia by having container deposit legislation. That legislation was passed in 1975 and amended in 1984. It has resulted in rates of recycling of something like 85 per cent for bottles and 90 per cent for cans. That is well over twice the national average. We can certainly see the results of this if we are driving from, say, Victoria to South Australia. In Victoria, or in New South Wales for that matter, all along the roads we see stubbies and cans. Every 20 feet, 30 feet, or so there is a can or a bottle by the side of the road. When we get over the border into South Australia, where deposit legislation applies, without a word of exaggeration the sides of the road are very clean because kids can get so many cents per can or so many cents per bottle and they collect them and take them back because deposit legislation applies. I do think that the South Australian legislation is something which deserves to be copied by other States because it does lead to a very much cleaner environment than we have in some other States.

In Victoria, even without that sort of legislation, efforts to achieve recycling of paper have resulted in nearly a 50 per cent paper recycling rate. It is stupid to burn paper, for example. It is far better to recycle it. I know that the Victorian Government is hoping to increase its recycling rate to 55 per cent quite soon.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier today I had occasion to criticise the morality of some of our corporate citizens in the way in which they use tax havens to avoid their corporate responsibilities to Australia. I want now to praise Mr Justice Brooking of the Victorian Supreme Court, who recently made a judgment which established a policy for dealing with breaches of commercial morality. I praise him very much for his action. He said that one of the conflicting commercial interests could have access to the books of another but must provide a summary of information so gained to the National Companies and Securities Commission so that the public interest could be examined by that Commission and, as a result of those investigations, charges may be laid. TALK.START.PARA: —Statistics from the Parliamentary Library and also sourced from the December publication of the Australian National Accounts reveal that in the year 1987-88 Australians spent a staggering $20.6 billion on legal gambling. —I ask the Deputy Prime Minister to report to the House on his visit yesterday to the Cyclone Aivu disaster area in northern Queensland. Can the Minister assure the House that the Commonwealth will support fully the disaster relief efforts?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —In company with the honourable member for Herbert, I visited the Aivu disaster area. The area concerned is immediately south of Townsville. I am aware that the honourable member for Dawson is also visiting the area. I did that at the request of the Prime Minister. It should be said at the outset that it is deplorable to see an article in the Sydney Morning Herald suggesting that the Prime Minister's absence was due to some improper conduct on his part. Let me make it very clear that the Prime Minister invited me to go on his behalf because he had an obligation, a commitment, to farewell the Australian armed forces contingent which was setting out on its most important mission to Namibia. It is the largest contingent of Australian soldiers deployed overseas since the Vietnam war. I think everybody would understand the reason why the Prime Minister had that obligation. I know that the Leader of the Opposition also attended.

ANSWER.PARA: The cyclone was one of major force, equivalent to that of Tracy. Fortunately, it crossed the coast just south of Townsville. Had it crossed at Townsville it would have caused massive damage. However, it caused extensive damage to a number of areas such as Ayr, Home Hill, Brandon, Giru, Mingela, Ravenswood and others. The damage was to the sugar crop in particular, but there was also damage to homes and business areas. I pay a tribute to all those who took part immediately in assisting those who have suffered as a result of the damage. There was one fatality but it was due to drowning. It was one that perhaps could have been avoided if the person concerned had availed himself of assistance offered. That is regrettable. However, there were no real casualties and that is very fortunate.

The real issue is that the emergency service personnel were there in time to deal with the issues. The forecasting of the cyclone was very accurate as to its point of entry and, accordingly, the emergency services were well prepared. The Army deserves the highest praise. It has sent 135 soldiers to the area and has done magnificent work. It has worked day and night and has provided no end of assistance to the people concerned. I think some 400 tarpaulins have already been used. We must also praise the emergency services of Queensland and the police in those areas, who have worked incessantly throughout the whole period.

There has been damage to the sugar crop and buildings, but the operation has been handled so efficiently that I would think by this weekend most services will have been restored to normal. There are problems from the point of view of lack of power and lack of adequate refrigeration and electricity. However, I understand that all those will be catered for by next Saturday.

The question usually raised at this time is what the financial commitments of governments will be. State governments have primary responsibility, but it is significant that the Commonwealth government is always able to give, and does, substantial assistance when national disasters take place. In other words, there is a scheme whereby assistance is given by the Commonwealth on a 75 per cent basis when a State reaches a certain level. The State of Queensland has reached that level. As a matter of fact, it appears that Queensland always reaches that level, whether there is a drought or a flood. There are substantial problems in that State from the point of view of droughts, floods, storms and cyclones, and the Commonwealth makes a substantial contribution. I also pay tribute to the Natural Disasters Organisation-Captain MacDonald, who was responsible for coordination-and the emergency services people in Townsville, who organised the whole of the relief program.

Despite the intensity of the cyclone and the problems that might be faced with flooding, a remarkably successful operation was carried out by all concerned-not only by the Army and the Air Force but by all those who participated. So when we talk about monetary assistance from the Commonwealth we should also mention the services made available through service personnel. For the benefit of the House I table a list of the payments made for natural disaster relief. I think the list encompasses Hansard's requirements. Madam Speaker, if you see fit I ask that they be incorporated in Hansard.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: VIETNAM: WITHDRAWAL OF TROOPS FROM CAMBODIA

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. I ask: What is the Government's response to Vietnam's announcement of the withdrawal of its troops from Cambodia by September 1989?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government-as do, I am sure, all honourable members in the House-welcomes the announcement that Vietnamese troops will be withdrawn from Cambodia by September this year. We express the hope that that stated intention of withdrawal will be completed in the time frame that has been announced. There is no doubt that this will represent an enormously hopeful step in the tragic history of that country.

ANSWER.PARA: We note that Vietnam proposes to re-convene the 1954 International Control Commission to supervise the withdrawal and the cessation of military assistance to the Cambodian factions. As honourable members would be aware, Australia has consistently called for the withdrawal of all Vietnamese troops from Cambodia because we have seen that as a necessary pre-condition for any settlement in that country.

Both the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Senator Gareth Evans, and I recently had discussions with a number of the parties involved in the Cambodian problem. During my recent visit to the region I indicated to Prime Minister Chatichai that in view of Australia's longstanding interest in and concern about this matter we were prepared to take a constructive approach to Australia's possible involvement in those settlement processes if such involvement was sought by the parties most directly concerned in the resolution of the conflict. It is a measure of Australia's standing in the region and the work of the Government since 1983 that Thailand wants Australia to participate in that peace process. While there are still difficulties which need to be resolved, we remain hopeful that all parties will make continued and determined efforts to advance the peace process. The need for an agreement among the Cambodian factions remains of fundamental importance if a permanent and peaceful resolution is to be achieved.

There is no doubt that the fact that the Vietnamese troops are now going to be on their way out of Cambodia is yet a further demonstration of the way in which the international situation is moving in a positive direction at the moment. I have said-I was very interested to hear Mrs Thatcher say something very similar yesterday-that we are living in very hopeful times. It is important in these circumstances that Australians should adjust their vision to these far-reaching and rapid changes, that we should look ahead and think positively.

I conclude by saying that it is unfortunate, but nevertheless predictable, that according to press reports today the Opposition parties are preparing yet again to prescribe for this country an irrelevant and indigestible dose of backward thinking on foreign policy, consistent with their approach on every matter of importance to this country.

—Can the Minister for Employment, Education and Training advise the House as to the current rate of unemployment?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his interesting question. I would be delighted to inform him and the House of the most recent figures released, indicating that the level of unemployment in Australia has fallen to 6.2 per cent, which the Prime Minister will be pleased to hear in relation to his seven-year comparisons is the lowest level of unemployment for seven years. It is perhaps important to remember that when we came to office the unemployment rate was hovering around 10 per cent; there was double digit unemployment. We have been able to reduce the level by almost 4 percentage points. This is part of a consistent decline which has occurred during the period of this Government. It is also important to remember that, while we talk about statistics, behind the statistics lie real people who have gained an opportunity to get into the labour market and who have therefore obviously been relieved from a position of near poverty as a result of their inability previously to get into the labour market.

ANSWER.PARA: I now give some of the more specific figures. In the March quarter of 1989-it is always important to look at the trends in quarters rather than just month by month-the seasonally adjusted unemployment level fell by 7,800 to 539,000 people, which is 59,000 or almost 10 per cent less than the same quarter a year ago. Employment has risen by 1.2 per cent and the labour force participation rate has increased from 62.4 to 62.8 per cent. The number of teenage unemployed looking for full time work has fallen by 4,200, or 17.4 per cent less than it was in the same March quarter of 1988.

Since 1983 the Government has seen the creation of 1.3 million jobs or a growth of 21.1 per cent. Two-thirds of that growth has been in the area of full time employment. The rate of unemployment has been reduced by nearly a third and there has been a reduction by half in the number of teenagers out of work and looking for a full time job. There has been a rise in labour force participation from 60.6 per cent to 62.2 per cent and a rise in female participation from 44.8 per cent to 51.5 per cent. This speaks volumes for the success of the Government's approach, bearing in mind the parlous situation in which we found the labour market when we came to office.

When we look at what happened in the few years before we came to office, we find that from 1979 to 1983 unemployment actually went up by 280,000, representing an increase of 68 per cent. Between 1984 and 1989 the unemployment figure has actually come down by a staggering 22 per cent. It is perfectly clear that the coalition parties are the unemployment experts and the Australian Labor Party is quite clearly the job creation expert.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs to the Auditor-General's special audit report. What action has the Minister taken on the 773 unacquitted grants totalling more than $67m?
