—I ask the Minister for the Arts and Territories whether the Government is aware of the extent of fraudulent activities undertaken by officers of the ACT Administration. What is the Government doing about it?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. I am aware of allegations which have been made suggesting that there has been some fraud or corruption on the part of officers of the ACT Administration. As the responsible Minister, I completely reject that assertion, particularly the assertion that at senior levels in the ACT Administration fraud and corruption are common.

ANSWER.PARA: Let me outline the facts. The ACT Administration last year, like other Commonwealth departments, was required to adopt new and special strategies to combat fraud in its operations. It therefore established an investigations unit to promote anti-fraud strategies and encourage greater staff awareness of the means of combating fraud. The way that unit operates is to conduct preliminary investigations. If matters are specifically drawn to its attention, they are referred to the Federal Police.

I cannot emphasise too much that the great bulk of these investigations is concerned with fraud by members of the public against particular departmental operations and services. Suggestions were made in today's Canberra Times that one investigation involving false invoices for concrete and other civil works had resulted in a series of charges being laid. The suggestion in the article that that was evidence of considerable corruption at every level of the administration is a breathtaking allegation without any kind of substance at all. It has been my practice as Minister to refer any allegations of improper conduct or fraud to the appropriate authorities. Whenever such an allegation is made the person who makes the allegation is asked to refer it either to me or to the appropriate authority.

During the recent ACT election, such allegations were made by one candidate, a Mr Collaery. I asked him to provide me with information. He did so. I referred that to the appropriate authorities for investigation and they provided advice that there was no basis upon which any prosecution could be made. I table that correspondence as evidence of the general practice.

I remind the House that I believe it is important, for the purposes of community satisfaction, that where these generalised allegations of fraud or improper practices are made, they ought to be dealt with specifically and in a way which protects the reputation of the many thousands of dedicated public servants who can be caught up in a generalised smear.

I remind the House that there are approximately 17,500 employees in the ACT Administration. At the present time there are three investigations into complaints about three separate officers. That being the case, there is no possible foundation for the generalised assertion which has been made and I repudiate that assertion.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. Given that the special audit report on the Department of Aboriginal Affairs presented to the House on 9 March 1989 stated that `policy guidelines were out of date, unrealistic, not relevant, not measurable, ambiguous and too narrow', I ask the Minister to say what actions he will take, and when, to re-establish effective administration in the portfolio prior to the establishment, if ever, of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hand The Hon G.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —In deference to the honourable member, I appreciate the thought behind the honourable member's question. He has discussed Aboriginal affairs issues with me on a number of occasions and he has shown quite an interest. The point he raises is quite a detailed and complex one, as he would appreciate, but in recent times, particularly whilst I have been the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, we have been attempting to put in place and have now put in place in a substantial number of areas actual plans and strategies developed by the communities together with the Department and other agencies. The problem raised by the auditor is longstanding. It is a product of a system that has been in place for a long time. As I said in December 1987, the system needs substantial overhaul. This is not a criticism of the work force employed in the portfolio area. The system has been created and developed over a long period of time.

ANSWER.PARA: The short answer is that we are working on programs and policies which will address substantially, under the new structure, the questions the Auditor raises. In the interim, we have been moving in that direction as best we can, without disrupting the communities involved, to address the questions raised by the Auditor. The point which the honourable member raises is very important and is one which we have been attending to and will continue to attend to until such time as we get it exactly right.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Attorney-General. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to the insidious activities of the unscrupulous building company, Manfal Pty Ltd, which trades as `Design for Living by Mansard'? Is the Minister aware of the unreasonable and deceptive building contract used by this company, which is advertised in all its literature as a fixed price contract, but which in fact contains a rise and fall clause? Can the Minister explain to the House--

—I raise a point of order, Madam Speaker. The Western Australian Government has already announced legal proceedings on this matter. Is it the propriety of this Government, that it proposes to pre-try these people?
—I find the question in order.

—There are no legal proceedings in Queensland where this situation also applies. Can the Minister explain to the House what can be done, and what is being done, by Federal authorities to help the hundreds of angry, frustrated and desperate home buyers who are now receiving bills for many thousands of dollars more than they budgeted for and who are being refused possession of their homes until the additional moneys are paid? It is a disgrace.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me make the point that this company trades Australia- wide. I have had a number of complaints from Queensland, including one from the Attorney-General of Queensland asking me to guarantee that some action will be taken under the Trades Practices Act. There are State laws which can be used, but of course Queensland has not got the laws. There can be State prosecutions in Western Australia, but they do not operate in respect of the area about which the honourable member is concerned. There can be laws dealing with fraud, misrepresentation and matters of that nature. It appears that Queensland has not got fair trading legislation. A recent editorial in the Courier-Mail commented:

ANSWER.PARA: Stories of consumers being ripped off do seem to emerge in this state with monotonous regularity.
. . . Queensland has had to rely largely on publicity, rather than having power for tough prosecutions.

The matter has been considered by the Trade Practices Commission because the Commission can take an interest on the basis that there would be an infringement of the Trade Practices Act, according to the criteria of what is called misleading or unconscionable behaviour.

This particular firm apparently advertises `fixed price' contracts. Many home buyers, particularly first home buyers, think that that means a fixed price. However, there are many unusual conditions in the contract. If the building is not started within 60 days, the price escalates. It is no surprise that building never starts within 60 days, so the price continually escalates. People are bound by a contract which has no fixed price in it. I am delighted to see the honourable gentleman opposite nodding his agreement. It is well known to Queenslanders. There have been many complaints about this particular organisation. I welcome the question by the honourable gentleman and make the point that the Trade Practices Commission is investigating these complaints. If we can get enough evidence there will be prosecutions.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs to the fact that the discriminatory grants to the Northern Territory land councils from mining royalty payments have increased from $700,000 a year under the former Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Minister Holding, to $4.9m a year since the present Minister took over the portfolio. I ask the Minister: How does he justify these grants for the administration of land councils when the funds involved would have otherwise gone to addressing the pressing needs of health, housing and education in these communities? Secondly, is it not a fact that the buying of political support in this way has fostered local dissatisfaction-perhaps the honourable member for the Northern Territory can tell us something about that-and support for smaller land councils? Thirdly, will the Minister advise the House when he intends to release the annual reports of the Northern Territory land councils?

—That was a fairly long question; I am not sure whether the honourable member knows what he is asking. It is a well-established fact that members on the other side do not like the Northern Land Council, and I suppose it is fair and understandable that they come in here and give it a bit of a crack around the ears. The funding given to the council is in order, and is audited accordingly. So there are no relevant questions to be answered about audits and annual reports. We know the honourable member's attitude to the Northern Land Council and in fact to any other progressive thinking Aboriginal organisation. I used to serve on a committee with him, so I know what his attitude to these people is. It is a longstanding view, and on this occasion he has chosen to give them a bit of a biff around the ears. As to what is termed in the media and by others as the breakaway land council proposals, the establishment of new land councils in the Northern Territory, I established a review of that. That is well documented. The report arrived in my office yesterday. I will be making judgments on that preliminary report in the not too distant future. Everything in regard to these requests for new land councils has been done in the proper way. I will not be bullied by people in the Senate, I will not be bullied by people using the media, to try to force the issue. There is a proper way to do these things, and that is the way they will always be done.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. In view of the forced eviction of three Chilean leaders of the National Telephone Union from the Australian Embassy in Chile, is the Government concerned that Australia will be viewed by the international community as inadvertently condoning the activities of the Bond Corporation in its insensitive treatment of the Chilean Telephone Company (CTC) employees, particularly as I understand the unionists were subsequently savagely beaten by security authorities? Would it not be appropriate for the Government to use its influence with the Bond Corporation to have the dismissed employees reinstated and retrained in alternative skills, as is Government policy in Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In February this year the Australian Embassy in Santiago was occupied on two occasions by members of the telephone union Sinate, one of the 18 unions involves in the Chilean Telephone Co., in which the Bond Corporation has a controlling interest. The unionists were seeking, amongst other things, to involve the Australian Government in their dispute with CTC management over retrenchments. The issue, which is a labour dispute, is essentially a matter between the registered unions and the management of CTC-a private company registered and operating in Chile. The Australian Government regards the occupation of the Embassy as illegal, disrupting the Embassy's normal activities and placing Embassy staff at risk. On the first occasion that the Embassy was occupied the unionists voluntarily left after 29 hours, but on the second occasion they refused to leave after a four-day sit-in. The Embassy, acting under instructions, arranged for the unionists to be conducted from the Embassy by six guards from a private security firm contracted to handle security at the Embassy.

ANSWER.PARA: Contrary to public statements following the second sit-in, I am advised that the security guards were not armed and that the three unionists were neither blindfolded nor gagged. I am further advised that they were not detained, interrogated or in any way maltreated. Of course the Australian Government regrets these incidents but regards the actions taken by the Embassy in Chile as necessary and appropriate in the circumstances, and fully consistent with the stand that Australia has taken in respect of human rights in Chile.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: MOUNT ISA ABORIGINAL CHILD CARE AGENCY

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Community Services and Health to his reply to a question without notice from the honourable member for Dawson, the Opposition spokesman on child-care, on 9 November 1988, and subsequent correspondence in relation to the Mount Isa Aboriginal Child-Care Agency. Given that his Department has made a grant of nearly $21,000 for a bus, how does the Minister explain the fact that there is no bus? Furthermore, will the Minister urgently and effectively use his influence to retain a marvellous Mount Isa organisation known as KASH, as its activities are vital to the health and rehabilitation of numerous Aboriginals in inland Queensland?

—The issues raised in this House concerning the child-care service in Mount Isa have been dealt with. For a period that service was closed, until all of those matters had been put in hand. A new management committee has been created. Savings have also taken place which have covered any of those costs. In relation to the bus, as was pointed out, that money was used on the administration of the child-care service; that was not appropriate and that is one of the reasons why actions were taken. That service has now been opened again, under new management, and is continuing to deliver excellent services to Aboriginal children in that area.

—Is the Minister for Land Transport and Shipping Support aware of a campaign by the Country Shire Councils Association of Western Australia and the Royal Automobile Club in Western Australia to place signs over the top of Australian bicentennial road development program road signs? Can the Minister inform the House whether this half-baked proposal is legal and, if it is not, of the likely penalties if the campaign proceeds?
—I raise a point of order, Madam Speaker. The question clearly seeks a legal opinion from the Minister and is therefore out of order. He used the word `legal'.
—Was the honourable member asking the Minister for a legal opinion?
—I was asking him whether the proposal was legal and, if it was not-
—The Minister may answer the first part of the question.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I appreciate the opportunity the honourable member for Canning has given me to answer this question. I can understand his concern about it because he has applied his efforts very effectively to secure for his electorate in excess of $11m, including about $5m for local government. I understand that there is some arrangement between the Country Shire Councils Association in Western Australia and the Western Australian motorist organisation to do what the honourable member for Canning has referred to as a possibility. I think it is petulant, childish and very possibly illegal. It is very likely that it will also be counterproductive. Under the provisions of the Australian bicentennial road development program there is a requirement that local authorities maintain the signs put up to indicate to people in the community the nature of the program and, in addition, that no signs should be placed adjacent to ABRD signs.

ANSWER.PARA: I would not like the funding for local government in Western Australia or in any other State to be placed in jeopardy, but some type of legal obligation could be placed on us to ensure that the provisions of the law relating to such road funding programs were kept intact. The unfortunate thing is that all local authorities-the 850 councils over the whole of Australia-know that under the road funding program the Federal Government has taken the opportunity to index the funds for local government to make sure that the value of those funds is retained in real terms. So why an exercise of this kind should be undertaken I do not know. During the six years of the Hawke Government the amount that has gone to local authorities over Australia for local roads has been increased in real terms by almost 10 per cent. This is a very foolish and, as I said, very likely counterproductive and very possibly an illegal exercise for the organisations concerned to undertake. I hope that they rethink this politically motivated exercise and that the local authorities do not participate in it.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: VIETNAM: WITHDRAWAL OF TROOPS FROM CAMBODIA

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Prime Minister, refers to his answer earlier today concerning the withdrawal of Vietnamese forces from Cambodia. The Prime Minister will recall that near the end of his answer he urged Australians to look to the future regarding change in the region. In looking to the future concerning that change, will he and others learn from the recent and bloody past and assure the House that he and the Government will work with others to ensure that Pol Pot and other members of the Khmer Rouge leadership group are prevented from standing at any election after the withdrawal of those Vietnamese forces?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome both the question and the spirit in which I believe it was put. I can assure the honourable gentleman-I do not think he will be surprised at this-that fundamental to all the discussions I have had and have authorised my Ministers for Foreign Affairs and Trade to have has been our concern that there be no arrangement whereby those who were responsible for the genocide and the totally obscene operations of the Pol Pot regime should ever have the opportunity of returning to a position of power.

ANSWER.PARA: I share the honourable gentleman's repugnance and abhorrence at all that was done under the Pol Pot regime. That has been my consistent view and I have ensured that it be put consistently by my Foreign Ministers. I can give the honourable gentleman the unqualified undertaking that that will continue to be our position in regard not only to the parties most directly involved but also to those who are in the historic position of having been associated with support for Pol Pot. By that I mean China in particular. As the honourable gentleman knows, China has been the principal supporter of the Khmer Rouge forces. In all the discussions we have had with our friends in China, we have made it clear that we cannot tolerate any return of those people to a position of power. I can assure the honourable gentleman that we are at one on this issue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Mr Beazley) proposed:
That the House take note of the paper.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the honourable member for Braddon (Mr Miles) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The failure of Government policy and the collapse of effective administration in Aboriginal Affairs.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miles Mr C.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I propose the following matter of public importance:

SPEECH.PARA: The failure of Government policy and the collapse of effective administration in Aboriginal Affairs.

This proposal is founded on three grounds: the collapse of effective administration of the Aboriginal Affairs portfolio, which is to do with Australia's most disadvantaged cultural group; the abject failure of Government policy in this area; and the failure of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to act responsibly in response to the crisis in public administration of Aboriginal Affairs. Never since the Commonwealth became involved in Aboriginal matters have Aboriginal Australians been treated as shabbily as they have been by this Government. First we had hopeless Holding and now we have hapless Hand: hapless because of his maladministration, hapless because he will not listen and hapless because his policy is in tatters. His judgment is flawed, his administrative skills are pitiful and his personal management abilities are abysmal. We also have a Prime Minister who has delayed and procrastinated in regard to the difficulties of the chaos and shambles in the Aboriginal affairs portfolio, if not swept them under the carpet.
Let us look at the record of this duo of a hapless Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) and an increasingly out of touch Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —The terrible twins.

—They are terrible twins, as the honourable member for Menzies suggests. As we have already heard, the policy directions of this Government were described in a report of 9 March as being out of date, unrealistic, irrelevant, immeasurable, ambiguous and too narrow. What an indictment. This Government has been in office for over six years, and statements such as this are still being made about the Aboriginal Affairs portfolio. The report went on to say that the portfolio is budget driven rather than policy driven. Here we have a Government and a Minister who do not have any set policies which will contribute to the welfare of the Aboriginal and Islander people in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: Accountability has become virtually non-existent in this portfolio. The recently released report of the special audit into the Department of Aboriginal Affairs (DAA) shows a portfolio in deep crisis. It is interesting that the Government brought it into the House right at the end of the last session. I just want to go over and highlight some of the issues which were raised in it. The Department was unable to confirm that funds it provided for over 1,700 projects had been expended on the purposes for which they had been provided. Of course, we heard in Question Time today that 783 grants, worth over $67m, remain unacquitted. The total, which is not known, could well exceed over $100m.

Compliance with grant conditions was found to be inadequate for almost all grants examined by the Auditor-General-grants ranging in value from $35,000 to over $2m. Thirty-eight per cent of DAA hospitality expenditure directly contravened guidelines. A sample of eight senior officers-ASO7 and above-showed that five did not maintain any attendance records. A senior officer put forward his own daughter as a member of a delegation from an institution with which she had no association. Supervisors were endorsing staff members' attendance records without any check of the calculations or days. There were serious defects in Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC) enterprise projects, the outcome of defective approval procedures and management controls.

The portfolio is in a shambles and the question has to be asked, `If Westminster responsibility means anything, is this Minister culpable?'. He has undermined his own administration to the detriment of the Aboriginal and Islander community. He has been non-existent as a legislator. He has been a disaster as an administrator. He has been a disaster for the Government by repeatedly misleading the Parliament.

I refer now to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure. The Minister is going to say, `I am coming in here and I am doing the things which you have highlighted in the last six months in the Department of Aboriginal Affairs and other areas of my portfolio'. We warned the Government about the difficulties in a minority report back in May 1985. This is what we said:
We recommend that there should be a comprehensive judicial inquiry into the Aboriginal Development Commission.
That was in 1985. It has not happened. We went on to say:
The Committee became aware of the possible commission of criminal offences, the occurrence of serious administrative malpractice and gross mismanagement.

Now, four years later, the same things are being said. The Minister will suggest that ATSIC is going to solve all these problems. We have had this Government's administration in Aboriginal affairs and it gives nobody-not this Parliament or the Aboriginal people-any confidence that any structure proposed by this Government will solve the problems.

Not only that, but very early on in this Minister's reign as Minister for Aboriginal Affairs he actually deleted a key accountability condition from the Department's grants guidelines. The clause gave the Minister the right to suspend funding an organisation where a person holding office is not a fit and proper person or is acting in a manner prejudicial to its interests.

The Minister deleted, took out, accountability. No doubt, that is one of the reasons why there is the mess that we see today in Aboriginal affairs. It was an eminently defensible check if one believes in accountability. The Minister removed it. The Minister did not want to have the power to be able to protect an organisation and its client group from a person who was unfit for his or her office.

Further, the Auditor-General-in a touch of understatement-suggests that in view of the findings of the audit the Government and the Parliament may wish to review the business enterprise provisions in the ATSIC Bill. So, even the Auditor-General is saying that there ought to be another good look had at this proposal by the Government. The bunglings and shambles in the administration of Aboriginal Affairs could never be so debilitating as under this Government.

I move on to the morale and the sackings which have occurred in the Aboriginal Affairs portfolio. This Minister has shown a total lack of interest in the administration of his portfolio, his agenda was radical reform. He was not going to allow himself to be distracted by the Sir Humphreys of this city. During the early months of his administration, the Minister did not even speak with the Secretary of his Department. There was a period when he went for over three months without discussing matters with the Secretary. The Secretary even had to justify appointments to the Minister's Senior Private Secretary. That was the situation which had arisen in Aboriginal Affairs.

The Commonwealth pays millions of dollars for policy advice, yet this Minister prefers to take his advice from the Northern Territory land councils and hired consultants. The Department did not even consider the ATSIC legislation before it was tabled in the House. Maybe that is one of the reasons why the legislation is in such a mess. The Minister shuts out his Department; he ignores it. Not only that, but when submissions were made to the Minister he did not even acknowledge them, as in the case of the ADC Board's submission on ATSIC.

When agencies in the Minister's portfolio were criticised in the special audit report, the Minister did not defend their record. He claimed the Pontius Pilate defence-he washed his hands, saying that he had no control and that they were self-destructing anyway. What an indictment of a Minister. Here is a Minister who needs to be building up the morale of his Department so that it might be able to do something for the Aboriginal people, but the Minister shows no confidence whatsoever in his Department. The record shows that it has been the Minister who has been destructive in this whole affair, not the coalition. The coalition has been calling this Government to account in Aboriginal matters. The Minister dismissed eight Aboriginals, the most senior Aboriginal people in administration in this country. They were dismissed from the ADC board for not supporting his proposal. He failed to give them any reasons for their dismissal or even to thank them. That is the sort of personnel relations this Minister has with his Department. He failed to defend the integrity of the ADC as a statutory authority when the Chairman and the General Manager were abused by the new board and, of course, we all know that he sacked his departmental head.

The chickens have come home to roost. There has been a massive exodus of senior and experienced staff from the portfolio. Since July 1988 more than a dozen senior staff have left the Department and the Commission, including the departmental secretary, a deputy secretary, two ADC general managers and a deputy general manager. In February alone 14 staff at all levels left the ADC within the first two weeks. That means that there would be a total turnover in that area of the Minister's portfolio within one year. The former Acting General Manager of the Aboriginal Development Commission in an open letter to staff has noted:
Restrictions on the permanent filling of positions are causing considerable stress to many staff who are required to work long hours to ensure an efficient delivery of service to our clients.

According to Mr Wyatt, Mr Bill Grey, the new Secretary to the Department, has acknowledged a similar effect in the Department of Aboriginal Affairs. Let me read out an independent description, in a letter from which we have already heard parts:

Morale is at an abysmal level, and members despair of ever being able to do their jobs properly. They have inadequate resources, especially of staff, to adequately deliver services and programs to the clients. There are . . . alarming rates of resignation and sick leave . . .

There is a real and extremely urgent need for some stability to be put back into the working lives of members in the DAA and ADC. It is unambiguously clear that when, or even if, ATSIC ever gets established the vibrancy and enthusiasm desired for the new organisation must necessarily be absent as spirits are now so low.
There is an urgent need for decisions to be made about the shorter term administration of the DAA and ADC.

This letter did not come from a Liberal Party stooge. It came from Ann Forward, who is the National President of the Administrative and Clerical Officers Association and a member of the national executive. Ann Forward is simply trying to get this Minister to give his portfolio a fair go. The implications of the latest Forward letter are a salutary warning to the Government. The portfolio is so demoralised that not only is the ATSIC reform package unachievable but also the very viability of Commonwealth administration of Aboriginal affairs advancement programs is threatened.

This Government's legislative program in Aboriginal affairs is in absolute tatters. This Minister has brought forward only one proposal in his period in office. The Minister has failed to proclaim the land rights legislation which was passed in May 1987, preventing Aboriginal people from owning land in certain areas in the Northern Territory. The coalition policy on ATSIC is very clear. It is interesting to note that this legislation, which this Minister is pinning his hopes on, is now undergoing radical surgery. The recommendations of the Senate Select Committee are very close to the coalition's policy. I suggest that the Minister heed those recommendations and take up those policy suggestions.

The Labor Government's policy in this area, of symbolism, separatism and perpetual guilt, has absolutely failed. It must be asked how long this Prime Minister will allow this discredited Minister to bungle the administration of disadvantaged services to the most disadvantaged cultural group in our nation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hand The Hon G.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yet again we have had to listen to a performance by a person who, quite frankly, has no appreciation or understanding of the portfolio area. The honourable member for Braddon (Mr Miles) has shown that time and time again. One of the quotations he used-he hung his hat on it a lot-cannot in fact be attributed to the Auditor-General; it is in the Auditor-General's report, but it refers to the Department of Aboriginal Affairs setting up a working party to look at the very question the honourable member was talking about. So he has not even read the Auditor-General's report correctly.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member refers to a lack of legislation. In December 1987 we brought a proposal into this place by way of a major statement. I had been only a few months in the job. That statement attempted to address what is a tired and worn out system of administration in the portfolio area. Since December 1987 I have striven to bring about the necessary changes to improve the service delivery to Aboriginal people in this country. I have insisted on accountability at all levels. There has never been applied the degree of accountability-or been such a desire by anyone to apply it-that I have applied in this portfolio.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why did you take it on?
—Order! The honourable member will cease interjecting.

—The honourable member has had his go. I suggest that he keep calm, and I will try to address the few sensible points he touched on. Most of the points the honourable member touched on were not relevant at all, unfortunately.
—They are to the Aboriginals.

—The honourable member makes a point about what is relevant to the Aboriginals. The point about Aboriginal affairs is that one must at all times try to understand what Aboriginals think, what their customs and their laws are. I will give one example of how out of touch the honourable member is. He is attacking the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and me for failing to appoint Aboriginal elders. That is in a whole number of the honourable member's press releases. He says we have not appointed Aboriginal elders. How can non-Aboriginal people choose and appoint the Aboriginal elders? The honourable member has no appreciation of Aboriginal culture.
—You said you were going to--
—If I had a bit of protection from the Chair to shut this goose up, I might be able to get on with the argument.
—Order! If the honourable member for Braddon continues to interject I will warn him and then name him.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. The honourable member, along with his colleagues in the Senate, has been engaged in this exercise. He comes in here today expressing concern about the work force in the Aboriginal Affairs portfolio. How dare he come in here and say that! His Party during the last six months has accused so many people of so many things with little proof for its accusations. He has no understanding because he has hardly ever been in an office of the Department. He is considered an absolute joke amongst the departmental work force because of his lack of understanding. One has only to read the honourable member's press releases-indeed, one ought to read them-to see that he is so out of touch. They are written by him or someone else who has no appreciation of Aboriginal affairs. The honourable member never worries about hurting people's feelings, let alone the innocent, particularly the officers of the Department.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member quoted a letter today from Ann Forward. Big deal! Last year he quoted another letter from Ann Forward which was leaked to him. The letter quoted today is no news to me. The letter deals with the question of morale. The honourable member should have listened to what I have been saying about work force morale in my Department. I go out and talk to the workers where they do their jobs. The people, the workers, are most crooked on those cowards, those abysmal human beings, who sneak in under the door of this place and under the door of the chamber over there and make all sorts of accusations about my work force. It is not fair. That is why morale is so low.

Again we have a Senate Estimates committee meeting with 400 or 500 more questions slapped on the table with a week's notice, causing people to have to work day and night, interrupting the flow of program delivery because of the increased workload. It is the design of honourable members opposite to disrupt program delivery. The honourable member has made no secret of that. He has been bragging for about three weeks about how he is going to destroy me.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about accountability?
—Order! The honourable member for Braddon will cease interjecting.
—Well, do something about him. Make him behave himself.
—The Minister will not try to assist the Chair.

—Honourable members opposite have been making all sorts of accusations about how my head is on the block again. I have news for them. My head is not on the block. The Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) is going to happen because the present system is tired and worn out.

SPEECH.PARA: The work force is striving, like no other department, to maintain a system that is tired, a system which was inherited, and which has developed over the years but which does not meet a whole range of needs. I agreed on the point raised by a National Party member, the honourable member for Cowper (Mr Nehl), at Question Time. We are striving to meet the suggestions made in the Auditor-General's report, suggestions such as that there be more involvement of people, the development of long term and short term strategies and plans for communities and organisations. That is an ongoing process. If one looks at the record while I have been the Minister one will see that it is one of the gains we have made.

As the honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Ian Cameron) will know from our travels around the community as members of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Aboriginal Affairs, it was obvious to everybody that the system was not working. The Standing Committee is still recognising the need for more and more to be done. We have new strategies and programs. We have sat down with the communities in the Torres Strait. We have sat down with the people in the central reserves. We are pumping money into those reserves, but not in a way that means we will have to go back in four years' time and fix it all up again. We are combining the employment, education, health and housing programs of government and pulling them all together. We are totally involving Aboriginal people in the development of those programs. That is where the system has not been able to cope. That is why we are moving into a new era.

The problems of 1978 to mid-1987, alluded to in the report, are a product of the past. If the honourable member opposite wants me to go through the performance blow by blow of the problems faced by every Minister in this portfolio, if we could get an hour or so, I would be happy to do it. Just as the honourable member, in a cheap political way, points the bone at me and says `This program failed under you, or failed under someone else', I could do the same to him. Aboriginal affairs is an incredibly difficult area to work in. It is an incredibly difficult area to administer in terms of government and programs. The most important thing is that the new policies we are trying to get through the Senate do get through. And we will get them through the Senate, because it is proper to involve Aboriginal people in the development and implementation of programs that affect their lives. That is what we are trying to do. That is what has been missing. That is why there have been so many failures-because people from the Parliament have gone out on a few hours visit, walked around with the latest fashionable hat on, had a look at the area and said, `Golly, we have to do something about this'. They come back, pressure the Minister, heap a bit of abuse on the Department and the next minute something is done. We are trying at all levels and especially at the community level to involve Aboriginal people in the development of the programs. We will get away from decisions made at a central level, where there is not enough flexibility, to those programs which work better in the relevant areas through community involvement. That is what we should all be trying to do.

I do not mind members of the Opposition getting up here at Question Time and having a bit of a swipe at me about what the Auditor's report says. I encouraged the Government to obtain all those reports. I want the whole lot out on the table. If members of the Opposition were smart, they would have done the same thing because the history of Aboriginal affairs is littered with mistakes. But by golly, I have to say that most of those mistakes were not made by Aboriginal people. They were made by people who thought they knew best and inflicted ideas and programs on them. Those days have to change. So all of these reports that have been obtained-the Auditor's report and the Public Service report-should all be put on the table. Let us have a look at them.

As I said, we are moving into a new era. There has not been one amendment from the honourable member for Braddon. We had a debate on one of the most far-reaching pieces of legislation ever introduced into this Parliament, to quote a prominent journalist in the gallery. We had not one suggested amendment coming from members of the Opposition, but there was total opposition to it. For the members of the Opposition there was nothing good in it at all and there was no way it could be improved. Then it gets held up in the Senate. We have been through the report of the Senate Select Committee that was developed over a six-month period. I do not want to be too critical of members of the Senate. They are a much more reserved and quieter bunch than we are, but they were a bit selective about where they went. They did not travel everywhere. They certainly never did a fraction of the travel I did, but I respect their right to conduct their affairs in their own way. They have conducted their affairs in their own way and have brought down a report. There is no great problem with that. We have had a look at the report. I am an accommodating person. I have said to this character, the honourable member for Braddon, time and time again, `If you have a problem, Chris, come and have a yarn'. The honourable members in that little corner over there are knocking on the door every day. They come in and want to fix up the problems for the people they represent. That is the difference, mate, between them and you. The honourable member does not represent Aboriginal people in this place. I disagree with members of the National Party on policy, but by golly if they have a problem in their electorate they are into my office like Flynn and they try to get the problem fixed up.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. I am having some trouble following the debate in this case. I have heard reference to `character', `mate' and `goose', amongst others, referring to an honourable member of this House, and I believe the honourable member for Braddon. I do not know to whom the Minister is referring but if he is referring to an honourable member, I believe that the member ought to be addressed by his title in the proper way.
—If the honourable member for Dundas was of the belief that he was referring to the honourable member for Braddon, I hope the Minister was not. The Minister will continue.

—I was not going to name him, but I guess if the cap fits, wear it. I will refer to the honourable member for Braddon in the future as the honourable member for Braddon and not as a goose or anything that might come into my head on the spur of the moment.
—The Minister will continue the debate.

—I was talking about the approach of people who have a lot to do with Aboriginal people and the difference in their approach to that of the honourable member for Braddon. The honourable member talked about the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC). That is extraordinary and something that I cannot understand, given the approach of members of the Opposition to the ADC. They have constantly told me, `Don't put a glove on the ADC'. I have had resolutions through the Senate condemning me for my attacks on the ADC-which have never really been attacks. Whenever I have moved to do anything there has been the rumour around that I am moving to do something in the ADC. If I talk to somebody in it, comment is made by the Opposition. To quote Senator Peter Baume-I think I can do it off the top of my head-he said, `If it is not losing money, don't touch it'. That is what he said on the radio the morning after the Senate report came out. For God's sake, members of the Opposition should have a look at that report.

SPEECH.PARA: Again, it is totally wrong for the commissioners solely to be blamed for the mistakes of the ADC. We do not want to do that. It is also wrong to blame the work force of the ADC. I have been trying to tell members of the National Party and the rest of the country that the system operates on two parallel structures. In communities or towns there is an ADC officer on one side of the passage and a departmental officer on the other side of the passage. That is a crazy waste of resources. This is not a good utilisation of resources. That is what I tried to tell members of the Opposition in December 1987. Over there, through your friends in the Senate, I have been prevented from improving things. The people on the Senate Select Committee could have come to me with every single recommendation they made. They could have said, `Look, Gerry, this is not the right way to go. We reckon that if you do this or do that it will improve the legislation'. They did not do that. They were engaged in an exercise of holding up the legislation. They do not care about the portfolio; they are trying to denigrate me and get my scalp so that the honourable member for Braddon can get a score on the board. That will not happen either. The fact is that the programs are now working better, there are more of them, and they will continue to improve. The Auditor's report will be addressed, as it has been addressed in other years by other Ministers. All the matters mentioned in the report from the Department's point of view will be addressed. I look forward to next week as I will be able to speak a bit more freely about the report when I make a statement with the Prime Minister which goes into the future of Aboriginal Affairs.

One thing that worries me is that the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson) said the other day, `God help me if I get Aboriginal Affairs or Veterans' Affairs'. Three members of the Opposition stood outside the door and said, `If Howard rings me up and offers me Aboriginal Affairs, Gerry, I am not going to take the job'. That is what members of the Opposition think about Aboriginal affairs. They are never going to be given an opportunity to get the job.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr I.M.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is my pleasure today to discuss this matter of public importance. It is important for us to understand that the public generally is very concerned about the administration of the Aboriginal Affairs portfolio by the Federal Labor Government. The matter of public importance states:

SPEECH.PARA: The failure of Government policy and the collapse of effective administration in Aboriginal Affairs.

I put to the House and to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) that the main reason for that is that the Labor Government has diverted an enormous amount of attention from the proper administration of Aboriginal affairs to setting up its new arrangements with the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission, which the Aboriginal people do not want. As we know, the Minister has travelled throughout Australia. I have not heard of any group that is interested in the sorts of arrangements that the Government has put forward. Not only that, there is also the proposed treaty which the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) seems hell bent on putting forward. While the pair of them continue to go around this nation proposing this sort of nonsense, the administration of the portfolio will continue to collapse in a heap.

Unfortunately for the Minister it starts at the top because he has had to sack Charles Perkins, the leading Aboriginal administrator of this nation. He has actually been dismissed by the Minister. Why was he dismissed? Because of his incompetence and the fact that his administration was full of misspent moneys and back scratching, et cetera. I am not saying that that applies just to Aboriginal people; it applies to all of us. We can all get involved. I think it is a sad indictment for one of the leaders of the Aboriginal people to be dismissed by this Government. He was dismissed because of his incompetence.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not true.
—The Minister dismissed him. He should tell me why he has been dismissed.
—You are playing the man.

—I am not playing the man. The Minister should tell me why he was dismissed. He was dismissed because his administration was incompetent. He was losing thousands and thousands of dollars because he was giving money to hotels and motels in inland New South Wales.
—That is not true.

—It is true. Those are the facts. It is very sad that the Government has placed these leaders in such a position. The Minister continues to go down the track of centralising Aboriginal administration and it cannot work. It does not work for the rest of Australia's administration. In this vast country we have a States arrangement. I agree with the Minister that it is impossible for one person to administer his portfolio effectively. It is absolutely impossible for one human being to do so. One cannot travel throughout the length and breadth of this nation and into the Torres Strait and have effective control over the hundreds of millions of dollars that are granted to Aboriginal affairs by this Parliament. It is important that the taxpayers know and understand that hundreds of millions of dollars are involved. In fact, this financial year there has been a $467m allocation through the Department to look after those people whom the Parliament has selected to help. When one thinks about it one realises that there are not many Aborigines in Australia. The census tells us that there are about 70,000 adults. There are probably a couple of hundred thousand altogether-men, women and children. Yet we seem to be hell bent on trying to rectify their social problems with money and it does not work. The Minister knows it.

SPEECH.PARA: I have now entered my ninth year as a member of this Parliament. I have been a continuing member of the House Representatives Standing Committee on Aboriginal Affairs, which was one of the first committees formed by the House of Representatives. There are now many other committees. I am probably the longest continuously serving member of that Committee. I have continued to take an interest in Aboriginal people not only in my electorate but throughout Australia. I know some honourable members will argue that I am a hard right winger, et cetera. I probably am. I have been brought up in a bush environment where one has to be a bit tough. I can tell honourable members that most Aborigines are the same. They are not fools. They do not wish to be governed from Canberra. They like to look after their own affairs at a local level. That is where the States play their part.

Not only is half a million dollars being spent by the Federal Government; we must also add the moneys that every State spends on looking after Aboriginal people. We are looking at about $1 billion. Obviously not all of that will be spent wisely. It is important to understand that many good projects are under way. Of course, we in politics always highlight the bad ones because they are the ones that come to our notice, and I have been to see the Minister about a couple. The coalition is totally opposed to a treaty. We think it is an absolute nonsense. We support the one Australia concept. If we are to pursue the reverse apartheid line in this nation, we will tear ourselves apart. A treaty will do absolutely nothing for Aboriginal people. The Prime Minister seems to be even more keen on a treaty than the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs is. God knows why. I cannot see how it will benefit Aboriginal people. Most of them do not even know what it is about.

Over and above that, the Government is trying to set up a new semi-parliament arrangement, making regions over and above our existing electoral regions. I am the person elected to represent all the Aboriginal people in the electorate of Maranoa. I do that in this place, nobody else. We do not want a so-called pseudo-Aboriginal-he has to be an Aborigine to be their representative-coming down here. The Aboriginal Development Commission is to be disbanded. An important matter which I press continually even on my side of politics is that if representatives are to be elected-not that I support the concept-the elections must be compulsory. Ever since we started funding Aborigines to the extent that we do-most had seen no more money than the basic wage-funding has been rolling into their hands. Some of them have no concept at all of handling the sort of money the Government parcels out to them. Then we wonder why the whole thing falls in a heap and nothing happens.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are trying to change that.

—The Minister agrees with me. That is what is happening. This does not apply just to Aborigines. If I decided to set up a commission in Maranoa, put a ring around a group of people and told them that they had to look after their own affairs, although no other section did it, they would make a mess of it too. It cannot be done. I would have thought that the Government would have learnt its lesson from our original set-up. It did not work. People ended up dropping themselves through the roof in Canberra, busting the safe open and pinching money and whatnot. Blokes such as Sugar Ray Robinson in my electorate are elected. Only about 20 people come in on polling day. The rest are manhandled out of the district or driven out of town on the day the election takes places. Unless there are compulsory elections, reasonable Aboriginal people will not be elected. There are a whole lot of standover merchants and rebels within the organisation. Most of the people who are elected are the stirrers in the communities. They are not the reasonable, decent Aboriginal people. There are hundreds of them out there, most of whom are very disappointed with the leadership that is offered.
—I raise a point of order. It is not a question of what has been said about me--
—Cry-baby.

—The Leader of the Opposition might think that I am a cry-baby. I am objecting to the broad-brush accusations levelled at Aboriginal people. I do not think that such language is parliamentary. I am sure that it was not the honourable member's intention to use it in the broad way that he did.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—I do not have much time to continue my speech on this subject. However, as I have indicated, I have taken a great deal of interest in Aboriginal affairs. Our side of politics believes in the one Australia. We believe in decent funding going to Aboriginal people, but we believe in decentralisation. It should be dealt with at the local government and State levels. If the Commonwealth were fair dinkum it would abolish the Aboriginal affairs portfolio and supply the funding through the normal channels. Aboriginal people would be a lot better off as a result.
—Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gayler Mr J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have some difficulty with the formulation of the matter of public importance. As I understand it, it speaks of two areas in Aboriginal affairs: first, the failure of Government policy; and, secondly, the collapse of effective administration in Aboriginal affairs. I believe that there is a causal link-that one does not go without the other. It is most unfortunate that the failure of Government policy has been largely brought about by the attitude of those opposite. Every time something new is put forward by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) or the Government it is derided and criticised by those opposite. As the Minister said quite aptly in his speech, there has not been one positive amendment or thought put forward in that regard by the shadow spokesman on Aboriginal affairs, the honourable member for Braddon (Mr Miles), or by the Opposition since the Minister has held the portfolio.

SPEECH.PARA: Unfortunately, this issue goes back to August 1988. In this very place, on the first day this House met, in an attempt to acknowledge the prior occupation of this country by Aboriginal people and their subsequent dispossession by European settlers, we could not get bipartisan support from those opposite. It is interesting to note that the criticism of those opposite and the Opposition's approach to that motion did not flow just from the Government. Eminent church leaders throughout this nation roundly criticised Opposition members for their approach. Aboriginal leaders and many in the community not connected directly with the Government criticised them for their approach. It is not surprising that the attitude of some of those opposite comes through with the Opposition's approach of knocking everything the Government puts up in relation to Aboriginal affairs.

It is very pleasing to see Aboriginals sitting in the gallery in this place today. I know Clarrie Grogan and Mick Miller personally. They have worked over many years with governments of different persuasions to better the lot of Aboriginal people. When they sit in this place and see the pathetic attitude of those opposite, they must feel that it is no wonder the whole Aboriginal issue is one of turmoil. We can consider, for example, the actions of those wandering around the country trying to torpedo the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC). I refer, in particular, to Senator Boswell and the Queensland Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Katter. When Senator Boswell addressed Aboriginal councils in far north Queensland he told them that they should pass motions divorcing themselves totally from the ATSIC proposal. He got to the stage of arriving at these council meetings with prepared press statements. He would stick the statements under their noses and say, `Get that through and we'll get a run all over Australia with it'.

The attitude of the Opposition is unfortunate. Aboriginal people are beginning to understand that those opposite have no views on Aboriginal issues. I found it rather enlightening that, when addressing the Hopevale Community Council, that luminary Senator Boswell said, `Look, I'm here today to address you on ATSIC, on Aboriginal matters. Whilst I'm not very good on Aboriginal matters, I'm better than anyone else the Opposition has down in Canberra'. That is the sort of attitude of those opposite. I see also that the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson) has taken some interest in this debate. In an article headed `Hewson: High Flyer with the Magic Touch' in the West Australian of 21 March, the honourable member for Wentworth is reported as having said:
I don't mind starting at the bottom: If you go into Parliament you expect you might have to start on the back bench or in a junior ministry . . .
I live in fear of some ministries . . .

He then mentioned the Aboriginal Affairs portfolio. That is the attitude of those opposite. We can find numerous such examples in the media. Senator Sheil, for example, referred to `black bludgers and stirrers looting the nation'. Unfortunately, that is the attitude of those opposite. It is high time that the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) pulled his troops into order in relation to Aboriginal affairs.

The matter of public importance talks of the collapse of effective administration in the Department of Aboriginal Affairs (DAA). Senator Tambling has roundly criticised DAA's staff and officials. In addition, Senator Crichton-Browne attacked the DAA staff at Geraldton. Senator Tambling attacked the DAA staff at Katherine in the Northern Territory. The shadow spokesman for Aboriginal affairs, the honourable member for Braddon, spoke about a lack of confidence and confusion existing within DAA officials.

The National President of the Administrative and Clerical Officers Association, Ann Forward, will certainly have to lift her game. How would anyone with any ability in the position of National President leak such a document to the shadow spokesman? It was done last year and he made a mess of it. He made a mess again today. If the organisation has a gripe and it does not want to speak to the Minister, it should get someone with some competence or ability to represent its thoughts and views in this place. Morale is low in the DAA.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have said that.

—The Minister has never denied that. However, if honourable members opposite run around the country acting in the way they have over the last 12 or 18 months and continue to do so, they will never get any morale into the Department. Neither will they get any support from the Aboriginal people.

SPEECH.PARA: I noted some of the comments of the honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Ian Cameron). He cannot even get the title of ATSIC right. He called it `Aztec'. He talked about centralisation of powers. The major thrust of ATSIC is to get decision-making into the regional areas, not centralise it in Canberra. The honourable member does not even know that. Honourable members should bear in mind that the matter has not come up in the Standing Committee on Aboriginal Affairs, so the honourable member may not have had the opportunity of reading the legislation and the Senate committee report.

I conclude on this note: The worst possible outcome for Aboriginal people would be for us to sit here in this place and carry out a slanging match. The criticism that has been poured on those opposite with respect to their attitude to a number of Aboriginal issues does not come solely from this side of the House. As I said earlier, eminent church leaders have roundly criticised the Opposition for its policies and its attitude to Aboriginal affairs. Eminent Aboriginal leaders and members of the community generally have made such criticism. Any criticism being made does not come solely from this side of the House. That is a very telling factor because, if church leaders and other members of the community also criticise honourable members opposite, as I said earlier, it is high time the Leader of the Opposition got his troops in order. I assure the shadow spokesman on Aboriginal affairs that the the Leader of the Opposition will not get the number wrong the next time he rings him.

TALK.START.PARA: —The debate is concluded.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hewson Dr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
—I do.
—He may proceed.

—The honourable member for Leichhardt (Mr Gayler) in the course of his matter of public importance address referred to a quotation attributed to me which he said appeared in the West Australian of 21 March. In making that comment, Mr Deputy Speaker, he ignored the fact that I had made a personal explanation earlier this week pointing out the nature of that quotation and the extent to which it had been misrepresented by the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys). The quote was taken out of context. I was not in any way attacking Aboriginals or veterans. I was responding to a question before I entered Parliament as to what would be my portfolio preferences, where I thought my talents would be better used, what sort of contribution I would make in different portfolios and so on.

SPEECH.PARA: The article in the West Australian was a repeat of an earlier article which had appeared in the Times on Sunday in June 1987, prior to my entering Parliament. I want to clarify the matter by saying that I was in no way commenting on Aboriginals or veterans, as such, but on my own comparative advantage in terms of potential portfolios. Mr Deputy Speaker, could I also take a point of order?

TALK.START.PARA: —You can take a point of order.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I take a point of order and ask you, or Madam Speaker through you, for a ruling on what sorts of penalties might exist in instances where members like myself come into this Parliament and make personal explanations, only to find that the personal explanation is ignored and the quotes or other references are continued to be misused in a public or private forum.
—From my understanding of the Standing Orders, a member is entitled to rectify the account of things by way of a personal explanation if at any time he is misrepresented in here or outside.
—Am I expected to come in here on a daily basis to correct such matters?

—I will draw the matter to the Speaker's attention. She may wish to say something about it. As I understand it, the provisions of the Standing Orders are that a member can continue to rebut any allegation that is made but I do not think there is any constraint upon a person making an allegation.
—I would appreciate it if you would look into it.
—I will draw the matter to the Speaker's attention.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, I present the Committee's 296th report entitled The Auditor-General: Ally of the People and Parliament-Reform of the Australian Audit Office.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-It gives me enormous pleasure to present this report. The inquiry which led to the report was the first comprehensive governmental or parliamentary inquiry into the Australian Audit Office since the Office of the Auditor-General was established at Federation in 1901. I note with great pleasure that the Minister for Land Transport and Shipping Support (Mr Robert Brown), who is at the table, and the shadow Minister, the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson), were both participants in the Public Accounts Committee during the period of this report.

SPEECH.PARA: In the 88 years since Federation government and parliament have changed dramatically and the purpose and conduct of audits have also been transformed. The Committee examined the role of the Australian Audit Office and the Auditor-General in the light of those changes. I stress that the report stands as an objective assessment of the need to reform the Audit Office and is above party political considerations. The Committee believes that the report will be an enduring contribution to the reform of parliamentary democracy in Australia. It is a document relevant to the reform of the Audit Office, not just at the Federal level but in the States, the Territories and prob- ably in other jurisdictions as well. It is a document unashamedly of the Parliament, for the Parliament and the people.

The terms of reference for the inquiry were to investigate, first, whether the Australian Audit Office had kept pace with developments in regard to the public audit function in the States and Territories and in com- parable countries. This question was answered with a conditional no. Second, the Committee inquired whether current arrangements guaranteed the independence and resources necessary for the Australian Audit Office to fulfil its role as determined by the Audit Act 1901. The answer to this question was no. It must be pointed out that the reasons for these negative answers were largely outside the control of the Auditor-General and the Audit Office.

The Auditor-General and the Australian Audit Office are responsible for reassuring Parliament that all governments' financial management and financial statements are sound. Considering the billions of dollars that the Commonwealth Government collects, manages and spends on behalf of all Australians, such reassurance is the foundation of the citizens' belief in government. Without the Auditor-General's examination and reports on Commonwealth accounts, Parliament, and ultimately the Australian people, have less reason to feel confident of any statements of a department or statutory authority about its income and expenditure. Therefore, a strong and independent Auditor-General and Australian Audit Office are fundamental to the credibility of audit opinions and the effectiveness of the Auditor-General and his staff.

Independence has a diminished practical value unless the Auditor-General has the human and material resources to exercise his responsibility. This report addresses the resources question by comparing three approaches to determining how many resources an Auditor-General requires. In theory, either the Auditor-General, Parliament or Government can determine how many resources are necessary for audit. The inquiry compared and contrasted how these approaches worked in different countries. It concluded that the least desirable basis for maintaining the Auditor-General's and the Audit Office's independence and resources was where the Executive Government determined audit resources. Australia is one of the few comp- arable countries in the world where Government has such influence over decisions on audit resources. The ideal situation is where either the Auditor-General makes a professional decision on how many resources are necessary for him, or her, to be able to give an opinion on a government's accounts or where Parliament makes that decision.

The Canadian Auditor-General has a very great discretion over how many resources he needs. The Committee rejected this model for Australia as unsuitable. The Committee's recommendation was for Parliament to decide how many resources it wanted to allocate for audit. This approach has been adopted by the British Parliament in recent years with the support of both Government and Opposition.

The Auditor-General audits the Government's accounts on behalf of Parliament and through Parliament, as I have said on behalf of the Australian people. The Committee believed that, fundamental to reform of the Australian Audit Office, was a more open and clear acknowledgment by Parliament that this was the case. Consistent with this emphasis, the Committee recommended the establishment of an Audit Committee of the Parliament comprising Government and Opposition members and senators and a representative of a minority party, if any, in the Parliament, and chaired by the President of the Senate or the Speaker of the House of Representatives alternately. The Audit Committee of Parliament will advise the Auditor-General on Parliament's audit priorities and make recommendations to Parliament on the Audit Office's resources.

Turning now to the question of human resources, the Audit Office has, as we all know, many very talented staff. However, in recent years it has lost many able personnel because the salaries of senior and specialist staff have lagged behind incomes available in the private sector. For example, the Australian Audit Office staff member responsible for the audit of the Commonwealth Bank earns from one third to one quarter the income of private sector auditors in charge of the audit of Australia's other large banks. Yet, of course, there is no evidence that the standard of the Commonwealth Bank's audit is any different from private sector audits of large banks.

Salary differentials between experienced auditors in the private and public sectors are now so substantial that the Audit Office is also having difficulty in recruiting junior staff. Thus, there are two problems. One is how to attract young, new staff and the second is how to maintain senior staff. It is so difficult for the Audit Office to recruit and maintain staff that Parliament must be made aware of the dangers that the current circumstances create for the strength and capacity of the Audit Office. The Committee recommended that the best way to overcome this problem was to establish the Australian Audit Office as a statutory authority, and to give the Auditor-General the authority to determine the terms and conditions of the employment of staff.

I turn now to the question of the relationship between auditing and the Auditor- General and a more efficient public sector. The practice of auditing has evolved so that auditors now have techniques to analyse how efficiently government programs are managed. The authority to conduct efficiency audits was introduced into the Audit Act in 1979, following the recommendations of the Royal Commission on Australian Government Administration. Internationally, efficiency audits, or value for money audits as they are sometimes called, utilise a very large part of the General Accounting Office's resources in the United States; while in Canada and the United Kingdom, approximately half of the resources of the national audit office are dedicated to efficiency audits-that is 5 per cent on comparable jurisdictions. By comparison, the Australian Audit Office devoted 6 per cent of its resources to efficiency audits in 1987-88. No witness before our inquiry recommended that this state of affairs should continue.

To demonstrate the importance of efficiency audits, I recall that one prominent participant in our inquiry made the point to the effect that where an auditor enters an institution to conduct a regularity audit, the person behind the cash register feels under pressure. But where an auditor arrives to conduct an efficiency audit, the permanent secretary or head of the organisation gets nervous.

A situation wherein only 6 per cent of the Australian Audit Office's resources are set aside for efficiency audits is not compatible with a commitment to increase public sector efficiency. Accordingly, the Committee recommended a major change in the Audit Office's orientation. There can be no reduction in resources for financial and compliance auditing. Therefore, the only way in which more resources can be allocated to efficiency audits to improve public sector efficiency is if more resources are allocated to the Australian Audit Office. The Committee has recommended that an additional $3.1m-a very modest amount-be allocated to the Audit Office in 1989-90. This will increase to an additional $15.7m within five years. Consequently, by 1994-95 approximately 50 per cent of the Australian Audit Office's resources and effort will be for efficiency audits. The effect will be to place increased emphasis on maximising the efficiency of the public sector and so make our Audit Office comparable to other audit offices around the world. I stress that despite differing views held by Committee members on the role and size of the public sector, we are on common ground in believing that whatever the role and size of the public sector it must be both efficient and accountable.

In conclusion I turn to an issue which lies at the heart of the inquiry, namely the relationship between Executive Government and the Parliament. The year 1988-89 is the 300th anniversary of the drafting in London of the Bill of Rights. The Bill of Rights was one of the foundations of parliamentary democracy, not just in the United Kingdom but in many other countries around the world including Canada, New Zealand and Australia. One achievement of the Bill of Rights was to assert Executive Government's accountability to the entire Parliament. The 1866 Exchequer and Audit Departments Act of the United Kingdom, on which the Australian Audit Act of 1901 was based, was another milestone in evolution of the accountability of government to Parliament. Indicative of the importance of the Audit Act of 1901 was the fact that it was the fourth Act to be passed by the first Australian Parliament. The report of the inquiry into the Audit Office points to the next step forward to strengthen the public sector's accountability to the Australian Parliament.

Political activity in the twentieth century in Australia has been characterised by the increasing domination of Parliament by Executive Government. This increasing domination has occurred whichever political party or coalition has been in power. The results of the inquiry into the Australian Audit Office provide Parliament with an opportunity to strengthen the accountability of Executive Government to Parliament. For this purpose, the Committee has recommended repeal of the Audit Act 1901 and its replacement by two laws-a new Audit Act and a new Financial Administration Act for the Commonwealth. New audit legislation will be a cornerstone of relations between Parliament and Government for the remainder of this century and into the next. It is my deepest hope that this report will be the catalyst for that reform. I commend the report to the House.
Debate interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have just been reflecting upon my response to the honourable member for Wentworth. While I will bring the matter he raised to the attention of the Speaker-I would imagine she will respond to him privately-my remarks should not be construed to mean that the Speaker may feel required to respond in the House to the remarks.
