SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I am grateful for the opportunity to speak on the tabling of the 296th report of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts. I commend particularly the Chairman of the Committee, the honourable member for Hughes (Mr Tickner). I hope honourable members have listened very carefully to what he had to say. Frankly, it was a very thoughtful and provocative speech associated with what I think is one of the more monumental reports to be tabled in this Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: As I look around the parliamentary chamber I notice that most of my colleagues present have had an interest in public accounting. I notice that in the advisers' gallery there are two people, both associated with the Public Accounts Committee report that has just been tabled. As I sneakily look up at the public gallery I even see senior officials of the Auditor-General's Office. But the numbers are not large. Now that the broadcasting of Parliament has gone off the major Australian Broadcasting Corporation stations, I wonder whether anybody might be listening at home. I suppose our only hope is that in the enclosed galleries, above us all, we have a large number of younger Australians present who may well--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Dundas might address his remarks to the Chair rather than literally playing to the gallery.

—I do make the point, Mr Deputy Speaker, that the future of this nation and this parliamentary democracy depends upon the young people listening to this debate. Their future will very much depend upon whether we have been able, within our parliamentary democracy, to re-establish effectively this Parliament's authority over the Executive. As one looks at the framework of this report one finds that even the parliamentary watchdog is in the hands of the Executive itself. The appointment of the Auditor-General is in the hands of the Executive Government. The amount of money that the Auditor-General has available to carry out his functions is in the hands of the Executive Government. Look at the position of the parliamentary committee that has responsibility for looking at the way in which the Auditor-General undertakes his work. Even it has been severely strapped for resources, such that its members are continually faced with the embarrassment of not being able adequately to deal with the information that comes before them about the way in which the Executive, itself, functions. Finally, even the way in which responses are made to Public Accounts Committee reports is in the hands of the Executive Government. It is not even in the hands of Cabinet; it goes beyond that, to the departments of state. Responses to reports of the Public Accounts Committee are in the hands of the Department of Finance. We have found recently, after inquiry, that the Department of Finance coordinates responses, but it is largely a post-box function whereby very junior officers in the Departments tell the Committee, if we read between the lines, that what the Committee's recommendations are about is of little consequence. This is a very serious situation.

SPEECH.PARA: When I played to the gallery earlier I wondered whether this report would really be seen as significant enough for the Cabinet to take it on board and respond. It is a particularly important document. It is crucial to the independent role of the Parliament that its recommendations be picked up. Accountability is dependent upon resources and also upon the Parliament itself asserting, as this report does, a role for the Parliament in the way in which the Auditor-General functions, the resources that are available to him and the nature of the appointments that are made. They are the crucial aspects of the report before us.

I want to take honourable members through the report because it contains some important pieces of information. Honourable members often assume that one of the principal functions of the Auditor-General relates to the scrutiny of the accounts of government departments and involves reporting upon whether the money is spent properly-compliance auditing as it is called. In recent years we have seen the development of a new form of auditing, efficiency auditing. In the last 10 years performance audits, as they are called in some places, or efficiency audits, as we know them, have made an increasing contribution. It was thought that they would play an important role in looking at the way in which government departments operate and bringing about efficiencies, but the fact of the matter is that the Auditor-General still has to carry out his compliance audit function. The resources available to him enable him to carry out that function but little more.

Notwithstanding the importance of efficiency audits-the tables in the report provide a great deal of information about the gains that have been made through the efficiency audit process-the Auditor-General has had little in the way of resources to allocate to them. The consequence of that is that very large programs involving income or expenditure greater than $10m can be expected to be the subject of an efficiency audit only once every 40 years. Table 17.2 refers to the effects of current resources available. It shows that statutory authorities have the prospect of being the subject of an efficiency audit once in 54 years. I wonder how many honourable members will see efficiency audits of every statutory authority. One would have to be the grandfather or the great grandfather of the House to see that. The prospect for government departments is once in 48 years; and, for departmental outriders-a slightly better performance-once every 20 years. I wanted to emphasise that because this whole question of resources, of the ability of the Auditor-General to undertake his scrutiny role for this Parliament, can be shown to be severely affected when we look at that very basic information.

A number of other matters are addressed in this report. We can follow it through very easily if we look at the recommendations, which are set out in a form that is very easy to follow. We recommend in the legislative area that `the Audit Act be repealed and replaced with two new laws, a Financial Administration Act and an Audit Act'. We recommend that a parliamentary committee-not the Public Accounts Committee, whose role is sacrosanct-`be established to advise the Auditor-General on Parliament's audit priorities and to consider its finances in detail'; in other words, to give the Parliament a role in determining those resources. As the honourable member mentioned, such a committee would be bipartisan, its membership consisting of the President of the Senate or the Speaker, alternating each year; the Minister for Finance; the Public Accounts Committee chairperson; the chairperson of the House of Representatives committee which uses Australian Audit Office reports; the chairperson of a Senate committee which uses Audit Office reports; three members of the Opposition; and a parliamentarian who is a member of a minority party or, if there is no such person, a member of the Opposition.

It is proposed that the committee nominate its chairman, along with the Minister for Finance and one person nominated by the Leader of the Opposition, to consider who should be appointed as Auditor-General. The whole question of the person involved ought to be outside the Executive area. It should not just be a matter of the Prime Minister making a recommendation but a Governor-General's appointment in which the Prime Minister receives advice from a bipartisan group. It is proposed that the appointment of the Auditor-General be for 10 years, a sacrosanct period, or until he earlier reaches retirement age.

We also addressed the question of resources and the way in which they should be dealt with. We dealt with the Auditor-General's mandate and with the question of performance audits and how they might be made more effective. We dealt particularly with the Department of Finance and its responsibility, particularly in matters of the Ministers' reports and the availability of that information to the Parliament through the Public Accounts Committee. We dealt with the audit of section 96 grants to State and Territory governments and with the way in which reporting generally is carried out. We dealt with the question of privatisation, in effect. Our view was that the Auditor-General ought to have the pre-eminent role in relation to the audit function but that that ought not to exclude private firms carrying out audit functions-firms chosen not by government statutory authorities, companies or departments but by the Auditor-General, their supervision being in his hands. The choice would be his. We called for the publishment of criteria on which the decision to employ private auditors on a contract basis might be based.

We want to establish better relationships between the Auditor-General and the private sector and made suggestions in relation to that. We also suggested that the Auditor-General should be subject to an independent audit of his own operations and made recommendations on the way in which that appointment ought to be made. Finally, and rather incidentally, we made the suggestion that as a symbolic matter the Audit Office ought to be related clearly to the Parliament and not to the bureaucracy. We suggested that the Australian Audit Office should have a new building, called Audit House, either within the Parliamentary Triangle or on State Circle adjacent to the new Parliament House, thereby establishing a clear relationship with the Parliament for all to see.

We have highlighted in this report a number of weaknesses, I want to mention one other. The efficiency audit concept is a very important one. The way in which and the frequency with which efficiency audits are carried out is very important. The fact that the Auditor-General is the subject of scrutiny by the Department of Finance in relation to his own resources is significant. In the preface to the report the Committee-not me personally-said:

Another weakness highlighted during the inquiry was that the Department of Finance was the principal adviser to Executive Government on the resources that should be allocated to the Australian Audit Office. This was so even though the Department of Finance was the Audit Office's most important auditee. The AAO appears to have been constrained in its efficiency audits of the Department of Finance because of this arrangement.
I repeat:
The Australian Audit Office appears to have been constrained in its efficiency audits of the Department of Finance because of this arrangement.
The Committee continued:

The Audit Office had never conducted an efficiency audit of any aspect of that Department's operations, despite the centrality of the latter to the efficiency and effectiveness of the Commonwealth sector. Nor had efficiency audits ever been conducted of the Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet, the Treasury or Reserve Bank.

I think those matters are significant and ought to be taken on board. In judging the way in which this report is responded to, the power of those vested interests ought to be kept very much in mind. The response to this report ought to be in the hands of the Parliament itself if we are to get the recommended reforms put in place.

I want to make one other personal comment. I mentioned the advisers boxes before. Dr Paul Nicoll, who helped us greatly in relation to this report, is present. I thank him on behalf of the Committee for the work he put into the report; it is referred to in the preface. I thank the other members of the staff, particularly Laraine Brennan, who is mentioned in the report, who were also instrumental in helping to prepare it and in ensuring that we were properly informed and who assisted in preparing this monumental document.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nehl Mr G.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I rise, with a great deal of pleasure, to support my two colleagues who have just spoken. The Public Accounts Committee report No. 296 has an intriguing title, namely The Auditor-General: Ally of the People and Parliament-Reform of the Australian Audit Office. In fact, that is the case: the Auditor-General and his Office are the allies of the people and the Parliament. I commend the Chairman of the Public Accounts Committee, the honourable member for Hughes (Mr Tickner), for his excellent tabling speech. I thought that it was first rate; it led the way on a number of points and I do commend him for it. I also commend the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock) for his contribution. Unlike the honourable member for Dundas, I will not play to the gallery and look up at the school children there--
—I am sorry; they have gone.
—Oh, they have gone, have they? They heard the honourable member for Dundas speak and away they went! Goodness gracious, that is no recommendation.

SPEECH.PARA: To the people who are listening to this debate and the Australian people in general the Australian Audit Office is totally remote. They do not know what it is; they have probably never even heard of it. It is completely unknown. Yet it is of vital importance to every Australian citizen because it is the watchdog of the people and the watchdog of the Parliament in terms of the financial management of the billions of dollars spent by any government. It is the watchdog of the financial statements and all the activities of government. Therefore, it has incredible importance for every single Australian.

Because of that importance, it is imperative that adequate resources be made available to the Auditor-General. The Auditor-General must be independent, so he must have adequate resources. Without sufficient resources, independence is meaningless; it means nothing at all. The Auditor-General has a basic disability-he cannot pay enough. He cannot pay his senior officers anything like what they would receive in private industry. Salaries are way behind and, as a result, too many-not all, of course, but too many-talented and brilliant people have been lost to private industry. Fortunately, the Auditor-General still has a great many talented, brilliant, hard-working and excellent people who are doing a fantastic job. But the upshot is that, if the Auditor-General cannot pay enough in a very competitive market, as well as losing senior people he will have difficulty in bringing in the best young brains. He must be able to pay them too. It is appropriate that the Parliament and the Government should address the question of providing adequate financial resources to the Auditor-General.

Finally, I wish to commend report No. 296 to the Government. I hope that it will accept and implement all the recommendations put forward in a totally bipartisan fashion by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts on behalf of the people and the Parliament.

DEBATE.TITLE: DEVELOPMENT OF MILITARY COMPLEX, GREEN HILLS, LIVERPOOL MILITARY AREA, NEW SOUTH WALES

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Approval of Work: Public Works Committee Act

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, it is expedient to carry out the following work which was referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works and on which the Committee has duly reported to Parliament: Development of a Military Police Complex at Green Hills, Liverpool Military Area, New South Wales.

The proposed work now before the House is for the construction of a military police complex at Green Hills near Holsworthy. The complex will provide new living and working accommodation for several military police units currently housed in substandard accommodation at Ingleburn. These military police units include a special investigation branch, a military corrective establishment and a military police school.

The existing military police complex at Ingleburn is spread over an area of 30 hectares and comprises more than 80 mainly weatherboard buildings. Most of these date from World War II and can no longer be economically maintained or renovated. The poor standard of these current facilities as well as their dispersed layout has an adverse effect on the training, morale and operational effectiveness of the various military police units.

The proposed complex at Green Hills will provide modern and efficient facilities. It will comprise four main building groups arranged around a parade ground. There is a centralisation and sharing of some facilities; however the planning has also taken into account that four distinct units will be stationed at the complex. Each unit has its own character and its own range of functions, and reports to different commands within the Army.

New facilities to be provided for the various units will include, firstly, headquarters and administrative offices; secondly, operational and training areas; and, thirdly, a separate secure compound for the military corrective establishment, including cell blocks, its own parade ground and recreation facilities.

There will be a sharing of common use facilities, such as a mess and canteen; living-in accommodation for a total of 40 students and 20 staff, and sports facilities. The estimated cost of the proposal as recommended by the Committee is $12.3m at May 1988 prices. This cost, updated to March 1989 prices, is now $13.17m. So, subject to the approval of the House to proceed, we intend to call tenders in mid-1989. Construction of the facilities is expected to be complete by early 1992. During this construction period, the on-site work force should peak at about 60 persons. I thank the Public Works Committee and its chairperson for their consideration and support for this proposal. I commend the motion to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Downer Mr A.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition will support this motion. It is important for the Public Works Committee, when examining proposed projects of this kind, to look carefully at their construction costs. It is difficult for the Parliament to know whether the Government's public works program is proceeding in the most efficient way. I have often argued on this side of the House that much greater use should be made by the Government of the private subcontracting system. It is important that this point is continually emphasised. I would like the Public Works Committee at some stage to take out a general reference looking at the totality of the Government's practices regarding construction projects of this kind. In the past the Government has been taking on private sector builders to proceed with the projects. We would like to see the subcontracting system operate in the public sector as it operates in the private residential market.

SPEECH.PARA: When the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr West) claims that that is what the Government does it is to misunderstand the way that the totality of the building industry works. As the Minister points out, these projects are put to the private sector under tender. This is an important point. It is alleged that at present only between 30 and 40 per cent of all Commonwealth expenditure projects worth more than $2,000 are being gazetted. That is a major problem. It is not an exclusive reflection on the Minister who has brought this project before the House; it is a reflection on the whole of the Ministry. It is a matter that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) needs to investigate quickly. If between 30 and 40 per cent of all such projects pursued by this Government are not gazetted, many small businesses in this country are missing out on the opportunity of tendering for government business. That is a serious matter. It is a criticism that comes, not only from the small business community, but from the broader business community. It is a reflection on Ministers' inept administration of their departments in this important area.

But, as I said, the Opposition supports this motion. We hope that the military police complex at Green Hills in the Liverpool military area will go ahead successfully and contribute to the efficiency and welfare of the military police in the Australian Defence Force.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 3) 1988-89[COGNATE BILLS:APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 4) 1988-89APPROPRIATION (PARLIAMENTARY DEPARTMENTS) BILL (No. 2) 1988-89]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 8 March, on motion by Mr Duncan:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that it is the wish of the House to debate the Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 1988-89 concurrently with Orders of the Day Nos 3 and 4, the Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 1988-89 and Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2) 1988-89. There being no objection, the Chair will allow that course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hewson Dr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity of leading the debate on the second reading of this package of Appropriation Bills-Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 1988-89, Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 1988-89 and Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2) 1988-89. The Opposition will be supporting the Bills as they are Budget Bills but I foreshadow that I will move an amendment at the end of my remarks commenting on the extent of the Government's economic mismanagement. The purpose of these Bills traditionally has been to meet essential and unavoidable expenditures additional to the appropriations made for the current financial year under Appropriation Acts Nos 1 and 2 and the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Act. These appropriations are usually required to meet commitments that have been approved by the Government since the Budget as well as requirements of an ongoing nature. There are a number of reasons why this might occur, but the principal factors underlying the requirements are usually some unavoidable cost and price increases or other parameter changes that have occurred since the Budget.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bills total additional gross appropriations of $683.9m. There is also a figure of $425.7m of savings, giving a net increase in appropriations for the year of $217.8m in expenditures, which is roughly 0.3 per cent of the total amount of estimated outlays for this year. Whilst this tends to be a fairly traditional procedure in the course of any financial year, there are some interesting points in regard to these additional appropriations which I am sure will be taken up by many of my colleagues in this debate.

I would like to make one or two general comments. Firstly, I draw attention to the fact that the savings of $425m-odd that are identified are not really substantial savings. In many cases they are deferrals, as distinct from formal cuts. In that sense they are indicative of what has become an increasing expenditure mode on the part of this Government. The Government has made much of the fact that it has set out to restrain the size of the Commonwealth public sector and to cut its own expenditure. But, as is the way these things are normally produced and misrepresented by the Treasurer (Mr Keating), the extent of any restraint has generally been exaggerated.

In recent experience, for example, there was a significant shift to an expenditure increasing mode in the last Budget, to which these appropriations relate. Over and above last year's May statement the Government announced a net increase of expenditure of some $400m. On a couple of recent occasions in the media and elsewhere the Treasurer has promised to increase expenditure further in the context of next week's economic statement which, as we have just heard, is to be brought down in this House on 12 April.

It is important when we look at the Appropriation Bills to attempt to provide some sort of background to these additional appropriations. We are helped in this regard by the recent release of the December quarter national accounts which, to my mind, confirm quite simply and quite dramatically the extent of the Government's economic mismanagement. In simple terms they show an overheated economy with a worsening balance of payments and inflation problem. This should not be treated as lightly as it has been by the Treasurer and other economic Ministers in recent months.

The key points of the national accounts data that were released on 3 April were several. Firstly, there is clear evidence that demand is rapidly outstripping supply. Demand has actually grown through 1988 by about 8.2 per cent. Production, on the other hand, has grown by only about 4.2 per cent-a 4 per cent gap between demand and supply. Not surprisingly therefore there has been a significant increase in imports. We are told that imports have gone up by about 21 per cent in the year 1988 at a time when our exports have actually fallen by about one per cent. So there is a direct and a very important link between the extent of the domestic overheating of the economy or imports and the balance of payments. Much of the overheating, I would suggest, as I have done on previous occasions, is the direct responsibility of the Treasurer's tending to play politics with interest rates and monetary policy, as was the case throughout 1987 and into early 1988 on top of what internationally was a commodity price boom for us and with the lingering effects of the 1985 and 1986 devaluations to boot.

Any first year economics student would say that if that configuration of factors is put together-the Minister for Land Transport and Shipping Support (Mr Robert Brown), who is at the table, has nodded in confirmation-we should not be surprised if the economy overheats dramatically. That is precisely what we have evidenced in the 8 per cent growth in demand in the course of last year against increasing supply constraints. Not surprisingly we have had a substantial increase in the magnitude of our balance of payments problem.

As I said, the Treasurer is directly responsible for that overheating. He started the process by forcing interest rates down prior to the July 1987 election and again in the lead-up to the New South Wales State election in the latter part of 1987 until that election took place in mid-March of 1988. That desire to drive interest rates down is now coming home to haunt him and the Government in terms of the magnitude of the balance of payments problem and in the acceleration of inflationary pressures which were also clearly evidenced in last week's national accounts which showed the gross domestic product deflator, which in the past has been one of the Treasury's preferred measures of overall inflationary forces in this country, growing at 9.1 per cent through the calendar year 1988. So there has been an overheated economy, demand outstripping supply, sucking in imports, underwriting a rapid expansion of inflationary forces, and all in a lead-up to a statement next week which promises to be even more stimulatory and expansionary in an already dramatically overheated economy.

It is interesting to put some interpretation on those fairly stark pieces of economic data. I think probably one of the most authoritative and honest assessments of our recent economic performance in this country has been offered by the Governor of the Reserve Bank in recent days. I suggest to this House that the honesty and openness of the Governor stand in very sharp contrast to the views that, up until that stage, had been put by the Treasurer. The extent of the disinformation that has been practised by this Government in relation to economic developments is nothing short of staggering. I think that the Governor's honesty should be emphasised and particular attention should be drawn to it.
However, I found it interesting earlier this week when the Treasurer was challenged about the Governor's remarks that he made the following statement-I quote from Hansard of 4 April:
The fact is that things the Governor said last week are entirely in accordance with policy. I endorse everything that he said last week, which the Governor well knows.

I think it would be interesting to go through some of the Governor's remarks against the background of the Treasurer's comment just to see the extent to which the Treasurer has now come in endorsing that much more open and honest assessment of the parlous state of our economic circumstances. The Governor made a number of key points in his address to the Businessman of the Year presentation of 29 March at the Regent Hotel in Sydney. The first point is as follows:
Growth has been so rapid as to be seriously under-estimated by the policy makers.

There should not be any doubt about that in the sense that most of the major growth-related statistics in this country are outstripping Budget time and earlier expectations as announced by the Treasurer. It is important. The Government underestimated growth. The Governor goes on to say:
Economic policies were designed for a less exuberant situation.

I emphasise that the Treasurer now agrees with this. Economic policies were designed for a less exuberant situation. That is, his economic policies are wrong. They are quite inappropriate to the dramatically overheated Australian economy that is before us at present. The Governor goes on to point out that while there are some positive features in unexpectedly rapid growth, he issues a sharp warning:
. . . an over-blown economy is just unsustainable.

We do not hear that sort of objective, open comment on the part of the Treasurer-an overblown economy like ours being described by the Governor of the Reserve Bank as just unsustainable. The Governor goes on:
In broad terms, we could say that the unexpectedly powerful economic growth has cost us a year in the strategy for winding down price increases and improving the balance of payments.

It is interesting that the Governor of the Reserve Bank has taken that opportunity to draw attention to the fact that this Government has not displayed any sense of urgency; in fact, it has displayed an alarming sense of complacency about the magnitude of the problems before us and the extent to which its policies have fallen off the pace. We have had an enormous amount of trouble getting the Treasurer to tell us something about his revised Budget estimates for this year. The Budget estimate for the current account deficit is now looking like coming in at about $14 1/2 billion or $15 billion. Indeed, implicit in the Governor's speech was an estimate of $14 1/2 billion for the current account deficit this year, dramatically above the $9.5 billion current account deficit that was forecast by the Treasurer in the Budget last August. Similarly, the inflation rate was expected by the Treasurer to fall to 4 1/2 per cent this year. But the national accounts tell us that the broad measures of inflation, in the year to December last, was running at a bit over 9 per cent and we know that the consumer price index is somewhere between 7 1/2 per cent and 8 per cent. That process, the fact that economic management has been allowed to slip through the Treasurer's fingers, has cost us a year, the Governor says, in the strategy for winding down price increases and improving the balance of payments.

I am pleased to see, by implication of the Treasurer's remarks in the House earlier this week, that he accepts that he has lost at least a year in terms of winding down price increases and improving the balance of payments. The Governor took a very positive response having identified the magnitude of the problem. He then went on in his speech to pose the question: What is to be done? He stated:
We need do claw back lost territory-
that is an appropriate description of the Treasurer's performance in the last 12 or 18 months-
to bring spending and production into better balance.
. . . to damp down spending.
He points out, and I quote:
The policy setting has tightened, but are we doing enough, quickly enough? Will it work?

The Treasurer now spends most of his time, whenever he speaks in response to questions like that, with a standard pat answer saying, `Look, you don't have to worry, there is plenty of monetary adjustment in the pipeline. It is all working, everything is going to be fine'-what I have been calling the don't worry, be happy strategy. `Don't worry, things are going to come good. Don't worry, we have done enough policy adjustment. Don't worry, interest rates aren't going to go any higher. Don't worry, we have an investment boom'. And so he prattles on.

The Governor goes on to point out some very real reservations about the extent to which he is concerned that maybe it will not work, maybe there is not enough policy adjustment in the pipeline. To quote him quite explicitly:
Over the past month or so, there have been some tentative signs of moderation in the strength of demand.

That is all we have got-tentative signs. Nothing like that it is all in the pipeline, it is all happening, the runs are on the board and the sort of language the Treasurer uses-just tentative signs of moderation in the strength of demand. He warns:
It is too early to say that a downturn is at hand.

What does he mean here? He is raising the prospect quite explicitly that the Government has not done enough. Does the Treasurer really say that? Is the Treasurer really prepared to admit that he has not done enough, because that is the way I read what the Governor is saying. If he has not done enough in terms of the Government's economic strategy, there is an implicit suggestion that there will be more pain to come: even higher interest rates, which is the only instrument the Government has. To my mind, if it is too early to say that a downturn is at hand, it begs the question just how much further interest rates may have to go before the job is done-in the Governor's terms. Indeed, the Governor went on to say:
We will have to hold to the tougher policies until it is clear that results are on the board.

To my mind that suggests that not only do we now have very high interest rates by historical standards but there is a very real risk that they may go even higher and that they will stay higher quite a lot longer than anybody on the Government side has been prepared to come into this House and suggest up until this stage. The Governor issued a couple of other warnings. He said:
This might well entail further turbulence and take a bit longer than expected earlier.

He was admitting quite explicitly that the adjustment process could take quite a bit longer than expected and, presumably, than the Treasurer had been saying up until this week. The Governor also warned:
It is also important to realise-
this was, if anything, a direct statement for the Treasurer's benefit-
that we can't keep the economy in a permanent state of sedation in order to keep the current account and inflation in check.

He was really saying that the problem is not simply one of macropolicy adjustment. It will not be enough just to increase interest rates and hope that that will pull back domestic demand and reduce the pace of imports. There is another dimension to the problem that has not received sufficient attention by the Government. We must have additional policy adjustment at the microlevel. The Governor went on to say:
The longer-term objective is maximum non-inflationary growth. Cooling the economy-
that is, putting it into a state of sedation-
is an essential but not sufficient condition-

for the job to be done. The statement `an essential but not sufficient condition' for the job to be done is very important. Even though all the Government is doing at this stage is trying to get by with a sole reliance on monetary policy and higher interest rates, the Governor warned, firstly, that that will not be enough and, secondly, that it misses the whole dimension of the magnitude of the problem, namely, the extent of needed micro-economic reform. In his words:

We need to press on with more constructive policies-to switch investment growth into export and import-replacing industries, to save more to finance investment, to sustain our international competitiveness and to raise productivity.

Those are all words that Government spokesmen have offered on occasions, but I suggest that none understand them. They certainly do not understand the magnitude of the policy adjustment that is implied in those remarks.

Let me look at some of the areas where structural adjustment is required. What is the Government's policy on the labour market? The Government seeks more centralised wage determination, greater concentration of union power, more wage increases quite unrelated to productivity, and so on-quite the opposite of what will be required, in the Governor's words, `to sustain our international competitiveness and to raise our productivity'.

Similarly, very real issues in the area of protection need to be addressed and addressed at a much faster pace than this Government has been prepared to do so far. There is also a need to recognise that our tax system, and this is implicit in the Governor's comments, discriminates against savings, discourages investment and works to encourage consumption and debt. With the sort of country we have and the magnitude of our short and medium term problems, effectively we have precisely the wrong tax system. Over and above that there are a host of other specific areas that need to be addressed and on which the Government so far is devoid of any policy response-issues such as dealing with bulk land transport; the wharves; coastal shipping and cabotage; privatisation; and government sector efficiency. Those are all areas in which the Government is absolutely devoid of any practical or substantive response. The Government talks about it but, unfortunately, it has done very little.

Most of the time we are given further disinformation. The Treasurer does that constantly when he talks about the state of the economy and what he intends to do about the various elements of macropolicy and microreform. We are now getting it in terms of his inability to deliver the goods. The statement that is to be brought down on 12 April was to be, initially, a statement not only announcing the tax cuts and new expenditure measures and so on but one explicitly including a package of microreform measures. Yet just a few days ago the Treasurer told us that those measures will be pushed off to May or later months and left to individual announcements by other Ministers. The fact is that it is all too hard. There is no capacity on the part of the Government to address any of these issues. It is just shoving them off. Presumably it will shove them off past the middle of the year and the election.

The Prime Minister said recently that he had put privatisation back on the agenda. On that day a few weeks ago I was fascinated to hear The World Today report as I was travelling by car. A succession of Australian Labor Party people from around the country were interviewed and none had any idea that privatisation was back on the agenda. Some expressed a dedication to the view that they would reiterate their earlier position and vote against any significant moves by the Government on privatisation. Yet it is fundamentally one of the most important areas that need to be addressed in the area of microreform in order to achieve some of the things the Governor talked about when he referred to a constructive process-that is, his warning, `Cooling the economy is an essential but not sufficient condition'.

It seems that the process of disinformation by the Treasurer has absolutely no bounds. He is attempting, selectively, to rewrite history rather than address any of the issues. On occasions he attacks us for playing the man rather than the issue. He is a past master of playing the man and not the issue. Almost every time he opens his mouth in this House he attacks the man; he never addresses the issue. He will not debate anything. In my case, on every single occasion, except the first, he has refused to debate me at any time or anywhere.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is he afraid of?

—He knows that I know that he does not know what he is doing, I suggest. He is now busily trying to rewrite history. I will cite one example of that. Yesterday in Question Time the shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), asked him this question about monetary policy:

SPEECH.PARA: Why has the rate of growth in the money supply as measured by M3 and broad money accelerated in recent months when monetary policy has been tightened?

The Treasurer was not going to be bowled over by such a question, so he waffled on and filibustered-it went on for about a page and a half in Hansard-without any understanding of the way the process of monetary policy works in a deregulated environment. As I have said, he spent much of his time in that answer rewriting history. For example, he tried to paint the picture that we are now in a deregulated financial environment where quantitative restrictions have been abolished. He said:
They left with deregulation in 1983-84.

What a very selective memory he has. They actually left in June 1982, before the Hawke Government came to office. Similarly, he explained why he had abandoned monetary targeting in 1983-84. He actually abandoned monetary targeting at the end of January 1985 and it was that factor more than any other that precipitated the exchange rate crises of early 1985. The key part of his answer, and the one I wish to draw to the House's attention, was his classic explanation of how monetary policy works in a deregulated financial environment. He talked about money being `available at a price'. He said:
It means that monetary policy is still as effective-
there is no way that those two comments could be remotely linked; however, he seemed to find a way-
that is, the slowdown occurs but it occurs with a lag and there is some cushioning which comes with the operation of monetary policy in a deregulated environment via price.

I thank the Treasurer very much for such a clear and quite explicit explanation of the way monetary policy works. He showed an acute sensitivity in the House and letters to the editor of the Australian Financial Review and on a host of other occasions to the fact that the market is confused about the way monetary policy actually works in this country, and about the direction of his intentions for monetary policy and so on, yet he makes statements such as that I quoted. It is no wonder the market is totally confused. It shows that he has absolutely no idea how monetary policy works.

It was disturbing to read statements that the Treasurer made recently in relation to the Reserve Bank. He tried to take full credit for everything the Reserve Bank does. He said, `They do what I say, I can assure you of that. That you can put your money on'. That should make us all sleep at night! It should make us all have a warm inner glow! Here is a guy with no idea of what he should be doing with monetary policy telling us not to worry because the Reserve Bank does what it is told when it comes to monetary policy. He has absolutely no idea how monetary policy works in a deregulated financial environment.

The matter of most concern to me is the extent to which the Treasurer has focused on the process of disinformation throughout the last 12 or 18 months as his last two Budget strategies have slipped dramatically into tatters. He has never expressed with the same degree of clarity as the Governor the magnitude of the problems and the nature of the policy responses that are required. He has never set down an alternative set of forecasts to those that are so dramatically off track. Indeed, they were already dramatically off-track before half of this financial year had passed. He refuses to debate most of us on relevant economic issues. He prefers to play the man rather than to debate the issue or debate alternative policy responses.
It is against that background that I move my amendment in the form in which it has been circulated in my name. I move:
That all words after `That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House notes that:

(1) budget estimates put Commonwealth Government outlays at over a quarter of Australia's GDP, and that this is funded by revenue collection that has made this the highest taxing Government in the post-war history of Australia;
(2) the Government's budget strategy is in tatters with its key forecasts on inflation and the balance of payments wildly off-track;

(3) the Government is locked into a strategy of sole reliance on monetary policy and high interest rates to bring the economy back on track with the result that home loan interest rates are now at their highest level in Australia's history; and

(4) the process of micro-economic reform has stalled with the Government either stopping or delaying much needed structural policies which are crucial if Australia is to increase productivity and to reduce its unsustainably high level of foreign debt.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the amendment seconded?
—I second the amendment and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Snow Mr J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the Appropriation Bills and oppose the amendment to the motion for the second reading of Appropriation Bill (No. 3). It is a privilege to follow the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson) but his amendment is amazing. In the first paragraph of his amendment he says that Budget estimates put Commonwealth Government outlays at over a quarter of Australia's gross domestic product (GDP). He does not say that the outlays have dropped from about 30 per cent of Australia's GDP to about 25 per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: The third paragraph of the amendment refers to the Government being locked into a strategy of sole reliance on monetary policy. The Opposition relies on nothing and it will not say what its policies are, whether with respect to taxation or spending cuts. The Opposition will not make its policy clear. In the past, it has made it fairly clear that it would get rid of ceilings on interest rates. It has also made it clear that it is opposed to wage and salary increases. Therefore, I guess the Opposition's policy would be going in the direction of lower wages, lower spending on important areas like education, the environment, pensioners, health and schools and no ceiling on interest rates.

The honourable member for Wentworth then spoke about delaying much needed structural policies. We needed those structural policies in the seven years between 1975 and the end of 1982. At last, structural policies are starting to take effect in Australia. They are being administered by a range of departments, not the least of which is the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce. It looks to me that it is fairly easy to make the choice between the parties offering themselves to the people in the next election, whenever it comes. It is easy to make the choice because, although it is not clear what the Opposition's policies are, it is a choice between confusion and a sound economic direction. There is confusion about whether we will get the dry economic policies, the words of the Opposition front bench, or a repeat of the soft decisions between 1975 and 1983. There is a choice between that confusing presentation and a government that has shown itself to be made up of a group of sound economic managers determined to make hard decisions.

The honourable member for Wentworth once again, as he always has, offered us a policy of scorched earth. He wants to cut essential spending, but will not tell us where. He will not tell us whether the spending is to be cut in the area of pensions, veterans' benefits, schools or health. We know from the record of the newly-elected Greiner Government in New South Wales that the very people for whom the Liberal Party indicated sympathy were those it hit when it was elected. The Opposition talks about having no controls on interest rates. If there were no controls, interest rates would go higher. That would smash business activity in Australia and cause a rise in unemployment.

We heard today the policy of a silent member of a team that was in office for many years. The Fraser-Howard Budgets had the silent member, the honourable member for Wentworth, behind them helping to make policy. The members of that team did not have the courage to change the financial structure of Australia or the markets of Australia. They could not deregulate the financial system; they could not float the exchange rate; and they could not get together a decent monetary policy or a coherent fiscal policy. The people who vetoed them are still there. They are in the corner and they are there behind them. These are the parties that gave us double digit inflation, a recession and high unemployment. They preached the gospel of hard decisions but they practised the gospel of soft decisions. It is easy for them to talk in opposition, but what will they do in government?

Honourable members opposite have tried to tell us that they have toughened up. If we look at their policies we find confusion. They did not know where to be soft; now they do not know where to be hard. What they have said is that they will squeeze wage and salary earners. If they do not mean what they say, we will get more of what they gave us when in government-wage squeezes followed by wage blow-outs. If they give us what they say, it will be even worse because they are talking about having no awards. Wages will be negotiated in small businesses and awards will be done away with. Honourable members should think about how that would affect wage and salary earners in the country areas in Australia, in particular. We should consider how that would affect people in a small country town who do not really have a big choice of jobs. Someone with an important job in the town may have a spouse and need extra to keep the family income up. Opposition members appear to be trying to give people a choice of having no job at all or receiving $4 an hour, which some people in the United States receive. There has been some deregulation of the labour market in the United States. That is not for Australia. People are not commodities on a shelf; they are human beings who need food. They have children to feed and educate and need to maintain shelter. The Liberal and National parties are saying that the wage and salary earners of Australia are commodities or goods which can be bargained for, sold to the lowest bidder and, if unsold, thrown on the scrapheap of unemployment.

The Opposition's policy of labour market deregulation is all about bringing people back to the breadline. Let those who fall for the Liberal and National parties' crocodile tears about the plight of wage and salary earners and about family incomes, heed the words which they have used in this institution. They have approved one wage increase out of the past 20. That would have given us average weekly earnings 34 per cent lower than they are now.

The Opposition has said, `No awards for wages and conditions of people in small businesses'. Most small businesses are ethical. Most small businesses want to pay what is regarded as a correct wage. What the coalition is saying is that there will be no guide for the ethical small business area. The few unethical small businesses will be able to take advantage of there being no award. Let those members of Parliament who want deregulation of the labour market and who want people to bargain with their bosses go out and bargain with their bosses; the taxpayers of Australia. We each have 70,000-odd electors. I would not like their chances.

The Australian Government has helped 1.27 million people, extra wage and salary earners, off the dole queues, out of a life of boredom, out of a life of poverty, and into employment. The Government has also seen some extraordinary improvements in a wide range of areas. In relation to business investment, with the previous Government we saw one of the biggest failures of economic policy over the last 40 years. We have seen one of the largest investment phases since 1948. We have seen demand outstrip supply. If there is any problem, it is the fact that we cannot keep up with growing business. Public sector borrowing would be the same size as it was in 1973, in spite of what the honourable member for Wentworth said. We are going to have lower Government spending, Government outlays are down to 25 per cent of gross domestic product from the peak of 30 per cent. We have done pretty well.

I would like to discuss some of the implications of the decisions made by the Federal Government for the electorate of Eden-Monaro. First, let us look at Queanbeyan, a town not far from here whose fortunes are related to Canberra. The feature since 1983 has been that development has been planned in a much more coordinated fashion. Private enterprise has been brought in to strengthen Canberra's economic base. Canberra is a company town and has always been a company town but it is good to see national organisations coming into Canberra and setting up here so that they can talk to government and to one another.

There has been planned development in construction. Parliament House has supplied many jobs to Queanbeyan people and to people in the area around Yass, Bungendore, Captains Flat and Sutton. Many jobs have been supplied to those people through the guided development which has taken place. This development includes the High Court, Parliament House and the Australian National Gallery and we hope it will include a national museum. I impress on the Government the need to plan for a national museum at the appropriate time so that we can maintain employment, particularly in the construction sector. We do not want to return to the Fraser days when Canberra went right down; we lost trades people to other areas of Australia and it took a long time for us to get them back when we needed them.

In Queanbeyan we have had some vast improvements, not only from the setting up by the Federal and State governments of local offices, but also in the number of private enterprise firms, factories and others, who have been prepared to set up there. The major area team for social security was set up recently, thereby filling a four-storey office which had been left empty since 1975. The Wran-Unsworth governments put in offices for the Valuer-General and for soil conservation. A branch of the State Government Insurance Office has set up in the new Riverside Plaza in Queanbeyan. We have offices for forestry and family and community services. Combined with private enterprise, we have a strong economy in the Queanbeyan, Yarrowlumla Shire and Yass Shire areas. Of course, accommodation is not keeping up. This is a challenge for private enterprise and for the New South Wales Government and local government as they look at the boundaries.

We have seen changes in the social strata. Unemployment has gone down from over 10 per cent in 1983 to less than half of that figure now. Women, who then wanted work, could not get it and had never had jobs now have them. People were fooled in 1975. People were fooled in 1988 before the State election. People here told me that they voted for the present State Government and have now had their rents in Housing Commission homes put up, in some cases by 30 to 40 per cent. I can remember people saying to me, when I doorknocked in Eden-Monaro and Queanbeyan in 1975, `If I want to keep my job, I will vote for Fraser'. I doorknocked the same places in 1977 and the people were gone from the town; there were empty offices, empty homes, empty flats.

The Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones) was in the House a little while ago. I am sorry he is not here now to hear me pay tribute to him, and to his predecessors, Mr Hurford and the present Minister for Administrative Services (Mr West), for the fact that the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation has had its losses turned into profits. The Corporation's role as an internationally recognised firm of consultants and engineers was reversed under the Fraser-Howard Budgets when we saw many opportunities lost overseas. Yesterday we saw and heard the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business strengthen the changes that were made by his predecessors. Losses have been turned into profits. The Liberal object of privatisation of the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation has been rejected.

In the Bombala, Nimmitabel and Eden areas we have seen a courageous decision by the Government on behalf of the timber industry. The Government has decided to renew the woodchip export licence so that it can proceed in partnership with the very important sawmilling sector. May I say that the people who came to me with representations were not the woodchip export people, but the sawmillers themselves who saw the need for a strong partnership between the sawmilling industry and wood chipping for export in an environmentally sensitive way. I pay tribute to the Government for taking into account important environmental concerns when it renewed that licence.

In the Snowy Mountains and on the south-east coast, from Jindabyne to Merimbula, Narooma, Bermagui, Ulladulla and Braidwood we have seen an amazing turnaround in tourism over the last three or four years. Local tourist offices and local government have tapped into the very important work being done overseas by the Federal Government in tourist promotion. We have also seen a change in attitude in those areas. Restaurateurs are no longer prepared to take their staff from the street. People are interested in making a career in the hospitality industry. I have been delighted to present certificates in a wide range of places throughout the electorate to people who have taken advantage of training systems which have been evolved through the cooperation of the Commonwealth Employment Service with organisations like the Retail Traders Association and local technical and further education colleges. Through these training systems we can encourage people to learn how to service the public properly and to consider their jobs as a career; a career which may take them into great opportunities in employment, or which may take them into businesses of their own.

I recall that in the last area where I presented certificates I was able to learn a fast track method of bed making. It was very interesting to see how people took pride in what was once regarded as a menial task. They saw it as a way of gaining fulfilment and satisfaction in their present employment, and of gaining hope for future employment. Important decisions need to be made in all those areas along the south coast and in the Snowy Mountains about zoning and about planning to cater for the people who are now there. But we should not just think of the people in the future; we should also think of those who are living there now and who need to be comfortable.

Some of the greatest changes effected by the Hawke Administration have been in the area of television and radio. It is good to see some honourable members here whose areas will very much be affected by aggregation. I refer to my friend and colleague the honourable member for Grey (Mr O'Neil) and a colleague on the other side, the honourable member for Fairfax (Mr Adermann). Their constituents who could receive no television or radio service at all are now receiving those services, as they now do also in the Eden-Monaro area. The south-east region was the beginning of television aggregation. It is up and running, it is working, and people have a better choice. They might want to watch Australian rules or soccer or rugby league. At last they will have a choice of commercial stations. Bombala, Jindabyne and Thredbo had no television at all when the Hawke Government was elected. Now, following many public meetings, agitation, and cooperation from Capital Television, the Australian Broadcasting Corporation and the then Department of Communications, ABC radio and commercial television services have been brought in to those areas. Radio 2CN could not be heard in the region around Canberra; now it can be. That follows strong representations to me from the New South Wales Farmers Association. Now farmers can have a choice of radio.

Formerly 2CN and 2CY in Canberra were required to broadcast Parliament. Now there is a separate station for that. Parliament has its own station and people have a choice of three national radio stations. Radio 2XL had problems in the Snowy Mountains and in Bombala. It has applications in now which I am confident will be approved. Radio 2EC had problems in Narooma; now there is a transmitter which enables Narooma people to hear that radio station properly. Many people could not hear it at all. EAR FM is a great community radio station. The ABC was lacking such a station for many years but that station now broadcasts to local people. It has a broad spectrum of listeners because it is prepared to have a broad spectrum of broadcasters, including pensioners, schools, Aborigines and business people. It is to be congratulated. Soon another 20,000 people who could not receive the ABC will be able to receive it. The area around Tomerong is already getting it, and from Tomerong to areas between Nowra and Batemans Bay. Soon the Eurobodalla Shire and the Bombala Shire will get it and it is hoped that there will be an improvement in Merimbula.

A great choice has come to the people of this area as a result of television aggregation. There are two new commercial stations in the vast areas of my electorate. It is proposed to transmit commercial stations, as well as the ABC, to Captains Flat. The Special Broadcasting Service will be available for Braidwood people, as well as three new commercial stations, and three commercial stations will be available to the people on the south-east coast, Cooma and the Monaro. Most people in Eden-Monaro now have better television and radio services because they have a wider choice. This is a first for Australia and congratulations must go to the Department of Transport and Communications and a wide range of interest groups.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aldred Mr K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the chance to speak on the Appropriation Bills as it presents an opportunity to bring yet again certain grave matters to the attention of the Australian people. They are matters the Hawke Government has been secretive about and certainly less than frank. For some considerable time I have been warning of the deteriorating position of the instrumentalities responsible for the protection of our national security. In large part this is due to a gross lack of resources provided to our counterintelligence services and an explosion in the Soviet bloc presence, both permanent and temporary, in Australia. The Australian Security Intelligence Organisation (ASIO), in its latest report to Parliament, said:

SPEECH.PARA: On the basis of its investigations in 1987-88, ASIO concluded that the level of activity and effectiveness of some foreign intelligence services in Australia is higher than previously assessed.
ASIO also said:

. . . several official and trade representations in Australia include their share of professional intelligence officers and/or co-optees. These officers are as active here as anywhere else in working to collect political, technical and other information . . .

Let me list just some of the existing Soviet bloc official and trade representations in Australia. The Soviets themselves have an embassy and trade office in Canberra. In Sydney they have a large consulate in Woollahra, a trade office in Bondi Junction, an Aeroflot office in the city, a tractor facility in Liverpool and various offices in the city area dealing in wool and wheat. In the last three years they have also established a trade office in North Melbourne. The Bulgarians, renowned for often acting on behalf of the Soviets in clandestine operations, have a consulate and separate trade office in Sydney. The East Germans have an embassy in Canberra and a consulate in Melbourne. The Czechoslovakians have an embassy in Canberra and a consulate in Sydney. The Hungarian presence is manifested in an embassy in Canberra and a consulate and a trade office in Sydney. Finally, the Romanians have a consulate located in Sydney's Bondi. This is quite an impressive list in a country of only 16 million people.

As I have said on many previous occasions, our counterintelligence services, with their existing resources, are not able to monitor fully the activities of the personnel working from these premises. Yet despite this fact, the Hawke Government is about to allow the Soviet Union to establish further consulates in Melbourne, Hobart and Perth, under the consular agreement currently being finalised. The Soviet's explanation for wanting to expand the number of their official residencies in Australia is: to service the impending arrival of the Soviet fishing fleet, to organise the Aeroflot charters that the Hawke Government will soon be allowing to fly into Australia, and to provide consular services as part of the human contacts agreement also being finalised by this Government. Negotiation on all four of these initiatives has been undertaken, in large part, by Mr Michael Costello, an acting deputy secretary at the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade.

Should all of these agreements come to fruition, as the Government seems to think they will, then the national security implications for Australia are almost too horrific to contemplate. The Government is well aware that the Soviet Union is in the practice of using consular posts as a cover for intelligence officers. They are also aware that the volume and dispersion of Soviet intelligence officers that could be placed in Australia as a result of the consular agreement, the fishing deal and the associated landing rights for Aeroflot would simply overwhelm the already overburdened and under-resourced counterintelligence services of our country. Mr Valeriy Zemskov may have left Australia, but his legacy lives on. One of his objectives was the New Zealandisation of Australia, and with the implementation of the agreements I have referred to-agreements in which he played a pivotal role for the Soviet Union-that objective will be brought all the more closer to success.

Undoubtedly, the significant increase in Soviet activity in Australia and our region in general began with President Gorbachev's Vladivostok speech in 1986. It was further spurred along by Prime Minister Hawke's later comments in Singapore, comments that resulted in stern words from Singapore's Prime Minister, Mr Lee Kuan Yew, and more than a few raised eyebrows throughout the Association of South East Asian Nations.

For the first time in its history the KGB is being subjected to public scrutiny through the Soviet media. This is undoubtedly a result of Gorbachev's policies of glasnost and perestroika. This development has led some Western commentators to adopt the view that this is an attempt by President Gorbachev to weaken the KGB's enormous power. However, this is true in part and in part only. The only facets of the KGB's operations that are being scrutinised are its internal functions, not its external espionage function.

In the hype surrounding Gorbachev's glasnost and perestroika campaigns, it should not be forgotten that his patron for many years was the late head of the Soviet Union and former long serving head of the KGB, Mr Yuri Andropov. Sources familiar with the Soviet Union, and in particular the KGB, have told me that Gorbachev is attempting to separate the KGB's internal police function from its overseas espionage function and is using perestroika as a vehicle to do this. Gorbachev's intention is to change the KGB into an agency dedicated to gathering foreign intelligence, mirroring the way in which the American Central Intelligence Agency is set up. I am informed that this intention was in fact flagged to Washington by the Kremlin late last year. Given this little known fact, it is hardly surprising that the new KGB Chairman, Colonel-General Kryuchkov, is a foreign operations specialist. If Gorbachev succeeds in his efforts, it is expected that the new revamped KGB will be far more effective than it currently is.

The KGB and Soviet military intelligence, the GRU, have greatly expanded their technological spying against Western nations through a huge increase in their signals intelligence, or SIGINT, capacity, and this is now being matched by an increase in agent operations in response to a recent call by Colonel-General Kryuchkov for increased activities abroad. Western intelligence agencies believe that Australia and its surrounding region are now considered by the Kremlin to be a priority target. The importance of Australia to the Soviet Union was amply demonstrated by the Soviet's decision to post Mr Zemskov to Canberra. Zemskov was a very senior KGB officer. In fact, he was the highest ranking KGB officer ever sent to this part of the world.

Further evidence of an increasing level of Soviet interest in our region was the recent trip through the South Pacific by the Soviet Ambassador, Dr Samoteikin. This was a trip obviously designed to drum up yet more fishing agreements in the region. Indeed, my colleague the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) this very week joined me in slamming the Government for jeopardising our national security and in condemning the Soviets for peddling lies throughout the region. The recent ASIO annual report also said:
While Australia has no reputation as a high technology leader to attract espionage in that field, there are pockets of interest.
It went on to say:

Through various agreements and treaties of cooperation Australia is privy to sensitive information supplied by various other countries. With this access comes a very great responsibility to protect the information supplied.

The House may recall the recent publicity given to comments by the Head of the Australian Defence Staff in Washington, Air Vice-Marshal Barry Gration, concerning United States Government apprehension about giving Australia access to specialised and highly sensitive equipment. I can tell the House that the initial reluctance of the United States to provide that equipment was because the Pentagon and the State Department had become extremely concerned about the security situation in Australia. As we know, the matter was finally resolved in Australia's favour. However, I am told that the security situation in Australia, particularly as it affects American-provided equipment and intelligence, will be on the agenda when the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) visits Washington some time in June.

I now wish to deal with some specific effects of the current swag of agreements this Government is negotiating with the Soviet Union. Firstly, I want to address the misconception the Prime Minister and other senior Ministers have nurtured concerning the fishing and Aeroflot proposals. On numerous occasions, as you will well recall, Mr Deputy Speaker, we have heard Ministers say that the agreements are no different from similar agreements the Soviets have with the United States. They have gone on to say that if the United States can handle the security problems, so can we in Australia. The Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) has attained a particularly high point of stupidity on this matter.

The truth of the matter, however, is somewhat different from the utterances of Labor Ministers. To begin with, the Americans do not-I repeat, do not-allow Aeroflot to fly charter flights into the United States for crew changeovers because they consider the security risk too great. Furthermore, the Americans were forced to reduce and restrict access to the number of ports the Soviet fishing fleet could use, due to the fact that American counterintelligence could not adequately contain the hostile intelligence activities associated with the Soviet fishing fleet. Indeed, United States and Canadian intelligence sources have estimated that 50 to 75 overt commercial fishing vessels operating off their Atlantic coasts are engaged in SIGINT and other intelligence operations.

Australia has not been excluded from the attentions of Soviet spy trawlers. In June 1981 the then flagship of the Australian fleet, HMAS Melbourne, was shadowed as it passed through the South China Sea on passage from Hong Kong to Singapore. Soviet vessels have been seen on a regular basis cruising off our coast, particularly during the previous Kangaroo military exercises held in northern Australia. Their main aim is to collect SIGINT data. I can also tell the House that the Department of Defence, in planning for this year's Operation Kangaroo, has drawn up contingency plans to deal with an expected deployment of Soviet spy vessels to monitor the operation and collect signals intelligence. The Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) will be able to verify this. He will also be able to verify that his Department is extremely concerned that its everyday operations around the country will be subject to almost daily monitoring by the Soviets if the fishing and Aeroflot proposals get the go-ahead.

Secondly, in relation to the consular agreement, I call on the Government to make a clear, concise and frank statement informing the Australian public of just what this involves: that is, how many more Soviets will be allowed into the country to stage the consulates; will they be allowed to purchase real estate for their consulates; and, if so, will they be allowed to select the prime intelligence collecting sites in Melbourne, Perth and Hobart, as they have done already in Canberra for their new embassy? Furthermore, will the Government be allocating more resources to our counterintelligence services to deal with the hugely expanded Soviet presence? Finally, the Government might also like to let us know whether it intends to reopen the now closed ASIO office in Hobart to monitor the Soviet consulate proposed for that city. Opposition to the attempts by the Soviet Union to coerce Australia into signing a fishing and Aeroflot deal does not reside only on this side of the House. On 17 October last year during a debate on Appropriation Bill (No. 1) the Australian Labor Party member for Herbert (Mr Lindsay) outlined many good reasons to reject the proposals.

I call on the Government to explain fully what it intends to do in relation to all of the Soviet proposals I have referred to. Does it intend capitulating to the pressure being exerted by the Soviet Union and the friends Mr Zemskov left behind, or does it intend adopting the only sensible course of action, that is, rejecting the proposals because of the enormous threats posed to our national security?

The Government's inept handling of these important matters is reflected in the totally inept handling of two freedom of information (FOI) requests I have submitted to the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. The first of the two requests deals with the proposed Soviet fishing and Aeroflot agreement. Due to departmental incompetence, this request is now the subject of an appeal by me to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal (AAT). A number of preliminary hearings have already been conducted by the AAT and I expect a full hearing to commence in the near future, at which I hope to obtain a great number of the documents that are currently being withheld from me.

The second of my FOI requests deals with Mr Valeriy Zemskov and his activities in Australia. Once again, I can only describe Foreign Affairs' handling of my FOI request as totally incompetent. The Department has now had my Zemskov request for 72 days, yet it remains unserviced despite the Freedom of Information Act requiring a response within 30 days. As a result, I will be lodging another appeal with the AAT tomorrow. In conclusion, I seek leave to table a copy of my FOI request concerning Mr Zemskov.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I call the honourable member for Oxley, I remind the House that the honourable member is about to give his maiden speech. I ask the House to extend to him the usual courtesies. I point out that the Deputy Speaker wishes to be in the chair during the honourable member's maiden speech.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Mr L.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In this my first speech in the Parliament could I say what an honour it is to be the first member of the House of Representatives to have taken the oath of allegiance in this new and permanent home of the Parliament of Australia. This place in history I share with the people of the Oxley electorate and I take this opportunity to thank those people for having the trust and confidence to elect me as their representative in the Federal Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: The Oxley electorate, with a population of approximately 102,000 people, is based on the provincial city of Ipswich, the oldest provincial city in Queensland, and takes in the surrounding urban and rural areas of the Brisbane Valley up to Esk in the north. The area has historical significance, being one of the earliest areas settled in Queensland, and as a result Ipswich grew very fast, with a strong economy based on agriculture, coal mining and at the time a very busy river port. A legacy of this early prosperity is a magnificent collection of historic buildings, many of which are listed by the National Trust. This, combined with the many recreational reserves in nearby areas, makes the area an attractive destination for tourists and day visitors from neighbouring centres. The city of Ipswich has also recently undergone a major redevelopment of its city heart which has re-established its position as a retailing centre.

No-one is elected to this House without a lot of effort and hard work by supporters, friends and family. I wish to thank all those people who, through their help and assistance, enabled me to be elected to Parliament. In particular I thank my wife Anne and our four sons for all their support and my mother and father, who are able to be in the gallery today.

To be able to serve my fellow Australians in Parliament is a responsibility I do not take lightly because I am fully aware of the effect the decisions we are called on to make have on the lives of the people we represent. The power entrusted to elected representatives should be respected by those people. I was reminded recently by a church leader of President Bush's inaugural address in which his first act was to offer a prayer. In that prayer President Bush said:
Use power to help people-for we are given power not to advance our own purposes nor to make a great show in the world, nor a name. There is but one just use of power, and it is to serve people.

This is a very meaningful and powerful statement and can be applied to any area where people are in positions of power. Whether it be in business, community groups or government, the same principle should apply.

The revelations which arose from the Fitzgerald inquiry in my home State of Queensland are a perfect example of situations where people placed in positions of power have abused that trust. This abuse has led to a disrespect by the community of elected representatives and people appointed to positions of authority. Although it is only a minority of people that have betrayed the trust that goes with the power they have been given, sadly innocent trustworthy people in those professions are the victims of that abuse of power.
