It will take a complete new administration to rectify the position in Queensland and it will be the historic opportunity for the people of Queensland later this year to correct the situation in that State.

The trust people place in governments is enormous and I am extremely pleased to come to this place as a member of a government that has a proven record of using the power vested in it to serve the best interests of the people of this great nation of ours. It is a government that, despite tough times, has given priority to the people who need the most help by showing care and concern for the poor and disadvantaged. It is a government that is committed to a fair and equitable distribution of wealth by reforming the taxation system so that tax cheats will now have to pay their way.

Before my election to Parliament I spent almost 25 years in the banking industry. Whilst in that industry, because of my concern for the welfare and conditions of my fellow workers, I became an active member of my union, the Australian Bank Employees Union. During this time I held a number of honorary positions. This involvement in my union gave me an insight into, and a better understanding of, the needs of my fellow workers and the broader objects of the trade union movement. The time I spent as an active union official was the most rewarding years of my time in the industry and I would like to place on record my sincere thanks to my fellow workers and union officials for their support and encouragement over many years.

As a former trade union official, I believe I am privileged to be a Labor member of parliament at a time when links between the industrial and political elements of the Labor movement have never been closer or more constructive. Under the accord, the Australian people have seen the unprecedented creation of more than 1.3 million jobs, real increases in the social wage, and improved competitiveness of Australian industry. We are now witnessing the massively valuable process of award restructuring which will, through consultation and cooperation, yield real improvements in productivity and in career opportunities for Australian workers. At the same time, negotiations between the trade union movement and the Federal Government are set to produce tax cuts and wage increases that, again, will alleviate the position of Australian workers. In other words, the accord processes, which have already done so much to put on a firm foundation the living standards of Australian workers, are still relevant, still productive, still yielding real benefits.

The Oxley electorate was not isolated from the general downturn in Australian industry during the late 1970s and early 1980s. This, combined with some adverse decisions taken by the State Government, saw the decline of the area's traditional employers, such as coal mining, railway workshops, power generation and a number of smaller manufacturing industries. The largest single employer in the area remains the Royal Australian Air Force Base at Amberley. Despite this downturn in its traditional employers, Oxley is well placed for the establishment of new industries with its existing services and ready work force. In addition, we have already seen a growth of employment in the service sector through the retail and hospitality industries and perhaps these areas will provide new opportunities in the future.

The Australian economy had to be restructured and it is through the accord that the trade unions and hence the workers of this nation have been able to play a vital role in the restructuring process. Industry had to be made more efficient and competitive and outdated work and management practices had to change to enable industry to attain these objectives. Workers are playing their part by accepting the restructuring of awards and changes in work practices as their contribution to making industry more efficient and competitive. However, industry must now also play its part. As workers have shown restraint in the restructuring process in the interests of the community as a whole, there is a major responsibility on industry to also show restraint. It is simply not good enough for workers to accept wage restraint and a lowering of living standards while some industries choose to pay substantial increases to senior executives and aim for higher and higher profit margins.

Industry has always been quick to pass on increased costs to the consumer; however, where there has been reduction in costs to industry, through lower import prices, particularly through movements in the Australian dollar, or reductions in overheads, the benefits have been taken as increased profit for the company instead of being passed on to the consumer.

Whilst the people of my electorate of Oxley have been prepared to show restraint, they, like all Australians, are entitled to have industry show similar restraint by reducing prices in the interests of the whole community, and this would go a long way in improving the living standards of the Australian people.

On its election to office in 1983 the Hawke Government recognised the need to reform and revitalise industry and, importantly, to lift its export potential as an integral part of the overall restructuring of the Australian economy. The Government's commitment to this reform saw strategies formulated for the steel and car industries in its first term, with packages in the following years for heavy industry; clothing, footwear and textiles industry; and the pulp, paper and paper products industry.

Further, the Hawke Government has introduced strategies for investment promotion; the development of the aerospace industry in Australia; and for the information industries. It also provides a 150 per cent tax concession for research and development, which is a substantial incentive for industry to develop new technologies and to take advantage of the expertise of our scientists. By developing research and development policies industry can increase its own productivity and also provide possible new export opportunities. All of this has encouraged the development and growth of more efficient industries, which has enabled greater internationalisation of Australia's industrial base and the reduction of government protection through tariffs and other forms of assistance. Overall, this should increase competition and reduce prices.

Clearly, the development of our secondary industries will play a significant role in improving Australia's economic future, although this will not be achieved overnight. We must continue to place emphasis on developing industries to further process our products before we export them. These secondary processing or value-added industries not only have the potential to have a large impact on the return from our exports but also could reduce our import bill by supplying the local market with refined products that we now purchase from overseas-products quite likely produced using materials we exported in either a primary or minimally refined state.

I was encouraged by the recent reports commissioned by the Australian Industry Development Corporation on this issue, the findings of which were made available recently. These reports dealt with the potential for value added production of hides, sheepskins, cotton and wool within Australia. I hope to see similar reports produced on other industries so that opportunities for new or expanded industries can be identified. I would strongly suggest that my electorate would be well placed to take advantage of the benefits that these types of industries could provide. The necessary infrastructure and facilities to support such industries are already in the area. With adequate consideration given to environmental issues during the planning stages and with the use of modern technology in plant and equipment, I am confident that such industries would be both welcomed by, and profitable for, the people of Oxley.

As I mentioned earlier, the service sector may hold new opportunities for growth, especially in the export area. When we speak of trade we mainly think in terms of primary and secondary products and do not consider the potential to trade in services. The fastest growing area of international trade over the past 20 years has in fact been in the service sector. Australia's services sector constitutes the largest sector of the economy, with about three-quarters of the work force employed in this area, and it produces over two-thirds of our gross domestic product. The service sector is directed mainly at providing the community with medical, educational, financial, travel and recreational services. The domestic market, therefore, consumes most of the services produced. However, there is considerable potential for expansion into the export market.

Tourism has seen more growth in export potential than any other area in the service sector and we still have many opportunities to exploit in this area. Health, education and financial services are also areas which can provide export potential. In our region and, indeed, throughout the world there is a considerable market available to trade in services. The Government is well aware of the long term potential of its service exports and welcomed the inclusion of trade in services on the negotiating agenda by the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.

The expansion of the service exports should go hand in hand with an increase in manufacturing, for there is a close relationship between the two. Both primary and secondary goods have a service component. For example, transport is a service used in the export of goods. If we are able to take advantage of this market, it will provide a substantial boost to our national economy by reducing our balance of trade deficit. An expansion in Australia's export trade can only produce more jobs and opportunities for Australians and hence improve our quality of life, especially for the poor and disadvantaged.

There is little doubt that only through a prosperous Australia, with a restructured economy, can the needs of Australians best be met. This provides people with not only economic but also social benefits as it cannot be denied that poverty is the greatest threat to the stability of society. In the late 1970s and early 1980s, as a result of Australia's economic ills, more and more people were being made dependent on social security payments for most of their family income. Most of these people were unemployed and had dependent children to support. These people were joined by a rapidly growing number of women who, through divorce or separation, were left without an income and usually without the skills to compete for a job. These sole parent families added to the number of children in need. Six hundred thousand children, at any one time, were dependent on social security payments, the real value of which declined every year. All of this was added to the existing problems of the aged poor, whose pension payments had not kept pace with increasing costs. Many people in my electorate were among those falling deeper and deeper into the trap of poverty, as were others throughout Australia.

The Hawke Government saw the needs of these people and set about addressing them. This was clearly illustrated in a reply the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) gave to a question without notice in the Parliament on 1 March this year. The Minister outlined how every year that we have been in government we have increased payments for the lowest income families, bringing payments for children from $10 in 1983 to $24 for younger children and to $31 for older children in 1988. The Minister was, of course, referring to the Government's cash for working families scheme, or family allowance supplement. This program represents the principal, but by no means the sole, action by this Government to fulfil its pledge that by 1990 no Australian child need live in poverty. The figures quoted represent a real increase in payments of 24.1 per cent. This was achieved by the Government during times of very tight fiscal policy. The Government will reach the benchmark it set itself for these payments this year and it has pledged to maintain payments in real terms. Pension rates have also been steadily increased since 1983 towards the target of setting the single pension rate at 25 per cent of the average weekly wage, with corresponding increases to the married rate. Pensions have also been fully adjusted for inflation.

Money alone, though, will not solve the underlying causes of these problems and these causes must be addressed if the problem is to be removed rather than treated. For this reason, the Government has taken action to introduce reforms in the provision of and access to education and training, particularly for women. Action has also been taken to increase the retention rate in the nation's schools and colleges. By encouraging more students to complete years 11 and 12 and then go on to higher education or training, Australia will be able to build the necessary skills base needed to ensure our future prosperity. At the same time, programs have been put in place to encourage girls to study science and mathematics subjects as they have been under-represented in these areas for too long. This Government recognises the importance of proper education and training to our young. Education not only provides the best qualification for gaining meaningful, rewarding employment, thereby guaranteeing financial security, but it also provides our children with the skills to become effective members of society. The Government has increased the availability of child-care places to enable more sole parents and women to re-enter the work force and has set in place affirmative action programs to assist them in obtaining employment.

Governments, though, can only provide the resources and guidance for the provision of services to the community; it is the people in the community that make things happen. I am very fortunate to have in my electorate a large number of community groups, both church and non-denominational, which provide very necessary caring attention to the aged and disadvantaged, which is a very important means of support to those people. I have been encouraging these groups and offering them every assistance in the good work they do.

When I campaigned for election to the seat of Oxley it was with a simple but important slogan: `Continuing the Labor tradition'. The Labor tradition had been represented and advanced in the seat of Oxley for 27 years by my predecessor, Bill Hayden, now the Governor-General. Bill Hayden provided dedicated and far-sighted service to the community and to the nation over nearly three decades of membership of this House, including as Opposition Leader and as a Minister in two Labor governments for some nine years. I was proud to tell the voters of Oxley of my commitment to continuing the Labor tradition there that Bill Hayden so brilliantly typified. In this my first speech to Parliament I am proud to reaffirm that commitment.

I am well aware that there was, and is, no quick fix to the economic problems facing Australia. The process of economic reconstruction, vital as it is, will take time. Equally, I am well aware of the real concerns that many families have about whether their quality of life is eroding. The Hawke Government's record at working to meet the twin goals of economic reconstruction and improved living standards shows it to be a government both of vision and compassion.

It is often claimed-not least by our political opponents-that the Labor Government is out of touch; that the Labor tradition has somehow been abandoned. I repudiate that suggestion. The Hawke Government's record of job creation and social justice initiatives in an era of necessary economic restraint, and its close and constructive links with the trade union movement, dispel any such suggestion. But equally I am bound to state that if I see evidence that the Labor tradition is in jeopardy it is my job to speak out. If the Labor leadership does get out of touch it is my job to keep the leadership informed about what is happening at the grassroots of our community.

That is what the people of Oxley elected me for: to represent their interests, to fight for their rights and to ensure they receive the full benefits of the Government's initiatives in jobs, industry development and family support programs so that their needs and aspirations are achieved. That will ensure that Labor's great tradition of service to the people of Oxley and to the Australian nation continues and prospers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Adermann The Hon A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I acknowledge the maiden speech of the honourable member for Oxley (Mr Les Scott). Although I do not always share his assessments, I congratulate him on the speech's content and presentation. I wish him well. As he made his maiden speech I was reminded of when I made my maiden speech 16 1/2 years ago when I entered the Parliament. It was my privilege then to represent, as the member for Fisher, some of the area that is now in the electorate of Oxley. As I have said, I wish the honourable member well.

SPEECH.PARA: The debate on the Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 1988-89, the Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 1988-89 and the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2) 1988-89 affords us an opportunity to scrutinise and comment upon the record of the Government and its handling of the economy. That record is absolutely wretched. Whereas last August we were exposed to grandiose promises and predictions by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), we are now being regaled by alibis and excuses for the complete failure of those economic forecasts.

With almost every forecast, every prediction, every assurance, the result has been the complete opposite. The assurances that inflation would fall have been replaced by the reality of rapidly escalating inflation. The promises of falling interest rates, recently echoed by the Prime Minister in Perth, have been eclipsed by savage increases and the almost unanimous opinion of bankers that housing interest rates will shortly hit an astounding 17 per cent. If we add to that the absolutely astounding statement by the Treasurer that it is the banks, and not the Government, which are responsible for rising interest rates, we almost have comic opera.

The Treasurer has been explaining for months how, through the Reserve Bank of Australia, the Government has exercised stringent monetary controls in Australia's best interests. Now he has the effrontery to protest innocence in regard to the spiralling interest rate debacle. This was the Treasurer who said last September:
We will not hesitate to adjust policy further if our balance of payments or inflation objects are being threatened.
Last year the same Treasurer said:
We started tightening rates up as I said by 3 per cent. Well let me just say when I was tightening monetary policy in April last year . . .

So let us have an end to this nonsense that it is the banks' fault. On an earlier occasion the Treasurer claimed all the credit, so now he must cop the crow. He must admit the Government's culpability is increasing the interest rates. The balance of payments deficit has already massively exceeded the total annual deficit forecast by the Treasurer. I will say more about that later.

Small business is in deep despair, faced by record interest rates and punitive taxation. There is no question but that increasing numbers will be forced into closure, insolvency and liquidation. In its boast of all the jobs it has allegedly created-I say `allegedly'-the Government turns a blind eye to the multitude of jobs which will be lost as businesses fail. We could go on. We could point to the Prime Minister trying to sidestep to qualify and otherwise escape from his commitment that by 1990 no Australian child will live in poverty. We have seen a pretty good example of sidestepping when he is reminded of that promise.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you do something about Ahern? He taxes children.

—The failed former leader of the Labor Party whom the Labor Party tossed out in Queensland is now here in Canberra. We are now blessed by his presence in this House. He will not be here for long, and for that I am extremely grateful.
—You have never fought for a thing for your electors.
—Order! The honourable member for Capricornia will contain his enthusiasm.
—Yes, I should think so. Very shortly he will be treated here as he was treated in Queensland.
—Order! The honourable member for Fairfax will get on with his speech.

—Right, Mr Deputy Speaker. We could, one by one, elicit the bogus promises which have been dishonoured by Labor in the last six years. The latest of course is the one when the Prime Minister said, `This Government will run its full term. There will be no early election'. Yet less than two years since the last election we see all the signs of an imminent election. That is one promise which Australia might hope the Prime Minister will break because most certainly that election will see the annihilation and defeat of the disastrous Hawke Government. However, the dismal record of the Government, the litany of broken promises, the confusion, bickering and failure in its policies are only too well known to the long suffering Australian taxpayers. I do not think that I need to extend the description further.

SPEECH.PARA: What I want to say is this: What concerns me is the complete inability and intent positively to confront these disasters. Next week the Treasurer apparently will make what he calls an economic statement. We have become used to these May statements which have consisted of platitudes and nonsense, and have never yet been in the nature of a mini-Budget which was desperately necessary. Therefore it would be altogether too much to hope that this occasion will be any different. Apparently the theme, and probably the entirety of this statement, will be addressed to alleged taxation cuts.

No matter what might be the state of the economy, no matter what might be the practicability of sustainable tax reform, the show must go on. I guess the Treasurer will not admit to the massive increased taxation rake-off which has been the hallmark of this Government. He certainly will not concede, as he should, that any tax cuts will return but a fraction of this massive rake-off. Of course, the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU), as we know, has presented the Government with its demands. It said what it wants. Despite the protestations by the Treasurer that it might have to wait a bit, there is not a shadow of doubt that the Government will again faithfully accept its riding instructions. Minister after Minister, from the Prime Minister down, despite the economic madness of following the ACTU course, have said that it is a soundly based, reasonable, realistic formula. So obviously they will not be rocking the boat.

We see the relatively new Minister for Land Transport and Shipping Support (Mr Robert Brown) heaping vitriol on the Australian automobile associations for exposing the massive reductions in road funding. Contrary to all the facts, that Minister time after time stands up in this House-even as late as yesterday-and has the effrontery to allege that road funding has increased. Yet despite the huge hike in fuel taxes being garnered by this Government, all over the nation roads are deteriorating, construction falling way behind schedule, and the picture unfolding that things will continue to get much worse.

My own electorate shows the tragic fingerprint of Labor-the extension of the Bruce Highway widening and the bypass of Nambour were programmed in the Fraser Government under that excellent Minister, Ralph Hunt, by way of the bicentenial road fund trust, to be completed no later than 1988. They were on target and they would have been completed. But since Labor took over the time has lengthened, accidents and deaths on the roads continue and it seems that it will be 1991 or later before that work is completed. Further towards the north the highway will continue to reap its harvest of death because the Cooroy bypass, which should now be under way, is years away. The Six Mile Creek horror stretch probably will not be rectified for five years or a decade. The highway, as it proceeds further north through the electorate of my good colleague the honourable member for Wide Bay (Mr Millar) who I see here in the House, will get very much worse before anything is done. Yet to the cynical amusement of residents of the Sunshine Coast and Wide Bay, our local newspapers are full of waffle and statements by the honourable member for Fisher (Mr Lavarch) about the generosity and largesse of the Federal Government and making all sorts of promises and giving all sorts of assurances that cannot possibly be kept. He is generally making an ass of himself, but we need something to laugh about in Fairfax. It is only because of the tremendous efforts of the Queensland State Government and the local government that we are seeing a big program of road works in my electorate. He criticised them yesterday, but they are State and local government road works.

It is only when we look at the areas of responsibility of the Federal Government that we find deficiency, delay and neglect. It would be refreshing if the Government discontinued its denigration of the concerned and responsible automobile associations and faced up to its own neglect and its own avoided responsibilities. Perhaps then the road disasters will receive overdue attention.

No matter where we look, the same inefficiency is evident. Recently I asked the Treasurer when he would honour his promise to restore the two per cent which was purloined from Public Service superannuants and veterans. You will remember that, Mr Deputy Speaker. After all, the honourable member for Herbert (Mr Lindsay) was telling Australia that he had managed to get Caucus support for the restoration in the next Budget, so I thought that my question to the Treasurer was fair enough. His non-answer was first an attack on me for having the effrontery to ask such a question and even to suggest that the veterans and others had no reason to complain. Then he went on in a manner which indicates that it would be vain and fruitless for superannuants and veterans to expect any honouring of the promise of restoration this year, or perhaps ever.

Another ill-designed so-called exercise in economy is seen in the latest Government excisions from the pharmaceutical list. We get all sorts of excuses and all sorts of assurances. The Minister and the bureaucrats apparently know more than the doctors. Surely the massive protests from doctors, pharmacists, patients and pensioners cannot be so blithely dismissed as inconsequential, but they always are when we make representations to the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) and the Department. In all its protests that economies are necessary, how on earth can the Department justify its action in sending out to doctors by way of communication in the form of a giant capsule or, as some doctors call it, a giant suppository 30 centimetres long to get their message across? We saw one here in this House today. I come from an electorate that has the Big Pineapple, the Big Cow and the Big Dinosaur; now we have the big suppository.

Has the Department decided that a simple 39c stamped conventional letter has outlived its usefulness? Has it opted for this bizarre, wasteful method of communication costing about twice as much? Is this the economy it claims its actions are designed to achieve? The heavy-handed bureaucratic manner in which alterations to the pharmaceutical schedules are made is absolutely deplorable. The Department seems to forget that it is dealing not with files but with people, many very old, frail and ill, easily confused and very apprehensive. When will the Department, let the doctors prescribe for their patients instead of its heavy-handed intrusion? After all, doctors know their patients, their needs and their problems, but this Government, which seems to think that every taxpayer is a tax cheat, also seems to think that every doctor is ripping off the system. In all probability it would be too much to expect that the Government would attack the root cause of Australia's malaise by departing from its doctrine of high spending. After the coalition Government dramatically and effectively cut back the prodigal government spending of the Whitlam years, total government spending in the 1982-83 Budget-our Budget-was of the order of $47 billion. All of this has been jettisoned by the Hawke Government and the 1988-89 Budget indicates spending of $82 billion, a huge leap.

In conjunction with this total mismanagement of the economy, the current account deficit, forecast to be $9.5 billion for 1988-89, is already over $9.6 billion. Only Labor could establish the unenviable record of producing for the first time in Australia's history monthly deficits of $1 billion and more. Having established that record, the Government has sustained that disaster consistently for nearly three years. Labor has presided over a growth in Australia's foreign debt from $36 billion in 1983, 20.9 per cent of gross domestic product (GDP), to an horrendous $121 billion in 1988, that is, 40.4 per cent of GDP. That is a huge percentage. I wonder whether the Treasurer feels that we have finally attained the status of a banana republic. If he does not, economists overseas certainly do. Not only has Moody's Investor Services Inc. downgraded our international credit rating from AAA in 1986 but there is a very real prospect of further downgrading. The Treasurer just has to accept and address these problems. Unless his April statement does so, he would be better off saying nothing.

Unless the Government seriously considers reducing its huge spending, all of the talk of tax cuts and the like is just semantics. Families facing housing interest rates, predicted to reach 17 per cent, increasingly face the prospect of never owning a home or losing the home they are struggling to purchase. Honourable members should talk to their banks to see how many houses are being sold or are for sale each week. Indeed, more and more homes will either be repossessed or experience forced sale. What is the Government going to do to relieve this quite unmitigated disaster?

The main problem with the Government is its total incapacity to plot an economic course and stick to it. From the time of the much vaunted Tax Summit, when the Treasurer put down his paper and said, `This is what I will do', the Australian Council of Trade Unions made it quite clear that the unions, not the Treasurer, would take charge of the decision making process. Never in Australia's history has a government so rapidly and so frequently made pronouncements and promises and then, in a matter of weeks, abandoned them and gone into reverse. The latest imbroglio over the Sydney Airport is just par for the course. Such fiascos have become so commonplace that they are hardly remarked on any more.

The incapacity of the Prime Minister, the Treasurer, Senator Button and Senator Walsh to look at privatisation of such enterprises as Qantas Airways Ltd, Australian Airlines and others has resulted from the total obstinacy and philosophical negativeness of the Left. Every time the Treasurer or the Prime Minister tentatively raise the prospect, there is a very quick veto by the Left.

The Government has also become very adept at avoiding issues and decisions by shooting them off to committees or inquiries, where they can quietly languish and hopefully die. That is where privatisation is at the moment. Sydney Airport will continue to increase in congestion, danger and inconvenience because yet another environmental impact study, not to be completed until safely after the next election, is to be undertaken.

That is why in Question Time we no longer get answers or information. Instead we get personal vilification, waffling and inaccurate allegations about the coalition's philosophies. It is interesting that we are repeatedly being asked, `What is your policy?'. It is obvious that the Government is completely unable to devise and institute policies to get us out of the trough and is plaintively hoping that the Opposition will come up with the answers. We are not about writing the policy for a failed and incompetent government, and the sooner the election is held and the Government is inevitably put out to pasture the better it will be. I am afraid that the speculation about when the Prime Minister will stand down and the Treasurer will assume the mantle is just daydreaming. The Australian people will shortly and decisively take that decision right out of their hands and it will be a long time before Australia ever has another socialist government.

I hope that in next week's statement the pensioners, who have been so disappointed and forgotten, and the veterans, who have been absolutely betrayed, will not again be ignored and insulted. Perhaps the Treasurer will change his inflexible mind and agree that one very positive contribution towards a solution to many problems would be to relieve the taxation burden on people's private savings. This would certainly assist in restoring economic growth, it would increase employment, and it would provide a real boost to primary industry and small business.

There is absolutely no incentive to save today. The repressive tax system puts a severe penalty on saving, so that between taxation, provisional tax and inflation saving is discouraged. Funds would become available if saving were encouraged; interest rates would be contained or fall; money would be available for home building loans; and it would certainly act positively against inflation.

Yet the Treasurer puts on his blinkers, his sternest face, and shouts, `No'. So we do not save; we just splurge and money is in short supply, interest rates and inflation soar, and we go from the frying pan into the fire. The Treasurer could well be writing his epitaph and next week's statement could be that epitaph. History will underline his culpability in the destruction of the Australian economy. Hopefully, there are better days ahead; soon the Hawke Government will be just a distant and unpleasant memory.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Price Mr L.R.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to speak on Appropriation Bill (No. 3) and the cognate Bills. I do not want to be provoked unnecessarily by the honourable member for Fairfax (Mr Adermann), who has just resumed his seat, but I wish to respond to one or two of his remarks. Firstly, he referred to the level of foreign debt. We should all be concerned about the level of foreign debt. However, the honourable member should realise that our foreign debt can be broken up into something like 60 per cent private debt and 40 per cent government debt. In this financial year the Commonwealth Government, together with all other forms of government, has a zero borrowing requirement. The public sector borrowing requirement (PSBR) is zero. Therefore, we are allowing private enterprise more opportunity to borrow and expand and fuel what has been a quite significant investment push. The latest quarterly figures showed an investment level of about 22 per cent, which is an outstanding achievement. Investment fuels job creation. The more capital goods we put into place and the more factories that exist, the more job opportunities are created. Certainly we have a current account deficit problem, but we are working our way out of it.

SPEECH.PARA: I acknowledge the traditional role that our primary produce and minerals play with their tremendous export potential. However, the Government has tried to broaden our base. For example, it has attempted to reduce the decline that has occurred in manufacturing industry. It is the Hawke Labor Government that has halted a 30-year slide, a 30-year attrition, from about 30 per cent of the work force being employed in manufacturing industry to 16 per cent. We have turned that around. We are getting net additions to those people employed in industry. Notwithstanding tremendous productivity improvements, computerisation and mechanisation, we are seeing manufacturing industry grow. What that means is employment for more people. To highlight the difference between the honourable member for Fairfax, on behalf of the Opposition parties, and the Government, we are about job creation and putting people into the work force. In our period in office about 1.3 million jobs have been created. The Opposition wants to be judged as a good manager, but under its administration the greatest growth industry was shattered families and employment opportunities and rapidly escalating double digit unemployment.I think that is rather disgraceful.

I would like to respond also to what has been said by some shadow Ministers. I was at a recent Price Waterhouse Urwick function at which the shadow Minister for communications, Senator Lewis, said, `We're not the Fraser Government. Don't judge us on our record. We're not like that. We had a mandate, but we're going to perform'. He made the comment on the day that Senator Chaney was pre-selected for a lower House seat. I thought I was hearing a challenge to the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) because, after all, he was the Treasurer for five years in the Fraser Government.

We can judge the records of the respective governments on the basis of job performance and growth in the economy. We need only compare the Fraser years with those of this Government. Honourable members opposite cannot say that the chief architect in the Fraser Government has somehow done penance and been rehabilitated. The people, particularly those families which were shattered by unemployment, will not forget the record of the Fraser Government. Honourable members opposite will have to live with it. Opposition members often say that we should take tough action to fix the situation. They say that the proposed tax cuts should be funded by reduced Commonwealth government expenditure. At the same time, Opposition members in the House say that Federal expenditure should be increased in this or that area-perhaps roads, pensions or other very worthwhile things. But they do not have the responsibility to indicate where they would cut expenditure. In these circumstances, the Opposition would let interest rates float even higher. It would cut back savagely on Federal government expenditure and investment and really contract the economy.

I do concede one point to the Opposition: it would very rapidly fix the current account problem. However, it would cause a monumental recession, if not depression. It would have unemployment rates shoot right up. It would control the current account deficit in that manner rather than in our way of recognising that it is a serious problem, but one that will not be fixed quickly. We recognise that we can restructure the economy. We can transform the economy, but we will do so with a minimum of social dislocation. That is the essential difference between the Opposition and the Government. The Opposition wants to get in there and smash families with the rod of unemployment. It wants to let interest rates go up even further; to have a contraction; and to kill off consumer demand. We want to manage the economy. We want to restructure it over a period. The problem with the economy is that it is growing too strongly, I suppose. We have a record of creating many jobs.

I am always amused when Opposition speakers say how concerned they are about the average wage earner or Mr and Mrs average Australian citizen. They have always opposed wage increases before the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. They say that we cannot afford them, that we should not have them, and that they are not on. They always say, `Oh, yes, you will get increases, but they will be linked to productivity'. However, on average, productivity is about 1.1 per cent--

TALK.START.PARA: —Under your government.

—Let us go on what it has been. The Opposition offers the work force of Australia a 1.1 per cent increase. Next week we will announce tax cuts that are pitched to the low and middle income earners. In addition, we have the process of award restructuring which will deliver money into the hands of the workers.
—That's right.

—It is all very well for the Opposition shadow Minister to sneer, but in the metals industry we are reducing 300 classifications to nine classifications. Two years ago, if someone on this side of the House said such an aim was a worthy one, he would probably have been laughed out of school. That that has been accomplished with the goodwill of the industry and the unions is a great credit to them. That is what award re-structuring holds in prospect. It also involves training and career paths. I hope that it will also remove some debilitating demarcation disputes. Certainly there are prospects of real productivity increases in those areas. I ask the Australian people to judge us by what we have achieved in our period of office and what was achieved under the Fraser years.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Fairfax raised the issue of transport and the amount of government spending in that area and what causes road tolls. No one argues that better roads would not have an impact on reducing the road toll, but the real cause tends to be driver-related. The first issue I raise concerns buses. In New South Wales, bus timetables are approved by the Department of Motor Transport. A bus proprietor who wants to establish a timetable for getting from one town to another has to get the Department to approve it. We have found that the Department is approving a time which involves the bus driver driving at average speeds greater than the speed limit.

The honourable member for Gilmore (Mr Sharp) has had a lot to say about the terror stretch between Goulburn and Yass. It is a terrible stretch of road. There was a bus fatality there not so long ago. It has not come out whether anyone checked the timetable of the departmental official who approved it. Was the driver forced because of the timetable approved by the Department to drive at speeds greater than the speed limit? If we start checking into some of these timetables, we may find that the State Government has condoned breaches of the law. I am not trying to suggest that the fault is solely that of the present State Government, but attention has been drawn to the matter and it is time that action was taken.

I regret that I have heard members of the Opposition ask for deregulation of the transport industry. They do not want to have any checks whatsoever. In this case, we have a check that should result in the saving of lives. It should be a safety factor, but it is directly the reverse. Whom should we blame? Should we blame the bus driver who has been told by his company to stick to his timetable and therefore breach the law? I find that he should be blamed. Do we blame the bus company that condones that breach or is forced to go along with it, or do we blame the official in the Department who approved the timetable? Attention to some of these sorts of matters can reduce the road toll.

In the trucking industry truck drivers have come in for a great deal of criticism for some of their driving practices. They are to be condemned for some of them. But where does the pressure come? Sole owner-operators have often mortgaged themselves to the hilt. They operate in a highly competitive system that forces them to cut corners and sometimes break the speed limit. I condemn those who let out the contracts, knowing full well what will be the result of their actions. What about the checking stations that have the opportunity to attempt to monitor the average speeds that must have been achieved between check points?

I draw those two aspects to the attention of the House. I know the honourable member for Dobell (Mr Lee) has made the suggestion, which I support fully, that we should have tachometers in buses and trucks. We would have a kind of black box that could not be tampered with that would keep a record of the speed at which these vehicles travel. That might involve the investment of some money, but it would be for the very considerable benefit of saving lives. The Opposition says that we are not spending enough money on roads. In fact, the Federal Government spent $1.2 billion this year; the States have spent $1.6 billion and councils, through local roads, are spending about $1.5 billion. In its period of office this Hawke Government has spent about $20 billion.

I would like to say to you, Mr Deputy Speaker, that I travel by road more than I actually do, but I frequently come from my home to Canberra. In the short years in which it has been my honour and privilege to represent the constituents of Chifley, there has been an enormous improvement. The last time I came down, which was for this week's session, I noticed that the Minister for Land Transport and Shipping Support (Mr Robert Brown) had opened the bypass. I cannot recall the name of the bypass.

TALK.START.PARA: —Berrima.

—Berrima. You are most knowledgable, Mr Deputy Speaker, and I thank you for your assistance. The quality construction of Berrima bypass has saved travellers even more time. The national highway system, for which the Commonwealth meets the cost of construction, which it fully maintains, and which is nearly 16,000 kilometres from coast to coast will be completed when the last section in Western Australia is opened next year by the Minister.

SPEECH.PARA: It is always possible to spend more money on certain activities, but we have done very well in spending $20 billion on roads in our term of office. People who use the roads would not argue that the roads have improved considerably. The Opposition should not come into the House and say that expenditure cuts of $5.5 billion should pay for tax cuts and then say, `We want to see road expenditure go up by a billion dollars', without telling us where it will get the money from. Frankly, I would not want to see one penny of the money spent in some of the Commonwealth programs in my electorate-whether it be for education in high schools or primary schools, for pensions or for the technical and further education (TAFE) college-diverted to roads. The Opposition cannot go on with its schizophrenic policy when National Party members, in particular, but Opposition members in general, talk about the need for more and more expenditure at a time when the shadow Minister for finance, who is at the table, the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson), advocates cuts in Federal Government expenditure without detailing where the cuts will come from.

In the western suburbs of Sydney we have now been subjected to the latest flood; the third in two years. I am disappointed that in the Federal electorate of Chifley, which covers part of the Penrith and Blacktown city council area, not one dollar was requested by the New South Wales Government to be spent on flood mitigation works, not one penny. I find that an absolute scandal. The New South Wales Government is very deceptive. The shadow Minister got up and said, `The Federal Government has not spent any money on flood relief in Penrith and Blacktown', but he knows full well that it is the State Government's responsibility to list the projects, prioritise them and then approach the Federal Government.

What happened in the last Budget? I will tell you what happened in the last Federal Budget, Mr Deputy Speaker. The State Government approached the Commonwealth Government with a program. Every project on that program was funded by the State Government-not 75 per cent, or 50 per cent, or 85 per cent or 99 per cent but 100 per cent. The State Government thought so little of the needs of the people of Penrith and Blacktown that it did not allocate one penny to flood mitigation.

The Premier of New South Wales, Mr Greiner, is running around saying, `I am prepared to spend an extra $5m'. I applaud that. He says, `I want to do it on a matching basis'. He has to do that under the scheme and he leaves people with the impression that the Federal Government is indifferent and will not match it. He does not tell the people that he is undertaking a review of needs and that that review has not been completed. The Federal Government is not in the business of allocating money when there are no projects. I think that the New South Wales Government should stop playing politics with people's lives and their property in the western suburbs. I am certainly one who advocates a flood free western suburbs. I know that goal will not come overnight. I think that is what the policy should be, both for the State and Federal governments and for the councils.

I am very pleased that the Minister for Resources (Senator Cook) will be taking the proposal for a task force to look into flooding problems to the ministerial council. This is something which I have advocated for some months. I believe that we need to work together to ensure that there is proper coordination at local government level-and now at trust level, I understand in my State-as well as between the two departments which are responsible and the Federal Government. I sincerely hope that after the review of needs in relation to flooding, my constituents in Blacktown Council and Penrith Council will be accorded the status of being on the list, will be given a high priority, and can look forward to the ending of the terror represented by the possibility of floods.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Chifley (Mr Price) referred to our indebtedness as a nation and seemed to pass it off as something that was about to disappear, on the basis that a Budget surplus has occurred for the first time in a very long time. He went on to rationalise that what has happened in the past six years somehow compares favourably with what happened under the previous Government. In fact, he dredged up information, events and his beliefs of what happened up to 13 or 14 years ago, as though all this information were relevant today. The truth is that the country's indebtedness is somewhere in the vicinity of $120 billion at a time when the value of our dollar, in terms of recent history, is at a fairly high level, as measured against the US dollar. To make a virtue out of the fact that his Government is responsible for only 40 per cent of that debt is stretching credulity a long way. The indebtedness of this country amounts to in excess of $7,300 per man, woman and child in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: As my colleague the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson) reminded me, by increasing our indebtedness since 1983 from $35 billion to some $121 billion today, and if one accepts the argument of honourable members opposite that 1 1/4 million jobs have been created, we have borrowed $70,000 to create each one of those 1 1/4 million jobs. That is some achievement!

I put it to you, Mr Deputy Speaker, that we could have the best houses in the street if we could get someone to lend us the money and we were not worried about the overdraft payments. That is exactly what this Government is doing. It is going into hock. In the process, it is not creating a debt which it will have to fix but one which the taxpayers, our children, and the coalition Government, when it is returned at the next election, will have to fix.

It is very easy for the honourable member for Chifley to make light of the scope of the indebtedness which his Government has overseen in more than six long years of office. One would have thought that after six years in office, the statute of limitations would apply and that the Government would stop making excuses and fatuous comparisons with what happened during the Fraser years.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Appropriation Bills are presented to the House at a particularly significant time for the Australian economy. Fiscal policy is now more important to the success of Government policy than at any time in the now fading life of this Government. The Government is floundering in a sea of uncertainty and doubt. In terms of economic policy some honourable members opposite know what they should do for the good of the country but they fear the political consequences-and particularly the consequences of their past actions. It is the past policies of the Government, led by the Treasurer (Mr Keating), which now make life so difficult for Australians. They are paying the price of his follies. It is those policies which will soon see the demise of this Government.

SPEECH.PARA: The Appropriation Bills provide the formal means by which the Parliament spends taxpayers' money and are therefore a reflection of the Government's fiscal policy. Additional appropriations contained in the Bills amount to some $684m, a minuscule part of the tax bonanza which the Government will reap in the second half of this financial year. After certain so-called savings, this represents a net increase of some $218m on expenditure outlined in the Budget only last year. A significant part of these additional costs is the cost to the Government of the national wage rise, while attempts to squeeze the Department of Defence seem to have led essentially to overspending rather than greater efficiency in that area.

The major threats to fiscal policy seem to be in the future. As has happened so often in the past, the Australian Labor Party seems willing to mortgage the future, mortgage our country, for the sake of its electoral fortunes. The fiscal problems facing the Government as the economy deteriorates are potentially enormous. The present large and very desirable surplus is based on a significant rise in taxation revenue, helped along by a large dose of inflation which has contributed to the recent economic growth. As economic conditions change, so will the budgetary challenges confronting the Government change. The Treasurer's 1988 bicentenary Budget started to fall apart soon after his Budget Speech on 24 August. The initial flaws in that Budget were the forecasts that inflation would decline and there would be gradual improvements in the balance of payments. The Opposition criticised these assumptions at the time, and after only a few months it was clear, even to the most sycophantic followers of the Treasurer, that those predictions which were the basis of the economic policy of the Budget were hopelessly wrong.

As we anticipated then, the opposite to what was predicted has occurred. Inflation has resumed its rise, but from levels which have been too high throughout all the years of the Labor Party's rule. Inflation will again be much higher than it is in other major countries this year. The current account deficit has obeyed economic reality rather than the vain commands of the Treasurer, and it is now at record levels. The current account deficit represents a huge drain on the savings of and potential for investment by Australians.

High inflation and the current account deficit are just symptoms of the major economic problems Australia faces. The Government has attempted to deal with those problems through the initially gradual but now more stringent tightening of monetary policy. The only consistency in monetary policy has been that no-one has known precisely what was being done at any one time. Economists have correctly observed that monetary policy is a blunt instrument in its effect on the economy. They mean by this that it is not a very efficient means of achieving the Government's goals and, even if it does, it can do a lot of damage in the process. This is even more the case in a deregulated financial sector, or even in a partially deregulated financial sector as we have today. The damage done by monetary policy is a result of its effects on interest rates and the availability of funds to finance industrial expansion and investment. The ideal is a monetary policy which neither encourages malinvestment and overexpansion, as we are presently experiencing, nor places such a burden on businesses that virtually no investment takes place. However, a loose monetary policy at one time will necessitate a tight monetary policy later. The Labor Government has lacked any will to cut the Budget and use fiscal policy to continue the fight against high inflationary pressures on the economy. This is because in part it is beholden to vested interests which rely on government spending for their existence, and it is trapped by ideological commitment to floundering policies such as the ill-fated Medicare farce.

Instead of taking the hard decisions, the Government has repeatedly fuelled rapid expansion of the economy, and this is underlined by enormous monetary growth and persistent inflation. This inflationary spiral, along with a range of new and onerous taxes, has allowed the Government to produce a large Budget surplus but it has removed the pressure on the Government to maintain a tight fiscal policy. For every apparent saving and efficiency gain the Government has made in the Budget it has created a new spending program to buy a miserable few votes or to silence some minority interest group. Any burden of restraint has been carried by State governments and the taxpayer. This is the standing record of the present Government on fiscal policy. We have a taxing surplus and limited spending restraint determined by political interest.

The dangers now are all in the future. Australia is facing major economic problems. It would be difficult to exaggerate those problems. The only variable is how long Labor can delay the forthcoming consequences of its misguided economic policies. An ability to delay is vital to the chances of this Government retaining office. For that reason political considerations are guiding the Government more than the long-term economic well-being of all Australians. It is clear that until recently the Treasurer saw it as being in his political interests to be seen as a tough so-called economic manager who was willing to make the difficult decisions. Now the Treasurer, the honourable member for Blaxland, talks about the difficult decisions but makes none of them. As I previously suggested he-or the people who advise him-knows what those decisions should be and the dangers of not taking them, but all we get are vague promises to do something in the future. Economic reality will not wait for the Treasurer to find the courage. Talk from the Treasurer in debates in this House will not help anyone beyond the headlines tomorrow unless he takes some action on fiscal policy and micro-economic reform. The Treasurer will not act because he knows that the greater political risk for him lies in the backlash from those who are suffering and who will suffer more as a result of his failures.

The measure of prudent fiscal policy is not how well it works if everything goes the Government's way and its economic forecasts are fulfilled. Fiscal policy success must be judged by the ability of the Budget to stand up to the worst case scenario, to use one of the Treasurer's favourite terms. Economic policy is too important to leave anything to chance, yet the Budget-which these Bills add to-has not stood up to the changes in economic circumstances we have had already, much less those which will follow as the Treasurer continues to abrogate his responsibilities.

Reagan's former budget director, David Stockman, in his book The Triumph of Politics, described how political considerations and the interests of congressmen undermined his efforts to produce a sensible budget. The way he chose to cater for these competing interests was by fiddling the budget forecasts of economic conditions. He produced what he described as a rosy scenario which promised a balanced budget in terms of the computer models used, but only because of totally unrealistic forecasts of growth, inflation and revenue. That sounds familiar, does it not? This is the sort of trick which the Treasurer pulled in his last Budget. The details are different but the principle of deception is the same. The trick is to delay the hard decisions, the bad news and the onset of reality. It will not work.

Let us just consider what will happen to the Budget as the economy moves into recession; and moving into recession is surely part of any worthwhile worst case scenario. The first development must be that revenue will begin to decline for State and Federal governments. Much of the present capacity of the States to accept lower payments from the Commonwealth has been derived from the boom in stamp duty revenue. That capacity will disappear. Federal revenue from income and corporate taxes will not grow as much as anticipated and sales tax will be much more difficult to expand. At the same time, the demands on Budget support will grow enormously. If unemployment also rises, the payment of unemployment benefit will reach the sky.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is sure to happen.

—It is sure to happen. That is part of the worst case scenario the Treasurer is fond of talking about but does nothing about. As families suffer from rising costs, high interest rates and less secure employment, the demands on public housing, welfare and other income support will also grow. As we know from experience, these additional costs can grow surprisingly quickly. If a government is to deal with these potential problems, it must first have fiscal policy firmly under control, and this Government does not now. That is at the core of any future problems. That control is clearly not present now, nor does it seem likely that it will be in the future. This Government has not overcome fiscal policy problems. Worse, it has created new spending problems with programs which will be a burden for all future governments and for the taxpayers who have to pay for them.
—They have given up.

—The Government has given up. It is weak, it is tired, and it is showing all the signs of collapse. The real danger is that, with an election approaching, Labor will yet again promise to be everything to everyone. Already, prospective promises to wage earners, pensioners and lower income families are taking on huge, pork-barrelling proportions. Those groups might well be deserving of the assistance that is available, but to make a whole range of new spending promises in the economic circumstances which this very Government has created will be grossly irresponsible.

SPEECH.PARA: On top of the economic pressures of the Budget, the political pressures of a looming election which the Labor Party is desperate to win represent a further threat to sound fiscal policy. It is ironic that initial economic adversity will lead to a political reaction which compounds those economic problems. The Government is constrained in its action on fiscal policy by its so-called accord with the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) and its commitments to the expansion of the poorly defined social wage. The dangers of the wage deals which the Treasurer is negotiating behind closed doors with the ACTU and his masters in it are not just the size of wage rises but the other deals which are made on the side.

The economic problems the Government faces, however, will not go away. They cannot be blamed on foreign governments or international conditions. Fiscal policy is only one of the tools the Government can use to deal with the problems it faces and which it largely created. The Opposition has repeatedly warned of the dangers of a gross national debt in the vicinity of $121 billion. The need for micro-economic reform and privatisation is now even more pressing than it was just a couple of years ago when the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) declared that micro-economic reform would be the focus of his third term. The Prime Minister has failed to deliver those reforms and has largely abandoned them.

Perhaps the most significant failing of Labor in government is the stifling of industrial relations changes to give wage earners more freedom and make the labour market more efficient. It is one thing to talk of award restructuring, but the centralised system of wage fixation itself is the problem.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a disaster.

—It is a disaster, and it is the system itself which is the problem. Until the labour market problems in Australia are seriously addressed, productivity will be improved only marginally, business will not be able to compete as well as it should in international and import competing markets, the current account deficit will show no long term improvements, and all Australians will be denied the rewards for effort which should rightly be theirs.

SPEECH.PARA: This legislation is another example of the failure of the Government to continue its task of fiscal reform.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has given up.

—The statements by senior Ministers suggest that the Government has given up, as the honourable member for Wentworth said, on trying to deal with the economy and making room for cuts in the Budget. Instead, it has its eyes firmly fixed on the next election, not wanting to offend anyone but at the same time threatening everyone's economic future. What is sad about this pathetic abrogation of responsibility is that it will not achieve anything. Labor will lose office and the legacy of the Hawke years will be that much more difficult for the coalition to fix.
—Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Mr H.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Appropriation Bills provide an opportunity for honourable members, under the protection of the Standing Orders, to discuss anything involving public affairs. They also provide an opportunity, given that they are supplementary Appropriation Bills, to examine the Government's approach to economic management and to contrast it to the approach of those opposite. The honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher) got quite agitated and excited, but unfortunately he fell into the trap that those opposite so often fall into of talking in generalities and using the rhetoric of the times without going into specifics. He talked about programs that needed to be cut because of the great drain they are making on the public purse, but he did not identify them. Never will we hear concrete proposals from those opposite.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like briefly to go through one of the Government's principal instruments of economic management, the historic accord entered into with the trade union movement. The accord framework has allowed the Government the flexibility to address major structural problems in the Australian economy. Under this Government's economic management through the accord there has been unprecedented job growth. Between April 1983 and March 1989 over 1.3 million new jobs have been created-a job growth of 21.1 per cent. Compare this to the endless dole queues of the Fraser-Howard years. Unemployment has fallen by over 150,000 or nearly 22 per cent since the election of the Hawke Government. When the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) was thrown out of office the unemployment rate was 10.1 per cent. It has now fallen to 6.2 per cent, the lowest figure for six years. The participation rate in February 1989 was 63.1 per cent, the highest level since publication of this series of figures commenced in 1966.

The historic level of job growth has not been brought about simply by the creation of jobs in the public sector. Of the 1.3 million new jobs created under this Government, 89.9 per cent have been in the private sector. It is undeniable that the wage restraint of the trade unions that has been possible under the framework of the accord has paid for the creation of these new jobs. It was estimated last year in a study by Phillip Lewis and Michael Kirby that real wages were 10 per cent below the level they would have reached without the accord. This study also credited the accord with assisting in the increase in employment by about 8 per cent or 600,000 jobs at that time. With the approaching wage-tax trade-off, the importance of the accord continues.

Honourable members should compare this with what we might return to under a government of the opposite persuasion-a return to the confrontationist years of the Fraser-Howard Government. Where would we get to if we talked as the honourable member for Wentworth did when he proposed his second reading amendment? He emphasised and isolated labour market reform as one of the structural changes he envisages in his amendment. Where would we get to under a Howard-led government with people of the ilk of the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith) as the Minister responsible for the industrial relations area? It really would be a return to the dark days of confrontation and conflict.

Let us compare this Government's economic management with the confusion of honourable members opposite. I am pleased that the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson), who is the Opposition spokesperson on finance, is in the chamber at the moment. He seems to be having a rather rough trot at present. Whilst he has made a meteoric rise to the front bench, he seems to be having a little difficulty in learning to negotiate the political tightrope. Let us look at his performance on the Face to Face program when he floated a few ideas. He floated the idea of allowing the States to impose new income tax. That is not a totally original idea from the conservative side of Australian politics. It was something that Malcolm Fraser pushed out under the heading of `new federalism'.

Whilst it was interesting that we got some discussion about tax policy from the Opposition, I believe that the Canberra Times editorial of 14 March best summed up the situation and gave some good advice to the honourable member for Wentworth. It concluded:
Dr Hewson's proposals might be adding to the debate, but they are hardly advancing it.

Of course, the honourable member for Wentworth has taken over from Senator Stone as the spokesperson on finance. Senator Stone really had a troubled road as the spokesperson, basically because of his inability to handle the incompetence and inconsistency of the Leader of the Opposition. Perhaps the honourable member for Wentworth is now having the same problem.

Let us look at the events which occurred when the honourable member was elevated to his current position. The good professor made a big deal of his personal trademark when he was talking about the vexed question of the Opposition outlining which programs it might cut to finance tax cuts. On 19 September 1988 the honourable member was quoted in the Melbourne Age. I am being very careful about quoting comments in the media attributed to the honourable member because I know that he has lectured journalists, telling them that they must not misquote John Hewson. I accept that and in good faith I read this paragraph from the Age of 19 September 1988, which quoted the honourable member for Wentworth as saying:
I personally think we'll need to spell out a reason- able amount of detail . . . I have always had a disposition to giving as much information as possible-it's a personal trademark.

But it has not taken long for the honourable member's personal trademark to be smashed against the rock of political opportunism. I now wish to quote from the lead paragraph of an article which appeared in the Australian Financial Review on 6 March. This is a quote from the article, not from the honourable member for Wentworth. It said:
The Federal Opposition may abandon its idea of detailing its tax and spending policies before the next election as part of a strategy it is considering to minimise political risks.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not say that.

—No. The article went on to suggest that the increasingly desperate Leader of the Opposition was the architect of this retreat. But it was not long before the honourable member for Wentworth joined in. In the Canberra Times of 8 March the honourable member for Wentworth was quoted as saying:

SPEECH.PARA: The position is that we really haven't made up our minds about when we will announce and how much we will announce.

This is a far cry from his advocacy of full information dissemination. It seems that the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), was not quite in on this variation or shift in the Opposition's tactics-or perhaps it could have been that he was not quite attuned to what was going on in general. His response was:
Oh, is that so? Well, you know check with me, I'm the one who does the tax policy.

I do not mind which Opposition spokesperson does the tax policy, but the Australian public deserves better from the Opposition. Opposition members must really wake up-after six years in opposition the Australian public expects that when they offer themselves as an alternative government at the next election within the next 12 months they should put forward concrete policy proposals, policy proposals that can stand robust debate and testing.

Unfortunately, however, we have people such as the honourable member for Fairfax (Mr Adermann) claiming that one of the reasons they do not want to do that is, to use his words, `the Government may be floundering, but it would pinch those ideas'. I find that a bit strange. I hope that the honourable member for Wentworth is able to get the cooperation of his National Party coalition partners in divulging this great information to the Australian community before the next election.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are a team.

—We really are not too sure about the Tweedledum and Tweedledee economic management of the Opposition. We are not sure whether the honourable member for Kooyong and the honourable member for Wentworth are really working in tandem. I do not know whether they are rowing the same way. Unfortunately, I do not think that the honourable member for Kooyong has been forgiven for letting the cat out of the bag before the last election with his chilling comment about `the howls of protest as we cut program after program'. The Opposition is in such a mess because it knows that any policy without the details will not be credible. But at the same time a policy which lists the cuts necessary to implement the Opposition's ideological nonsense will be unacceptable to the electorate. If the honourable member for Wentworth has resiled from his personal trademark out of loyalty to the Leader of the Opposition, that loyalty is surely misplaced.

SPEECH.PARA: A vital component of the accord at the very outset was a commitment to improvements in the social wage. Since the election of the Hawke Government, considerable gains have been made in the social wage. I wish to quickly list some of the achievements. The first is Medicare. Tonight we heard the honourable member for Curtin calling Medicare a farce. Medicare has overwhelming community support; it is a universal and equitable system of health insurance for all Australians. We must remember that prior to Medicare about two million Australians had no health cover at all. Two million Australians had no health cover at all under the Liberal-National Party coalition Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —That does not worry them.
—It does not seem to worry Opposition members because they have not come up with any alternatives.
—What about the queues?
—Order! The honourable member for Corangamite will cease interjecting.

—I was ignoring him, Mr Deputy Speaker; but I thank you for your protection. I turn to community services. The number of child-care places funded by the Commonwealth has more than doubled, from 46,000 in 1983 to well over 110,000 in 1988. Between 1982-83 and 1986-87 the Government increased expenditure on dis- ability services by 78 per cent. I turn to the first home owner scheme. In 1987-88, the Commonwealth provided $222m under this scheme, which helped an estimated 52,000 low and moderate income households to buy their first homes and provided continuing subsidies to a further 247,000 home buyers. Under this Government, rent assistance for low income families has increased by between 150 and 200 per cent, depending on the size of the family.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me turn to the family package. This major social reform is part of this Government's landmark commitment to ensuring that by 1990 no child need live in poverty. The cornerstone of the family package is the family allowance supplement. The magnitude of this social reform was recognised by the Secretary of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, Bill Kelty, when he stated that, left to its own devices, the trade union movement would have taken 50 or 60 years to achieve increases for low income earners equivalent to those paid by the family allowance supplement. The family allowance supplement is a significant income redistribution device.

While the Government's achievements in the social wage area are obvious, I do not deny that there are areas of further need. One of those areas is housing. Measures are necessary to improve the available housing stock. An important sector in the housing area is public housing. This Government should continue to look at increasing funding for public housing. That is not to forget that the majority of renters are in the private rental market. Even though there are those who have received great assistance from the Government, a case can still be argued for further assistance to those in the private rental market.

The Commonwealth Government needs to be involved appropriately with State and local government-the other two spheres of government-in the proper planning for and provision of residential stock. There is a need to return to some of the visionary things that occurred during the Whitlam years. Under the Department of Urban and Regional Development (DURD) much work was done in appropriate planning, especially for our two major cities, Sydney and Melbourne. My colleague the honourable member for McEwen (Mr Cleeland), who has been of great assistance to me tonight in this speech, would know that on the northern urban fringe of Melbourne, in the electorates that we both represent, there is considerable immediate pressure as they are the areas that have the only available housing stock for development. Unfortunately, the municipalities in the area are under considerable pressure because of the population increase they will have to cater for over the next decade.

When the Plenty Corridor, which reaches into the electorate of McEwen, was first considered, the population of the municipality of Whittlesea was estimated to increase from about 80,000 to 200,000 by the turn of the century. If honourable members considered the size of the municipalities or their electorates they would realise that this is a dramatic increase. It is dramatic because of the infrastructure that is required across the whole social wage, whether it be education, hospitals or other facilities. These things have to be planned, and planned well. In regard to employment, why should we go through the tortuous process of putting in place new residential stock in areas which are far from employment? We must return to the notion of total planning.

In the interview I referred to on Face to Face, the honourable member for Wentworth suggested that a number of things the Commonwealth Government was involved in should properly go back to State government. He may even have referred to the role of local government. I think we have an obligation as a national government to assist and be involved in overall planning, especially for our major cities.
