Our immigration policy is also important in planning. The Federal Government cannot insist that Australia take on board another 140,000 people without involving itself in the proper placing and appropriate settlement of those people. That is a challenge. It is an area in which, quite properly, the Federal Government should have a role. Perhaps it is apt for us to reflect on some of the innovative things that happened under Minister Uren and the old DURD during the Whitlam years. Our involvement, through proper planning, can be successful and appropriate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McArthur Mr F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have just heard a speech from the honourable member for Scullin (Mr Jenkins) espousing the virtues of the Whitlam Government and the big spending policies of the current Government. In regard to his defence of the Hawke Government, I draw his attention to a document released by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) comparing the six years of the Fraser Government with the six years of the Hawke Government. On every economic barometer the Fraser Government was better. The honourable member did not refer to those statistics in his very weak defence of the present Government's economic record. He referred on a number of occasions to expenditure and the vision of the Whitlam Government. We well recall the high inflation rates of the Whitlam Government. In 1974 the inflation rate reached 16 per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer to the amendment foreshadowed by the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson). I am pleased that he is in the House because it gave the honourable member for Scullin scope to refer on a number of occasions to the high quality performance of the honourable member for Wentworth in putting forward the sound economic policies of the Opposition in preparation for government.

The amendment put forward by the honourable member for Wentworth summarises the difficulties facing Australia under the Hawke Government. In the first paragraph he talks about the Government being `the highest taxing government in the post-war history of Australia'; in the second, he talks about inflation; in the third, he talks about the high interest rates, and in the fourth, he talks about the need to increase productivity and about the unsustainably high level of foreign debt. I draw the attention of the House to those matters.

I would like to talk about April 1989 when the mini-Budget will be brought forward and discuss where the economy is and what are the fundamental problems facing Australia, the Australian taxpayers and the Australian people. Imports are exceeding exports. The national debt went from $36 billion in 1983 to $121 billion in 1988. We have an overheated economy led by overseas borrowings. Reasonably good commodity prices are helping the overheated economy. As a result of the Government's trying to slow down the overheated economy, which has been brought about by the big spending loose fiscal policies of this Government, we have high interest rates. According to the figures today, the prime lending rate has gone from 17.5 to 18.75 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —And going higher.

—And it is going higher. House owners, small businessmen and those who have Bankcard accounts are very greatly concerned about their interest rates over the next three or four months. This is against a background of a Budget estimate confidently put forward in the House that there would only be 4.5 per cent inflation. Now it is running in the range of 7.7 per cent. If we draw a comparison between inflation rates in our nations, we see that in September 1988 in America it was 4.1 per cent; Japan, 0.5 per cent; Canada, 4 per cent; West Germany, 1.2 per cent; France, 2.9 per cent; and even in the United Kingdom, which is having some problems because of prosperity, the inflation rate is 5.4 per cent. The average inflation rate of the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development is 3.9 per cent and the Australian inflation rate is in the area of 7.3 per cent, and we have yet to finish the financial year.

SPEECH.PARA: The other bogey which is causing great concern to Australians is the current account deficit. Let us look at the accumulating figures. In 1985-86 it was $14.8 billion; 1986-87, 13.2 billion; and 1987-88, $12.2 billion. This year when it was supposed to be brought back to $9 billion we already have a current account deficit of $9.6 billion. If we analyse that figure, we see that we are running into a potential deficit of $16 billion. If we look at the total revenue expenditure of the current Government, which the honourable member for Scullin was so busy defending, we see that in the first year of Government, 1982-83, there was $42 billion worth of revenue and in its last Budget near enough to $82 billion of revenue. It has nearly doubled in the short time of the Hawke Government.

New taxes have been introduced disregarding the fiscal drag and bracket creep on the poor old income tax earner who is now $58 worse off because of that aspect of the income tax. I will refer to that later. New taxes in this so-called reformist Keating Government have been introduced year by year. In 1983 a consumer price index increase was introduced for beer, cigarettes and petrol. Lump sum superannuation taxes were also introduced in that year. So year after year the CPI moves in on these luxury items and the poor old taxpayer is not quite aware that he is paying more, but he knows that at the end of the 12 months things seems to cost a lot more than they did at the beginning of the year. In 1984 there was a one per cent Medicare tax, a 10 per cent tax on wine, a resources rent tax and excise on new and old oil. In 1985 we had that wonderful capital gains tax that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) was never going to introduce and in 1986 we had the fringe benefits tax. Company tax moved from 46c to 49c. Wine tax moved up to 20 per cent. In 1988 we had this complicated tax on superannuation. I will concede that the Government was forced by international pressures to reduce the company tax from 49c back to 39c in an endeavour to attract investment into Australia.

I draw the attention of the House to proposals for tax reform. The greatest problem facing all taxpayers in Australia is the fact that they are moving into a higher tax bracket and they are paying more total tax as their marginal rate goes up.

Access Economics Pty Ltd, in its publication of November 1988 and its suggestion of a broad brush for tax reform, made certain observations. The authors of this document have a Treasury background and put forward some very simple propositions which average Australians are now understanding very clearly. Under the current Government, the tax regime produces an incentive for consumption and debt. Of course, in those circumstances, there is no incentive for future saving and investment which is so vital in Australia. During the regime of this bracket creep, the income-based broadening consumption tax has actually been reduced.

The point that Access Economics is making, which all Australians now agree on, is the impact of inflation upon average income earners. As wages continue to grow by the effect of inflation, taxes go up. Over the last four or five years real wages have fallen, but because of the impact of bracket creep a higher proportion of wages is paid in tax. The tax is well ahead of inflation and the poor old wage earner's standard of living is falling in real terms. Again, that document refers to the peak zone of damage being in the area of $35,000 of income. At that level the top marginal rate is paid and it is suggested that by 1990 this will be 1.1 per cent of average weekly earnings and wage earners will be in that bracket.

If we look at the background of tax by stealth, where inflation pushes individual taxpayers into higher brackets, we can see the remarkable change over the years as taxpayers have moved into higher brackets by no fault of their own and by no legislation action by government. In 1954-55 the top marginal rate of 66c in the dollar was 18 times average weekly earnings. In the 1984-85 figures, this was a salary of $400,000 per annum. At that level of taxation, obviously income earners were being taxed at a high rate, but they certainly had to have a very high income.

In the 1970s, the top marginal rate was five times that of average weekly earnings. As we moved into the 1980s the 49c marginal rate cut in at $35,000, which was one and half times average weekly earnings. So the net result is that Australians have less tax and less money to put into savings and develop their own lifestyles. The other skewing of investment and inflationary pressures is the fact that the present Labor Government was not game politically to put a capital gains tax on domestic dwellings, so this made the investment appear in many different quarters. We saw the prices of houses in Sydney, Melbourne, Perth and around Australia reach record heights. One of the reasons was the fact that capital gains tax was placed upon investments in a very discriminatory way by the fact that housing was no longer capital gains taxed.

The National Australia Bank summary in December 1988 made some very interesting observations on the saving investment crisis facing Australia along the same lines. Our future place in the world, the future of our living standards and our lifestyles really depended upon addressing this problem of inflation and the way in which it affected the average taxpayer. Investment funds were now moving to houses which did not have any capital gains tax away from productive activities. The funds that have been accumulated by hard-working Australians and which should be put into bank accounts are now melting away with inflation. So Australians who have any spare capital or even those who can borrow some funds are putting them into property, shares, antiques as is the Treasurer (Mr Keating), paintings, insurance bonds, spas, swimming pools, and the domestic home that I have referred to.

There is a difficulty facing Australians with their funds. They have some concern about the drop in property values that is now becoming apparent and the fall in share market values that may be around the corner. If they invested $100 at 10 per cent they would receive a nominal $10. If inflation were running at, say, 6 per cent and they had to pay a 40 per cent tax rate of $4, their net return, especially if we took into consideration the Medicare levy of 1.25 per cent, would be negative for funds in investment holdings. The National Australia Bank, in its article, suggested that we ought to calculate interest and take into account the inflationary impact so that the investors and savers in Australia would be encouraged to leave their money in banks and building societies so that they could be made into productive investments for the betterment of Australia. A friend of mine in one of the biggest building finance industries in Victoria suggested, in discussions, that we should take a flat rate of tax from source at, say, 25 per cent, as that would provide an incentive for individuals to invest, and help the tax man obtain the rightful tax from those sources of funds that were invested in building societies.

I wish to refer to an article highlighting the difficulties that faced the Reagan Administration in America and some of the claims that had been made about the Reagan years. In my view, President Reagan tackled the problems with vigour and foresight and the United States economy continues to grow. The first claim the article made was that the United States deficit was excessive by world standards. However, commentators have tended to overlook the fact that there were $60 billion worth of surpluses at the State and local government level; whereas in Australia State and local governments and, until recent times, the Federal Government run massive deficits. The second claim was that the US trade deficit, unlike ours, was the result of a consumer binge, fuelled by tax cuts, causing a domestic deficit. Mr Maley, a visiting fellow at the commerce faculty of the University of New South Wales, suggested, in the article, that the change in the US deficit was the result of a massive reduction in US lending abroad. The third claim was that there was a debt-driven Keynesian import boom. However, during the Reagan years America created in excess of 15 million new jobs, dropping its unemployment rate to about 6 per cent. Mr Maley stated:

One of the outstanding features of the American economy over recent years has been the extraordinary flexibility and responsiveness of the labour market. Wage and work practice negotiations, occasionally on an industry basis but overwhelmingly by enterprises, have yielded private bargains forged in terms of enterprise survival and profitability.

The next claim was that US investment was lagging behind private saving at an all-time low. Mr Maley pointed out that under Reagan the US was the only major industrial nation to increase investment as a share of gross national product (GNP). The five points Mr Maley suggested as being the successes of the Reagan Administration were cutting tax; surging entrepreneurship and productivity in response to tax cuts; slowing the Carter regulatory explosion; reducing and containing total government expenditure as a proportion of GNP; restructuring and innovation in a competitive environment; and rapid labour market adjustment, especially at enterprise level.

Finally, I wish to bring to the House's attention Margaret Thatcher's comments on the problems faced by the Reagan Administration and her admiration for the way in which Reagan led the American people during the, at times, difficult economic conditions. At the end of his presidency the American economy remained buoyant and remarkable, given the length of time that it had maintained its profitability. The National Review of 1989 reports Margaret Thatcher as saying this about Reagan's leadership:

President Reagan saw instinctively that pessimism itself was the disease and that the cure for pessimism is optimism. He set about restoring faith in the prospects of the American dream-a dream of boundless opportunity built on enterprise, individual effort, and personal generosity. He infused his own belief in America's economic future in the American people. That was farsighted. It carried America through the difficult early days of the 1981-82 recession, because people are prepared to put up with sacrifices if they know that those sacrifices are the foundations of future prosperity.

Having restored the faith of the American people in themselves the President set about liberating their energies and enterprise. He reduced the excessive burden of regulation, halted inflation, and first cut and, later, radically reformed taxation. When barriers to enterprise are removed and taxes cut to sensible levels (as we have found in Britain in recent years), people have the incentive to work harder and earn more. They thereby benefit themselves, their families, and the whole community. Hence the buoyant economy of the Reagan years. It has expanded by a full 25 per cent over 72 months of continuous economic growth-the longest period of peacetime economic growth in US history; it has spread prosperity widely; and it has cut unemployment to the lowest level in over a decade.

I leave the House with this philosophical commitment of the next Howard-led government: the Howard government will cut taxes and expenditure and return Australia to a genuine long term prosperity that is not based on overseas borrowings, current account deficits and the capacity, as is the case with the present Government, to fudge the next difficult economic decision, which may be the case next Wednesday night when the Treasurer brings down his April statement in preparation for the election-whenever it is held.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I seek leave to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
—I do.
—The honourable member may proceed.

—The honourable member for Scullin (Mr Jenkins) suggested in his speech that on the television program Face to Face I had advocated allowing `the States to impose income tax'. I did not advocate that. If the honourable member for Scullin knew anything about the issue, he would--
—Order! The honourable member will not debate the matter. He has pointed out where he was misrepresented.
—If he knew anything about the issue he would know that they already have the power under the Fraser legislation.
—Order! The honourable member is now debating the issue. He will resume his seat.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Neil Mr L.R.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to take up some of the remarks of the honourable member for Corangamite (Mr McArthur), who spoke about some of the taxes the Government has introduced. We on this side of the House make no apology whatsoever for introducing a capital gains tax, a fringe benefits tax and for knocking off the free lunch. If that affects some of his supporters, some of the silvertails who had free lunches-that were called business lunches and were claimed as a tax deduction-that is hard luck. The working class people of Australia never had an opportunity to have so-called business lunches. I am delighted that we took action to knock off those free lunches.

SPEECH.PARA: I am also pleased that the Government stopped the bottom of the harbour schemes and introduced measures to stop tax avoidance. The Australian Labor Party should be extremely proud of some of the measures it has introduced to stop the rorting of the taxation system. When the honourable member for Corangamite holds up the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) as a symbol to get Australia on the road to economic wonders, one thinks of when we came to government: he had left us with a deficit of $9.6 billion. The inflation level had reached double digit figures and unemployment had gone through the roof. The honourable member for Corangamite is a brave man if he puts that fellow up as leader because the people of Australia do not have short memories. They will remember what that gentleman was like as Treasurer.

I was extremely pleased that the honourable member for Oxley (Mr Les Scott) said in his maiden speech that we had introduced the steel industry plan. As a member representing the steel industry city of Whyalla, I am extremely proud because on 16 April Whyalla will celebrate its seventy-fifth birthday. If ever a community can hold its head high, it is the Whyalla community. When Malcolm Fraser closed the shipbuilding industry in Whyalla, which is remote from most major cities, many people thought that it was the end of the world. Admittedly, Whyalla was down on its knees. But the people, with their resilience, intestinal fortitude and courage, stuck with it. As a result of the Labor Party's restructuring of the steel industry, Whyalla is now up and running again and doing extremely well.

I am extremely proud of that because Whyalla has a population consisting of 64 different nationalities. When immigration debates take place in the House I am extremely proud to say that we epitomise what immigration is all about. The 64 nationalities in Whyalla work extremely well together; they cooperate. I cannot praise enough the contribution that nationalities from all over the world have made to that community. It is very fitting that on 16 April Whyalla will celebrate 75 years of being. It should be very proud in doing so.

The Minister at the table, the very competent Minister for Employment and Education Services (Mr Duncan), raised with me the figures of youth unemployment. It is pleasing to note that a figure recently released pointed to a decrease in the number of teenage unemployed seeking full-time work of 15,700 to 77,800. That is 5.5 per cent of the teenage population. The teenage unemployment rate dropped to the lowest figure, 14.8 per cent, since the monthly surveys commenced in February 1978. We should pay a tremendous tribute to the Hawke Government for attaining those figures.

A continuing problem causing concern for the constituents of my electorate of Grey is the level of unemployment in the over-55 age group. It is a requirement for each person in receipt of unemployment benefit, to provide the unemployment benefit form SU 19b. This form needs to be completed each fortnight by the claimant to prove that he or she has been seeking, or searching for, work. While I am in favour of beneficiaries providing proof of their willingness to seek employment, it is of grave concern to me that many older men and women, many of whom have health problems which restrict the scope of occupations available to them over and above their age disadvantage, are finding it increasingly difficult to approach three different employers each fortnight to provide the required information.

Job opportunities in the Grey electorate are restricted to one basic employer in each of the Iron Triangle cities and small offshoot industrial and support industries. Add to this a large rural area-bigger than the majority of electorates represented here in the chamber-which at present is undergoing extreme drought conditions with associated problems for small business, and the result is an ever decreasing number of businesses able to survive, reducing the already depleted vacancies available. The circumstances which prevail in areas outside the metropolitan region make it well nigh impossible for a person already disadvantaged by age and possible health restrictions to fulfil the requirements laid down in form SU 19b. The bureaucrats who make these blanket decisions do not know or care about how the decisions will affect smaller populated areas such as the Grey electorate.

These people face humiliation each time they approach employers, only to be told that no employment is available to them due to age or health. The feeling of uselessness is debilitating to them. They constantly feel depressed and unworthy of any support. These people are not considered for positions vacant, competition being high for any vacant job. Applications are received from all areas of the State with young, healthy people being given preference each time, but still these people must continually approach employers in an effort to maintain their benefit rate.

Further to this, many large companies display signs at entrances to their premises which state that all company recruitment is made through the local Commonwealth Employment Service and no personal approaches to the company for employment will be considered. This further reduces the already limited area available to the job seeker to approach employers and puts further additional pressure on him or her to find the required number of companies or businesses to approach.

I understand that provision has been made whereby lodgment of the SU 19B form can be made on a 12-weekly basis under certain conditions. However, the problem still remains that, through the limited number of business houses and companies in the area and the long period of time in which the benefit would be drawn, these people still face the trauma of constant rejection. It is crucial that provision be made for a new category of benefit which encompasses these people. It should be a benefit which can be received without the stigma associated with drawing unemployment benefit for a long period and without the pressure of having to make approaches to employers on a constant basis, which the majority of the community recognises as a futile exercise. The benefit should take into consideration health and age factors for those people who do not meet the criteria for the invalid pension, but who are at a distinct disadvantage to the majority drawing unemployment benefit.

A constituent in my electorate who is suffering from silicosis is finding himself in the unenviable position of constantly approaching employers with regard to possible employment prospects and each time being told that his health condition and his age are against him. However, if this gentleman does not furnish the documentation required by the Department of Social Security and provide proof of his active job seeking, his benefit will be severed. The stress placed on this gentleman to provide the necessary documentation during each period is causing further deterioration of his health and well-being. He said, `After spending 40 years in the work force, I am being humiliated and demeaned because of my health condition and my age'. He continually makes approaches to the same employers even if he is feeling unwell.

This is an urgent situation which needs to be rectified immediately to give these people the respect they deserve. They do not wish to be reliant solely on benefit payment, but through no fault of their own they find themselves in this position. Many of them have been retrenched or have taken voluntary early retirement for age and health reasons. They do not have the same rights as a person on another form of pension or benefit; in many instances, they are at a greater disadvantage. For example, a small retrenchment package can return approximately $30 to $35 a week, as is the case for a single person claiming unemployment benefit. However, a pensioner on married pension is allowed $70 a week and a single pensioner $40 a week before the benefit is affected. This places the retrenched person at a distinct disadvantage. It may be said that retrenchment packages are voluntary, but let us not forget that in many cases those who accept voluntary or early retirement make way for younger people to enter the work force. I urge the Minister to look at encouraging this to take place by bringing the amount of allowable income for those on unemployment benefit at 55 and over in line with other benefits.

The idea of unemployment benefit being a temporary benefit needs to be laid to rest once and for all. In some areas of Australia we will never again achieve full employment, and this needs to be recognised. Consideration must be given to a form of benefit which will allow these people to receive benefits without the stress now endured by them. They should not be penalised because they are unable to compete successfully against younger people in an extremely competitive labour market.

A further problem affecting many people in my electorate is the rate of payment for Austudy for married men with dependants. Many men and women are returning to school to further studies to obtain new and necessary skills to allow them a fighting chance to seek employment in an area where employment prospects are low and competition is high. At present, the rate of payment for Austudy recipients with a dependent spouse and children is considerably lower than is the unemployment benefit. This is a disincentive to those people who are willing to take the enormous step of furthering their education.

A constituent in my electorate wanting to further his education was unable to do so because his rate of payment would be less than the married rate for unemployment benefit. This gentleman's financial commitments did not allow for a drop in his current benefit payment, as he had an expectant wife and two children to support. The age of the children, all under school age, does not allow for the wife to apply personally for unemployment benefit. Therefore, taking into account the Austudy payment with dependent spouse and assistance for the children through the family allowance supplement, this family would receive $50 less than if the husband stayed on the existing unemployment benefit. These are the people who must be assisted as a priority. They are willing to make the commitment by returning to school to further their knowledge to gain employment but many cannot take the desired step because of financial commitments. Their budget does not allow for a decrease in existing benefit payment.

I understand that in this time of spending restraint, we must spend according to Budget allowance. However, I feel that these people deserve our assistance immediately. They have taken the step to further their skills; they have shown their willingness and incentive to give themselves a better chance to return to the work force. They do not class the receiving of benefits as their inherent right, nor do they wish to continue in this manner. Their desire to obtain work through self-betterment is worthy of support by all of us here today.

I ask that assistance be made available at the earliest opportunity to allow married men and women who wish to take this step to do so with confidence and financial security. I implore all honourable members present to show their commitment to the many ordinary men and women facing this situation and ask that the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) give urgent consideration to the plight of many of our fellow Australians and have the problems within the system rectified as soon as possible. I note that the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand), who is sitting at the table, is nodding in agreement and I am pleased that he is very supportive of this.

TALK.START.PARA: —I always support you, because you put sensible arguments at all times.

—I thank the Minister. I conclude by mentioning a progressive move that is taking place in my electorate which, I am pleased to say, has the full support of the people I represent. I refer to the acquisition of Special Broadcasting Service (SBS) television. For a long period I have been attempting, through various Ministers for Transport and Communications, to have priority given to the Spencer Gulf area in my electorate for the broadcast of SBS television. It is quite appropriate that this should be done. As I said earlier in my speech, people of 64 different nationalities live in Whyalla. A strong contingent of Italians and Greeks live at Port Pirie. These people like to be associated with SBS television, not only because of the soccer, which they all like, but also because of the first class news services and other services shown on SBS. I am pleased that the present Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Willis) is very sympathetic to the cause. I hope that in the not too distant future I will be able to announce that the Spencer Gulf area in my electorate will be able to receive SBS television. This will be a tremendous breakthrough. I can assure the people in my electorate that I will continue to strive to have this first-class, superb television service broadcast to my area. I certainly support it wholeheartedly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cobb Mr M.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have just heard a compassionate and sincere speech from the honourable member for Grey (Mr O'Neil). Perhaps it is a pity that he, instead of some other members of the Government, is not on the front bench. I congratulate the honourable member on his speech and the bipartisanship which he displayed.

SPEECH.PARA: I am particularly delighted to see the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) at the table tonight. No doubt he specially came into the chamber to hear my speech. I wish to raise a matter on which I received quite a sympathetic hearing for the Minister some time ago. I am pleased to see him in the chamber tonight to hear me speak on the matter again. The matter I wish to raise concerns the St Ignatius Catholic primary school at Bourke which has 150 pupils, about a third of whom are Aboriginal children. In 1987 the teachers and principal of the school took a quite novel and bold step when they started to run some classes with Aboriginal children and some classes with white children. I have to say that this has been done with considerable success. The arrangement has been very beneficial for the Aboriginal children.

At the outset, lest anyone should think that I am talking about apartheid in any shape or form, I would like to explain what has happened. Much agonising thought went into this decision before it was made. In fact, from what I hear, the teachers had considered the matter and had talked about it for about 10 years. When they eventually went ahead, they did so against the advice of nearly everybody else. But the teachers at the school, who have a particular compassion for Aboriginal children, recognised the disadvantage that existed. People who have had some experience with Aboriginal children, particularly in country towns, will know that most Aboriginal children arriving at school for the first time have never had a book in their hand, their parents may not have a television and, therefore, they have never seen Sesame Street and they do not know the alphabet frontwards and backwards as many white children do. Therefore, they start behind many of their classmates.

Aboriginal children also have an inherent natural shyness. They have a fear of being embarrassed if they are asked a question. They fear that they will be humiliated if they do not understand something. I guess this is a natural fear. Unfortunately, if they do not understand something they are too frightened to ask about it and this leads to boredom and, eventually, to mischief. In the end it sadly leads to absenteeism and lack of motivation. As a result many Aboriginal children end up learning very little.

Recognising this, the sisters and lay teachers at the school consulted the Aboriginal parents in Bourke who sent their children to the school. The Aboriginal parents readily agreed with the teachers that it would be a good idea to trial having the Aboriginal children in separate classes. I guess most of the Aboriginal parents trusted the sisters because they knew that they intended to do well for the children. They said, `Do whatever you think is best for them'. When the classes were started they were an instant success. The Aboriginal children immediately had a higher degree of confidence when they sat in classrooms purely amongst their own. They became keen to learn. They started to learn rapidly and, not surprisingly, their attendance levels rose. Of course, the white children, who were not being disrupted by bored Aboriginal children, started to do better too. So this was a beneficial side effect.

I hasten to say that all of the Aboriginal parents were given the option that their children could still attend white classes if they so wished. One or two of the Aboriginal parents chose to have their children stay in the white classes. But most of them volunteered to put their children in these separate classes. The children, of course, still mix. They mix for sport and they mix in the playground. The still mix in classes for music, arts and craft and, interestingly enough, science.

Aboriginal children are taught in a flexible way when they attend the separate classes. If the bell rings at the end of 40 minutes and they are learning something about which they are all interested and keen, the teachers will ignore the bell and continue the lesson. They just play it by ear. I guess that is the secret of the success. I would not say that this arrangement would normally work anywhere. However, it works very well at St Ignatius because the teachers have a high degree of experience. They have a great love of the Aboriginal children at the school and their attitude is absolutely A1. I cannot stress too much how necessary that is for this scheme to work. On top of that, the scheme would work only where there was a high number of disadvantaged Aboriginal children students. If they were not in a disadvantaged position it would not, of course, be necessary to take such a step.

I pay a tribute to Sister Eileen Quade, a former principal of the school, for taking this bold step. I also pay a tribute to Sister Marietta, Lois Wilson and the other teachers who have followed on and been involved in the scheme. The morale of the school, as a whole, has gone up since then. I do believe that this school could be a blueprint for other schools in other towns in similar situations. Perhaps the same model could even be tried in some secondary schools. I know that the situation in some of the secondary schools is quite desperate in many aspects, even in towns like Bourke, where the percentage of absenteeism and mischief-making is at an abysmal level in many cases.

We have to recognise that in some of these outback towns, where the Aborigines tend to live on the fringes, the children suffer a type of culture shock when they turn up at school for the first time. They are disadvantaged, because it is not unusual for some of them to sleep in three or four different homes through the week. I have seen them bashed after pension night. It can be unusual for seven, eight or nine-year-olds not to have been sexually molested. It is terribly sad, because it forms a pattern in their minds and sets them on a road of behaviour which is detrimental to them and to the whole community. If somehow we could educate a generation of Aboriginal children to grow up and move normally into the work force and become-this is the most important point-responsible parents, who will be deeply concerned to do the best for their children and to see that their children go through school, take the hard subjects, study and do well and get jobs, we will hopefully be progressing towards getting over some of the problems we have today with Aboriginal people in Australia.

This scheme is working. In fact, it is the only successful Aboriginal story of some magnitude that I know of in my electorate. I am delighted that it is working so well. One other problem at that school, which I did raise with the Minister some time ago and to which the Minister has given some consideration, for which I am grateful, is the aspect of fees. Everybody at the school is obliged to pay a fee. The black parents, generally speaking, have not paid any fees at all to speak of. That places an extra burden on the school most of which is ultimately put back to the white parents, some of whom are getting a little tired of this. I acknowledge it is very difficult to suggest the correct solution.

One can talk about just giving a straight Government grant, or garnisheeing welfare cheques, to ensure that the payments will be made. But it is not quite as easy as that. For example, if one did something as drastic as garnisheeing the welfare cheque of an Aboriginal parent, the parent probably would not send the child to school. That would be a particular shame. In a Budget this year for Aboriginals of $808m, this area certainly needs consideration.

I move now to another topic which I have raised twice previously this week; that is, the plight of the people in the Nyngan area because of the floods there in the last week. I want to apprise honourable members and get on the record what is happening. As I have said before, several tens of thousands of sheep in that area have already been lost because of flood waters which have covered about 5,000 square kilometres in my electorate. There is now an immediate concern for the 40,000 or more sheep which are still standing in water, or standing on little islands in the water. Some of them have been standing in water for five days or more. Fortunately, today I am pleased to announce that there has been a decrease in the level of the waters in some areas. This decrease has allowed the farmers to move some of their sheep to higher ground, or at least towards higher ground, because in some cases sheep have to be moved through water for up to 10 miles, which is a very slow and tiresome process.

I am grateful to the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) for making available a Chinook helicopter which arrived yesterday. It can lift about six tonnes which is 150 to 200 bales at a time. Yesterday afternoon, on its first run, it delivered several hundred bales to these starving sheep. Today it has made about five drops which amounted to 25 or 30 tonnes. At this stage, though, we are only feeding sheep which are on ground; we are not yet feeding any sheep still in the water. I am pleased to announce also that the sheep ate ravenously where the hay was dropped. We did not experience any shy feeders, as often happens when sheep are fed with fodder for the first time. They all moved and ate straight away.

I would like to pay tribute to the Haddon Rig stud which made available 20,000 bales of first cut lucerne at cost, which works out at about $3 a bale. I guess it could have normally sold that for about $4.50, so it is quite a generous gesture. The farmers who receive this hay of course have to pay $3 for the bale and they pay 50 per cent of the cost of the freight to get it from Haddon Rig through to Nyngan where it is picked up by the helicopter. That particular freight cost does not amount to much and the State Government picks up the rest of the cost. The chopper, of course, is very expensive to run. I am told it costs around $9,000 an hour, which sounds like an extraordinary amount of money, but there are 10 personnel up there with the Chinook helicopter and two refuellers. Of course, the services of the helicopter are provided free to the farmers in the area.

The State Government provides certain benefits for the people in these difficulties, the main one of which is $40,000 which will become available later for those in need, at a concessional interest rate of 6 per cent. When that amount was first set I guess it was a reasonably generous thing to do. One cannot have a drain too much on the public purse. Probably nobody appreciates that fact more than I. Even in this Federal forum, I say to my State Government colleagues that there may be a need to review this. It will not affect very many people in that area, but there will be some people in desperate need. Some of them have lost several thousand sheep. They have nearly lost all the sheep they had. Forty thousand dollars will probably only buy 500 or 600 sheep these days. Some people have lost 10 times that amount. Those sheep will have to be replaced.

Today I was talking to Merv and Gloria Johnson on the phone and they were telling me the most incredible stories. They have lost about 6,000 sheep and they still have 600 or 700 alive, standing in water. The sheep have gone up to low shrubby trees and are putting their necks in the branches of the trees to try to keep out of the water. As one can appreciate, the length of the fleece is very critical and these sheep are heavy in wool. The water goes into the fleece, is held there, and can give the sheep an extra 20, 30 or 40 pounds of weight. It becomes very tiresome for the sheep to try to stand up. If they go down they drown. The Johnsons, of course, are very stressed, because they are seeing their life's work being literally washed away overnight. It is a very tragic situation. How they will replace those sheep is beyond me.

I know one chap south of Gongolgon who has lost 5,000 sheep out of 5,500. He is only a small-time fellow. He is not a rich grazier, in any sense of the word. He had built up his business and this will no doubt ruin him. Another fellow, Chris Elder, and his wife, moved, I believe, onto their farm only a couple of months ago. They put 4,000 of their best ewes, the great bulk of their flock, on the Bogan River and they cannot even find any of those 4,000 ewes, from what I last heard. Imagine the distress that is causing them.

I was talking this matter over earlier this evening with Jeff Wise, who has been marvellous in this whole thing. He is the district veterinary officer based at Dubbo. We talked about the plight these people are in. When disaster strikes people they usually lose either their assets or their income. They rarely lose both. The people at Lismore, for example, or in the cyclone at Gympie, could lose their house or have it ruined in the flood. If, for example, a person loses a job then he or she loses an income. But these people here have essentially lost both income and assets. Perhaps there is a special case for them. They cannot insure their assets because the premiums they would have to pay make that just beyond the pale. Most of them-not all-are in debt already. The value of the assets which they have lost is probably equivalent to the equity portion covering their debt. One can imagine the situation they are in. Having lost all their sheep they have lost their income, so they cannot serve their existing debt, let alone the costs that will arise from now on with replacing sheep, replacing fencing-the average farmer up there would have lost several thousand dollars worth of fencing-as well as paying for feed for the stock they have left, cleaning out dams, the cost of delaying shearing, et cetera. If left alone these people can only go backwards. It would mean ruin for some. That would be a shame because we would be losing skills built up over not one generation but sometimes several generations. It is very hard to be a stockman and survive out in that area. It is a pretty harsh climate. My heart goes out to those people, as I am sure do the hearts of all in this chamber.

I have already spoken of some of the problems that are yet to come, such as the sheep deaths that will still occur from the weakness that will eventually overcome them; from bogging in the mud as the waters recede and they try to get to water to have a drink; from the ewes lambing-fortunately there are not too many up there; and the pregnancy toxaemia problems that go with ewes heavy in lamb. One of the big problems that will arise from now on is fly strike because of the humid conditions and wetness of the wool. Some of the sheep will be eaten alive by maggots-not a pleasant thing to experience.

Possibly worst of all, and something we do not learn too much about from the agricultural and veterinary manuals, is the peculiar problem that arises when sheep stand in water for many days. After seven days or so their hooves soften to such an extent that they separate from the coronet, the lower leg. When sheep move through the black soil up there, it sucks off their hooves. I was talking to a fellow, Mac George, who went through this with a mob in 1976. He said that after the water receded and the sheep were standing in the little pools of mud, they drove them up onto the higher and harder ground but the sheep immediately turned around and went back into the mud because their hooves were so tender and flyblown. They were so stressed that they just wanted to get back for relief. They lost the will to eat and eventually they all had to be destroyed. The ironic thing in that case was that poly pipe and pumps had to be flown in by helicopter to provide the sheep with water because they could not get to the water; if they had to go through the mud they just bogged in it.
We can see from that the sorts of problems these people have to put up with. I ask everybody to be aware of those problems, and if special help is needed perhaps consideration should be given to it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent Mr L.

TALK.START.PARA: —In today's debate on the Appropriation Bills I would like to speak on a couple of important matters. One is the matter of privatisation, which has re-emerged just when everybody thought it had been buried by the last Australian Labor Party National Conference. Australia has very few public enterprises, public assets, compared with many other Western nations. We just heard the honourable member for Parkes (Mr Cobb) talking about farmers losing their assets. That illustrates how catastrophic it would be if the Australian people lost their assets. It ever privatisation comes they would lose their assets; they would lose their employment, they would lose their livelihood. Britain and France, with whom we compare ourselves, have until recently had public ownership, even in the areas of car and steel manufacture. The topic of privatisation pops up with such regularity and such tenacity that one wonders what fuels it.

SPEECH.PARA: Privatisation is the dogma of the New Right which was embraced by members of the Federal Opposition a few years ago. When it was first mooted by them our side of the House flatly rejected it, and rightly so. As I mentioned, there are very few public enterprises in Australia-many fewer than in most Western democracies that we usually compare ourselves with. Those public enterprises that we do have were not set up for ideological reasons but out of sheer necessity, either because private enterprise did not want to invest in areas it saw as unprofitable or because it was found that public enterprise was needed to compete with a private monopoly to protect the public interest from private greed. So when one considers the roles of public enterprise, one of which is to keep private companies honest, one can understand why privatisation is so keenly sought by some conservatives.

By destroying public enterprises the privateers will achieve two things. First, there will be no public competition and therefore no check on private cartels. Second, there is a handsome profit to be made in banking, telecommunications and aviation by the corporate raiders and the financiers if they are allowed to grab our profitable public enterprises such as the Commonwealth Bank, Telecom Australia, Australian Airlines and Qantas Airways Ltd. This nation is indeed indebted to my Party, the great Australian Labor Party, for not allowing such economic cannibalism. Believe me, there are lots of economic cannibals who would love to take part in the feast of privatisation and gobble up our very efficient and profitable public enterprises. I do not want to be uncharitable and name some of these fat cats from the corporate world, titled or untitled, who would benefit enormously from privatisation at the expense of the general public.

Let us remember that privatisation has been tried elsewhere and has been found wanting. In Britain the sale of public assets was used to finance once-off tax cuts for the rich. In France, profitable public enterprises were flogged off by the Government to its corporate friends at bargain basement prices. Do we want to see a deregulated transport market with all of the planes flying under Sir Peter's colours, making uncontrolled profits at the risk of passenger safety? Or do we want to see our national carrier, Qantas, taken over by a foreign cartel? Of course not. However, whilst there is strong resistance within the Government to privatisation, those who would benefit from it-a mighty powerful group of the Establishment-have managed to persuade some members of the Cabinet of its usefulness. They have of course disguised their greed by referring to quasi-economic arguments such as `private is efficient, public is inefficient', `why should the Government invest money in enterprises when private consortiums can do it better', and so on.

Let us pause for a moment to examine these totally unsupported assertions. There is not one iota of evidence to support the claim that private enterprises are inherently more efficient than public ones. The fact is that there are many very efficient and profitable public enterprises, like the Commonwealth Bank, and there are many inefficient and unprofitable privately owned enterprises, like the notorious Nugan Hand Bank. As far as efficiency is concerned one has only to look at the long list of failed companies that were inefficiently managed by the private sector. The latest scandal of mismanagement and alleged misappropriation of funds is the saga of the private rescue organisation, the National Safety Council of Australia. It certainly illustrates how costly it can be to let private enterprises take over the functions of government and run them without proper control. It is mind-boggling to think that an individual such as this one can set up a $2 company with a private army clad in uniforms and wearing insignia reminiscent of the swastika and milk out of that private company tens or even hundreds of millions of dollars and then disappear as mysteriously as he appeared. It took a nationwide manhunt to find him. As the Age put it on 23 March:

With the Victorian division (of the NSCA) facing liquidation, with potential debts of $235 million, questions are being asked about how it has been able to afford to acquire helicopters and turbo prop aircraft reputably better equipped for search and rescue than some aircraft available to the defence forces.

Of course, there are many more questions that should be asked about this matter, especially relating to national security. As in the case of the failed Nugan Hand Bank, we may ask what role the Central Intelligence Agency (CIA) and our own spooks in the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation (ASIO) played in the NSCA. I do not expect any real answer to this question as the spooks, domestic or foreign, shy away from public exposure and scrutiny. I doubt that we will ever hear the full story. However, it is our duty as members of parliament to charge our colleagues on the Joint Parliamentary Committee on the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation to probe how it was that our spooks did not take a proper and timely interest in the mysteries of the NSCA. In its recent annual report ASIO drew the public's attention to the activities of foreign diplomats in Australia and their role in gathering information from Australians of ethnic origin. However, it failed to mention the interest and involvement of United States diplomats and military attaches in the NSCA. When the matter was reported and the attention of the Victorian Commissioner of Police was drawn to the fact that there may be some CIA involvement in the NSCA, Commissioner Glare declared, `That is not illegal'. One wonders how much confidence one can have in so-called private resource organisations carrying out a function which should be properly carried out by the State and not by alleged charities and CIA front organisations.

But let us leave the spooks for another debate and concentrate on privatisation. As far as efficiency is concerned, that is a mixed bag. Some public companies are efficient and some are not, just as some private companies are efficient and others are not. Efficiency is determined not by the type of ownership but by the quality of management, technology, capitalisation, the loyalty of the work force and the degree of competition. The privatisers do not wish to take over the fire brigades, the suburban railways or tramways, the Country Fire Authority and so on, but they are aiming to buy Australian Airlines, Qantas and the Australian Telecommunications Commission at bargain basement prices. Each of these public enterprises is well managed. Each of them is highly profitable and is becoming increasingly profitable every year. As well as providing necessary public services and performing a necessary role as watchdog over private enterprise, each of these companies puts much of its profit back into the public purse for the benefit of the community. The same cannot be said about private companies. Some do not even pay their taxes.

In a recent edition of the Brisbane Courier-Mail a front page article entitled `The corporate giants that paid no income tax' pointed out that six of Queensland's 15 largest companies paid no income tax last year while a few others were listed to have paid only between 0.5 per cent and 33 per cent, and only three paid or exceeded the 39 per cent company tax limit. Contrast this to the return to the public provided by our top public enterprises. For instance, Qantas's operating profit has increased from $62.3m in 1984-85 to $153.3m in 1987-88. Telecom's profit has increased from $385.2m in 1984-85 to $777m in 1987-88. Over the same period Australian Airlines' profit has increased from $29.9m to $46.8m and the Commonwealth Bank's profit has increased from $223m to $273.4m. What juicy targets for our corporate raiders! I am glad that the party I belong to has resisted the onslaught of the greedy privateers. No doubt the Opposition will continue to press for privatisation with dogmatic tenacity in an attempt to buy the support of the greedy corporate sector, the support it used to enjoy but lost because of its catastrophic mismanagement of the Australian economy when it was in power during the Fraser-Howard years.

This brings me to the second matter that I want to discuss. It has become fashionable lately to insinuate that the Labor Government has abandoned Labor principles and its supporters and taken up the cause of the rich and powerful. Honourable members will know that I am not uncritical of the decisions of the Executive. I have in this place criticised decisions such as the sale of uranium to France, the introduction of identity cards, deregulation and, as I have today, privatisation. But I cannot accept the unfounded and unsubstantiated criticism that the Hawke Government has abandoned the workers and battling families of Australia. No government in Australia's history has done as much for working people as our Labor Government. The Opposition, which is laden with millionaire businessmen and other useless sons of the Establishment, and the press constantly claim that Labor has betrayed its traditional supporters, yet the same people always oppose workers, wage rises, job creation and improvements in the social wage.

Let us compare this to the achievements of the Hawke Labor Government. We have delivered modest and sustainable wage rises despite the constant opposition of the conservatives. We have created 1.3m jobs. Nowhere else is the contrast between the previous Government and this one so stark. The conservatives when last in power threw hundreds of thousands of wage and salary earners out of work. We got them back to work again, and everyone knows that having or not having a job is the key difference between those who are in poverty and those who are not.

We have also cleaned up the taxation system, under which it was almost optional for the high income earners to pay tax. As I said before, some companies are still trying to avoid it. In the last three financial years the Labor Government has raised more than $2.4 billion through the fringe benefits tax. In 1982-83, the last year of the Fraser-Howard Government, only $4.8 billion was raised from company tax and $259m from withholding tax. This compares with $10.2 billion from company tax and $700m from withholding tax raised by the Labor Government last year. Even allowing for inflation this is a considerable increase. In addition, the Australian Taxation Office is now hunting down corporate tax minimisation schemes by conducting detailed audits of suspected companies.

Let us look at education. We have kept more working class children at school than ever before, Prior to the election of the Hawke Government only 36 per cent of students completed year 12. This figure is now 60 per cent, and there are many more places in higher education for students to proceed to upon completion of high school, thanks to our expansion of the tertiary education system.

This Labor Government has been quietly and steadily going about the job of reconstructing and restoring the economy, which was left in a shambles by the previous Fraser-Howard Government. As a result, we have improved the standard of living of the people. Our annual income per head of population has increased in real terms by more than $2,500 per year since 1983. The authors of `Futile Diversions' are the guilty men of the past who for decades let this country rely on the export of agricultural products and mining commodities and neglected to support our manufacturing industries. In its document called Future Directions, the Liberal Party laments `Labor policies which have attempted to shield certain groups in the community from the effects of a reduced national income'. Well, we on this side of the House do not apologise for attempting to shield those families and groups in the community which have fallen victim to decades of conservative support for capitalist greed. We do not apologise for the family assistance scheme-a milestone in Australian social legislation-which targets payments directly to some 150,000 low income families. Under the scheme a family with three children and earning under the income test level will make a tax free gain of $86 per week, increasing by a further $15.26 if they rent privately. Nor do we apologise for increasing the number of people who are in superannuation schemes.

Labor's supporters in the conservation movement will note that we have acted decisively to protect the Australian environment. We prevented the damming of the Franklin River. We handed the administration of Uluru back to the traditional Aboriginal owners. The Labor Government prevented the despoliation of the Daintree Rainforest and took steps to protect the Kakadu National Park from mineral and mining exploration by adding a further 7,000 square kilometres to the World Heritage List. Most recently, we have prevented the Tasmanian Government from lowering environmental safeguard standards for the Wesley Vale pulp mill project and from consequently dumping enormous quantities of highly toxic substances into the environment.

No amount of Future Directions or diversions will cover up the difference between the way this Government has treated its traditional supporters and the way they were treated by the Opposition when it was in power. Australian families are much better off today than they were under Fraser and Howard. The affairs of this nation are in good hands, and the Australian people know that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—Of course they know that, because they have a job to go to and that is thanks to the Labor Government and its policies. The Australian people will not be diverted by the cheap Opposition manifestos or by last minute promises. They will ensure that at the next election, whenever it is held, the affairs of the nation remain in good hands by re-electing the Hawke Labor Government for a fourth term.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Porter Mr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —After that speech by the honourable member for Hotham (Mr Kent), people would think that everything in the garden was rosy. One wonders whether these Labor politicians ever get out of this place into the electorate. If the honourable member would venture out of his office-and I bet he is too scared to do so-he would find that there is a great deal of concern amongst the Australian public about the policies of this Government which have driven more out of their homes, fewer people can afford homes and we have the longest public hospital queues that we have ever had in this country.
—What do you think I did before I came into Parliament?
—Order! The honourable member for Hotham was heard in silence. I ask him to extend the same courtesy to the present speaker.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. I appreciate your defence, but I do not really think I need it. Nevertheless, I will continue with the comments I want to make and leave the people to judge the honourable member's comments.

SPEECH.PARA: Before the last election the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) said that by 1990 no Australian child would be living in poverty. As this House knows, he said subsequently that what he really meant was that by 1990 no child would need to live in poverty. More recently he has watered down that commitment even further to claim that there would be no financial need for any child to live in poverty. One could well argue that that is already the case-that with our welfare system there is indeed no financial need for children to live in poverty. But plenty do. Unfortunately, there are many parents who spend their welfare payments not on looking after their children but on other things, such as alcohol.

Even so, part of the Prime Minister's program for achieving his goal of eradicating child poverty is the child support scheme. Basically, this scheme is to improve the collection and payment of maintenance from the non-custodial parent of a broken marriage. For some time the concern has been the default rates on maintenance, which were extremely high-up to 70 per cent of non-custodial parents were not making regular payments or were making payments that were less than the maintenance awarded. As a result, the onus of the sole parent was falling on taxpayers in general, rather than on the non-custodial parent.

Under the child support scheme, employers deducting tax also deduct maintenance payments from the wages of the participating non-custodial parents. The employer then pays it over to the Australian Taxation Office and the Tax Office then passes the money to the Department of Social Security, which in turn pays it to the supporting parent. A new branch of the Australian Taxation Office, called the Child Support Agency, is the collecting agency under the legislation. The Agency costs about $10m a year to administer and employs a staff of 180. Other departments are involved, too. The Attorney-General's Department has 47 new members of staff at a cost of about $2m and the Department of Social Security has an undisclosed number of new staff to administer the scheme.

The Child Support Agency is operated out of the Tax Office because employers are already collecting tax on behalf of the Government and therefore the maintenance payments are merely added to the tax which is already paid by the employer. The money collected from the non-custodial parent by the employer is paid to the Tax Office once a month with the employer's normal tax payments. The Child Support Agency then puts all the collections together and turns them over to the Department of Social Security, which is responsible for making the payments.

The Government decided that payments of maintenance by the Department of Social Security would be made monthly on the first Wednesday of the month following the month when the money was collected and was paid over by the Tax Office. I want to raise the problem of the long delays in this bureaucratic procedure. Take, for example, a maintenance award for support of, say, $50 a week. Deductions for maintenance are made from the non-custodial parent's wages beginning, say, on 3 November, a Friday, and each Friday thereafter. By the end of November the non-custodial parent has made maintenance payments of $200 but none has yet been paid to the supporting parent. By 7 December the $200 is paid by the employer to the Tax Office. In the meantime the non-custodial parent has made another payment of $50. The Tax Office gives the money to the Child Support Agency, which then turns it over to the Department of Social Security, which then has to prepare to make the payment. That preparation includes giving effect to the Department's claw-back rules. These rules apply certain income tests to the benefits the Department pays out under various income support programs. To the extent that the custodial parent receives maintenance payments from the non-custodial parent, money otherwise payable under the Department of Social Security's pension and benefit programs may be reduced.

The Department of Social Security takes a month to receive the disbursement from the Child Support Agency within the Tax Office, effect its claw-back, advise the banks and financial institutions and finally make the payment. Under the hypothetical example that I have given it makes that payment on 6 January. That payment, which was originally made by the non-custodial parent on 3 November, is finally made to the supporting parent on 6 January, the first Wednesday of the month following the month when the money was due with the Registrar. The payment made on 6 January will be $200. By that time the non-custodial parent has in fact made payments of $500. A full 10 weeks' payments have been made, but the supporting parent receives only four weeks' payment. In other words, it takes 2 1/2 months for the first maintenance payment made by the non-custodial parent to actually get to the supporting parent. Rationalising this delay, the Treasurer's office says that it is simply the cost to the individual supporting parent who has signed up for the scheme of having the agency as his or her cost-free enforcer of maintenance in the future.

I have raised complaints that I have received from supporting parents in my electorate with the Treasurer (Mr Keating). As honourable members can imagine, the Treasurer's response was entirely unsatisfactory. He admitted that there is a 2 1/2-month delay and said that there is nothing that he can do about it. I repeat: the cost of entering into this maintenance scheme is a 2 1/2-month delay before the sole parent actually receives the maintenance payment. No wonder the Director of Research and Information at the Law Institute, Mrs Carol Bartlett, said:
We do need a system of automatic collection, but they have messed the present effort with hopeless and uncoordinated administration.

How many times have we heard that said of this Government? Who is the one who suffers from all this? It is the poor sole supporting parent, the one who is left with the children and no income, the one who experiences a 2 1/2-month delay in receiving the payment made by the non-custodial parent. The 2 1/2-month delay is a serious deficiency in the scheme. The Government has a duty to the sole parents to do better. I urge the Government to speed up the payments to initial entrants to the scheme.

The other matter I want to raise in this debate also relates to the Tax Office. There has been a lot of publicity recently about the Tax Office's issue of tax file numbers. I want to go to the origin of the tax file number because I think there is a serious problem in the way in which the Tax Office is issuing tax file numbers. I was on the committee that reviewed the Government's original proposal for an ID card, the Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card. I am sure that the House recalls that that Committee rejected the Government's proposal. When we on the Committee were hearing the evidence from representatives of the Tax Office, I raised with them the possibility of using the tax file number instead of an ID card. One of the concerns I had was whether the revenue gains from using the tax file number would be similar to those from using the ID card, that is, in the tax area. The response that the Tax Office gave, in a letter dated 6 March 1986 given to the Committee, was:
The use of the existing tax file number with its very low integrity would produce relatively little extra revenue.

So, when the proposal to use a tax file number was first raised with representatives of the Tax Office they said that it would raise little extra revenue because the integrity of the tax file number is so low.

As the months wore on, the Tax Office got the message that we were not going to support the ID card but rather that we were going to suggest that the Government implement a tax file number. The Tax Office then came back to the Committee and proffered another view.

TALK.START.PARA: —You were not the only one opposed to the ID card.

—The honourable member is quite right. But none of the Government members crossed the floor when the vote came on. They talked about it but they never acted on it. One member of the Labor Party had the guts to vote according to his conscience, but not the honourable member for La Trobe or the little weasel that sits next to him and gets up here each night and tells us how terrific he is.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I take a point of order. I object to those personal remarks by the honourable member. I do not indulge in such personal remarks and, Mr Deputy Speaker, I ask that you ask him not to indulge in them, either.
—I ask the honourable member to withdraw that remark.
—I withdraw the remark. It is quite clear that the left wing--
—Sensitive.

—Members of the left wing are not only sensitive; they are also absolutely gutless. They are all talk and no action. An opportunity was given to the honourable member to cross the floor and vote against the ID card and he did not do it. He voted with the Government for the ID card. As I was saying, when it became clear to the Tax Office that we were going to oppose the ID card and recommend a tax file number, it had a change of heart. As I said before the honourable member interjected, initially the Tax Office had said that the use of the existing tax file number with its very low integrity would produce relatively little extra revenue. As I have said, subsequently it came back to us in a letter dated 25 March 1986 and said that it was possible to use the tax file number:

SPEECH.PARA: It would seem a reasonable proposition that the identity of taxpayers who have been regularly lodging tax returns and paying tax for more than five years could be accepted at face value at the commencement of any upgraded identity check procedures. The three million taxpayers with a taxation record of five years or under would be invited to confirm their identity . . .

In other words, the Tax Office was saying to us, `You could use a tax file number and one of the ways you could use it would be to accept the tax file numbers of those people who have been putting in tax returns for five years or more and ask those who have more recently put in tax returns to prove their identity'. We accepted that evidence. In fact, when the Government introduced the tax file number legislation that is what we believed would happen. I believed, as I think nearly everyone in the Parliament believed, that the tax file number system would be likely to improve tax collections, that it would enable the Tax Office better to link information it obtains from banks and other financial institutions with income tax returns. We believed that the Office would ensure the integrity of the tax file numbers by accepting only those who had a record of lodging tax returns with the Tax Office and asking others to prove their identity. When the legislation went through this Parliament a lot of discussion was concentrated on the proof of identity procedures.

Has Mr Boucher, in the rush to the next election, actually adopted those procedures? No. The Government is terrified of upsetting anyone and has given the orders: `We do not want to ruffle any feathers. We want to issue everyone with a tax file number. Issue them to everyone! It does not matter whether they are dead people, anonymous people, the ghosts in the system-issue tax file numbers to them all'. What is more, in South Australia they are being issued in unsealed envelopes. No wonder the Privacy Commissioner complained today about the way this matter has been handled.

The concern I have is that the mass issue of tax file numbers undermines the integrity of the whole system. The Tax Office has confirmed that it is issuing tax file numbers. It is automatically sending tax file numbers to all those who submitted an income tax return last year. It is posting them out to everyone who did not lodge a return through a tax agent. So it is issuing them to people who lodged a return for the first time last year. Mr Deputy Speaker, I remind you that last year there was an amnesty. Anyone could go along and lodge a tax return. So instead of purging the false names the Tax Office is, in effect, confirming the legitimacy of all the false names in the system. The Tax Office complained to us two years ago that these false names would undermine the value of using the tax file number. It told us that the use of the existing tax file number, with its very low integrity, would produce relatively little extra revenue. It was saying that the only way to use the tax file number was to upgrade its integrity. That is what the Tax Office said it would do. Is it doing it? No. It is just posting tax file numbers to everyone, even the people who used the amnesty last year to lodge returns.

Who could have lodged returns last year? Let me give some examples. An itinerant worker who completed a number of tax returns last year in the false names under which he or she worked will now be sent tax file numbers for all those false names. He will therefore be able legitimately to continue to evade tax-certainly legitimately under this procedure-by splitting his income amongst the Tax Office legitimised false identities. So all the false identities have now been posted tax file numbers and people continue to work under three or four names and put in three or four tax returns in those false names. What do they get? They get the advantage of the tax free threshold three or four times. What on earth are we implementing this whole system for?
Mr Kent interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member should be quiet; we have had enough of him. What is the system for? We introduced the system to improve the integrity of the tax file number and increase tax collections. What the Government is doing through the Commissioner of Taxation, Mr Boucher, is knowingly issuing tax file numbers to ghosts. The Tax Commissioner has said to us, `We cannot issue them to everyone because of the low integrity of the tax file number'. Yet that is what he is doing. What more proof do we want? He is sending them to dead people.
—Really dead people.
—As the honourable member for Moreton says, really dead people. The situation is hopeless. This Government is spending $280m on a worthless scheme.
—Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Milton Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am taking the opportunity, in supporting Appropriation Bill (No. 3), to congratulate the Government and the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, Senator Richardson, on the decision to ensure that the environmental guidelines relating to the Wesley Vale pulp mill in Tasmania will be strictly applied to the mill operations.
—Shame!

—An Opposition member, who has now left the chamber, says `Shame'. In fact, all that members of the Opposition are concerned about is making comments like that and then walking out of the chamber. They are not prepared to debate this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: Before I go into the question of the Wesley Vale pulp mill, I would like also to congratulate the Government on its very good environmental record. In the term of this Government we have ensured that there is environmental protection for Kakadu National Park and for the temperate rainforest in South West Tasmania. We have ensured the continued protection of the Great Barrier Reef, we have ensured that the Daintree tropical rainforest in Queensland has World Heritage status, and we have passed over the ownership of Uluru National Park to the Aboriginal people, something that should have been done long ago. In all these issues the Opposition has opposed us. I want to say right now to the conservationists who may either read this speech or be listening at present, `Just look at the record of the Opposition on environmental matters'.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are vandals.

—As the honourable member for Hotham says-he too referred to our very strong environmental record in his speech-they are vandals. We may not have done all that the conservation movement wants us to do, but the fact remains that we have taken some very important environmental protection measures which will mean that future generations of Australians will be able to look at these wonderful areas of Australia that have been preserved by the Hawke-led Federal Labor Government.

SPEECH.PARA: Getting back to the Wesley Vale pulp mill, I consider that it was a disgraceful and shameful exercise by the Liberal Government in Tasmania to approve a weakening of the guidelines which would have released, in the form intended by the company, dangerous organochlorides into the environment.
