For the benefit of honourable members and the listening public, let me explain how a pulp mill works, in view of the fact that about four mills are planned around Australia, all adjacent to the coastline. Take the Japanese company Harris-Daishowa (Aust) Pty Limited. Honourable members should not be misled by the `Harris', which is a very minor part of the company; it is in fact a Japanese company. Harris is out of it. It is Daishowa.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is fully Daishowa.

—Fully Daishowa, as the honourable member has pointed out. It plans to build a pulp mill in New South Wales. Other companies plan to build pulp mills near Orbost in Victoria and Bunbury in Western Australia. All these mills involve a two-stage process. The first process reduces the logs to pulp by using a combination of mechanical and chemical processes which is called the kraft process. The second stage is a bleaching plant in which the wood pulp is bleached by treatment with chlorine gas in one case or, alternatively, a combination of chlorine and chlorine dioxide. So these are the two methods of achieving the bleaching. It is this second process-that is, the combination of chlorine and chlorine dioxide-which leads to the environmental problems. During the bleaching the chlorine bonds with organic material to produce the chemical by-products known as organochlorides. This material is a waste which is usually piped through an ocean outlet into the sea.

SPEECH.PARA: Earlier today I had occasion to refer to the environmental problems caused by the release of the organochlorides into the environment through pesticides and herbicides. I will quote from an article by Dr Peter Craig of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) which was published in the Australian on 16 February. The article reads:
In the bleaching of paper pulp, up to 1000 different organochlorides will be formed, the specific compounds depend on the species and age of the timber being pulped.

The majority of these will be unknown compounds because eucalypts have never before been processed by the kraft-chlorine method and because chemists have yet to identify all the compounds found in the by-products from existing kraft mills.
Little or nothing will be known about their properties or the effects on humans and the environment.
The pulp mill effluent is usually introduced into the ocean through a pipeline mounted on the sea bed and designed to maximise dilution of the effluent.
This process is in accord with the adage that the solution to pollution is dilution.
Unfortunately, organochlorides defy the adage.

On release into the ocean, they tend to attach themselves to particles that will drop to the sea bed if currents are not strong enough to carry them away. In this way, they can accumulate on the sea bed where they are available to bottom-feeding fish and may have a herbicidal effect on seaweeds.
Organochlorides will also accumulate in the fatty tissues of fish and shellfish whose habitat is in the area of the outfall.

I thought it was important to quote extensively from that article because it is written by an expert from the CSIRO. This is an expert article, in contrast to some of the superficial articles I may quote later in my speech. Opposition members have been keen to criticise the Minister, Senator Graham Richardson, for his decision to ensure that the environmental guidelines are followed strictly.

TALK.START.PARA: —He is doing a top job.

—As the honourable member for Grey says, he is doing a very good job. Senator Richardson's decision to ensure that the guidelines are followed strictly was a good one, but people who criticise fail to draw attention to the dangers which I have just outlined to the House. Both in the Baltic and off the Canadian coastline marine life is particularly sensitive to the effects of many of these organochlorides. The dioxin contamination from the organochlorides has caused contamination of shellfish and fin and gill rot, tumours and reproductive failure in fish. Both DDT and PCBs can be detected in all the seas of the world and have been found, for example, in penguins in Antarctica.

SPEECH.PARA: The organochlorides persist for many years before they decay. Marine scientists are not yet in a position to say what the long term consequences to marine life of this continual dumping of organochlorides into the sea will be. The Wesley Vale mill was expected to release some 60 million litres of effluent containing 13 tonnes of organochlorides each day. Yet the Tasmanian State Government was prepared to relax the environmental guidelines in such circumstances. That Government issued a statement which it described as an interpretation of the environmental guidelines but it was, in fact, a repudiation of existing strict controls. It was an irresponsible statement. Yet Tasmanian Liberal members in this House have the audacity to claim, as one did this morning, that the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories has been playing politics. It is they who are playing politics in their support of a State government led by a Premier who has a proven record of confrontation with the Federal Government. It is irresponsibility of the worst order by Opposition members who are prepared to support a reinterpretation of the guidelines which allows for no mention of dioxins. The original guidelines were quite specific in stating that there must be no detectable increases in dioxin in fish and shellfish. I quote from an Australian Broadcasting Corporation radio interview with Dr Bob Brown, an Independent State parliamentarian, on 23 February:

Yes. Well, for example, the dioxin issue. Previously, the dioxins would not be allowed into the marine life of Bass Strait, now we find that the dioxins will not be allowed to have a detrimental effect. That simply means that we would have a long argument over what detrimental means, but dioxins will be allowed into the marine life of Bass Strait. We see that the technology that's going to be the best practicable technology to protect the environment now has, that means in the new definition, commercially proven and widely acceptable. Which means that it's technology which has already been in considerable use elsewhere in the world. We're not getting anything new, innovative, and we're not getting any technology which is special in this mill. We're going to get technology which is already used elsewhere in the world where we know that this sort of mill is creating tremendous pollution, where we've seen the closure of fisheries in Canada and increasing alarm about the consumer products coming out of these mills such as coffee filters, napkins and milk cartons which are concerning people right round the world because of the organochlorins getting into them.
Further, Dr Brown said:

There is a compelling argument for preventing this form of technology being brought into the Australian environment and we must remember, when the proponents of this mill, say that it's the best, it'll be the cleanest mill in the world, they're quite wrong. There are alternative technologies which avoid organochlorins and dioxins going into the atmosphere all together. The Russians are introducing that, the Swiss are introducing that. We just simply should not have this polluting technology which is going to put up to 13 tonnes of organochlorins into Bass Strait each day.
I wish to quote from a Tasmanian television program of 26 February on which Charles Woolley said:

For the past 18 years a pulp mill, now owned by North Broken Hill, has been operated on the site. It's a small mill, it will be replaced by a huge one. It'll be the biggest current industrial project in Australia and the biggest ever in the history of Tasmania. The company promises to provide up to $300m a year in taxes and balance of payment credits for the Federal Government. There's also the promise of 700 permanent jobs directly and indirectly.
That is what Opposition members concentrate on, but they do not talk about the debit side. Charles Woolley went on to say:

The mill will consume some 5,500 hectares of forest a year, opponents claim one tree in every six. And then there's the effluent. The company in its own environmental impact statement estimated about 1.5 tonnes a day of toxic organochlorin wastes would be discharged into Bass Strait. If dioxins are involved then typically they would occur in this material. The company can't guarantee they're not there but say it's unlikely. The farmers don't accept that assurance.
A farmer who was interviewed said:

They banned DDT years and years ago because they found it had organochlorins in it and this thing's going to start putting out exactly the same stuff that we've been banned. And so they now they started bringing in the meat testing in Japan and if we start showing up with organochlorins in our meat, well that condemns us straight away. There's a lot of money in meat, there's a lot of money in onions here and they're testing for it now so if it pops up we've lost the market.

That farmer is going to suffer from what is proposed with the Wesley Vale pulp mill, but do we hear Opposition members talking about those things? No, of course we do not. I am sure it must be obvious to all honourable members that the interviews I have quoted bear out the facts I have set out previously in my speech. I want to quote Bob Brown again because he is a Tasmanian and appreciates the need to preserve an environment in Tasmania which is still wild and untamed in many places. He said:

Well, the human species has got along for millions of years without kraft, chlorine bleaching factories, we know that we can do that, the record is there, but it hasn't ever got along without this wild environment, without the natural planet itself. How far can we push the planet in the direction in which, how far can we pollute it? How far can we degrade the earth, the land, the sea, the air without which we ultimately pay the penalty?

That is a very important statement. An important aspect of this whole issue which has been neglected in the argument about the level of emissions from the proposed Wesley Vale pulp mill is the fact that the dioxins, which are one of the organochlorides produced by the bleaching process, are the most toxic substances in the world. Dioxins were the basic poisoning substance in agent orange which was sprayed on the communist forces in Vietnam and to which many of our veterans were inadvertently exposed. The dioxin danger will not be limited to discharges from the mill.

TALK.START.PARA: —Your Minister said he was happy to have a shower in agent orange.
—Quite frankly, I find that difficult to believe.
—It is in Hansard.

—I would not mind having Hansard quoted, if that is the fact. The dioxins will also be present in the products arising from the mill's manufacturing processes, such as baby napkins, feminine tampons and toilet paper. No known safe level of dioxins has yet been proved. Dioxin concentration grows in animal tissues in a concentration which can be as high as 66,000 times the original contamination. The problem is that whilst these facts should be in the forefront of public discussion, the environmental impact statement deals with the issue in a perfunctory and superficial manner.

SPEECH.PARA: In addition, the proponents of the Wesley Vale pulp mill rely on articles by Allan Jamieson which appeared in the Age of 16 November 1988. I found the article to be superficial and completely lacking in any objective content. Is that the sort of article upon which Opposition members rely when they call Senator Richardson irresponsible? It is they who are irresponsible, particularly those Tasmanian Liberal members who would allow the Wesley Vale pulp mill to go ahead without the environmental safeguards which Senator Richardson has insisted must be upheld by the company. Allan Jamieson is the process manager for the Wesley Vale pulp mill project and is hardly the unbiased observer which the article appears to suggest. When I spoke this morning I wanted to make one environmental statement-that is, I am totally opposed to the Antarctic mineral resources regime. I hope in the future to have an opportunity to discuss this in the House. Hopefully, our tourism report will mention these matters but, of course, that remains to be seen.
Debate interrupted.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Luther College-Cyclone Aivu-Veterans' Affairs-Domestic Violence-Nursing Home Care-Three Mile Island Accident

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the House do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Halverson Mr R.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 11 February 1964, a co-educational secondary school named Luther College officially opened its doors and welcomed its first students. The school was built on a magnificent site of 13 hectares, at the corner of Plymouth and Yarra roads, Croydon-an outer eastern suburb of Melbourne. Since that first day 25 years ago, the school has grown steadily both in size and in reputation. It is highly regarded and respected as an educational institution-not only by the many students, staff, parents and members of the Lutheran fellowship who are, or have been, directly involved in its initial planning and continuing development, but also throughout the wider community.

SPEECH.PARA: From the original seven teachers and 53 students, the Luther College family has increased to a student body of almost 550, and a teaching staff of 49, plus administrative, teacher support and boarding house staff.

The story of this outstanding school has been comprehensively detailed in a very interesting and readable book which has been published by the college council as a major contribution to the silver jubilee celebrations. The book is entitled Bell, Clock and Cross-A History of Luther College 1964-1988. The opening paragraphs of the introduction to this special volume state:

Bell, Clock and Cross may appear to the casual reader to be a strange kind of name for a resume of the history of a school, but to those who are aware of the structure and character of Luther College, Croydon, the appropriateness of the title will be readily appreciated.

Bells are usually appealing as instruments of cheer, but they are also, quite often, regarded as instruments of incitement. Perhaps the bells summoning staff and students to the classroom for the first period in the morning sound less cheerful than the ones signalling the close of the period of the day. But the sound of a bell usually serves to arouse, to revitalise, to lift the human spirit, encouraging enterprise and achievement.

Clocks are perhaps most aptly described as a means of discipline. They constantly remind us of the fact that our time is limited. They put pressure on us. Just as they are in the business world, so they are in schools-relentless, unyielding instruments which undoubtedly help us to organise ourselves in the direction of success, but which also tend to engender feelings of frustration, even of despair.

What about crosses? Unlike bells and clocks, crosses are mute and unchanging. They are simply there, bearing silent testimony to the Christian faith. At a place like Luther College the cross is of much greater significance than the bell or the clock. Luther College was conceived, dedicated and has always effectively operated as a Christian school. It has demonstrated its commitment to the Christian faith and Christian principles through its care and concern for the educational, emotional, physical and spiritual needs of those students fortunate enough to pass through its doors.

Celebrations to mark the twenty-fifth anniversary of Luther College have included a silver jubilee concert, a thanksgiving service, the unveiling of a commemorative plaque, a special founders day assembly and open day, and the planting of a commemorative tree in the grounds of the school. A time capsule is also being prepared, and it too will be `planted' in the school grounds during the college's traditional Maifest activities early next month. Unlike the commemorative tree, it is planned to dig up the time capsule in 25 years' time, when the college celebrates its golden anniversary.

I am delighted that such a fine school as Luther College is located within the boundaries of the electorate of Casey, and I would like to take this opportunity to acknowledge the contributions made and achievements attained by the school during its first 25 years. Congratulations on a job well done.

To the dedicated people who possessed the vision, courage and commitment to establish the school, to the present students and staff who have the important responsibility of continuing to build on the firm foundations laid for them over the past quarter of a century, to all who have had in the past, or will have in the future, the opportunity to experience the care and the training provided by Luther College, I would like to say you have every reason to feel very proud and very blessed because of your association and involvement with the Luther College community. Best wishes to you all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lindsay Mr E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —At approximately 11 a.m. on Tuesday, 4 April 1989, Cyclone Aivu struck the north Queensland coastline approximately 60 kilometres south of Townsville. It was one of the most powerful cyclones to hit north Queensland and had a force equivalent to that of Cyclone Tracy, which devastated Darwin in 1974. Cyclone Aivu caused extensive damage to the towns of Giru, Brandon, Ayr, Home Hill, Inkerman, Clare and Mingela and to the historic mining centres of Ravenswood and Charters Towers. Numerous homes and buildings were unroofed and much structural damage was caused. The litter of devastation was testimony to the violence of the winds. Established trees were uprooted and shrubbery, corrugated iron, broken glass and other debris were strewn everywhere. The $450m sugar cane crop was flattened by the 230 kilometre per hour winds. The sugarcane crop loss is conservatively estimated at $20m. Power lines were brought down and electricity and water supplies were cut. One person was drowned and approximately 20 other persons were injured and required medical attention. Heavy rainfall which accompanied the furious winds caused local flooding. Cyclone Aivu has since developed into a tropical rain depression. Now the threat of widespread flooding is an additional anxiety faced by the people of the region.

SPEECH.PARA: The State Emergency Service called on the Natural Disasters Organisation for urgent assistance. Townsville-based Defence Force personnel responded immediately to the pleas for help. At about 4.30 p.m. on the day of the cyclone the Defence Force Aid to the Civil Community Group commanded by Major Peter Hanlon and comprising 139 soldiers from Delta Company, 2nd/4th Battalion and five other units of 3rd Brigade left Townsville by road for the devastated area. They took nine Landrovers, 10 Unimog trucks, four Mack dumper trucks, a recovery vehicle, a bulldozer, a water purification unit, a light observation helicopter, sandbags and tarpaulins.

The group arrived at last light and proceeded to place tarpaulins over holes in the roof of the Ayr Hospital and other damaged buildings. They also commenced the gigantic task of clearing debris. The light observation helicopter was used extensively to carry out reconnaissance flights to assess damage. The Army's 9 Transport Squadron moved stores, generators, a Telecom ground station and tarpaulins to the area. The troops on the disaster scene quickly established liaison and working procedures with police and emergency services.

When cyclone warnings for the north Queensland coast commenced, the Army placed liaison officers on the spot to work from police stations at Townsville, Innisfail and Mackay until the emergency was over. Yesterday an Iroquois helicopter from 35 Squadron of the Royal Australian Air Force base at Garbutt carried out a reconnaissance of power lines from Townsville to Clare and Proserpine. This morning another Iroquois helicopter from 35 Squadron went to Mackay to provide food relief and was available for medical evacuation purposes. Iroquois helicopters of 35 Squadron are still on standby ready to provide assistance.

Travelling in an Iroquois helicopter piloted by Squadron Leader Ian Fogarty, I visited the scene of the disaster yesterday in company with the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Lionel Bowen), the Leader of the Queensland Opposition, Mr Wayne Goss, Brigadier Jim Connolly, Commander of 3rd Brigade, Lavarack Barracks and Captain John McDonald of the Natural Disasters Organisation. The Deputy Prime Minister spoke with police officers and other officials at various locations in the disaster area and guaranteed the people of the region that the Commonwealth Government would provide financial assistance to the Queensland Government, which has primary responsibility for disaster relief in that State under the relevant guidelines of the natural disaster relief arrangements. These arrangements provide that the Commonwealth Government reimburses at least 50 per cent of State outlays on eligible measures for the relief of personal hardship and distress.

In respect of other eligible relief and restoration measures, such as repairs to roads and other public facilities, concessional loans to farmers, small businesses, needy people and voluntary non-profit bodies, the Commonwealth Government provides financial assistance when a State's total outlays on these measures in a financial year exceed its assessed financial capacity as represented by an annual base amount. This assistance is on a dollar for dollar basis in respect of outlays up to 75 per cent above the base amount and $3 Commonwealth to $1 State thereafter. Queensland is already eligible to receive $3 Commonwealth for each $1 of State funds.

I commend the professionalism of the military personnel from the 3rd Brigade, the officers and airmen of 35 Squadron, local police, the State Emergency Service, the North Queensland Electricity Board and council workers. They served magnificently and they have earned the enduring gratitude of the people of north Queensland.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fischer Mr T.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I desire to inject some reality into the picture which has been painted throughout this week in respect of the Government's alleged care for veterans and war widows following some recent statements made, particularly by the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys). I am delighted that he is present in the House tonight. I remind the House that it was this same Minister who, in the House on 23 May 1988, said:

SPEECH.PARA: Well, I was a motor mechanic for many years and I've had kerosene and petrol and oil thrown on me so if he wants to throw Agent Orange over me I don't think that's going to worry me in any way . . .

That is but a passing indication, but nevertheless an indication that is in Hansard, in relation to the Minister's attitude at that time in respect of the agent orange issue. That leads me to point out to the House the 10 big cutbacks to veterans and war widows under the Federal Labor Government since May 1985. They show the extent of its approach and attitude and give the lie to the figure that the Government continually cites, that it has increased expenditure overall-and it has-from $2.5 billion to $4.5 billion. But that is a smokescreen for the reality of what is happening in relation to its assistance and programs.

The first cutback concerned the travel allowance, which was reduced by half to a flat rate of 11.6c per kilometre in the mini-Budget of May 1985. It particularly affected country veterans. Secondly, the subsistance allowance, including meals and accommodation, was reduced substantially for veterans, resulting in considerably less Government expenditure for that program. Thirdly, in regard to the dental scheme, four categories of treatment were severely limited, causing considerable hardship to the veterans involved. Fourthly, the totally and permanently incapacitated pension criteria were tightened very significantly under the Veterans' Entitlements Act which was introduced late in 1985.

Fifthly, provision was made for termination of the dependants allowance by commutation, albeit on a voluntary basis, and that there would be no further increase in the dependants allowance, another cutback. Sixthly, war widows and their dependants, as well as service pensioners and their fringe benefits, will no longer have access to the repatriation pharmaceutical benefits scheme. In other words, war widows were wiped out of the repatriation pharmaceutical benefits scheme. Seventhly, war widows who also receive an age pension had their social security component frozen at a maximum level of $60.05, with no consumer price index (CPI) adjustments. Eighthly, in 1986 a two per cent Defence Force retirement benefits cut-back was imposed, along with a six-week deferment in increases in CPI. That still has not been rectified, despite indications by the Government that it was planning to do so.

Ninthly, from 1 January 1988 a $5,000-plus statutory patient contribution was imposed on veterans in nursing homes, even when they were in nursing homes for war-related conditions. Tenthly, and finally in this list of 10 big cutbacks by the Federal Labor Government to veterans and war widows, there was a serious cutback in the list of available drugs under the repatriation pharmaceutical benefits scheme, along with other related cutbacks, including some which came into effect on Saturday, 1 April, causing great hardship, difficulty and confusion for veterans.

That is the reality of the Government's treatment of veterans and war widows. That is the type of treatment that the Government has meted out to those who served their country in time of war, contrary to the dictum put down by Ben Chifley many years ago when he told the House of Representatives:
Upon this national Parliament rests the responsibility of seeing that the right thing shall be done for those who served their country in time of war.

By contrast, our commitment-the commitment of the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson), my commitment and the commitment of all members of the coalition-is to provide a fair go for veterans, a fair go for war widows, a comprehensive program to see that they get that fair go and the treatment, disability and service pension assistance which they so richly deserve. Our program will be administered by a modern, separate Department of Veterans' Affairs. I think that that clarifies some of the debate which broke out this week in relation to veterans' affairs and repatriation. It spells out the true picture in terms of looking after that very important category of people, veterans and war widows.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Neil Mr L.R.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —Domestic violence is not something that is new or unique to our time, but it is an area which must be given very serious consideration by us all. It is now recognised that domestic violence is a major social problem in Australian society. It is not a simple problem with simple answers. It is a complex issue and one which we all need to be aware of. While the provision of services to combat domestic violence is generally a State or Territory government matter, the Federal Government commits a considerable level of funding. It is a sad fact that many women and children are living in fear of serious injury, or worse, each day of their lives. Therefore, it is of immense importance that the Federal Government has brought this issue to the attention of the public. Domestic violence is widespread throughout the community, and occurs in many varied home styles, regardless of race or creed. Statistics show that 95 per cent of perpetrators are men, with as many as one in three being directly affected by domestic violence.

SPEECH.PARA: The Federal Government has declared this month of April 1989 National Domestic Violence Awareness Month as part of a three-year national domestic violence education program. I am pleased that this program has been put in place. It aims to educate the general public on this complex problem and will look at ways to reduce the incidence of abuse. The percentage rates of those in need of help are staggeringly high. In my electorate of Grey alone it is not unusual for one family per day to seek assistance from a women's and children's emergency shelter. In some months there is a dramatic increase on this figure. It is of vast importance that shelters of this nature be maintained to the fullest extent, with adequate funding being made available to allow the continuation of the commendable work now being undertaken and enable the Government to look at the differing areas of domestic violence. Many shelters are finding the increased demand on their services difficult to meet. Therefore it is of utmost importance that the Government continue to support this important program. Without the current service provided by the shelters in my electorate, many women and children would have to remain in a potentially dangerous environment, in the hope that their situation would improve or change.

In these times of violence, one man to another, a harmonious home life is one which most of us take for granted. However, in many cases this is not the daily routine. Australia cannot continue to tolerate the level of physical and mental abuse which is widespread throughout our community. I congratulate the commitment shown by all coordinators of shelters in and around Australia. Their unstinting work and efforts on behalf of the women and children of Australia are worthy of very high praise indeed. I have been deeply impressed by the obvious love, compassion, kindness and caring shown by the women who run the shelters in my electorate. I have visited these shelters and I totally support their wonderful work.

It is important for people living with the fear of violence in their homes to know that they have the choice to find help. An alternative is one which should not be taken lightly. Domestic Violence Awareness Month, a government initiative, is highlighting this sensitive area in an effort to bring to the attention of members of the public the fact that there is help and support available to them in their area. I commend the Government on taking this sensitive issue to task. It is not a popular issue; therefore the significance of highlighting this area shows great concern and courage by the Hawke Government.

Each of us is accountable for his or her own actions. However, it is unreasonable and unrealistic to expect women and children to stand up for their rights and confront a brutal partner. It is therefore pleasing to me that in 1987-88 the Government allocated as a major policy initiative $1.6m over a three-year period to a national education campaign on domestic violence. A total of $208,000 was expended in the 1987-88 financial year and an allocation of $680,000 was made for expenditure in this financial year.

Activities undertaken last year related to research on community attitudes towards domestic violence, in an effort to provide the basis to develop a campaign. The announcement of an awareness month for April 1989 is something which I feel will highlight to us all the very real problem of violence in our community and help us to become better informed as to available services and counselling in and around us. Time, and a change in our acceptance of the problem, will be needed before changes can be made. We must understand that it is not our right, nor our privilege, to abuse our partners or our children. I ask all members present today to continue to give their support for such a worthwhile program.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrew Mr J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to rise and follow the honourable member for Grey (Mr O'Neil). I endorse the sentiments he has expressed tonight. It is appropriate that I should follow the honourable member for Grey because the issue I wish to raise is one in which he has been partially involved. I want to recognise tonight the cooperation he has given in relation to the matter I shall bring to the attention of the House. It is also appropriate that I should find myself in the House when the Minister for Housing and Aged Care (Mr Staples) is at the table because the matter I wish to raise is also one which directly concerns him.

SPEECH.PARA: A great deal of concern has been expressed in South Australia about the question of nursing home care. South Australians feel that their enthusiasm about being diligent providers for aged citizens over the past two decades is very much to their disadvantage now that the Minister for Housing and Aged Care, for his own well-intentioned reasons no doubt, is endeavouring to introduce what he sees as some equity into nursing home care. South Australians are feeling unfairly penalised.

The area of nursing home care that particularly concerns me is a Roman Catholic nursing home known as Star of the Sea at Wallaroo. Wallaroo is one of the port towns in the Copper Triangle of South Australia. I have to say to the Minister that last weekend and indeed this week the citizens of Wallaroo indicated that they were bitterly unhappy about the intention of the Department of Housing and Aged Care and the Minister to close the nursing home beds at the Star of the Sea nursing home. After this announcement was made it was not long before Monsignor Pope, Sister Gabrielle and Mrs Thoday from the nursing home came to see me.

While I appreciate the fact that the Department is acting from what it sees as a statistically equitable point of view, it is quite unfair for it to take statistics for an urban area and apply them to a rural setting. If you are as familiar, Madam Speaker, as I am with a rural area you will know that to move retired people from one town to another is totally dislocating. In an urban setting it may not be difficult to move them from one suburb to another. The threat that these aged people of Star of the Sea feel is the threat of having to leave the community of Wallaroo to settle somewhere else. Many of them, because they are in nursing home beds, are quite unable to make any sort of provision for themselves.
A protest meeting was held at Wallaroo last Sunday evening. Five hundred people from a town of barely 2,000 attended that meeting.

TALK.START.PARA: —You gave up a Sunday night yet again.

—Yes, I was there, as the shadow Minister for veterans' affairs, the honourable member for Farrer, acknowledges. More significantly, the bishop of the area, Bishop De Campo, was there. He clearly had to restructure his Sunday evening in order to attend this meeting. While, appropriately, he did not become directly involved in the protest, his very preparedness to be there indicated his concern about what was happening to Star of the Sea.

SPEECH.PARA: The real concern is that these people have made provision for this nursing home. They, among others, made it possible for the nursing home to be set up, and they are currently finding themselves losing the right to occupy the nursing home beds. The Department has not been totally callous. It has said that in taking away the nursing home beds it is prepared to offer some sort of subsidy to extend the hostel in the town so that people who occupy the nursing home beds can occupy the hostel rooms. What the Department and the Minister fail to recognise is that we cannot use an urban statistic and urban criteria in order to determine what ought to happen in rural areas. I indicate to the Minister that when he visits the electorate of Grey he will receive a deputation from the people of Wakefield via the member for Wakefield, thanks to the generosity of the honourable member for Grey.

An action committee has been set up in Wallaroo and it will be bringing to the Minister, through me, the concern it feels about what is happening to aged care in Wallaroo and what may well result from the decision to close the nursing home bed at the Star of the Sea. It is simply not good enough to propose to replace these nursing home beds with hostel beds, since the nursing home beds are what keep the Star of the Sea viable.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jakobsen Ms C.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to speak tonight about an accident which some people here will recall: the accident at the Three Mile Island nuclear power plant in 1979. This week marks the tenth anniversary of that accident. Honourable members may have listened to a very good program on Australian Broadcasting Corporation radio which discussed the accident. The containment on that occasion was claimed to have been quite successful. Perhaps it was compared with Chernobyl, where more radioactivity was released into the atmosphere directly and where the results and consequences were much more obvious. But the population in the vicinity of the Three Mile Island reactor will not know for some years yet, and possibly for at least a generation, the real level of damage to their health and to the health of their future families. It was thought that the escape of large amounts of radioactive iodine, for instance, would be a problem for local people. That still remains to be seen. The authorities could not even get into the plant to carry out an inspection for five years after the accident because it was so radioactive. Even then the inspection had to be performed by robotic equipment, which discovered that a 30 per cent meltdown had occurred. This was much greater damage than was previously suspected by the United States authorities.

SPEECH.PARA: It is interesting to note that there has been no commissioning of a new nuclear installation in the United States since that time. Perhaps it is no wonder when one realises how frightened the population in the area must have been and also how much more concerned ordinary people in the US, no matter how close to the reactor, would have been after that accident. The clean-up bill was in excess of $1 billion, and the American community was severely shocked by the disaster.

People across the world are now expressing concern about the greenhouse effect, caused by the excessive release of carbon dioxide into the atmosphere through the burning of fossil fuels. Some nuclear power advocates are seizing upon this problem to promote the so-called cleanliness of nuclear energy, suggesting that for that reason it is a viable alternative to fossil fuels. This argument is not valid on at least two grounds. First, nuclear power only produces electricity. It is not, therefore, a substitute for fossil fuels such as petroleum or diesel, or even coal in certain industrial applications. Secondly, nuclear power plants are themselves potent pollutants. They may not affect the carbon dioxide level in the atmosphere but they present insurmountable environmental problems both through their by-products and through the disposal of the vast plants themselves at the end of their relatively short working life.

The world's environmental health is a complex matter and I am simply making this speech tonight, as I know many others would if they had the opportunity, to point out that it is impossible for us to find a simple solution to those problems. It is especially difficult when some people in a very un- popular industry, and a very unsafe industry, grasp at the straw of something like the greenhouse effect, which is in fact caused by our civilisation as much as the burning of fossil fuels. It is the way we live as much as the fuels that we use in an endeavour to promote what I believe is a very dangerous and vastly overrated source of energy for the future.

It is interesting, too, that environmentalists in this country and in other countries perhaps have not grasped this problem before. But most of them would say without a shadow of doubt that we ought to be looking to other forms of fuel and electricity generation rather than nuclear power. We are fortunate that Australia is, at least in the main, a nuclear-free nation. We have the odd little nuclear reactor for medical use, but in the main we are nuclear free and I for one would like to keep it that way. We would be doing the world and our country a disservice if we were to fall for the sham that has been put up by nuclear power proponents now that the greenhouse effect has become the problem that it has, and accept that nuclear power ought to be used as a substitute for fossil fuels. It is not an accurate argument, it is not a genuine argument and it should be rejected out of hand.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, I require the debate to be extended.
—The debate may continue until 11.10 p.m.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Humphreys The Hon B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to hold up the House for long but it is important that I respond to the Opposition spokesperson on veterans' affairs, the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer). He attacked me for my statement in relation to agent orange. I said that when I was an honourable garage proprietor I had petrol and kerosene thrown over me. When a veteran said he was going to throw agent orange over members of parliament, I said that if he wanted to do it I could not stop him, and that if he wished to do it I would not be concerned if that satisfied him. He knows that and he has misrepresented me here tonight. The honourable member for Farrer is a Vietnam veteran and he should be ashamed of himself. He is a member of this Parliament and a member of the party that would not give the Vietnam veterans a royal commission. Who gave them the royal commission? It was the Labor Party after all the years those opposite were in government. It was those opposite who sent the Australians over to Vietnam to fight.
—What good has it done them?

—Do not worry about what good the Commission did. The honourable member and his colleagues sent the Australians over there. They sent them to fight, but when the veterans asked for a royal commission it was the Labor Party that gave it to them. The veterans were not happy with that, so we gave them the Hogg inquiry into the findings of the Evatt Royal Commission on the Use and Effects of Chemical Agents on Australian Personnel in Vietnam. Hogg reported and we gave extra Vietnam veterans counsellors and also gave the veterans halfway houses. What did those opposite do? When in government they did nothing for the Vietnam veterans and Opposition members. The honourable member for Farrer should be ashamed of himself for getting up in this place and accusing Labor of doing nothing. We are very proud of what we have done on behalf of the Vietnam veterans, in the form of extra counsellors, $400,000 for halfway houses and so on. We have allocated a lot of money for the Vietnam memorial. We have done everything we can, and are continuing to do what we can, for the veterans. This Government will be in government for a long time and will look after those veterans.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Farrer did not mention that it was a Labor Government that ensured that the totally and permanently incapacitated (TPI) pension was payable for life. He did not mention all the good things that Labor has done, nor did he mention the extreme disability allowance. It is disgraceful that he should come into this Parliament and attack the Labor Government on these issues. I suppose he is not interested in the fact that we reduced from 100 per cent to 70 per cent eligibility for the TPI pension. I suppose that that, in the honourable member's mind, is no good either. We set up the Veterans' Entitlements Act monitoring committee and, having considered all the recommendations from that committee, we accepted half of them. The honourable member in his policy mentioned only two. Members of this House should read that policy. It says that the Liberal Party intends to do something for veterans when economic circumstances allow. There is nothing that they will do for the veterans.

The honourable member for Farrer talked about cutbacks, but he has said nothing on that topic in his policy and will say nothing about it in this Parliament. He has not said what he would do on behalf of the veterans. Does he intend to reintroduce all the areas in which he has mentioned cutbacks? Does he intend to give the veterans all that money? He has put himself under no obligation on behalf of the veterans' community. He goes around the country saying that the Labor Government intends to do away with the Veterans' Review Board. He has been scaremongering the veterans again. He has been going around telling absolute lies.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister will withdraw the world `lies'.

—I withdraw. They were absolute untruths. The honourable member also said that we intended to do away with the War Graves Commission. He has told veterans that. That is another untruth. Then he says that this Government intends to do away with the Repatriation Commission. He has been going around the country scaremongering the veterans, those persons who are most in need, the aged veterans. The honourable member who is the coalition's spokesperson, a Vietnam veteran, has been going around spooking the veterans. He should be ashamed of himself. The Government has spent $100m on repatriation hospitals. We had to spend that money because the former coalition Government let those hospitals run down. The honourable member should have no worries about our policy on assisting veterans. Let us not forget that the Business Council of Australia in its report last year said that there should be more cuts and that we should save $4 billion and do away with the Department of Veterans' Affairs. Who agreed with that Council and said that we had not gone far enough? Who said that?
—The shadow finance Minister.

—No, it was the shadow Treasurer. Then, to cap it all off, the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson) came into the House today and said that he had been misrepresented by me. But he had not been misrepresented and I quoted him correctly. The honourable member made a personal explanation--
—Order! The Minister's time has expired, but as no other Minister has risen to respond to matters raised in the adjournment debate this evening, the Minister may continue for another five minutes.

—Thank you, Madam Speaker. I shall not need another five minutes, but I wish to make the point that I did not misrepresent the honourable member for Wentworth. I do not do that. I have been in this Parliament for over 11 years and I do not misrepresent anybody. The honourable member came back into the Parliament and said that he did say that, but that he had said it before he was a member of parliament and he did not mean it. He said that he lived in fear of two portfolios-the Aboriginal affairs portfolio and the veterans' affairs portfolio. He did not want to work for the Department of Veterans' Affairs or for the Department of Aboriginal Affairs. He likes the veterans, but he does not want to be their Minister. That was what he was trying to say. The honourable member for Farrer stands condemned for coming into this Parliament and saying that this Government has done nothing on behalf of the veterans' community.
—Order! The debate having concluded, the House stands adjourned until 2 p.m. next Monday.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Langmore Mr J.V.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 15 March 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the Punta del Este declaration make any mention of the need for parallel progress in the areas of (a) Third World debt, (b) financial flows to Third World countries and (c) monetary issues.
(2) If these matters are mentioned, what progress has been made.
(3) What does the Government advocate for coping with the problems in these areas.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Ministerial Declaration on the Uruguay Round (the Punta del Este Declaration) was mindful of the negative effects of prolonged financial and monetary instability in the world economy, the indebtedness of a large number of less developed contracting parties to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT), and considering the linkage between trade, money, finance and development and determined that action to liberalise world trade would promote growth and development.

In this sense the Declaration noted its concern with the issues (a), (b) and (c) and was convinced that a freer trading system would promote growth and development and through this, address the debt, financial flow and monetary issues facing the developing countries.

(2) Progress has been made in a number of areas of direct interest to the developing countries including in tropical and natural resources based products. To this extent, the Round should fulfil the intentions set out in (1). Finalisation of the agreements reached in Montreal at the Mid Term review has been made conditional on agreement on agriculture and textiles among others.

(3) The Treasury sets out the Australian approach to handling the debt problem in the Submission to the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade. In that Submission, the Treasury notes that Australia has consistently supported the present case-by-case, growth oriented debt strategy as the only realistic way of resolving debt problems over the longer term. It is recognised that there can be no lasting solution to debt problems without the restoration of growth. This requires fundamentally that debtor countries pursue appropriate macroeconomic and structural policies, oriented to growth and aimed at attracting the necessary external financing. In addition, however, Australia has recognised and has pressed the point strongly in international fora-that growth in debtor countries also depends critically on the policy actions of the major industrial countries.

For example, at the IMF/World Bank Annual Meetings in Berlin in September 1988, the Treasurer again emphasised the importance for sustained world economic growth of further progress in reducing external imbalances between the major deficit country, the United States, and the major surplus countries, in particular West Germany and Japan. He referred to the need for the United States to further reduce its fiscal deficit and, with other industrial countries, to avoid undue reliance on monetary policy, the costs of which include higher interest burdens for developing country debtors. The Treasurer noted that Japan had shown leadership in acting to lift domestic demand but that West Germany could do more in this regard.

The Treasurer emphasised the importance of market access for the resolution of debt problems, noting that it was a sad indictment on decades of supposed international cooperation that protection by developed countries reduces developing country national incomes by almost twice the amount of official development assistance that they currently provide.

Australia has also been a strong supporter, through its financial contributions and participation in decision-making, of the key role of the IMF and World Bank in the debt strategy. Central to this role is the provision of policy advice and financial assistance to debtor countries to promote economic adjustment and catalyse private and other official finance. The wider role of the IMF in particular in helping to strengthen international policy coordination, reduce global imbalances and improve the functioning of the international monetary and trading systems is directed at an improved world economic climate in which debt problems can be more satisfactorily resolved.

The Fund and Bank have established a number of new facilities to assist developing countries facing debt difficulties and are augmenting their financial resources with those difficulties in mind. (The World Bank agreed in April 1988 on a General Capital Increase of $US74.8 billion). Indeed, since 1982 the World Bank has become the largest single source of new money for the heavily-indebted middle-income countries.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Blunt Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Consumer Affairs, upon notice, on 18 October 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the Minister's Department or any other Government department provide any financial or other assistance to the Australian Federation of Consumer Organisations or any of its affiliated organisations; if so, what is:
(a) the assistance provided;
(b) its value; and
(c) the basis on which it is made available.
(2) Does the Minister's Department or any other Government department provide financial or other support for Price Watch work undertaking by individual organisations; if so:
(a) what is the value of the assistance provided;
(b) what is the basis on which it is obtained; and
(c) why is the assistance provided.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Consumer Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. The Australian Federation of Consumer Organisations (AFCO) and both the Australian Financial Counselling and Credit Reform Association (AFCCRA) and the Australian Consumer's Association (ACA), members of AFCO have received government assistance through my portfolio. I have no knowledge as to whether any other Government Departments have provided any financial or other assistance to organisations affiliated to AFCO.

(a) Financial assistance is provided to AFCO and AFCCRA in the form of grants-in-aid. AFCO has also received a grant in 1988-89 to support its involvement in Price Watch activities (see Question 2). In 1988, AFCCRA received an additional financial contribution to help meet the travel costs associated with the attendance of its members at the National Forum on Consumer Credit. In March 1989, AFCCRA received a financial contribution to assist with the costs associated with its annual conference. ACA also received a financial contribution in 1988 to enable it to undertake a research project on defective products.

(b) In the 1987-88 financial year, AFCO received a grant-in-aid of $209,000 and AFCCRA a grant-in-aid of $20,000. In the 1988-89 financial year, AFCO was allocated a grant-in-aid of $217,000 and AFCCRA a grant-in-aid of $21,000.

AFCCRA was given $4,000 to help meet travel costs associated with the attendance of its members at the National Forum on Consumer Credit. In March 1989, AFCCRA was given a financial contribution of $5,000 to assist with the costs associated with its 1989 annual conference. ACA received a financial contribution of $25,000 for its defective products research project.

(c) The grants-in-aid were provided to enable AFCO to fulfil its role of providing input on consumer issues to Government decision making processes. AFCCRA provides specialist advice and liaises between government and non-government sectors concerning credit, debt recovery, insolvency and law reform. Grants-in-aid are assessed against certain criteria which specify that the activities for which the grant is provided must be non-profit making and benefit a wide section of the community in a demonstrable way. Organisations are accountable for the use made of grants-in-aid and other financial contributions and are required to submit audited financial statements.

(2) Yes. The Department of the Treasury has advised that it has provided grants to the Australian Federation of Consumer Organisations (AFCO) and the Australian Pensioners Federation (APF) to support their involvement in price watch activities.

(a) Payments of $15,000 and $18,000 were made to AFCO and the APF respectively on 24 June 1987. The same amounts were paid to the organisations on 27 June 1988. Funds of $33,000 have been allocated in the 1988-89 Budget for renewal of the grants, subject to Ministerial approval at the appropriate time.

(b) Grants were provided on the basis that funds were to be directed towards the setting-up and operation of price watch committees, the distribution of information to local consumers and travel expenses in relation to these activities. In accordance with usual conditions attached to particular purpose grants, evidence is required in due course that funds have been spent on price watch activities and any unspent amounts are repayable to the Commonwealth.

(c) The assistance is provided to enable AFCO and APF to participate in an extension of price watch committees across Australia. The APF wrote to the Prime Minister in December, 1986 suggesting a national, community-based price watch organisation and the Prime Minister announced the Government's support for the initiative in March, 1987. The National Prices Network was established with the co-operation of the National Consumer Affairs Advisory Council, a representative of which has observer status on the management committee of the Network. AFCO and APF were invited to serve on the National Prices Network which was established to oversee the implementation of the initiative.

(2) Who supplied this facility and how frequently is it supplied.
(3) To whom is this service distributed.
(4) Is this service circulated outside the Minister's office.
(5) What was the cost of providing this service in (a) 1983, (b) 1984, (c) 1985, (d) 1986, (e) 1987 and (f) 1988.
(6) In those years has the supplier changed.
(7) Was the contract subject to public tender; if not, why not.
(8) Who pays for this service.
(9) Who tendered for the service.
(10) How was the successful tender selected.
(11) Does this service contain confidential material or is it based on information in the public domain.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.
(2) Monitair Pty Ltd, five days a week.

(3 and 4) To my office, to the office of the Minister for Local Government, to the office of the Minister Assisting the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, and to Senior Officers of my Department. In addition a gratis copy is supplied by my Department to the Shadow Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. The Office of Multicultural Affairs obtains a copy of the clippings direct from Monitair.
(5) It is difficult to provide this information on a calendar year basis. Financial year expenditure during the period was:

(6) No. However, it should be noted that Monitair was first engaged to supply an electronic media monitoring service on 31 May 1984 and the press clipping service commenced on 14 January 1985. Previously these services had been provided `in-house'.

(7) My Department did not organise public tenders. It operates within a period contract which was arranged by the Department of Administrative Services on behalf of all Government Departments and Statutory Authorities located in the Australian Capital Territory. (8) The Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs.
(9 and 10) See Question 7.
(11) The service contains only publicly available information.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Blunt Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice on 28 February 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How does he distribute his press releases and speeches.
(2) Is press material distributed by Viatel, if so, (a) when did this process begin, (b) what does it cost and (c) did it replace any other procedure.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) My press releases are distributed: (a) physically to the parliamentary press gallery; (b) by facsimile; (c) by Viatel; and (d) with press packs at press conferences. My speeches are distributed: (a) internally; (b) accompanying press packs; and (c) on request to external locations.

(2) Yes. (a) This process began on the 5 October 1988. (b) The Viatel charge of currently $3,900 per annum, paid on a monthly basis. A consultant was required to set up and maintain the data base initially at a cost of $3,810. It costs a further 10 cents per minute to update the data and it costs a user 14 cents per minute to read the data. (c) No.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hollis Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Resources, upon notice, on 1 March 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: Further to the answer to question No. 118 (Hansard, 2 November 1987, page 1860), have arrangements yet been made for the federal Government to provide all meat inspection services in abattoirs in Victoria, Queensland and Western Australia; if so, on what dates.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Resources has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service of the Department of Primary Industries and Energy has provided a meat inspection service in all Victorian abattoirs, producing for both the domestic and export markets, since 3 April 1988.

With regard to Queensland and Western Australia, the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service provides a meat inspection service on export registered establishments only. Such establishments can produce for both the export and domestic markets. The Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service assumed responsibility for domestic inspection on export works in Queensland on 27 March 1985 and in Western Australian on 20 February 1987.

Inspection of product in establishments registered by Queensland and Western Australian State authorities is undertaken by inspectors employed by either the State or local government, under State legislation.
